[Kit Collins]: I find them in order and I move for approval.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: We had another long, substantive conversation on the draft proposals for Medford Square, West Medford Square, and the draft updates to the ADU's ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: We reported them out of committee, and later tonight, they will be up for a vote to refer to the Community Development Board for further discussion in public hearings.

[Kit Collins]: Move for approval.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for outlining the steps that this proposal will take after a vote to refer it out to the Community Development Board this evening.

[Kit Collins]: And just to quickly recap the steps that have been taken to get us to this point, like all proposals that have been generated in our comprehensive zoning overhaul this year, or this term, rather,

[Kit Collins]: Um, these proposals, the zoning proposals for West Medford Square, Medford Square, and updates to our ADU's regulations were all developed in the Planning and Permitting Committee, um, with committee members, the zoning consultant, Innes Associates, and, um, city staff members of the Planning Development and Sustainability Department.

[Kit Collins]: We met on this proposal three times between March and April.

[Kit Collins]: We had a public Q&A on the three proposals last week after they're referred out of the City Council this evening.

[Kit Collins]: They will then begin the public hearing process before the Community Development Board.

[Kit Collins]: So far in the process, the Community Development Board has been

[Kit Collins]: taking their time to hold as many hearings on the zoning topics as they have felt the need to, which I think is great and I'm sure they will continue to do.

[Kit Collins]: That is another opportunity for community members to ask questions and give comment on these proposals as they have been doing.

[Kit Collins]: when these proposals were in the planning and permitting committee as well.

[Kit Collins]: So there has been a lot of discussion of these specific proposals themselves.

[Kit Collins]: In committee, there will be a lot more discussion about the specifics of the proposals in CDB when they're gone into in-depth.

[Kit Collins]: So I won't do that yet again here.

[Kit Collins]: But if folks want to learn more about these proposals before the CDB public hearings, there is a lot of information

[Kit Collins]: on the city zoning website medfordma.org slash zoning.

[Kit Collins]: And I encourage all residents to continue to be involved in the planning and permitting committee process and to attend the CDP public hearings.

[Kit Collins]: With that, I would motion to refer the three proposals to the Community Development Board.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you president bears I think all of the important points have been stated already but I was present at this meeting.

[Kit Collins]: Talked about it with Chief of Staff Nazarian and Director McDermott and they emphasized that this was really just a targeted change to make sure that visitors to City Hall and City Hall employees can access the parking that they need to go to City Hall and do business and go to their jobs.

[Kit Collins]: not intended to be punitive and the committee did ask for a guarantee that it wouldn't just be all of a sudden tickets are being issued there's going to be a substantial you know informational period and warning period and issuing warnings before they start doing enforcement related to fines so really not intended to be punitive just want to make sure that people who need to park at city hall are able to do so and

[Kit Collins]: the large amount of public parking that is next to that lot is still, for the moment, public parking.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bearson.

[Kit Collins]: Yeah, it's a difficult topic to bring up.

[Kit Collins]: I thank the president for bringing it up, continuing to bring it up.

[Kit Collins]: Speaking for only myself as one Councilor, this is something that is obviously, I'm sure I'm not speaking only for myself when I say this is something that is extremely preoccupying to many of us right now.

[Kit Collins]: And we're in uncharted territory relating to how a local government can and should respond

[Kit Collins]: to this.

[Kit Collins]: But what I think is unacceptable would be to say, because this is uncharted, we have no agency to chart our own path here.

[Kit Collins]: That would at least be unacceptable to me.

[Kit Collins]: I think that the work ahead of us right now collaboratively throughout the entire government of the city of Medford is to craft a policy collaboratively so that we can all be sure that we are doing what we can to make sure that public safety in Medford

[Kit Collins]: is in every way directed towards public safety in Medford.

[Kit Collins]: And some of our very most initial conversations about this, obviously, it's a fraught topic.

[Kit Collins]: I really think that everybody's intentions about this are good.

[Kit Collins]: But I think that we have to keep in mind that a response can look like a lot of things and be more helpful than what it is right now.

[Kit Collins]: I think that there is a very... I think that, you know, it's kind of trite,

[Kit Collins]: Inaction is action, and I think that's what we have to be wary of when it comes to what we are declining to do.

[Kit Collins]: When it comes to our response to ICE and other federal agencies in Medford, we can't just do nothing.

[Kit Collins]: That's obviously insufficient.

[Kit Collins]: I think the resident said that very well.

[Kit Collins]: Right now, we have a lot of ordinary residents in the community that are taking on the work of

[Kit Collins]: figuring out what public safety looks like in this time when federal agents are coming into our community, barely letting even our chief of police know, certainly not letting other city leaders such as ourselves know, being in public property, being on residential streets, masked, unidentified.

[Kit Collins]: There's residents taking on the onus of saying, hey,

[Kit Collins]: Who are you?

[Kit Collins]: What are you doing here?

[Kit Collins]: Is this okay?

[Kit Collins]: This seems suspicious.

[Kit Collins]: Let's make sure the people in the neighborhood are okay.

[Kit Collins]: Because our local government has not taken on the onus of doing that community safety work.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that needs to change.

[Kit Collins]: I think we need to share that responsibility with the community, obviously.

[Kit Collins]: And we share the responsibility of, if ICE has been present in the community,

[Kit Collins]: using our official channels and our official power to say, what comes next now?

[Kit Collins]: What do people need now?

[Kit Collins]: Are people good?

[Kit Collins]: What do they need?

[Kit Collins]: Do they know their rights?

[Kit Collins]: Is there support that's needed in the wake of being visited by ICE?

[Kit Collins]: And it goes further than that as well.

[Kit Collins]: But what I think is really unacceptable is to say,

[Kit Collins]: Our responsibility is to do nothing and pretend that that's enough, because it obviously isn't.

[Kit Collins]: So I thank community members for leading the way here, and I feel resolute that, frankly, city leadership needs to follow in the footsteps of residents who are already doing the work of figuring out what community safety looks like in this time.

[Kit Collins]: So the conversation has to continue.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for being here, Chief.

[Kit Collins]: Nice to see you.

[Kit Collins]: I want to thank you for your efforts in putting together the annual surveillance report and for your whole team, which for one, I'm sure was a collaborative effort.

[Kit Collins]: As was stated, this is the first annual surveillance report that we're getting on the body-worn cameras program for a full year of usage.

[Kit Collins]: When we spoke last year, I think it was just about like a month of 2023 that they had been in operation for.

[Kit Collins]: This one is different in that we're

[Kit Collins]: Glad that we're really sinking our teeth in on this one.

[Kit Collins]: It's good to be able to see a full year's worth of reflections and data.

[Kit Collins]: For folks who are just tuning in for the first time, I just want to set some context.

[Kit Collins]: This is the annual recording that we get on body-worn cameras.

[Kit Collins]: through to year 2028.

[Kit Collins]: Ordinarily, surveillance technology undergoes a use policy and impact report process.

[Kit Collins]: Body-worn cameras were exempted from that through 2028.

[Kit Collins]: So I think this makes this an all the more valuable part of this process, because this is our opportunity to discuss and to learn and to talk about those topics, which would otherwise we'd have several conversations about and several documents about.

[Kit Collins]: I also just feel it's important to state that in terms of the goals of this ordinance that this report falls under, to me as one Councilor, it's more important than ever to be having these conversations, and it's more important than ever to be refocusing on the goals behind all of the reporting and all of the conversations under the CCOPS ordinance, which is to make sure that residents in Medford are informed of what surveillance is going on in our community, to make sure that they have all of the information that they need about surveillance technologies that are approved in our community,

[Kit Collins]: And to make sure that we are all of us as city leaders very aware of protocols and the policies to keep that information surveillance data secure.

[Kit Collins]: It's important all the time, as we discussed a lot over the past couple of years, lots of security risks, cybersecurity concerns to take into account when we're talking about surveillance technology.

[Kit Collins]: And in these times when we know that there are other jurisdictions active and present and working in Medford, I think it's all the more incumbent on us to make sure that we're getting good information out to Medford residents and being really aware of what our policies are for keeping a very, very tight lid on the surveillance technology and data that we do have.

[Kit Collins]: and staying really clear on those policies that make sure that we're only collecting the surveillance data that we absolutely need for local public safety goals.

[Kit Collins]: And I just feel that that's important to state at this time, especially just a couple days after ICE was in Medford, again, for federal agendas that may or may not be related to local public safety goals.

[Kit Collins]: Having said that,

[Kit Collins]: Like I said, this is the second annual surveillance report that we've looked at on body-worn cameras.

[Kit Collins]: I do just want to be transparent as we're talking about the guidelines of the report and state per the ordinance, we're supposed to receive the annual surveillance report by March 15.

[Kit Collins]: We got this one on April 24.

[Kit Collins]: Going forward, I think it's really helpful for us to get it by the first quarter so that we can have more time earlier in the year to review.

[Kit Collins]: So I hope that next year we can be more familiar with the cadence of reporting on a full year of body worn camera usage.

[Kit Collins]: Great.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: It's very useful to be able to look through a report, very thorough.

[Kit Collins]: A lot of what is in the report is critical information, well organized, asked for.

[Kit Collins]: There are some areas where those statistics are not asked for by the ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: So if that is inflating the scope of work, if that added to the timeline issues, that's actually not necessary.

[Kit Collins]: just wanted to take this opportunity to clarify that.

[Kit Collins]: Not an issue, yeah.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: tuned into meetings about this particular ordinance before, so folks can know we're talking about the goals of the annual surveillance report, and this is true of any surveillance technology administered by any city, any department or agency in the city, is to provide a high level and generalized summary of the policies and usages concerning the surveillance technology, how it's been used, if the user feels it has been effective, which the chief has stated he believes that it has,

[Kit Collins]: the city.

[Kit Collins]: Um whether and how often surveillance data was shared with external persons or entities, the number of public records requests received by the city.

[Kit Collins]: Summary of any complaints or concerns that were received about it.

[Kit Collins]: The results of any audits.

[Kit Collins]: Whether the civil liberties and civil rights of any communities of groups in the city of being or have been disproportionately impacted by the use of the surveillance technology estimate of the

[Kit Collins]: with entities outside of the city relating to that data.

[Kit Collins]: And the report covered all of those topics, some more detailed than others.

[Kit Collins]: So thank you for that thoroughness.

[Kit Collins]: So that jumps out to me as the biggest red flag.

[Kit Collins]: That's a pretty high number to be deviating from the policy.

[Kit Collins]: So I'm curious if you can fill out that picture with

[Kit Collins]: What do you think isn't getting across what specific training is planned to make sure that we get that up to 99.9% instead of 33?

[Kit Collins]: Yep.

[Kit Collins]: Great, thank you.

[Kit Collins]: That's helpful.

[Kit Collins]: The action discussion item for this committee meeting is, as it almost always is, Paper 24-033, Zoning Ordinance Updates with the Innes Associates team.

[Kit Collins]: This is the 24th Zoning Updates project meeting with Innes Associates.

[Kit Collins]: Tonight, we will be discussing

[Kit Collins]: Upcoming meetings and public Q and A's.

[Kit Collins]: We have a few new ones to announce and promote.

[Kit Collins]: Updates to the draft Medford Square zoning proposal, updates to the draft West Medford Square zoning proposal, a review of other upcoming zoning topics and updates from now through the end of the year.

[Kit Collins]: and other updates as NS associates and city staff and councillors see fit.

[Kit Collins]: With that, Paola, unless you need more time to get settled, I'll pass it to you.

[Kit Collins]: more height and somebody made the suggestion, not me, though I'm very sympathetic to it, that it's in a way that you can argue it's advantageous to have your maximum heights right next to a highway because there aren't abutters on the highway, there are only commuters and it also provides a visual and sound barrier from the surrounding business districts and residential districts to the highway, which can be nice because the highway is quite noisy, air pollution and whatnot.

[Kit Collins]: So this map reflects a switch to MX3 on those parcels to the east of Clippership Drive, whereas it used to be a mix of MX2 and MX3.

[Kit Collins]: The way that I put it, and other people put it differently, was what should the default zoning be for this square?

[Kit Collins]: I think that's the site that makes sense to apply to most of the land area.

[Kit Collins]: So here we see those kind of minor additions of MX2B, but I see that the changes to by right heights have been adjusted for West Medford Square, as they have been for Medford Square.

[Kit Collins]: So just to reiterate, that's not a change, like we just talked about, it's not a change to what those mean.

[Kit Collins]: Citywide, it's a change to what they mean in the squares.

[Kit Collins]: So in Mixed Use 2A, it's now five stories by right with two incentive above if incentive zoning applies.

[Kit Collins]: In Mixed Use 2B, it's seven stories by right plus two incentive zoning stories above if developers seek and achieve incentive zoning.

[Kit Collins]: I think that makes sense.

[Kit Collins]: I think that having the residential only zoning in the square be your urban residential too makes a lot of sense because of the specific area and its amenities.

[Kit Collins]: Great, thank you for the question.

[Kit Collins]: Alex, this is something we've been talking about throughout this process on each of the major proposals that we've come across before.

[Kit Collins]: Ennis has been doing great work in considering intersectional studies and a host of context criteria when putting these zoning proposals together.

[Kit Collins]: When it comes to specific traffic studies, I think we use that term, that is something, the most appropriate use of a traffic study is kind of where they currently sit in site plan review.

[Kit Collins]: A traffic study done now as we craft new zoning that will be implemented

[Kit Collins]: kind of based on the will of private developers over the next several decades would quickly become dated and unuseful.

[Kit Collins]: So while that is a factor and how these zoning proposals come together.

[Kit Collins]: What's great about our public process for when major developments do come in is there's a baked-in process for those kind of context and mitigation studies and mitigation mechanisms that are respondent not to the conditions right now in the year 2025, but these specific conditions when a development is actually getting proposed and is about to be constructed.

[Kit Collins]: Um, so all that to say the context is absolutely an ingredient in these and the more specific mitigation studies and plans come into effect when specific developments are proposed.

[Kit Collins]: Anybody else want to speak to this quickly?

[Kit Collins]: It's been great to get very solid on what is mandated by the new state law, which requires that ADUs be permissible by right in any zoning sub-district that allows single-family zoning by right, and then to spend the time that was needed on those questions of

[Kit Collins]: Those are protected ADUs.

[Kit Collins]: For the local ADUs where the city has more discretion, how do we want to answer those questions?

[Kit Collins]: Based on my notes from the committee's past couple of conversations, it sounded to me like there was general consensus that we were okay with a second ADU being allowed as long as it was always by special permit, which is what I heard in your presentation.

[Kit Collins]: It sounded like there were good reasons for keeping the special permit local ADU at a maximum of 900 square feet, just to affirm that these are intended to be accessory dwellings.

[Kit Collins]: I'm always trying to find the synonym for inferior, not inferior to, but smaller than.

[Kit Collins]: Diminutive to, the main structure.

[Kit Collins]: After two hours, my vocabulary starts to...

[Kit Collins]: Correct me if I'm wrong.

[Kit Collins]: I think the only two questions that are new to this discussion are, should bigger detached ADUs be allowed for historic accessory structures?

[Kit Collins]: And then those dimensions, which will be tailored after the residential districts are proposed.

[Kit Collins]: It sounded to me like the recommendation was that larger detached ADUs sometimes make sense for historic accessory structures.

[Kit Collins]: because you want the accessory use to fit the building envelope and the intent is to use an existing smaller structure that's not big enough to be a principal dwelling, but can work as an accessory structure.

[Kit Collins]: Am I paraphrasing that roughly correctly?

[Kit Collins]: Seeing not, great.

[Kit Collins]: seeing none.

[Kit Collins]: So we have added a number of public Q&As to our zoning meetings timeline in addition to our regularly scheduled

[Kit Collins]: planning and permitting committee meetings and CDB public hearings.

[Kit Collins]: So tomorrow,

[Kit Collins]: We have a public Q&A.

[Kit Collins]: It is not germane to this topic that we discussed tonight.

[Kit Collins]: It will be a focus group meeting on Zoom for Tufts institutional zoning.

[Kit Collins]: On Zoom only, Thursday, my first, 7 p.m.

[Kit Collins]: The goal of this meeting is to hear from area residents on what they would like to see for zoning changes to the Tufts University campus.

[Kit Collins]: This is prior to us drafting or workshopping a proposal for this area.

[Kit Collins]: The intent is to hear questions, concerns, suggestions, preferences from the residents in that area before we start crafting a proposal and before we go and begin negotiating an institutional zone with the university.

[Kit Collins]: So this is geared towards Tufts University neighbors, but it is, of course, open to everyone.

[Kit Collins]: And again, that's tomorrow at 7 p.m.

[Kit Collins]: on Zoom.

[Kit Collins]: All details are on the city website.

[Kit Collins]: excuse me, proceeding chronologically on May 7th.

[Kit Collins]: The neighborhood and urban residential proposal will be back at the Community Development Board for a public hearing that was referenced tonight.

[Kit Collins]: I encourage everybody to join.

[Kit Collins]: The CDB public hearings always include public comment.

[Kit Collins]: It's a great opportunity to learn about the proposal.

[Kit Collins]: and to put your opinions on the record.

[Kit Collins]: The following evening, May 8, we'll be having a public Q&A on what we discussed tonight, Medford Square zoning proposal, West Medford Square zoning proposal, and the proposed updates to the ADUs.

[Kit Collins]: regulations.

[Kit Collins]: We will be having that at 6.30 p.m.

[Kit Collins]: at the Andrews Cafetorium, I believe.

[Kit Collins]: Yes.

[Kit Collins]: Everybody's welcome.

[Kit Collins]: Ask questions, hear comments, hear an overview of these proposals again.

[Kit Collins]: And just to restate in case anybody is new to this process.

[Kit Collins]: Now that this well, assuming that the vote goes favorably now that this proposal will be reported out of committee, it will be referred to the city council where it will be immediately referred to the Community Development Board, all zoning amendments updates or new zoning.

[Kit Collins]: After being workshopped in committee, procedurally have to be referred to the CBB for a public hearing before they may be referred back to the City Council, where we will take the final vote to ordain.

[Kit Collins]: So this is kind of the end of the beginning for a zoning proposal.

[Kit Collins]: There's a lot of opportunities for public comment and learning still to come.

[Kit Collins]: And we hope that anybody who's interested will participate in as many of them as they like.

[Kit Collins]: So all of these upcoming meetings can be found at medfordma.org slash zoning.

[Kit Collins]: Did I miss any important dates?

[Kit Collins]: I don't think so.

[Kit Collins]: So I would motion to approve.

[Kit Collins]: And I appreciate the context that with all of these financial decisions, it is not just seven people and city staff making a decision, but rather making decisions against a backdrop of a lot of state, regional, and federal best practice.

[Kit Collins]: Another thing that I don't want to get lost in the sauce now that this project has gotten to the point where we're talking about it in the terms of bottom lines and loan orders is for folks who are not at the committees of the whole that started that started in December or the meetings, since then.

[Kit Collins]: The work that we're talking about funding is work that will allow our elementary, in the case of the current paper and and middle schools and the previous one to have functioning HVAC and roofs that do not leak so what we're talking about we're talking about $25 million, and it is a lot of money.

[Kit Collins]: Absolutely, if that feels like an eye popping number that makes sense because that's a really really big number in the context especially of individual lives and small businesses and individual households in the context of a city as Councilor Gallagher pointed out.

[Kit Collins]: It is still a big number and we're allowed to react to it as a big number but that is also what things cost.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that as we're talking about it as a

[Kit Collins]: large and intimidating number to be committing.

[Kit Collins]: We should also be talking about like, wow, if there's $30 million worth of updates that our schools need, then like the only thing worse than seeing $30 million go out the door is to not spend that money, because that's stuff that students really need and teachers really need.

[Kit Collins]: And it's going to make our schools a much better learning environment, which is the whole point of communities having schools.

[Kit Collins]: So I think that this is,

[Kit Collins]: a really good use, I think it's really good when we can use a relative fraction of our amount of free cash to open the door to a project that it would be completely insensible to fund entirely through free cash and that can open the door to a project that it then makes more sense to complete with borrowing and I'm really looking forward to developing a clearer picture

[Kit Collins]: of the spending and appropriation plan for the rest of our free cash in collaboration with the city administration.

[Kit Collins]: I think that is critical context for our budget season this year, and we'll continue to work on that.

[Kit Collins]: But I think that I, for myself as one councilor constituent, I'm thinking of this as a very good example of how we can use free cash to our community's best advantage.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: I really appreciate the overview.

[Kit Collins]: That's right, sorry.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears and thank you to my colleagues for their words in response to this prompt so far and thank you so much for being here and speaking up.

[Kit Collins]: I, this has been said before but I don't think it should go unmentioned that in it

[Kit Collins]: It's not irrational, you know, in these times, depending on who you are and how you present and have a reasonable degree of thoughtfulness about how out there you put yourself and your convictions and to put your testimony on the record.

[Kit Collins]: So really, thank you.

[Kit Collins]: And I think for an advocate, such as yourself or somebody in your position, it probably goes without saying, but it shouldn't, which is that when you stand up for yourself and your own identity, you're standing up for everybody, you're standing up for everybody within marginalized identities.

[Kit Collins]: So thank you for doing that for the residents of Medford and for continuing to hold leaders to account for doing the same.

[Kit Collins]: I think

[Kit Collins]: We're in such a unfortunately interesting period right now where it seems to me that a lot of the conversation, the central point for a lot of conversations is like, what are you going to do about it?

[Kit Collins]: Which is the right question to be asking, because we all have to be doing as much as we possibly can.

[Kit Collins]: And it's unfortunate that the thing that we have to be doing is

[Kit Collins]: working to resist a government whose goals are actually to make Americans less safe and less healthy and less well, with worse futures and less safety and less happiness.

[Kit Collins]: That's a shame.

[Kit Collins]: That's a shonda.

[Kit Collins]: And it is

[Kit Collins]: thrusting in, I'm not a historian, but it feels to me like kind of an unprecedented time when we are at these various levels of government trying to negotiate what we can enforce and what we can ask of each other.

[Kit Collins]: And for myself, as a person with a microphone and a title, it feels very shameful and insufficient to say

[Kit Collins]: there is a limit that we can observe to official action.

[Kit Collins]: And in some ways, I think that goes without saying.

[Kit Collins]: Like, I found out about the ICE presence, the reported ICE presence in South Medford earlier this week, where I live, through Reddit.

[Kit Collins]: Because they just come in.

[Kit Collins]: Because they just come in.

[Kit Collins]: And they don't want us to know.

[Kit Collins]: They just come in, and they try to take people.

[Kit Collins]: And there's no, obviously,

[Kit Collins]: Obviously, there's no collaboration with local or state or regional forms of government because that's not the goal.

[Kit Collins]: The goal is not to collaborate.

[Kit Collins]: The goal is to displace people and divide communities and to make us enemies to one another, which is a completely false and inhumane pretense.

[Kit Collins]: All that to say, I think that like we can all envision

[Kit Collins]: responses that would help, that would stack on top of all what we're trying to do.

[Kit Collins]: For example, I think it would be really great if the Medford Police Department and other local police departments in communities all over the nation felt more loyalty to their residents than they do to an antagonistic federal government.

[Kit Collins]: I think it would be ideal if we didn't have to create this pseudo public service hotline

[Kit Collins]: For example, the Luce hotline and other ice watches would be ideal if we didn't have to create a grassroots pseudo public service mechanism.

[Kit Collins]: And if people could instead call the police and say, hey, there are people kidnapping my neighbors.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think that people in Medford feel that they can do that.

[Kit Collins]: And I have not received, I've not seen an indication that that is something that our public safety officials are willing to do.

[Kit Collins]: I think that people should be able to call 911 and say, hey, ICE is here and we don't know that they have a warrant and please come protect us.

[Kit Collins]: And that is what we should be asking our police to do.

[Kit Collins]: What we'll continue to, and this council has to continue to call on the mayor's administration and the police department under her jurisdiction to do more and to have more loyalty to our residents and our neighbors than we do to a federal government, which we know is going to antagonize communities like ours, no matter what we do.

[Kit Collins]: But in the meantime, I think it is also rational and needed for

[Kit Collins]: You know, and this is the part where I feel a little bad because I want the whole answer to be stuff within our control, but I don't think that it is I don't think I don't think that's that that's realistic.

[Kit Collins]: And that's, that's where I get very heartened to see people in our community who do not have official roles nonetheless.

[Kit Collins]: Taking creative measures to keep each other safe by joining those ice watches by.

[Kit Collins]: taking part in getting trained on the Luce hotline and being a part of that mechanism for keeping each other safe.

[Kit Collins]: And I should be clear, like other Councilors have been, I think that the limits to how aggressive our local forces have been in being vocal and assertive and just doing, you know, leaving it all on the field, doing everything we could possibly think of

[Kit Collins]: to combat ICE in our communities.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think it is in any way attributable to people not caring or being okay with what's going on.

[Kit Collins]: I'm not going to speculate about convictions or motives, but these people are members of our community too, and I don't think that's it.

[Kit Collins]: I think it's the intimidation machine.

[Kit Collins]: and a fear of making things worse because of retaliation.

[Kit Collins]: I just wanna make that clear.

[Kit Collins]: I don't wanna point the finger at anybody.

[Kit Collins]: I think that that's part of the goal of this is for us to be pointing our fingers at each other and that's not what we should be doing.

[Kit Collins]: We need to be welcoming each other into extremely resilient local systems of public safety.

[Kit Collins]: So to that, I think we need to continue to call upon

[Kit Collins]: the mayor's administration, including the NPD and all of our public safety infrastructure to say, let's stand up taller together and if you do that we will have your backs.

[Kit Collins]: And at the same time, I've seen wonderful examples in other communities of ways that these resistance methods that are getting distributed throughout the communities like

[Kit Collins]: If we could have, you know, a house with a megaphone and some noisemakers on every block, you know, where we train people so that there's like a house with a megaphone and noisemakers on every block.

[Kit Collins]: So if you know what to look for, and if you do, again, I'm not trying to be inflammatory for the sake of being inflammatory, it's just we know this is what's going on.

[Kit Collins]: And what we need is a siren that goes off whenever ICE is there trying to kidnap people.

[Kit Collins]: And that would be great if that could be Medford police.

[Kit Collins]: But if it's not, it has to be the residents.

[Kit Collins]: And then ideally, our official public safety capacity can be a part of that too.

[Kit Collins]: So I'm sorry if I've gone on a little bit long.

[Kit Collins]: I find it very fraught and challenging, the question of

[Kit Collins]: As your representatives, I feel the responsibility that we should be able to fix this all on our own.

[Kit Collins]: And we can't, and we'll keep trying, but we have to enthusiastically collaborate with each other to resist this for as long as it takes.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bearson.

[Kit Collins]: I apologize to my colleagues for being late to the chambers.

[Kit Collins]: I was listening on Zoom while commuting through heavy traffic.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for the discussion so far and I appreciate everybody's patience with giving this process the time that it needs to get to the voting stage.

[Kit Collins]: And though we disagree, I appreciate Councilor Lazzaro's thoughtful consideration of my motion in our last meeting and the conversation that's followed.

[Kit Collins]: I know we have a couple of ideas being floated in the past half hour or so, and one of the questions is, should we

[Kit Collins]: vote to reinstate the mayor on the school committee or not.

[Kit Collins]: I said a lot about my reasons for making the motion to remove the mayor from school committee.

[Kit Collins]: A week ago and I won't give that same spiel again, because all of my colleagues have heard it already and anybody else who's interested can find it online.

[Kit Collins]: So, just to with more brevity, explain my thinking.

[Kit Collins]: I think with our review of the city charter, something that has been kind of in the back of my mind as we have considered various possible changes and adjustments that we could make to our current city charter, something that I have been kind of coming back to as we go along is this question of when is it worthwhile to make changes for the sake of change?

[Kit Collins]: When is it worthwhile to make progress for the sake of doing things differently?

[Kit Collins]: When is it important to hold out for different changes?

[Kit Collins]: A reason that I have not been more

[Kit Collins]: along throughout this process is that I am wary of Medford, all of us invested in things such as a new charter that will make our community better.

[Kit Collins]: I am wary of us spending momentum on changes, on a new charter

[Kit Collins]: that I believe that a new charter should meaningfully engage with the question of power and balance because that is a fundamental thing that the city charter decides for the city and then we live with that for a long time.

[Kit Collins]: I was wary of the city charter process that allowed us to spend our momentum and our energy for positive progress and change in productive ways but in ways that also deferred progress that I think that we really need to see such as renegotiating that question of power and balance.

[Kit Collins]: I'm not saying I'm the only one with the right opinion about this I'm saying that that has been heavy on my mind throughout this process because we deserve a product that is not only good, but great.

[Kit Collins]: And as Councilors we sign up to have the conversations and take as long as it takes to try to get to the product that we think best does that.

[Kit Collins]: To that end, thinking about what is my role, I want to speak for other Councilors, what is my role as a Councilor in this process?

[Kit Collins]: This was not a process that was initiated by the council.

[Kit Collins]: This is a process that was initiated by the mayor, and it is our statutory responsibility to review the charter, make amendments, and then approve a version that will then go to the mayor and hopefully the voters.

[Kit Collins]: There's one way of looking at my role as a Councilor on this process, saying my role is to

[Kit Collins]: look at the draft city charter, make sure there's nothing glaringly problematic, and then vote it out so that the voters can decide either yes, this is worth doing or no, this is not meaningfully better than what we currently have.

[Kit Collins]: I think there's another way of characterizing my role as a Councilor in this process, which is to say my role is to insist on an outcome that I think is so good, so meaningful, so important, that I would personally endorse and campaign for the outcome.

[Kit Collins]: That is the attitude with which I have been approaching this project.

[Kit Collins]: to the inconvenience of many, including myself.

[Kit Collins]: I believe that this charter, unless it reimagines the balance of power in regard to the school committee and the city council, in regard to the other branches of government, I'm not saying it's not a good charter unless it does that.

[Kit Collins]: I'm saying it does not represent a meaningful change to the level of representation that residents will enjoy.

[Kit Collins]: And that's why

[Kit Collins]: That's why I made my motion last week, and that's why this has been important to me.

[Kit Collins]: Because as we've taken time to assimilate what we've been hearing in our inboxes and on phone calls and from the surveys and with our meetings, that has, at least to me, been what I interpret as the through line of this.

[Kit Collins]: People are asking for increased representativeness.

[Kit Collins]: We had a lot of fights about what that meant for the city council, and I think those were productive.

[Kit Collins]: And as everybody knows, I backed off on 5-4.

[Kit Collins]: 8-3, I think, is

[Kit Collins]: clearly what most people would like to get the chance to vote on.

[Kit Collins]: But what I hear is that people want better representation, full stop, and they don't just mean the city council.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that that has to include at least a beginning to ask the question of the balance of power between the mayor and the other two branches of government.

[Kit Collins]: And that is why I will not be supporting the motion to put the mayor back on the school committee.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears quickly.

[Kit Collins]: Um, while I was looking at the amendment proposed by Councilors Scarpelli in section nine for to change the first periodic review of the charter to within five years of the charter's approval I noticed in section nine for subsection

[Kit Collins]: I believe a motion was passed one week ago to amend that section so that it would reflect three appointees of the mayor, three appointees of the city council, and three appointees of the school committee, but that is still reflected as four, three, and two.

[Kit Collins]: And I believe that motion passed.

[Kit Collins]: Okay.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I just wanted to flag that and make sure that it made it into the final version that we take a vote on tonight.

[Kit Collins]: I think that there will be things that will have a variety of contentment with the draft that we vote on tonight, but I also want to make sure that our procedure for going forward is at least reflective of the motions that we made.

[Kit Collins]: not about emotion, but I just want to state because of a couple of comments from a couple of different people that I've heard in this.

[Kit Collins]: Actually, it's a couple of comments that I've heard from elected in the past 15 minutes or so, and something that has characterized this process, not to mention a lot of other discussion topics before this Council this entire term.

[Kit Collins]: I think that we do a really good job of talking to each other productively when we share

[Kit Collins]: Our feelings and our preferences and our rationales and we make a lot of ground we have a lot of meetings we have a lot of productive conversations.

[Kit Collins]: When we engage with a topic and we say why we feel a certain way on that topic.

[Kit Collins]: This chart review process in the city council chambers, in particular, has been characterized by.

[Kit Collins]: some people choosing not to explain why they feel the way that they do, but rather illustratively ascribing motivations to other people.

[Kit Collins]: It is really frustrating that not all electeds can just rest on the laurels of their own opinions and have to time and time again resort to the political manipulation of putting words in people's mouths, speculating about what the public will perceive in other people's actions.

[Kit Collins]: I just think it cheapens this process.

[Kit Collins]: I wish we could leave it in behind.

[Kit Collins]: I hope that can die with this process.

[Kit Collins]: It is really tiring.

[Kit Collins]: It doesn't make any of us look good.

[Kit Collins]: But I hope that all electeds

[Kit Collins]: Yes.

[Kit Collins]: a draft proposal for the West Medford zoning proposal.

[Kit Collins]: This is the very first time we'll be looking at a preliminary proposal.

[Kit Collins]: It is by no means the last time we'll be looking at this proposal before it proceeds along in the process.

[Kit Collins]: The object of tonight is to review a presentation giving us an overview of the proposal by NS Associates that will acquaint us with the boundaries of the West Medford Square zoning district.

[Kit Collins]: preliminary proposals for which areas, which blocks should be which sub-districts and why the goals of this zoning and how that aligns with the overall goals of the comprehensive citywide zoning project.

[Kit Collins]: Folks who have been regularly attending this meetings will know this already, but the West Medford Square and also the Medford Square proposal also still in progress.

[Kit Collins]: These two proposals follow on the heels of kind of a more general discussion of our approach to commercial and mixed use, sorry, mixed use areas in the city.

[Kit Collins]: I think about a month ago, we held an initial discussion on a commercial framework for the remaining corridors and squares throughout Medford.

[Kit Collins]: There was a lot of public comment on that kind of bird's eye view, 30,000 foot view discussion.

[Kit Collins]: One comment that we did hear quite frequently, I think, in my opinion, was that people were very specifically asking for height and density in West Medford Square to support it as a more vibrant commercial square to piggyback off of its kind of unique location with the commuter rail stop.

[Kit Collins]: And it's true of West Medford Square as it is with the rest of this citywide zoning project that I think wherever we look as we kind of look all around the city to do these updates and these re-evaluations, our goal is to preserve what we love about these places, preserve the uniqueness of each of these space, each square, each corridor, each neighborhood.

[Kit Collins]: and to make sure that we're preserving what we love about those places, but not down zoning everywhere.

[Kit Collins]: We know that we need development, we need to support development, we need to vastly increase housing.

[Kit Collins]: So we're looking to do that in each square, in each corridor, in each neighborhood in a way that is tailored to each square, corridor, neighborhood.

[Kit Collins]: So that applies to West Medford Square as it does to each of our zoning topics.

[Kit Collins]: Before I hand it over to Paula I just wanted to mention because I know there are folks who are attending tonight who are maybe new to this process, because they're West Medford residents or business owners who haven't been involved in the zoning overhaul process previously just to state this in the context of the rest of the kind of the arc of the overhaul.

[Kit Collins]: This proposal, this draft proposal, this draft proposal process for West Medford Square has been preceded by many other topics in the Citywide Zoning Review timeline.

[Kit Collins]: The first package that the City Council ordained was the Mystic Avenue Corridor District that was back last fall.

[Kit Collins]: We then followed by ordaining a green score rubric, which updates environmental and climate resiliency related incentives and rewards for rewards for developers and major building projects.

[Kit Collins]: We ordained the Salem Street corridor district.

[Kit Collins]: Currently in process is the neighborhood and urban residential zoning topic, which is going to have its second date before the Community Development Board this month, I believe.

[Kit Collins]: Medford Square zoning proposal is also in progress.

[Kit Collins]: It's still in this committee and updates to the ADU ordinance is still in progress.

[Kit Collins]: It has not yet been referred out of this committee either.

[Kit Collins]: So this is one piece of a citywide process, and we welcome everybody's participation and involvement in as much of this project interests them.

[Kit Collins]: With that, Paola, if there's no initial comments from any of my fellow councilors or from city staff, I'd love to turn it over to Paola to begin her presentation about the draft West Medford Square zoning proposal.

[Kit Collins]: Well, the purpose of this meeting is to get our initial two cents on the record.

[Kit Collins]: So I'll just give my my first reaction to

[Kit Collins]: our first look at the zoning proposal.

[Kit Collins]: I think that this is a really strong place to be starting in.

[Kit Collins]: I feel really good about this map as the first thing that we look at in this proposal process.

[Kit Collins]: Like I mentioned at the beginning of the meeting, I think our goal is with any zoning proposal that's a part of this process is to match existing by right heights or build upon them where it's appropriate.

[Kit Collins]: And this proposal does that, as was shown in the maps in the presentation.

[Kit Collins]: Currently, the zoning for a lot of the center of West Medford Square is already six stories by right.

[Kit Collins]: There's a lot of apartment one, which is three stories by right.

[Kit Collins]: So I think it's really appropriate for us to be looking at this map and considering next use to be kind of as a default for a lot of that commercial center, because I think what I have heard from a lot of constituents so far is they'd like to see increased development potential in West Medford Square.

[Kit Collins]: And given what's already allowed by right, I think that mixed use 2B allows that.

[Kit Collins]: Another thing that pops out to me comparing this proposed draft with the map of the current zoning for West Medford Square is that this is a really cool opportunity for us to create a more thoughtful gradient from the center of West Medford Square into the kind of surrounding neighborhood.

[Kit Collins]: We were looking at the current zoning map earlier,

[Kit Collins]: you know, we have a lot of those six story by right three story by right, and then it's surrounded by a ring of single family.

[Kit Collins]: That's just a really abrupt drop off.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that, um.

[Kit Collins]: We should absolutely consider and present to the public a map more like this one that has that central ring of six stories by right.

[Kit Collins]: Four story by right next used to a where where it makes sense where mixed used to be doesn't make sense.

[Kit Collins]: And then the step down employing you are too.

[Kit Collins]: I think that we should employ you are too pretty intensively around here because of the

[Kit Collins]: commuter rail stop.

[Kit Collins]: Something that we've been trying to prioritize throughout the zoning map is ground floor commercial.

[Kit Collins]: And obviously that's something that people already, you know, I would say both love and miss about West Medford Square.

[Kit Collins]: We love the ground floor commercial that's there and we miss the storefronts that we used to be able to patronize that have been vacant for a really long time.

[Kit Collins]: And I think people are really, really eager

[Kit Collins]: to see those storefronts get filled again and mixed use zoning.

[Kit Collins]: This is true citywide is like a way for us to allow that by right while also allowing the residential units by right that will support that commercial base.

[Kit Collins]: And that's part of the reason that I think we should be looking at mixed use to be as a default here.

[Kit Collins]: A point that was raised during our ongoing discussion of neighborhood and urban residential is that with the mixed use zoning, being able to add more housing units on upper floors through those increased by right heights has a benefit in that it allows us to free up a little bit more of our green space on those lots potentially.

[Kit Collins]: This is, in some cases, a developer decision.

[Kit Collins]: It allows us to not need to use so much of the footprint of a lot

[Kit Collins]: For adding housing units.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that we are so really It gives us an opportunity to think about how does increased development increased density interplay with protecting green space in West Medford square and with the residential areas surrounding it.

[Kit Collins]: Um,

[Kit Collins]: Something that was discussed in brief when we were looking at the section studies just earlier, and we kind of spent a little more time talking about this in the context of West, sorry in the context of Medford Square actually something that we'll revisit.

[Kit Collins]: Obviously, I hope it goes without saying, but it shouldn't that, you know, certainly in West Medford squares and elsewhere, we're conscious that we really need to prioritize land area for uses for residential for commercial, but we're not unaware of the need for parking, both for the active business area and for the commercial and for the commuter rail.

[Kit Collins]: And Paula and Emily from the associates team so far I've done a really great job of presenting some I think novel and very compelling ways that we could integrate parking into the fabric of some of these mixed use developments so that it doesn't.

[Kit Collins]: doesn't necessarily monopolize some of the area that could be put to productive use and developments, but does retain some parking in and around the square for those who will continue to need it.

[Kit Collins]: You are too should be allowed to go to four stories.

[Kit Collins]: The area under consideration could be expanded one more block to the west with mixed use one, which is three stories by right, plus one story with incentive zoning.

[Kit Collins]: On the north side, this is within a stone's throw from the commuter station, and I believe MX1 would be appropriate additional density while stepping down from the center of the square towards the residential neighborhood.

[Kit Collins]: The area under consideration could also be expanded to the east one to two blocks with MX1 to step down away from the center of the square and expand the corridor.

[Kit Collins]: I think the MX1 doesn't have to require ground floor commercial, it could be left optional so that based on the evolving needs of the area, it could be residential or mixed use.

[Kit Collins]: Sure, Councilor Scarpellile.

[Kit Collins]: Wait, I apologize.

[Kit Collins]: What was the request?

[Kit Collins]: Yeah, thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I think I'm I apologize that it wasn't listed on the action discussion items I think the intent was that we could ask those of the parking director while he's here for the GLX update.

[Kit Collins]: Great, thank you.

[Kit Collins]: So we'll go in that order.

[Kit Collins]: First to the review of the parking department surveillance impact reports and use policy.

[Kit Collins]: So as a quick overview, these are parts of reporting requirements that are mandated.

[Kit Collins]: under the Community Control over Public Surveillance Ordinance, which was ordained in 2023.

[Kit Collins]: All city departments that use surveillance technology must complete certain reporting requirements, they must have an impact report for the surveillance technology that they use, they must have a use policy,

[Kit Collins]: for the surveillance technology that they use, and this must be annually reviewed and approved by the City Council.

[Kit Collins]: There's also an annual report submitted by the city agency that's using the surveillance technology.

[Kit Collins]: and an annual report that is compiled by the city council that kind of compiles all of this information into one publicly accessible report.

[Kit Collins]: So this is the first time that we're having the parking department before us.

[Kit Collins]: They have one surveillance technology in use, I believe.

[Kit Collins]: And thank you for being here to present and thank you for the timely application of the impact report and use policy.

[Kit Collins]: Councilors had this in their packets to review before this meeting.

[Kit Collins]: So I'd like to invite up parking director

[Kit Collins]: MacDermott, to give a brief overview of anything that you'd like to say, Jermaine, to the use policy, the impact report, the technology that we're talking about are the automatic license plate readers.

[Kit Collins]: And if you could give an overview, you know, just you don't have to read word for word from the report, but just an overview of what these are, how they pertain to like what the surveillance element is, why the parking department uses them.

[Kit Collins]: That would be helpful to kick off the discussion.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Great, thank you very much.

[Kit Collins]: Are there any initial questions from councilors?

[Kit Collins]: Seeing none, would you mind also giving an overview of the impact report that you supplied to the council?

[Kit Collins]: Just the headlines.

[Kit Collins]: Great, thank you and I appreciate that.

[Kit Collins]: I think that this is kind of the the intent of the city working together to put these kind of safeguards around surveillance technology so that we can make sure that there's a structure for exactly that kind of checking and rigor which is to say

[Kit Collins]: any access to surveillance data or surveillance technology that does not have to exist, should not exist, because it makes us all a little less safe and less cyber secure in the city.

[Kit Collins]: So appreciate that.

[Kit Collins]: I'll keep an eye out for questions from my, oh, I see one question from Councilor Callahan.

[Kit Collins]: Go again, Councilor Callahan.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Great, thank you for that answer I appreciate that and great to know that this has already been at least raised to sense energy techno.

[Kit Collins]: I know for myself and this brings up a question that I was going to kind of the question around the longevity of this data both locally and with G techna and sense and.

[Kit Collins]: I think it would be useful in the use policy to have some language that specifies like a concrete sunlighting date for the data, whether it is stored locally, and some clarity around the municipal records retention schedules.

[Kit Collins]: I know that those are citywide, but I think that people are generally familiar with

[Kit Collins]: what that actually dictates.

[Kit Collins]: I think it would be a helpful amendment to the use policy to see that specified how long this data is being stored.

[Kit Collins]: I can understand that it needs to be stored for some amount of time in case somebody wants to make an appeal, which they should be able to do, of course.

[Kit Collins]: But I think it'd be helpful to have some concrete language about for how long is it remaining.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: And according, and kind of going along with that, sorry, looking back at my notes here, I think that it would also, it sounds like the information that we've received from CENCEN and GTECNA so far is that there's no indication that they have any agreements with other entities to use the data that is transferred back to them in any kind of way, which is great to hear.

[Kit Collins]: That's what I'd like to assume.

[Kit Collins]: I think it would be helpful to have that, some language around that and like,

[Kit Collins]: even if it's an annual confirmation of that in our contract with them written into the use policy.

[Kit Collins]: I think that is in a lot of cases with surveillance data and surveillance technology, you know, it's kind of the concentric circles of it all.

[Kit Collins]: It's not just, is it secure here?

[Kit Collins]: Is it secure with the people who have access to it?

[Kit Collins]: Is it secure with the people who created the software that allows us to get this data in the first place?

[Kit Collins]: So if that could be kind of a related amendment in the use policy, just that we're confirming with the people who enable the surveillance technology that it is also,

[Kit Collins]: not being transferred, not being sold, not being shared, and like a very specific sunlight date on their end as well.

[Kit Collins]: I think that would be very valuable.

[Kit Collins]: Okay, great.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Seeing no other further questions from councillors at this time.

[Kit Collins]: I just had one other.

[Kit Collins]: Let me pull up the section of the, this is on the, still on the use policy.

[Kit Collins]: For number six, you mentioned, and you spoke to this at this time, the parking department is not seeking to share access of the technology or the data with any other agency, department, bureau, division, or unit.

[Kit Collins]: That's great.

[Kit Collins]: That makes sense.

[Kit Collins]: I think it would be helpful just to shore up that language to make it a declaration of this is something that will not happen.

[Kit Collins]: Not only are we not intending for it to happen right now, this is something that we are not allowing within the parameters of this technology's use, would be a helpful amendment.

[Kit Collins]: Any other questions, comments, concerns, compliments from other councilors on the parking department's impact report or use policy?

[Kit Collins]: Seeing none.

[Kit Collins]: So we just caught along to few hopefully quick amendments to the records retention, some confirmations there and a quick amendment to the use policy section six to state affirmatively, you know, the switch from no intent to share access to will not share access.

[Kit Collins]: If that can be updated and then submitted back to the council next week to be included in our annual surveillance reporting, that would be great.

[Kit Collins]: The planning and permitting committee on March 26th met to discuss two additional topics that are part of our comprehensive citywide zoning overhaul.

[Kit Collins]: The topics discussed at this meeting was the first topic meeting for the Medford Square zoning proposal

[Kit Collins]: And I believe our second look at updates to the ADU's ordinance, we will meet on both of these topics again before they are reported out of committee and referred to the Community Development Board for public hearings.

[Kit Collins]: Motion to approve.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I wanted to thank you again for coming before us to again, describe this project.

[Kit Collins]: For folks who weren't at the previous presentations that the city council received on this, just to quickly paraphrase the overview that you gave, my understanding is this is to support the urgent and necessary HVAC repairs and roof repairs so that when kids go back to school in the fall, they'll have functioning air conditioning.

[Kit Collins]: and non-leaky roofs to enjoy at the start of the new school year.

[Kit Collins]: Very glad that we can support that.

[Kit Collins]: I'm so glad to hear.

[Kit Collins]: Obviously, taking on a major capital expense is not something that any of us take lightly, but I'm glad that this project is one whose scale enables us to do those ADA upgrades that I know people in the community have been asking for a long time.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for your diligence around that as well.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate all of the documentation for continuing to keep the council abreast of this and I would motion to approve.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: I just want to share my gratitude for this Councilors for the sponsors for shepherding through this draft which strongly and boldly defines protections for seekers of gender affirming and reproductive health care in Medford.

[Kit Collins]: This draft has gone through a careful legal review, and its sponsors, Councilors Sang and Lazzaro, made sure it was in alignment with other communities and with state law.

[Kit Collins]: And I want to highlight that this is protective of the whole city because it guarantees that if the federal government decides to pick a fight over cities allowing unfettered access to health care, then we won't be fighting that battle alone.

[Kit Collins]: We'll be going in as part of a regional and statewide cavalry.

[Kit Collins]: We are in a moment where the federal government is attacking women's access to health care and trans and non-binary people's access to health care in a deliberate attempt to punish political enemies and create a distraction from this administration's catastrophic economic agenda.

[Kit Collins]: They're making a goal of actively making Americans' lives worse.

[Kit Collins]: And I'm very grateful for this leadership to do what we can on the city level to say that won't happen here.

[Kit Collins]: So I want to extend my gratitude to the sponsors and also to the residents who held this council to account for making this ordinance happen.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: I want to thank yourself and Councilor Lazzaro for putting this together for this meeting's agenda.

[Kit Collins]: I just think this is a moment in which it's really, really important for city leaders and leaders at all levels to be vocal.

[Kit Collins]: We're in a really scary era where the federal government is using all sorts of strategies

[Kit Collins]: to try and actively make people more scared, more vulnerable, more unsafe.

[Kit Collins]: The goal of detentions like Ramesa's is to intimidate activists into hiding, to intimidate organizers into silence, to make non-citizens feel endangered, to make everyone afraid to speak up.

[Kit Collins]: And I would hate to see the city of Medford perpetuate that because it's not going to help us withstand this very insidious culture.

[Kit Collins]: So I'm very grateful to your leadership and putting this language forward.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: I do wanna take this opportunity just to read into the record some of the basic rights and resources that I think we need to be making every effort to communicate and distribute via city communication channels.

[Kit Collins]: They include, you have the right to remain silent.

[Kit Collins]: You have the right to not answer questions, including questions about your immigration status.

[Kit Collins]: You have the right to call your attorney.

[Kit Collins]: You have the right to see your warrant.

[Kit Collins]: I must have a warrant signed by a judge to arrest or detain you.

[Kit Collins]: You have the right to not sign any documents, even if ICE instructs you to.

[Kit Collins]: If ICE comes to your home, you have the right to not open the door.

[Kit Collins]: If ICE claims to have a warrant, you have the right to ask them to slide it under the door.

[Kit Collins]: If ICE agents do not have a warrant signed by a judge, they cannot enter a home without permission from an adult.

[Kit Collins]: If ICE comes to your business, you have the right to not answer questions about specific employees.

[Kit Collins]: You have the right to not introduce ICE agents to employees that they request to see.

[Kit Collins]: If ICE comes to your business, you have the right to not allow them into private areas of your business.

[Kit Collins]: If ICE agents do not have a warrant signed by a judge, they cannot enter private areas of your business without your permission.

[Kit Collins]: So I think the least that we can do as a city, and we should go further than this, but the least we can do is make sure that all of our residents and business owners and community members unambiguously know their rights in this scary and uncertain time.

[Kit Collins]: I've had a number of residents reach out to me stating, I actually don't know what a person's rights are.

[Kit Collins]: Maybe I know what I can do if ICE comes to my home or to my business, but what if they just approached me on the street, like Ramesa was approached on the street?

[Kit Collins]: We have the resources to, I mean, this information exists everywhere.

[Kit Collins]: There are tons of nonprofits that are doing really good work at sharing this information.

[Kit Collins]: It would be an extremely light lift for the city to put together really basic immigration, know your rights documents.

[Kit Collins]: We could work with our community liaisons team and other resources that the city already has to make sure this is translated to every language that is spoken in the city of Medford.

[Kit Collins]: and then use all of our official and informal communication channels in the community to try and make sure that everybody is empowered with this information.

[Kit Collins]: It's not all that we should do, but we have to start there.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: And I want to start by thanking everybody who's worked so hard in this process.

[Kit Collins]: Genuinely, thank you so much for your hard work volunteering on behalf of this community.

[Kit Collins]: This has been an interesting process, and it's been characterized by hard work by many volunteers to bring this forward.

[Kit Collins]: The CSC's process was long and as expansive as it could be, given the resources they were allocated for a project of this size, scope, and importance.

[Kit Collins]: The council's process, I think, has been good faith, but fast.

[Kit Collins]: Back in 2024, the council requested to begin the charter review process earlier, earlier than 2025.

[Kit Collins]: The mayor's office did not indicate that this was something they could.

[Kit Collins]: compromise on.

[Kit Collins]: Um so in the past few short months, we've tried to do as thorough and thoughtful of of a review as this project deserves.

[Kit Collins]: Um I don't think that that's quite a long enough time for something as important as this but we've done our best.

[Kit Collins]: Uh this is after all as we're all very well aware the city's guiding foundational legal document and I have maintained that it would be inappropriate and irresponsible

[Kit Collins]: for the council to consider its role as a rubber stamp on this document, no matter how eager we all are to complete this project and get it to the next phase of its journey.

[Kit Collins]: The past few months of public meetings on the charter have been, in my estimation, largely consumed by one issue, which is council makeup.

[Kit Collins]: We've had a lot of conversations about council makeup, wards or districts.

[Kit Collins]: And as everybody knows, I preferred the district model.

[Kit Collins]: Four district Councilors plus three at-large was the original proposal.

[Kit Collins]: And then it was compromised to four district Councilors plus five at-large to allow for a bigger council, more total representatives.

[Kit Collins]: I was pretty dug in, but I've been thinking about it.

[Kit Collins]: And that is not the hill that I'm going to die on.

[Kit Collins]: Because in my thinking about this over the past several weeks, if that central kernel is representativeness, whether the council is 5-4 or 8-3 doesn't really get at the heart of the issue.

[Kit Collins]: I think the most important thing that we could have done or could do for meaningful representativeness, which is a spectrum, is reevaluate our strong mayor system of government.

[Kit Collins]: Because a more representative city council only goes so far when the mayor, most of the time, holds all of the cards.

[Kit Collins]: An alternative to a strong mayor system was never given terribly serious consideration in this process.

[Kit Collins]: I'm not, I do not mean to criticize the Charter Study Committee for this.

[Kit Collins]: It was a volunteer process with volunteer resources and they made incredible strides given the resources and the time that they were given.

[Kit Collins]: But this process did not interrogate our current strong mayor system, notwithstanding what I perceive to be genuine community interest in considering other alternatives, including recent specific efforts to renegotiate the balance of power between the city council and the mayor relative to the budgeting process.

[Kit Collins]: This was brought up in our previous fiscal year.

[Kit Collins]: And it shows up in lots of different ways.

[Kit Collins]: Something that I really, I think it's important to surface is that

[Kit Collins]: On balance, the types of requests that I get from residents most often is essentially asking the city council to do something or fund something.

[Kit Collins]: And the answer is almost always, we can't.

[Kit Collins]: That's the mayor's purview.

[Kit Collins]: All of our major functions, ordinances, zoning, budget review are constrained by the much, much greater jurisdiction of the mayor.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that when residents say they want representativeness, they want representative not just for talk,

[Kit Collins]: and for exposure, but for action.

[Kit Collins]: That's meaningful representation.

[Kit Collins]: What I mean to say, and I'm sorry, it's taken me a bit of a walk to get here, but this is important, and I really wanna make myself clear, is that this process has clarified for me that I believe the interest of the community is for a more genuinely representative system of governance where the executive office has less power, not no power, less power, and is more meaningfully checked by the school committee and the city council.

[Kit Collins]: In addition to people enjoying more local representation on the school committee and on the city council.

[Kit Collins]: So, on top of that, the mayor's most recent draft which gave us a week to consider amendments.

[Kit Collins]: Many of those amendments further expanded mayoral power relative to the power of the Council and some of them were totally benign, but there are a number that I found very problematic and.

[Kit Collins]: Frankly, I think that's the opposite of the direction that we should be going in.

[Kit Collins]: I'm not saying we should scrap this and build a strong council or city manager draft charter, though we could do that with an elected charter commission.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think that we should.

[Kit Collins]: We could.

[Kit Collins]: That's not what I'm advancing.

[Kit Collins]: But I, as one councilor, I'm going to need to see some additional amendments that at least start to move this issue of power balance in the right direction.

[Kit Collins]: and start to engage with that topic of the balance of power between mayor, council, school committee.

[Kit Collins]: I will support the amendments to protect and preserve the city council's right to make appointments to commissions unless otherwise specified.

[Kit Collins]: I support the proposed amendment to remove the mayor's residency requirement for ward Councilors, which as the councilor stated, places a burden on ward Councilors greater than other electeds.

[Kit Collins]: I would also like to make a motion to amend section 9-4B to amend the number of appointees allocated to future charter study committees by the mayor, city council, and school committee.

[Kit Collins]: To change that language to this review shall be made by a special committee to be composed of three appointees of the mayor,

[Kit Collins]: three appointees of the city council, and three appointees of the school committee.

[Kit Collins]: That's changing four mayor, three city council, two school committee, to three mayor, three city council, and three school committee.

[Kit Collins]: And I would also like to make a motion to remove the mayor from the school committee.

[Kit Collins]: That would be amendments to section 4-1, beginning with striking the last sentence of section 4-1A.

[Kit Collins]: These amendments

[Kit Collins]: In my one councilor's opinion, skip over I think the relatively smaller issue of four, three, or sorry, five to four versus eight to three, and more meaningly begin to engage with the city's balance of power.

[Kit Collins]: Those amendments would leave me feeling comfortable supporting this draft, including eight ward councilors and three at-large councilors.

[Kit Collins]: And again, I want to acknowledge that there's impatience to get this done.

[Kit Collins]: I hope that in my willingness to make uncomfortable motions, people and my fellow Councilors might consider that this stems from a desire, that this stems not from an enjoyment of making uncomfortable and perhaps unpopular motions, but rather from a sincere desire to get this as right as possible because it's important.

[Kit Collins]: I changed my mind on five and four and eight and three, and I've changed my mind on some other things too.

[Kit Collins]: And I think it's my responsibility to take the votes that I think will be best for this community.

[Kit Collins]: Our next charter needs to advance the cause of improving the balance of power between the mayor and the city council and the school committee.

[Kit Collins]: And I think this would move the ball forward.

[Kit Collins]: If it takes a special meeting next week to discuss this and then move this forward expeditiously, staying in April, that is fine with me.

[Kit Collins]: And we are not the only body that has affected the timeline

[Kit Collins]: of this draft project.

[Kit Collins]: So those are my two motions.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: No, sorry, finish your thought.

[Kit Collins]: Did you finish your thought?

[Kit Collins]: Okay.

[Kit Collins]: Um the motion to refer to committee of the whole was not mine.

[Kit Collins]: Uh though I do support it.

[Kit Collins]: I think that we should take the available committee of the whole meeting next week and then immediately meet on this again in a regular meeting or special meeting.

[Kit Collins]: Um but the the motion to move this to a committee of the whole wasn't mine.

[Kit Collins]: to what?

[Kit Collins]: No, I'd like to vote on it now.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I'm not going to restate my rationale because I think I spent at least five minutes explaining myself earlier and nobody wants to be kept here for longer than necessary.
