[Kit Collins]: And if folks want to watch that back on the live stream that's already on the city's YouTube and send me their thoughts and comments and show up to the special meeting next week, I think it'd be great to continue the conversation about this.

[Kit Collins]: balance of power.

[Kit Collins]: I only wanted to make the point that based on some of the hypotheticals that were being asked this evening, I have a concern that people are going to come out of this meeting saying this process is definitely going to happen in spring of 2026.

[Kit Collins]: That is not an accurate thing to say.

[Kit Collins]: And I want us to be proactive about not spreading that speculation in the community.

[Kit Collins]: It's because I want this to go forward successfully that I support that I'm going to support the motion to have a special meeting on this next week and I just I

[Kit Collins]: Every community is a fertile ground for rumors.

[Kit Collins]: I don't want this to get out the gate and have people thinking this is definitely going to be a spring of 2026 election.

[Kit Collins]: It's certainly not what I want.

[Kit Collins]: And I don't think that this timeline at all locks us into that timeline.

[Kit Collins]: And I feel very confident that we'll all be making best efforts to stick to the November 2025 timeline.

[Kit Collins]: So I just wanted to be very clear about that because there was this question and questions about it just earlier.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: And with that, I'd like to move the question.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: So I remember the very first resolution that I ever sponsored after becoming Medford's first Jewish city councilor.

[Kit Collins]: It was about condemning anti-Semitism because it was in the wake of an unintentional but still real and painful anti-Semitic event that occurred in Medford in December of 2021.

[Kit Collins]: I know that the councilor's intention with this resolution was simply to make Jewish residents, or at least certain Jewish residents, feel supported.

[Kit Collins]: But this resolution makes omissions that imply that supporting Jews is contingent on ignoring, erasing, and minimizing the genocide in Palestine.

[Kit Collins]: And as a Jew, I find that offensive, unhelpful, and unacceptable.

[Kit Collins]: This city council has already passed a resolution about Israel and Palestine in March of 2024.

[Kit Collins]: On that one, frankly, I think we got it right.

[Kit Collins]: Jewish, Arab, and Muslim residents and allies came together, we collaboratively crafted a statement that did not receive universal support, but earned hours of impassioned support from community members, many of whom had never been inside these council chambers before.

[Kit Collins]: In that statement, we condemned the murder of Israelis by terrorists on October 7th and the taking of hostages.

[Kit Collins]: We did not fail to condemn the murder of Palestinians by the IDF for every single month since then the taking of political prisoners terrorism in the West Bank by Israeli settler extremists and Israeli war crimes to name one but not the other.

[Kit Collins]: However, unintentionally sends a very strong message that messages, some pain is more real and more important than other pain to specifically mourn the 1200 Israelis murdered by Hamas on October 7 2023, but with no acknowledgement of the over 62,000 Palestinians murdered since then in Gaza by the IDF.

[Kit Collins]: which, according to the Lancet Medical Journal, could be undercounted by up to 40% and does not even include the over 100,000 people who have died of starvation and disease in Gaza.

[Kit Collins]: and does not include Palestinians murdered by extremist Israeli settler terrorism in the West Bank, that is participating in the dehumanization that allows this genocide to continue unchecked.

[Kit Collins]: And to affirm Israel's right to exist while failing to mention Palestine's right to exist is offensive to Palestinians in our community and perpetuates a false, unhelpful right-wing ideology.

[Kit Collins]: It is incredibly radical to suggest, as this resolution does, that the Palestinians, quote, lack a permanent homeland.

[Kit Collins]: The city of Medford cannot be in the business of normalizing this objectively fringe and right wing opinion.

[Kit Collins]: If the council is going to be bold enough to weigh in on Israel and Palestine, we should be bold enough to call things what they are.

[Kit Collins]: What's happening in Palestine is not, quote, hardship.

[Kit Collins]: It's not difficulty.

[Kit Collins]: It's not complexity.

[Kit Collins]: It is war crimes.

[Kit Collins]: It is genocide.

[Kit Collins]: It is apartheid.

[Kit Collins]: Supporting Jews is not contingent on erasing the genocide of Palestinians.

[Kit Collins]: Supporting Jews is not contingent on erasing the solidarity, pain, and outrage that so many Jews share with Palestinian victims of genocide.

[Kit Collins]: Personally, I will never support any language that clearly does not dare to weight all human life as equal, knowing that as a Jew, I'm supposed to read this with gratitude.

[Kit Collins]: Further, I find it really irresponsible to force anti-Semitism and Israel and Palestine together into one topic.

[Kit Collins]: The implication is that it's anti-Semitic to criticize Israel.

[Kit Collins]: That is false.

[Kit Collins]: That is a false premise that we must not entertain.

[Kit Collins]: Right now we are in a moment where many people, including many people in our community, including many Jews like me in our community, are actively exercising their free speech to criticize Israeli genocide, Israeli war crimes, Israeli terrorism.

[Kit Collins]: In response, across America, conservative movements are weaponizing the language of Jewish safety and weaponizing accusations of anti-Semitism

[Kit Collins]: in a coordinated effort to delegitimize criticism of Israel.

[Kit Collins]: They see clearly that a good way to shut people up is by suggesting that they are being anti-Semitic.

[Kit Collins]: And that is why we cannot afford to entertain this false premise anywhere.

[Kit Collins]: Even here at Medford City Hall, we cannot entertain this.

[Kit Collins]: It is dangerous, it is corrosive, it stifles free speech, and it silences Jews.

[Kit Collins]: Again,

[Kit Collins]: I really do want to be clear, I appreciate any opportunity to reaffirm our commitment to ending anti-Semitism.

[Kit Collins]: Anti-Semitism is real and deadly.

[Kit Collins]: which is why we should not allow it to be twisted into a tool for stifling pro-Palestinian activism.

[Kit Collins]: It does not make Jews safer when we cheapen a real phenomenon with irrelevant and politicized conflations.

[Kit Collins]: It does not help Jews when we reaffirm right-wing messaging that ignores or legitimizes the genocide and the war crimes that occur every day with American tax dollars, when we legitimize false claims about the dangers of peace activism.

[Kit Collins]: It really makes me wonder how weak does a person have to think Jews are, that our safety is contingent not only on the eradication of Palestinians, but on that genocide also going unmentioned and unprotested.

[Kit Collins]: At best, that premise treats Jews like children, and at worst, it allows us to be used like pawns.

[Kit Collins]: If we want to pass a different resolution that aligns with the language we passed last year, that would be fine with me, but this isn't it.

[Kit Collins]: This language takes more issue with certain forms of protest than it does with a historic genocide that is directly affecting members of our community who have family in or displaced from Palestine.

[Kit Collins]: And I have no idea why we would entertain the notion that the city of Medford should weigh in on how its residents should or should not exercise their constitutional right to protest.

[Kit Collins]: We are Councilors, not parents.

[Kit Collins]: It is not our job to tell people how to use their free speech.

[Kit Collins]: It is condescending and we should not pretend that it is anything other than irrelevant to the goal of supporting and protecting Jews.

[Kit Collins]: I also know that there are people who will agree with what I've said tonight and those who won't, that's also fine.

[Kit Collins]: There's obviously a difference of opinion on this within and outside of the Jewish community and anyone who pretends otherwise is lying.

[Kit Collins]: But that doesn't make it okay for this council to normalize, however unintentionally, right-wing messaging that uses Jewish identities as an excuse for stifling free speech and protest.

[Kit Collins]: It doesn't make it okay for this council to conspicuously fail to stand equally strongly against anti-Palestinian hate and anti-Palestinian rhetoric as we continue to condemn the poison of antisemitism.

[Kit Collins]: And it certainly isn't for anyone outside of the Jewish community to tell any Jews how we should feel about it.

[Kit Collins]: a motion to table.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: The statistics I was referencing was pulled from BBC and Al Jazeera, internationally respected incredible news sources.

[Kit Collins]: Obviously, any Jew would take issue with being called anti-Semitic.

[Kit Collins]: It's not the first time I've been called anti-Semitic, but I think it's

[Kit Collins]: It's very convenient to have a term for why it's anti-Semitic to observe and literally describe a genocide that is going on.

[Kit Collins]: It doesn't make it Holocaust inversion.

[Kit Collins]: It doesn't make it anti-Semitic to observe and tell the truth.

[Kit Collins]: I struggle to find words for how offensive it is

[Kit Collins]: to be told over and over again that telling the truth about this is in any way offensive to my religion and my family, who are only here in the first place because of real, not rhetorical, not invented, not fictionalized or exaggerated anti-Semitism.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I was listening in on my commute here.

[Kit Collins]: Sorry for being late to the chambers.

[Kit Collins]: On the specific amendment, I just wanted to clarify, is this replacing any text from the draft?

[Kit Collins]: I would say, in general, I want to be deferential to the sponsors of the ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: And you have been very, very closely involved in crafting a language to meet the intent of this.

[Kit Collins]: And I trust that intent is to be as strongly protected as possible, which is my preference as well.

[Kit Collins]: I like that the original second paragraph calls out very explicitly what we're trying to do.

[Kit Collins]: I hear the concerns about adhering this with other city ordinances and state law as a protective mechanism for being able to do this protective work while also making sure that if the federal government decides to pick a fight legally, we'll have allies.

[Kit Collins]: I think that's fine.

[Kit Collins]: But that part that I'm...

[Kit Collins]: suggesting that we take out would be the part that says, provided however that gender identity may be demonstrated through medical history, care or treatment of the gender identity, consistent and uniform assertion of the gender identity, or any other evidence that the gender identity is sincerely held as part of a person's core identity, and provided further

[Kit Collins]: that gender identity shall not be asserted for any improper purpose.

[Kit Collins]: And my motivation behind that is just especially in this environment, I think we're gonna see more people with gender identities other than like woman assigned female at birth and man assigned male at birth who don't have documentation that it's a core part of their identity because it's less and less safe to do that.

[Kit Collins]: I just don't think that we need to uphold that premise in our definitions.

[Kit Collins]: If that's something that legal counsel insists we change before we take a vote to ordain this, that's fine, but I'd rather we delete it.

[Kit Collins]: Um, my assumption perhaps is that

[Kit Collins]: Maybe the intent in this language is that local police counts as a law enforcement agency of the Commonwealth, but I think that we should, I think we should make it really clear.

[Kit Collins]: We're talking about Medford, yeah.

[Kit Collins]: No, I think that's a good point.

[Kit Collins]: Do you know the answer?

[Kit Collins]: The meeting documents for this meeting, if they're not already uploaded, they'll be on the City Council's public portal website, which you can go to the City of Medford website and click on City Council and you'll find our public portal.

[Kit Collins]: If the documents for tonight's meeting aren't up yet, I'm sure they will be by tomorrow.

[Kit Collins]: and after this is voted on, if it is approved, it will eventually be added to the city's muni code and search city of Medford muni code.

[Kit Collins]: I know there's a backlog on ordinances that still need to be uploaded there, but in the meantime, you can find them on the city council public portal from the date on which they were voted on.

[Kit Collins]: I just wanted to thank you both for your hard work over many, many months to bring this draft forward and for making sure that this got a lot of attention right now so that we can get it on, get it up for a vote as expeditiously as possible.

[Kit Collins]: And I've been really working very hard to make sure that this both captures the spirit of what Medford residents want this to be and also has the protections of being closely aligned with other communities ordinances and state law.

[Kit Collins]: So thank you for your hard work.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you to all the community members who reached out to us to hold us to account for working on this.

[Kit Collins]: Appreciate it.

[Kit Collins]: Right.

[Kit Collins]: Mr. Clerk, please let me know when you're ready to go and I'll call the meeting to order.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: He did let me know that he would probably be running pretty late tonight and that he would join whenever he can.

[Kit Collins]: Great.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: All right, there will be a meeting of the Medford City Council Planning and Permanent Committee, March 26th, 2025.

[Kit Collins]: This meeting will take place at 6 p.m.

[Kit Collins]: via Zoom.

[Kit Collins]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Kit Collins]: present.

[Kit Collins]: For present, one absent, the meeting is called to order.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you all very much for being here tonight.

[Kit Collins]: The action and discussion item for tonight is 24-033, zoning ordinance updates with the NS Associates team.

[Kit Collins]: So tonight what's on our agenda is to follow up on two topics that we have discussed once before at our committee meeting two weeks ago.

[Kit Collins]: On March 12th, we reviewed a early framework for updates to Medford's accessory dwelling units or ADUs ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: We had a long discussion to get this update project started off.

[Kit Collins]: The update from Innes Associates flagged updates that the City of Medford must make to our ADUs ordinance to become in compliance with the new state law that requires that ADUs be by right in any residential district that allows single family homes by right.

[Kit Collins]: So we talked about that and what that means for our zoning ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: And the zoning consultant and associates also flagged areas where there are more decisions left up to the city when it comes to local ADUs and options that we have for further updates we can make to further regulate or encourage ADUs beyond just the new regulations that are required by state law.

[Kit Collins]: And so we'll be looking at an updated draft

[Kit Collins]: of the ADU's ordinance tonight in response to the questions and feedback that councillors and committee community members had two weeks ago.

[Kit Collins]: We will also tonight be visiting the topic of

[Kit Collins]: updated zoning for Medford Square.

[Kit Collins]: This will be our very first time looking at a proposal of an updated zoning map for Medford Square and it will not be the last time we talk about it either.

[Kit Collins]: Two weeks ago, we looked at a really preliminary introductory, a 30,000 foot view of a zoning map that encapsulates a commercial framework or a zoning map encapsulating a commercial framework for the city touching on all major squares.

[Kit Collins]: corridors, mixed-use, and commercial districts, and we decided that from there we're kind of going to draw the telescope in.

[Kit Collins]: We're going to go from that bird's-eye view commercial framework and focus the dial on Medford Square, and then West Medford Square, and then other major corridors and mixed-use and commercial districts.

[Kit Collins]: So the first one up is Medford Square.

[Kit Collins]: I know that the Innes Associates has presented, has prepared

[Kit Collins]: Um, some maps and some diagrams for us to look at and respond to tonight.

[Kit Collins]: So we'll be able to get a lot of questions and ideas and concerns on the record.

[Kit Collins]: And that will be followed up by, um, further conversations on this topic in this committee, um, over the next several weeks.

[Kit Collins]: So I know that Paola has a presentation, um, on all of this before I throw it over to Paola.

[Kit Collins]: Um, I want to ask if any of my fellow Councilors have any questions or comments to start off the evening.

[Kit Collins]: Great.

[Kit Collins]: Seeing none, plenty of time for that later on.

[Kit Collins]: Paola, please go ahead with your presentation.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Paola.

[Kit Collins]: Yeah, I think that I've previewed the section studies that you're going to present next, and I think folks will find them very interesting context.

[Kit Collins]: But let's take a pause here in case there are any preliminary

[Kit Collins]: questions or comments on this aerial view.

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Leming will go to you first, unless you wanna hold your question for later.

[Kit Collins]: Yeah, thank you for putting that suggestion in that question on the record, Councilor Leming.

[Kit Collins]: I don't know if Paula has a response to this.

[Kit Collins]: I'm certainly always helpful.

[Kit Collins]: I think these are exactly the areas where we should be evaluating for where our subdistricts of greatest height and density makes most sense.

[Kit Collins]: And I've thought before that I'd really love to see some increased height along 93 so we can kind of kill two birds with one stone.

[Kit Collins]: adding some development potential while blocking some noise from 93 for the residential and business areas that are closer to the square or bordering the highway.

[Kit Collins]: On the matter of the traffic patterns, I think most folks on this call, whether they're Councilors or community members, already know that through zoning, we cannot and we won't directly change traffic patterns.

[Kit Collins]: I know that you know that, Councilor Leming, I'm just stating that for the record for in case there's any newer to zoning folks on the call.

[Kit Collins]: Not that that's what you're suggesting.

[Kit Collins]: I think is the the question is kind of like forecasting ahead for feel free to clarify.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Councilor Leming.

[Kit Collins]: I'll go to Planner Evans and then Councilor Callahan.

[Kit Collins]: I do just want to note kind of at the beginning of this discussion, or kind of whenever we're talking about like traffic patterns and zoning changes at the same time, I think it's wise to enter into that discussion, not assuming that development

[Kit Collins]: that increases in development will always necessarily at every step of the way also result in increases in car traffic, especially since we're considering policies such as TDM, transportation demand management, at the same time as zoning.

[Kit Collins]: This can interact with traffic patterns in

[Kit Collins]: In many ways, it's not a 1 to 1 relationship, so I think this is going to be 1 of those incredibly multifactorial things.

[Kit Collins]: I would think that the short answer would be zoning would not.

[Kit Collins]: Directly overlay onto our ability to update our future traffic patterns because.

[Kit Collins]: eminent domain taking of public lands that are used for our roadways, and a lot of our roadways leading into Medford Square are state roads.

[Kit Collins]: We're going to have the same land mass available for traffic lanes that we could design however we wish if we had the millions of dollars required to do that.

[Kit Collins]: But I will go over to Planner Evans for a response and then Councilor Callahan.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for that planner Evans, Councilor Kelly and go ahead.

[Kit Collins]: Go ahead, Councilwoman.

[Kit Collins]: Is it feasible to consider a higher and more dense sub district for specific parcel it sounds like there's an interest in that being further investigated for a further meeting if it does turn out that it's confirmed that the lots

[Kit Collins]: directly abutting 93 to the east of City Hall are really too narrow to accommodate mixed use three, then that'll be good information to have.

[Kit Collins]: This is a map of one version of what could be made possible.

[Kit Collins]: So even when we say, you know, this could go up to eight, this could go up to 12, this could go up to six, that's depending on if developers are trying to develop just within what's by right, or if they're taking advantage of incentive zoning,

[Kit Collins]: to a certain degree, to maximum, to minimum, not that under this new zoning, every building shall be a certain height, setting a minimum and a maximum.

[Kit Collins]: for the south side of High Street and for Mystic Valley Parkway.

[Kit Collins]: We know that we need parking to, you know, parking has a big role in the square.

[Kit Collins]: It is where a lot of our city's major destinations are.

[Kit Collins]: And we also really do want to be

[Kit Collins]: using more of our, I think we want to be using more of our land area for giving people places to live and stuff to do and companies and offices to visit.

[Kit Collins]: So I will be, I just wanted to throw my support behind version two for this particular section and then for the south side of High Street as well.

[Kit Collins]: I think that's a really smart way to be using our topography.

[Kit Collins]: And in general, I know this is brought up for Clippership Drive as well.

[Kit Collins]: I think in general, hiding parking is a great idea because it allows us to keep our building frontages exciting and full of places that people can walk into.

[Kit Collins]: The only kind of question that I think I'll have going forward is, and I'm not sure if this is really an answerable question or if this is something that will vary development by development,

[Kit Collins]: is when we're talking about putting parking inside of a building, how does that impact the actual usable, rentable, inhabitable space within that floor map or within that parcel?

[Kit Collins]: Though as I think more about it, it seems that that's probably more of a economic consideration on the developer side.

[Kit Collins]: But I just want to make sure that we're not

[Kit Collins]: trading, useful commercial and residential space for parking, whether it's inside or outside of a building envelope.

[Kit Collins]: My understanding, and I'll pass it over to city staff or economic development director after this, but I think that how, as folks know, um, how uses interplay with zoning is that we have this ability to say,

[Kit Collins]: clearly defined uses that are allowed by right, that are allowed under certain circumstances, and that are never allowed.

[Kit Collins]: And it's my understanding that it is both tricky and we also get into heavily constrained legal waters when we start saying, we start cherry picking, picking and choosing, and that would require

[Kit Collins]: You know, perhaps I think there's always a long list of things in a commercial district.

[Kit Collins]: It's a lot of different types of companies and offices that are going to be available by right.

[Kit Collins]: It's often a smaller list of those that are more regulated by special permit or explicitly not allowed.

[Kit Collins]: And I think it gets very complicated when we try to use zoning to get more specific about that, which is why I think this overlaps so heavily with the work of the economic development director and city planning staff.

[Kit Collins]: And while you're getting set up, Paola, I'll just state I wanted to give you a brief vocal rest since you've been presenting a lot tonight.

[Kit Collins]: And while you're getting the PowerPoint up, I said this at the beginning of the meeting, but for anybody who's joined after our initial five minutes, at our previous committee meeting on the 12th, we got an overview of potential changes to make to our existing accessory dwelling unit ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: We already have a regulation around ADUs.

[Kit Collins]: We are considering kind of two buckets of updates and changes to that.

[Kit Collins]: One are changes that the city is compelled to make because the state passed a new law and it is now required that wherever single family homes are allowable by right, ADUs must also be allowable by right.

[Kit Collins]: So we have to make some changes to the ordinance to be in compliance with that state law.

[Kit Collins]: And beyond that, there are additional decisions that we could make per our local jurisdiction.

[Kit Collins]: We kind of got a initial conversation on all of those areas and questions two weeks ago, and councilors and community members got some ideas and thoughts out on the record.

[Kit Collins]: And I think we're going to revisit some of those questions tonight and kind of develop a path forward on some of those on some of the questions before us in terms of local ideas.

[Kit Collins]: Go ahead.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Paola, for that overview.

[Kit Collins]: That's really helpful.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate the way that you organized it.

[Kit Collins]: I see a hand on Zoom.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much.

[Kit Collins]: We will take public participation on ADUs after questions and comments from Councilors.

[Kit Collins]: So sit tight.

[Kit Collins]: We will definitely get to you.

[Kit Collins]: begin with my own clarifying questions and then see if there are others from other Councilors.

[Kit Collins]: So I'll just repeat some of this to make sure that I am understanding the presentation correctly and hopefully for the benefit of other viewers as well.

[Kit Collins]: So kind of going down the line of these various questions before us.

[Kit Collins]: to the first question around local ADUs, municipal jurisdiction.

[Kit Collins]: It seems like per our, it seems like you adopted the preference that it seemed like it was voiced for most Councilors at our last committee meeting, that we do want to allow local ADUs in more residential sub-districts beyond just those where single family homes are allowed by right.

[Kit Collins]: So is this understanding correct that in this draft, yes, local ADUs are allowed in all sub-districts,

[Kit Collins]: by right, but they're not allowed by right on lots that have for those larger residential building types, such as townhouses, multiplexes, multifamily units, sorry, multifamily buildings greater than six units.

[Kit Collins]: On your single family homes, your two families, your three units, those can have a local ADU by right, regardless of the residential subdistrict.

[Kit Collins]: Is that, do I have that right?

[Kit Collins]: Great.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for verifying my rambling paraphrasing.

[Kit Collins]: Just to return quickly to the municipal jurisdiction, municipal decision topic of can we have a second ADU on a single lot by special permit, I just want to make sure that I'm clear on this.

[Kit Collins]: So the conditions that trigger a special permit process, it's not that every local ADU must be approved by special permit.

[Kit Collins]: It's that if a second ADU

[Kit Collins]: on a single lot has to go through the special permit process.

[Kit Collins]: And through that special permit process, they may go as high as 1,200 square feet.

[Kit Collins]: Is that correct?

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Personally, I am fine with having the maximum area be up to 1,200.

[Kit Collins]: In this case, where it is moderated by a special permit process, I don't think that I would want any local ADU to be able to go quite that high.

[Kit Collins]: I think that 900 is reasonable.

[Kit Collins]: But since this is kind of bordered by the special permit process, I'm kind of OK with it because it has that level of supervision over it.

[Kit Collins]: And then the last comment that I wanted to put out before my fellow councillors, like I was saying, I think that the 900 square foot number seems about right to me for local ADUs in general in this non-special permit scenario.

[Kit Collins]: I understand the concern about, you know, if we're going above 50% of the gross floor area, then like which unit is inferior to which, I can understand that could get a little murky.

[Kit Collins]: I do think that in cases when you have an attached or internal ADU that it could, there might be a situation there would be helpful to be able to go above that maximum.

[Kit Collins]: So pending what legal counsel, what Attorney Silverstein has to say about this, I think it might be helpful in cases of an internal or attached ADU to be able to go up to 60% just in cases where like that is what makes sense for how the building is structured internally.

[Kit Collins]: So if we keep that flexible pending,

[Kit Collins]: a comment from Attorney Silverstein, that would make sense to me.

[Kit Collins]: And all of the other changes from my perspective as one Councilor sound good.

[Kit Collins]: I was not particularly in favor of us growing our base of ADUs just for them to be used as short-term rentals.

[Kit Collins]: We want them to be used as housing for people who need housing of the scope and the scale.

[Kit Collins]: So that looks great to me as well.

[Kit Collins]: Are there any questions or comments from my fellow Councilors?

[Kit Collins]: Being none, I'm just going to pause for a second to deal with a Zoom issue.

[Kit Collins]: I think that's helpful.

[Kit Collins]: So it's in considering the dimensional standards governing what's possible for the ADUs.

[Kit Collins]: It is about conformity with the building code, but when we're considering the interplay of the code regulations on the principal dwelling and then on the ADU, it's always the more permissive of those regulations that can be used.

[Kit Collins]: I think that this is something for us to take a closer look at before we get the final version.

[Kit Collins]: of these updates to make sure that we're taking a fine tooth comb to how this plays out in each of our districts.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that we're all aligned with the perspective that was shared.

[Kit Collins]: We're doing this update because we want more ADUs to be built.

[Kit Collins]: That's the reason that we're expanding them into all residential sub-districts.

[Kit Collins]: That's the reason we're going further than the state mandates.

[Kit Collins]: And so we do want to be turning over other stone when it comes to making sure that the new language makes it easy for people to take us up on these regulations and add ADUs beneficially in a way that's good for property owners and also good for the community overall.

[Kit Collins]: So I'll be making a note of those, talk about that more.

[Kit Collins]: And you have three minutes.

[Kit Collins]: Mark just asked you to unmute.

[Kit Collins]: I'll click again.

[Kit Collins]: You're gonna have to click a button to unmute yourself.

[Kit Collins]: Try one more time, and then I'll go to somebody else and try to come back to you later.

[Kit Collins]: All right, we will come back to you.

[Kit Collins]: Next, I will go to Gaston.

[Kit Collins]: Name and address for the record, please.

[Kit Collins]: You have three minutes.

[Kit Collins]: Yes, Don, if you want, if you have multiple questions, feel free to state them all.

[Kit Collins]: NR 1, 2, and 3 under local ADUs, because per the state law, ADUs in those sub-districts are protected ADUs, so.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you president bears for reading out the full text of the resolution.

[Kit Collins]: I'm glad to have collaborated with members of 509 on this resolution and I thank them for bringing their fight for a fair contract to our attention.

[Kit Collins]: I was talking about this resolution with some community members before the meeting and over the weekend and they said, you know, why is this a Medford issue?

[Kit Collins]: And to that I say, you know, Tufts is a huge employer in our community.

[Kit Collins]: So many members of our community are involved with Tufts.

[Kit Collins]: In various ways, perhaps they work at Tufts or teach at Tufts.

[Kit Collins]: Tufts is a major employer in our community.

[Kit Collins]: It has a major footprint in our community.

[Kit Collins]: And when it comes to fair employment, fair wages, and the right to collectively bargain, this is a rising tide lifts all boats issue.

[Kit Collins]: And with a large, ostensibly non-for-profit that is such an outsized presence and an outsized footprint in our community, I think it's the least that we can do to say we must participate in holding you accountable to treating all workers with fairness, and at the very least, participating in good faith with efforts to collectively bargain.

[Kit Collins]: Our relationship with Tufts University and the city of Medford overlaps in many ways.

[Kit Collins]: We've spoken at length in these chambers about the payment in lieu of tax agreement that the city of Medford has with Tufts.

[Kit Collins]: What we are talking about is a very large, extremely well-endowed, very powerful institution that absolutely has the resources to pay its workers commensurate with their value, to pay them competitively, and to pay them so that they can comfortably live in this community.

[Kit Collins]: And so I hope that my fellow councillors will join me tonight in urging them to do just that and to engage in a good faith negotiation process with these essential Tufts University workers.

[Kit Collins]: But more importantly, I understand that there are a couple members of the bargaining unit that are attending the city council meeting tonight, and I'm sure that they can speak to their efforts much more eloquently than I could.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for the bears 1st, I apologize if my audio isn't coming through.

[Kit Collins]: Well, my Internet is unstable right now.

[Kit Collins]: I. I hear the counts are appreciate him bringing that up.

[Kit Collins]: Preference would be to.

[Kit Collins]: Vote on that as a B paper.

[Kit Collins]: I would certainly be in favor since these workers requested that the most persuasive to this employer.

[Kit Collins]: I'd like to honor sentiment for our bargaining units here in the city.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, everybody.

[Kit Collins]: How's that?

[Kit Collins]: All right.

[Kit Collins]: Thanks so much.

[Kit Collins]: Well, thank you so much to my fellow councillors for your comments so far.

[Kit Collins]: It's exciting to be at the beginning of another budget process again with you all, and I'm grateful for all of everybody submitted, I think.

[Kit Collins]: very additive and thoughtful preliminary budget recommendations.

[Kit Collins]: It is, you know, the work ahead of us is funneling down the request from the Council into a tight, succinct list that we can hope to

[Kit Collins]: fit into the overall operating budget of things that we think are the most critical and most needed by the community this year, and I think that we're off to a strong start because I see a lot of overlap between a lot of different Councilors, based on the comments and feedback that we've all been hearing from residents over the past year and longer than that so I'll quickly summarize.

[Kit Collins]: The priorities that I submitted ahead of this meeting, and I'll skip the entire preamble.

[Kit Collins]: This goes without saying, but I think it is worth saying out loud that we cannot permit any reduction from the school committee's budgetary request for Medford Public Schools.

[Kit Collins]: It would be very important to me that we prioritize meeting that this year, as we always prioritize meeting that.

[Kit Collins]: Similarly, prioritizing meeting the library department budgetary request and maintaining at least level service and hours of operation.

[Kit Collins]: In parallel with what some other Councilors have mentioned about prioritizing the funding recommendations, the funding asks from the Medford Bicycle Advisory Committee, I'd like to see us fund one additional traffic engineer for a total of two within the Department of Traffic and Transportation to focus on walking, biking, transit, and the implementation of a vision zero and complete streets policy.

[Kit Collins]: I won't get too into the details here, obviously, that there's a lot of ground that such a position could cover.

[Kit Collins]: But other councillors have said a lot in this meeting about things, kind of things we can fund where we'd see a very big return on impact.

[Kit Collins]: And I think this is one of them, because these are the people who, if we're able to get them inside of City Hall, could help us out not just with responding to constituent concerns and doing things with the resources that we already have,

[Kit Collins]: but also applying for state and federal grants that would help us do the transformative road design and pedestrian and bicycle safety projects that we already know that we need.

[Kit Collins]: I will also mention funding a therapeutic recreation and inclusion specialist and an office manager for metric recreation.

[Kit Collins]: We heard a lot from the families of youth with disabilities about where these two positions would fit into the puzzle when it comes to making

[Kit Collins]: Medford recreation and just not even recreation, but participation citywide, more accessible for people with and without disabilities.

[Kit Collins]: And I think it's incredibly important that this year we start putting things into the budget that will move us closer towards a fully accessible future for Medford.

[Kit Collins]: I also recommend that we increase the budgeted amount for our city solicitor salary so that we can, God willing, this year fill that position, which I know we are all very, very keen to see that filled.

[Kit Collins]: My estimate was that infusing $36,000 into that line item would bring this into competitiveness with our neighboring municipalities.

[Kit Collins]: I'm not sure if we've received yet the classification and compensation study that could give us further guidance on what that should be raised to.

[Kit Collins]: And lastly, I'll just mention similar to in previous years, I'd like to see us maintain all grant funded personnel in the health department, the Office of Outreach and Prevention, the Office of Planning, Development and Sustainability.

[Kit Collins]: aligned with what I said about Medford's Bicycle Advisory Committee's funding recommendations.

[Kit Collins]: I'd like to see us increase our capital spending earmark for expanding our network of separated protected bike lanes, completing the bike master plan, and doing design studies for Vision Zero and Complete Streets policies.

[Kit Collins]: And this one, I think, is small dollars compared to things like salaries.

[Kit Collins]: But I think we should also be putting more money into installing and maintaining road safety equipment interventions, everything from bike racks and flex posts to increased signage, as well as planning new crosswalks where we already know that we need them, such as on Salem Street.

[Kit Collins]: Pardon me, just finding my notes that I toggled away from.

[Kit Collins]: I also wanted to co-sign recommendations that I've heard so far from a couple other councillors that I haven't mentioned.

[Kit Collins]: I'm really glad that Councilor Lazzaro brought up the dive team training for the Medford Fire Department.

[Kit Collins]: It seems to me that a lot of recommendations from many councillors have all been circling around safety improvements that will have such a vast qualitative impact.

[Kit Collins]: Improvement for the people of Medford.

[Kit Collins]: I think that we should really be focusing this year on things that will make life safer for the people of Medford so I think that talking about accessibility improvements talking about pedestrian cyclist and driver safety improvements talking about trainings that we can fund for our First responders that they can do a better job and do the do the job that they want to be doing making life ever safer for Medford residents is where we should be focusing in this budget cycle and

[Kit Collins]: I'd also like to just quickly co-sign the idea from Councilor Leming, funds to help us jumpstart our affordable housing linkage and update our linkage fees program.

[Kit Collins]: These are funds where if we invest them now, we can see a return on investment from, we can make it so developers in our community are paying into these funds that we already know that we need and that will manifest in better funding for infrastructure and better funding for affordable housing.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: I was also trying to keep a list of suggestions that were made by multiple Councilors.

[Kit Collins]: I'll quickly run through mine, and if yourself or other Councilors hear ones that are missing, I'd welcome to hear that.

[Kit Collins]: The notes I was taking, it sounds like from many of us, there was a shared priority around the citywide therapeutic inclusion recreation specialist, the office manager for Medford Recreation,

[Kit Collins]: Prioritizing the suggestions of the Medford Bicycle Advisory Commission as it pertains to both city staff and increasing infrastructure and signage.

[Kit Collins]: One of those, of course, being a rather larger spend than the other.

[Kit Collins]: The request from the fire department on training for a fire department dive team.

[Kit Collins]: increasing the salary line item for a city solicitor, meeting the Medford Public Schools and Medford Public Library budgetary requests, the nexus study for affordable housing linkage, and to update the linkage fees program.

[Kit Collins]: and maintaining our grant-funded positions, notably the Community Liaisons Project, as well as other grant-funded positions in Outreach and Prevention, Planning, Development, Sustainability, and the Health Department.

[Kit Collins]: I'm sure that I missed a few, and I'd welcome additions to that list.

[Kit Collins]: I think this is a great list, I think it's an ambitious list, and I think that these are all things and more that we absolutely should be funding this year as soon as possible because these would provide such an incredible return on investment for Medford residents.

[Kit Collins]: beyond the realm of what is quantifiable because of course we're talking about important educational experiences for kids in Medford, we're talking about important recreational experiences for all people in Medford, we're talking about safety improvements for all people in Medford, and we're talking about the city being better resourced to provide the type of services that Medford residents deserve and also expect from our city.

[Kit Collins]: So this would be my short list for recommendations to come out of this meeting that we could push forward in additional meetings.

[Kit Collins]: But of course I'd welcome discussion, modifications and additions to this list from my fellow Councilors.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Yes, I don't want to, I'd be happy to make the motion, but only if there's no other discussion or ideas from the fellow councilors.

[Kit Collins]: I think that process sounds good.

[Kit Collins]: It closely mirrors what we did last year.

[Kit Collins]: I feel comfortable with this shortlist going forward.

[Kit Collins]: I think it represents a lot of the ideas that we've all talked about.

[Kit Collins]: And it'd be good to have this kind of top six compiled for our next meeting and sendable to the mayor.

[Kit Collins]: I would request that the individual budget memos submitted by Councilors also be included in the packet.

[Kit Collins]: And I'm happy to make that in the form of a motion if there isn't any other discussion from Councilors.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bearson.

[Kit Collins]: Yeah, I think that's a really good question.

[Kit Collins]: A question that's, you know, always on our minds and probably on the minds of residents as well as we approach budget season.

[Kit Collins]: One of the reasons that advocated two years ago for increased

[Kit Collins]: powers of the council during budget time so that we could have a seat at the table for that kind of question exactly.

[Kit Collins]: We do not have the power to make those decisions when it comes to how that reallocation process happens in the budgetary process.

[Kit Collins]: and how to, we don't have a seat at the table when it comes to getting in the weeds and saying this is exactly how we square that circle.

[Kit Collins]: When we get to the end of the budget process and we're trying to do everything that Medford residents deserve with a finite pool of money.

[Kit Collins]: But at this stage, I do think it is valuable to put on the table and to emphasize everything that we know Medford residents deserve as prioritized as much as we are able to do.

[Kit Collins]: And then through the process, through our budgetary meetings with department heads, through our back and forth with the mayor to get that better understanding of what is possible, both financially and politically this year, and give us a clearer idea of if we are in a position of having to advocate for a small set of priorities, to be empowered to say, all right, given what's on the table,

[Kit Collins]: these are our non-negotiables and try to make sure as best as we can that those happen for the good of the community.

[Kit Collins]: So kind of a higher level question but just to reinforce that the city council doesn't, you know, I'm sure that we all would love the jurisdiction to get into the weeds and be able to talk reallocation and

[Kit Collins]: seeing exactly how these things play out in the line items.

[Kit Collins]: For myself, I think it's valuable to start on the principles and to start saying, we know that all these things are things that we want and things that we believe the community wants.

[Kit Collins]: And we know that we don't deserve anything.

[Kit Collins]: We know that residents don't deserve anything less than what they're already accustomed to.

[Kit Collins]: Let's start the conversation there.

[Kit Collins]: And then in the process of the budget,

[Kit Collins]: we're going to continue to have.

[Kit Collins]: Discussions in public meetings.

[Kit Collins]: Um let's see how let's see how close we can get to making that real in budget.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears, for bringing that up.

[Kit Collins]: I'm glad that you raised that.

[Kit Collins]: I wasn't thinking about that when I was putting together my memo, but I'd be happy to put that forward at this time.

[Kit Collins]: I think that we all want to be in a position where if we do take a vote and approve a residential exemption this year, we want to be able to implement it.

[Kit Collins]: And the interim assessor made it very clear that he would need increased capacity in his department.

[Kit Collins]: starting early in the fiscal year to be able to do that so that residents could see the effects of it.

[Kit Collins]: So I'd be happy to forward that at this time to also include that as a funded priority increased capacity for the assessor's department so that they'd be able to implement a residential exemption if one is approved.

[Kit Collins]: I also think that dovetails with some other notes that were raised by some of my fellow Councilors around capacity for the assessor's department.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: There will be a meeting of the Medford City Council Planning and Permitting Committee on Wednesday, March 12, 2025 at 6.20 p.m.

[Kit Collins]: in the City Council Chamber, second floor, Medford City Hall, 85 George P. Hassett Drive, Medford MA and via Zoom.

[Kit Collins]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Kit Collins]: present.

[Kit Collins]: Four present, one absent.

[Kit Collins]: The meeting is called to order.

[Kit Collins]: Apologize for the late start this evening.

[Kit Collins]: We had the swearing in for Fire Chief Evans in the chamber immediately before this meeting, and folks were busy doing the good work of mingling after that event wrapped up.

[Kit Collins]: We didn't want to rush them out.

[Kit Collins]: So the action and discussion item for tonight's meeting is, as it frequently is, paper 24-033, zoning ordinance updates with the Innes Associates team.

[Kit Collins]: This is our 21st meeting on the zoning update project.

[Kit Collins]: We have with us Paola from Innes Associates, in addition to city planning staff,

[Kit Collins]: We have a couple topics for tonight.

[Kit Collins]: As folks who have been engaged in this process might be aware, we recently wrapped up the Green Score Zoning Proposal and the Salem Street Corridor District Zoning Proposal.

[Kit Collins]: Those have been ordained as of last night.

[Kit Collins]: The neighborhood and urban residential zoning proposal was workshopped in this committee over the course of four meetings in January and February, and we are working to find a date for a public Q&A for that topic, after which it will be sent to the Community Development Board to begin the public hearing process.

[Kit Collins]: Tonight we're going to cover two topics.

[Kit Collins]: We're going to start with a really high level introduction to a commercial framework for all of the city.

[Kit Collins]: Paola is going to walk us through a really bird's eye view of a way of looking at the commercial districts of our city, squares and corridors, major hubs.

[Kit Collins]: We are not going to be voting on anything tonight.

[Kit Collins]: This is intended as an introduction to this topic and an opportunity for councillors

[Kit Collins]: city staff and members of the public to state their initial questions, initial preferences, initial concerns for what they'd like to see in which areas, in which quarters, on which squares, what they'd like to see, what not they'd like to see, what questions they have.

[Kit Collins]: then City Council leadership, City staff, and NS Associates will take all of that feedback and work together to combine it into the next iteration of a commercial frameworks proposal for our next meeting on this topic.

[Kit Collins]: So we're going to go through that introduction with Paola, and then after that, Paola will give us updates to the ADU zoning ordinance to incorporate the new state law on ADUs, and we'll have a further discussion of other ADU zoning proposals.

[Kit Collins]: So with that, unless there are any initial comments by councillors, and seeing none, I will pass it over to Paula from Ines Associates.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much for the overview, Paola.

[Kit Collins]: Really helpful.

[Kit Collins]: So like we stated at the beginning, this is intended as kind of a bird's eye view introduction to this topic.

[Kit Collins]: So I think the best use of our time in this meeting is kind of our first impressions, preferences, questions, and comments that Councilors are coming into this discussion with.

[Kit Collins]: I know I've gotten some questions and preferences from community members already saying,

[Kit Collins]: Why not this there?

[Kit Collins]: Why not this there?

[Kit Collins]: So we'll save public comment for the end of this topic.

[Kit Collins]: But I first want to recognize Councilors who have some thoughts on this kind of initial jumping off point.

[Kit Collins]: And I'll go first to President Bears on Zoom.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Next, I'll recognize Councilor Callahan and then Councilor Lazzaro on Zoom.

[Kit Collins]: Actually, that was a motion or a request that I made during the UR slash NR discussion.

[Kit Collins]: I offer that if that's helpful.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Councilor Callahan.

[Kit Collins]: We'll go next to Councilor Latero.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Councilor Lazzaro.

[Kit Collins]: In my comments, I'll be brief.

[Kit Collins]: I know I received a couple of comments from community members earlier this week, requesting specifically more density in Medford Square and West Medford Square, and I hear that reflected in the comments from some of my fellow councilors.

[Kit Collins]: Of course, we know that what exactly that means, what sub-district that means, how we're going to tailor it to specific squares and specific corridors will depend on where it's going and will depend on the research that Paula's already said she's going to do of lot size and what is feasible, kind of scaling down what we decide we want, the consensus we come to, to what is actually feasible on the lots in these specific locations.

[Kit Collins]: the city.

[Kit Collins]: Um but I do think in keeping with the goals, I think that here we have to in every part of the city that we look at that we rezone.

[Kit Collins]: We have to be focused on the goals of, um.

[Kit Collins]: Allowing for the type of development and density that we want to need in these specific places, and we also have to be keeping an eye on parity between all of the

[Kit Collins]: zoned much differently, given a different treatment than another, and that each area is able to enjoy the same potential for commercial and residential development and not left out of that potential.

[Kit Collins]: I also wanted to note, and also I see that the section on the

[Kit Collins]: The section to the west of 93, north of the river, that's currently penciled in as mixed-use 3, I just wanted to note, I think it's really interesting to be able to consider using mixed-use 3 zones along 93 where it's appropriate, and I think that there's a potential benefit there.

[Kit Collins]: where taller buildings could serve as sound insulation and kind of aesthetic insulation from the highway, from people who are living or just doing business or being around in those abutting areas.

[Kit Collins]: So I'm really eager for us to look at using those lots along the highway to concentrate more development, taller development,

[Kit Collins]: city.

[Kit Collins]: When we go when we go tall, near the highway to block it out.

[Kit Collins]: It's also the point was made to me recently, I forget by who, that when you are developing at those level of heights, that's when the economics really makes sense for the kind of air filtration and soundproofing that can make quality of life inside those buildings better.

[Kit Collins]: Lastly, I just wanted to note I forgot to mention this at the beginning of the meeting, but the map that Councilors and community members are looking at tonight.

[Kit Collins]: A lot of this is the proposal.

[Kit Collins]: Some of this reflects proposals that have already been made in the case of some of the neighborhood residential and urban residential.

[Kit Collins]: Parts on this map, that's part of the proposal that's going to the CD board next.

[Kit Collins]: And as I think we're probably all aware, the Mystic Avenue corridor and the Salem Street corridor reflects zoning that was done earlier in the citywide process.

[Kit Collins]: So I just wanted to make that clear for folks.

[Kit Collins]: A lot of this is just our jumping off point that we will further workshop and change and tweak and become part of the proposal.

[Kit Collins]: And some of it along Salem Street and Mystic Avenue in particular reflects rezoning that we've already done earlier in the year.

[Kit Collins]: I'll go back to President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Looking for fellow comments from Councilors.

[Kit Collins]: This is a great jumping off point.

[Kit Collins]: I think that this gives us kind of enough to get out of the starting blocks on tweaking this initial proposal.

[Kit Collins]: And I believe

[Kit Collins]: double check with Paula but I believe that our next meeting in two weeks we can probably expect to see a revised version of this map, including just some formatting changes to make it clear to Councilors and residents, which parts of the map have already been updated which have not.

[Kit Collins]: And we might see some changes as well, perhaps in sub districts.

[Kit Collins]: Along the lines of President Bears his comment or begin to see tweaks to the map.

[Kit Collins]: Based on Councilors and community members feedback for what they'd really like to see prioritized in each of these squares and corridors.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: uses in the city, we want to increase them where they make sense.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you all so much for your comments.

[Kit Collins]: Paola, I'll turn it back over to you and we can begin our discussion of the updates to the ADU ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Paola.

[Kit Collins]: So just to repeat that back in simplified layman's terms, for those less familiar with this topic, the new state law places several new mandatory regulations on cities.

[Kit Collins]: around essentially that we are not allowed to prohibit ADUs in these new sets of circumstances.

[Kit Collins]: And so we are updating our ADU ordinance to be in compliance with the new state law.

[Kit Collins]: Beyond that, there are several options that we can take for ways we might want to tailor.

[Kit Collins]: construction the use of ADUs further based on our specific zoning.

[Kit Collins]: So it strikes me that the work before us is to essentially approve the amendments to our existing ADU ordinance, incorporating the mandatory updates from the state, and then to make those decisions on ways that we might want to further handle the treatment of ADUs based on the decisions that the state is leaving up to municipalities.

[Kit Collins]: I'm sorry.

[Kit Collins]: I don't know if that's correct.

[Kit Collins]: Um do I have a correct that a lot of the updates that were suggested in the new draft 80 ordinance from Councilor Leming.

[Kit Collins]: It sounds like many of those have been covered by the new state regulations.

[Kit Collins]: Is that correct?

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Sorry, Councilor Leming.

[Kit Collins]: great.

[Kit Collins]: And I do think that gets to one of the questions before us.

[Kit Collins]: Um, but we're not bound by state law.

[Kit Collins]: One of the things that is up to the city of Medford.

[Kit Collins]: Um, should we allow 80 years in any residential district, not just the districts where a single family housing is allowed by right?

[Kit Collins]: Um, so we hear recommendation from Councilor Leming, um, to paraphrase you that we should Go next to a couple of our non voting members on zoom Councilor Lazzaro, and then we'll go to Councilor Tseng

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Council Liz Howard.

[Kit Collins]: So to paraphrase, and please let me know if I captured your concern correctly, I think I'm hearing a question about if allowing ADUs beyond what the state mandates, if we're making those by right, sorry, if we're making those by special permit as opposed to by right, if that is gonna be prohibitive to people actually following through on those projects.

[Kit Collins]: Planner Evans or Director Hunt, can you speak to a recommendation on that?

[Kit Collins]: I think there's maybe two questions here, because the ADUs in districts where single families are allowed by right, the ADUs are allowed by right.

[Kit Collins]: I think the two questions before us are,

[Kit Collins]: If we decide to allow ADUs in other residential districts where there were single families not allowed by right, do we want to allow ADUs there?

[Kit Collins]: And if so, should it be special permitted or by right?

[Kit Collins]: And then in addition to that, if we're allowing a second ADU, are those by right or those have to be by special permit?

[Kit Collins]: Sorry, we should probably be both speaking into the microphone.

[Kit Collins]: If I can zoom us... Oh, sorry.

[Kit Collins]: I'll go to you in just a second, Councilor Tseng.

[Kit Collins]: That's really helpful, and I do think, especially for people who are new to this topic, it can be a little bit confusing.

[Kit Collins]: I think that there's kind of a flowchart of options before us.

[Kit Collins]: There's the bulk of this, we don't have an option on because it's state law.

[Kit Collins]: In any sub-district that allows single-family homes by right, we must allow ADUs by right for all types of housing within that sub-district, not just the single-family homes.

[Kit Collins]: I think we kind of have a short flow chart of decisions before us that are under our jurisdiction as a city.

[Kit Collins]: Should we allow ADUs in any residential subdistrict, not just the ones that allow single family homes by right?

[Kit Collins]: If so, should they be by right or special permitted and should be tried to tailor by on what lots, they may occur either by right or by special permit and I do agree with the comments from our PDF staff that there are some types of structures, especially in you are one and you are two or just wouldn't make any sense.

[Kit Collins]: to have an ADU on one of our denser housing, on one of our most dense housing types.

[Kit Collins]: I think the next major decision bucket is should we allow a second ADU on lots that already have one, by special permit, and if yes, in what districts?

[Kit Collins]: There's another question.

[Kit Collins]: Who should be the special permit grant authority for ADUs that are specially permitted?

[Kit Collins]: It seems like the clear recommendation there is it should be the CDB.

[Kit Collins]: I would agree.

[Kit Collins]: Do we want to allow ADUs that are bigger than 900 square feet or more than half of the floor area of the principal area?

[Kit Collins]: And if yes, by right or by special permit?

[Kit Collins]: And then finally, we haven't even touched on this yet.

[Kit Collins]: Do we want to consider a short-term rental option for ADUs and what would the recommendations for regulations be there?

[Kit Collins]: So far, our conversation has been mostly around those first three questions, but I did just want to orient us in the questions before us so that when we leave this meeting and as associates kind of has a better

[Kit Collins]: all of the feedback that they might need to start drafting the updates to the ordinance for us based on the stuff that is under our jurisdiction.

[Kit Collins]: So eager to hear more comments from councilors on kind of the three main questions.

[Kit Collins]: In my mind, should we be allowing ADUs in any residential sub-district, not just the ones that allow single families by right?

[Kit Collins]: Should we be allowing a second ADU and special permit and in what districts under what conditions?

[Kit Collins]: Go next to Councilor Tseng and then President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Councilor Sheng.

[Kit Collins]: Go next to President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Go back to Councilor Tseng.

[Kit Collins]: Oh, sorry, we couldn't hear your last comment, Councilor Tseng.

[Kit Collins]: Go next to Councilor Leming.

[Kit Collins]: And if I'm

[Kit Collins]: that.

[Kit Collins]: If I may.

[Kit Collins]: I do want to note and sorry.

[Kit Collins]: Okay.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for the discussion on that.

[Kit Collins]: I do want to note.

[Kit Collins]: I think all Councilors are certainly aware of this.

[Kit Collins]: Um.

[Kit Collins]: The current Medford short term rental ordinance gets

[Kit Collins]: most closely on this ordinance, that the issue really has been enforcement.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that that is our first major obstacle to clear, which is, I think we're all aware of the enforcement issues across many departments of the city.

[Kit Collins]: Outside of the scope of zoning, I think that the first question is, what is the, kind of, what utility would we want to get out of allowing

[Kit Collins]: creating special regulations for short-term rental of Airbnbs, sorry, short-term rentals at all, maybe guided by the context of our enforcement problems so far.

[Kit Collins]: Personally, as one Councilor,

[Kit Collins]: I am not interested in kind of tailoring our updated ADU ordinance to short-term rentals at all.

[Kit Collins]: One of the reasons why I'm excited about this ordinance is because studies of housing in Medford have shown that

[Kit Collins]: You know, we have a housing shortage, but we also have a shortage of very specific types of housing, in particular, including small apartments for people who live alone, students, people who are downsizing.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that's one really important thing to come out of allowing more

[Kit Collins]: ADUs, I would be, I'm kind of, I'm feeling very protective of if we are able to pass regulations that allow more ADUs to flourish where they're appropriate in our community.

[Kit Collins]: I would really want those to be protected as a mechanism for adding more of those small types of housing to the community because we know

[Kit Collins]: And I think this is in the housing production plan, that a particular shortage of housing type is people who would really like to live alone and they don't need a lot of space, but they have to live with roommates or with family when they prefer not to, because there just aren't studios and one bedrooms available.

[Kit Collins]: That would be my preference, is to not consider regulations for a short-term rental for ADUs at this time.

[Kit Collins]: Seeing no hands raised from councillors at this time, I'll just throw my two cents in.

[Kit Collins]: I want to make sure that we leave this meeting with at least kind of a draft of the consensus for where to go on these main questions for Innes Associates that we can hopefully look at draft amended language in a meeting or two.

[Kit Collins]: For myself, I would like to see ADUs allowed in all of our residential districts, not just ones where single families are allowed by right.

[Kit Collins]: I think especially since we have this kind of like staircase mechanism with our residential districts, a lot of housing types carry over from one to the next.

[Kit Collins]: So to me, it would be arbitrary to say, well,

[Kit Collins]: this historic conversion, or this two-unit dwelling unit can have an ADU because it's in this subdistrict, but this other housing type, which is exactly the same, but it's in a different subdistrict, cannot have an ADU under the same conditions just because the subdistrict that it's in.

[Kit Collins]: So I'd like to see ADUs allowed in all residential subdistricts.

[Kit Collins]: But I agree with the idea thrown out by President Bears that I think when we get into UR1 and UR2, it makes sense to be looking at by right for detached, like kind of where detached is spatially possible.

[Kit Collins]: I think it makes sense for that to be by right.

[Kit Collins]: And then by right for attached or detached in any neighborhood residential district for anything other than a multiplex.

[Kit Collins]: Um...

[Kit Collins]: In terms of the question around, should we allow second ADUs by special permit?

[Kit Collins]: I think I agree.

[Kit Collins]: It's hard for me to picture.

[Kit Collins]: Obviously, I'm always happy to consider recommendations from city staff or our consultants, but it's hard for me to picture a lot where it kind of makes sense to have two detached ADUs on the same property.

[Kit Collins]: I think it could make sense to look at where would it make sense to allow a second ADU if detached, where there's already a detached one, or vice versa.

[Kit Collins]: I'm happy to defer to the planner's recommendations on if we should allow ADUs bigger than 900 square feet.

[Kit Collins]: 900 square feet is quite small, so I don't think that that square footage needs to be set in stone.

[Kit Collins]: I'm happy to consider something a little bit larger.

[Kit Collins]: And I think it makes sense for us to receive a recommendation from the zoning consultant along those lines, factoring that in, whether it's certain types of ADUs being allowed on certain housing types,

[Kit Collins]: by special permit, depending on the district, along with the recommendations that were made by councilors earlier in the meeting.

[Kit Collins]: So more allowance of ADUs across residential areas, but tailoring to make sure that it's appropriate and makes sense with housing stock, especially when you get into those denser housing types.

[Kit Collins]: We discussed allowing a second ADU by in residential districts, which residential districts and should it be by special permit.

[Kit Collins]: It sounds like there's an interest in seeing a special permit option and also seeing a little bit of tailoring, depending on that we're not seeing.

[Kit Collins]: two detached ADUs on one yard.

[Kit Collins]: I think all of these should reflect that the CDB should be the special permit granting authority where there is a special permit involved.

[Kit Collins]: I think we're looking for a little bit of flexibility when it comes to that maximum square footage.

[Kit Collins]: You could hear a recommendation there.

[Kit Collins]: Just want to thank you so much for being here tonight, to you and the rest of the commission.

[Kit Collins]: Really appreciate the work that you do year round and I, you know, I want to echo the point that you made earlier in your presentation that it is

[Kit Collins]: unfortunate and outrageous that a lot of the time action on bike safety, road safety issues in general is motivated by preventable tragedies occurring in the community.

[Kit Collins]: So I'm sorry that you have to do the work that you do, but thank you for helping us rise to the occasion and make things safer for cyclists and pedestrians and drivers and everybody going forward.

[Kit Collins]: I'm so glad that this discussion is happening.

[Kit Collins]: I'm a cyclist myself, but I think we're all, whether you own a bike or not, we're all aligned for

[Kit Collins]: doing what we can concretely to make the road safer for everybody and as I think people know if you look at the side of the road or right in front of you when you're driving around or on the bus in Medford cyclists in Medford in our in our surrounding communities they look like everybody, their commuters, their kids going to school, their elders.

[Kit Collins]: it's incredibly important that we do whatever infrastructural work and whatever funding is necessary to bring about these changes that are documented to keep people safer.

[Kit Collins]: So I will support any budgetary proposal that we submit to the mayor this spring for FY26 to move the needle on these things that will make cycling safer in Medford.

[Kit Collins]: I want to echo your gratitude

[Kit Collins]: to Director Blake for the hard work that him and his team have been doing to expand our network of bike lanes in the city.

[Kit Collins]: Bike lanes alone are not enough.

[Kit Collins]: It is also incredibly important.

[Kit Collins]: I know the commission has been working hard on this.

[Kit Collins]: It's incredibly important to know that, to work so that drivers know how to behave around cyclists and around bike lanes.

[Kit Collins]: And we have a lot of work to do in the community.

[Kit Collins]: so that people know the rules of the road and they respect them for their own safety and for other people's safety.

[Kit Collins]: So I look forward to continuing these conversations so that we can put money where it needs to be so that people are safer on the roads.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much.
