[Kit Collins]: Councilor Leming, how did you find them?

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: On the motion to approve by Councilor Leming, seconded by Councilor Callahan, all in favor?

[Kit Collins]: All opposed?

[Kit Collins]: Motion passes.

[Kit Collins]: 25-023 offered by Councilor Scarpelli, Education and Culture Committee report, February 25th.

[Kit Collins]: Who is the vice chair for this committee?

[Kit Collins]: May I recognize you to give a brief summary of this meeting?

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Councilor Callahan on the motion by Councilor Callahan to approve seconded by Councilor Tseng all in favor.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you President Bears this was our final of four meetings in the planning and permitting committee on the neighborhood and urban residential topic which proposes an updated and modernized framework for residential neighborhoods of the city.

[Kit Collins]: Like I mentioned, it was preceded by three other topics during which we workshop this proposal.

[Kit Collins]: And at the February 26 meeting we referred it out to the city council for its immediate procedural referral to the Community Development Board for further

[Kit Collins]: public meetings, public feedback and promulgation of recommendations motion to approve on the motion to approve of Vice President Collins seconded by seconded by Councilor Callahan.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much, President Bears, for the overview.

[Kit Collins]: I know a lot of people are here tonight for this topic.

[Kit Collins]: I'm really excited that we've made it to this point.

[Kit Collins]: I'm excited that so many people are here engaging with the comprehensive zoning overhaul.

[Kit Collins]: Before we get into discussion, I'm sure there will be a lot of discussion.

[Kit Collins]: I want to give a brief overview of the proposal before us, how we got to this point, the meetings that we had, what the proposal says.

[Kit Collins]: I'm then going to ask President Bears to recognize Emily Innis from Innes Associates to walk us through on a more

[Kit Collins]: the planning and permitting committee meetings.

[Kit Collins]: Detail technically technical level and overview of the proposal before us tonight now that it's come back from the CD board, and then I am eager to hear discussion from my fellow Councilors and from the community.

[Kit Collins]: So I'll start with a quick outline of the public meetings on this topic that got us to today.

[Kit Collins]: This proposal was developed as all of the other zoning proposals were in this process.

[Kit Collins]: Um in the planning and permitting

[Kit Collins]: The CDB began its public hearing on this topic on January 22nd.

[Kit Collins]: That is a step that we always take with any zoning proposal or any zoning change or amendment.

[Kit Collins]: It always goes from the city council to the CDB board for their public hearings before it comes back to the city council and that's what that last step is what's happening tonight.

[Kit Collins]: but the CDB began its public hearing on January 22nd.

[Kit Collins]: There was a lot of community feedback.

[Kit Collins]: A lot of people in this room know.

[Kit Collins]: So the public hearing was continued to March 5th to allow more time for the board to consider and deliberate and to allow for more opportunities for public comment.

[Kit Collins]: In the interim, we added a new step to our review timeline, which is a public Q&A.

[Kit Collins]: We had that on February 10th.

[Kit Collins]: This wasn't something that we did for our phase one zoning updates.

[Kit Collins]: It wasn't something that we did for the Mystic Avenue corridor district proposal, which passed in December.

[Kit Collins]: But with Salem Street, we heard really loud, really clear that people wanted more information.

[Kit Collins]: They wanted more opportunities to ask questions.

[Kit Collins]: They wanted more opportunities to give public comment.

[Kit Collins]: So I want to thank city staff and Innes Associates for their flexibility and making sure that we got a local in-person Q&A on the calendar, which I understand a lot of residents attended, and I'm so glad that they did.

[Kit Collins]: On March 5th, the CDB had the continuation of its public hearing on the Salem Street Corridor District.

[Kit Collins]: They reviewed updated recommendations from the zoning consultant that were put forward after all of the public feedback that was heard on February 10th, and they heard additional public comment on that night.

[Kit Collins]: So that brings us to today.

[Kit Collins]: And in addition to this public meetings, these public meetings, they also want to note, I know for I as one Councilor, I've been receiving a lot of public feedback throughout the process of the zoning, through emails, through phone calls, through texts.

[Kit Collins]: I'm sure that all of my colleagues have too.

[Kit Collins]: And I want to again, thank everybody for engaging with us on this topic.

[Kit Collins]: And I hope that you'll continue to do so as we approach other topics through the spring.

[Kit Collins]: Another important part of this process, I think, are the new resources that we added during the Salem Street phase of the zoning overhaul.

[Kit Collins]: While Salem Street was working its way through the committee to CBB back to City Council process, city staff have worked alongside myself and President Bears to overhaul the communications and online resources that we publish about zoning.

[Kit Collins]: creating new ones and making sure that we're using all of the communication channels that the city has.

[Kit Collins]: We spent many hours on a total redesign of the zoning website so that it's easier for residents to learn about proposals, upcoming meeting dates, look at visuals and graphics, and separate fact from fiction.

[Kit Collins]: I say it a lot, I know that zoning is really detailed, it's really technical, it's often confusing, and not just for residents, for city staff and Councilors alike, but I also know that Medford residents don't scare off that easy, and I'm really glad that the community has encouraged us to overhaul the information that we have online so that it's easier for residents to be informed and involved, and we're continuing to work with the mayor's office to keep making that better and better.

[Kit Collins]: So onto this specific proposal.

[Kit Collins]: I will give a high level like I said I'll give a high level overview of what's before us before Emily will walk us through more of the details.

[Kit Collins]: The Salem Street corridor district proposal is one part of our comprehensive and citywide zoning overhaul.

[Kit Collins]: This began in the spring of 2024.

[Kit Collins]: Green Score and the Salem Street Corridor District are the third and fourth major packages to come out of this process.

[Kit Collins]: They were predated by the phase one technical updates and the Mystic Ave Corridor District proposal.

[Kit Collins]: Overall, the goal of this process is to take the goals and the visions of the Housing Production Plan, the Comprehensive Plan, and the Climate Action and Adaptation Plan and help make them real in our community.

[Kit Collins]: These plans were not written by the city council.

[Kit Collins]: They didn't come out of this room.

[Kit Collins]: These plans were the product of years of community feedback, community meetings, and community feedback.

[Kit Collins]: They speak to our shared goals for the future that we all love.

[Kit Collins]: A future of the city where there are homes for young adults who can afford to settle.

[Kit Collins]: Apartments where students and workers can live comfortably and where our elders can downsize.

[Kit Collins]: Neighborhood squares that are lively and full of businesses and people running errands and meeting friends close to where they live and where we are more climate resilient than we are today.

[Kit Collins]: So what do these goals look like for Salem Street specifically?

[Kit Collins]: How does this end up in the proposal that we're talking about tonight?

[Kit Collins]: This proposal allows for moderately increased residential housing on Salem Street from the 93 Rotary up through Haines Square.

[Kit Collins]: We can do that by regulating density, height, and lot size principally.

[Kit Collins]: By-right densities are moderately changing.

[Kit Collins]: By-right heights are also moderately changing, but they are not always increasing.

[Kit Collins]: Right now, maximum by-right heights for most of the corridor is three stories.

[Kit Collins]: Under this proposal, that's staying much the same everywhere except for in mixed-use two sub-districts.

[Kit Collins]: In mixed-use two sub-districts, it's proposed to go up by one story, so you can build to four stories as your buy-right maximum.

[Kit Collins]: In Haines Square, this proposal would actually lower maximum heights.

[Kit Collins]: Right now, if you wanted to, which I don't think a lot of residents would want to, you could be building a six-story apartment building or a 15-story hotel.

[Kit Collins]: This proposal will bring that down to scale.

[Kit Collins]: I next want to quickly touch on commercial.

[Kit Collins]: Salem Street, we all know, is characterized by many beloved small businesses from convenience stores to karate dojos to bike shops, and all of them are nonconforming under our current zoning.

[Kit Collins]: This proposal allows for ground level commercial buy right to encourage small business development and make it easier to see more of these things and these types of businesses that we already love.

[Kit Collins]: I'll quickly touch on incentive zoning.

[Kit Collins]: Through incentive zoning under this proposal, it is possible to build above the three-story maximum and the four-story maximum by right.

[Kit Collins]: Developers could build up to four stories in mixed-use one sub-districts and up to six stories in mixed-use two and commercial sub-districts if they maximally satisfy a certain community benefit conditions.

[Kit Collins]: Incentive zoning increases are not allowed in multi-unit residential sub-districts.

[Kit Collins]: those areas top out at three stories permanently.

[Kit Collins]: There's no opportunity for going above three there.

[Kit Collins]: I do want to stress that incentive zoning is not a blank check for developers.

[Kit Collins]: Any uses that are not by right uses will still go through site plan review and public permitting procedures that involve studies and negotiation of community benefits and impact mitigation agreements on a case-by-case basis.

[Kit Collins]: This proposal also includes development context standards, regulations for how upper floors must be built and shaped to ensure that new buildings don't feel out of place nor block light from existing residential homes.

[Kit Collins]: The committee, the consultant, and the CDB also paid special consideration to what kind of uses the community did and did not want on Salem Street.

[Kit Collins]: And Emily Ennis will speak more about that next, but I'll just quickly mention this zoning proposal does reflect changes to allowed uses based on a lot of community feedback that we heard throughout January and February.

[Kit Collins]: Under this proposal, the only medical uses in the district will be quote-unquote neighborhood medical, which is a new defined term.

[Kit Collins]: They are no more than 1,500 square feet and no more than five employees.

[Kit Collins]: Neighborhood medical will be allowed by special permit only in mixed use two and commercial sub-districts.

[Kit Collins]: Hotels, which are allowed under our current zoning, would be prohibited under this proposal throughout the entire corridor.

[Kit Collins]: And I want to quickly speak to what this proposal does not allow, because there's been a lot of talk about this proposal in this community, and not all of it is accurate.

[Kit Collins]: I want us to be armed with the facts.

[Kit Collins]: I know that there's been a lot of concern about what zoning in the city will allow for large dorms.

[Kit Collins]: This zoning proposal does not create conditions for large dorms on Salem Street.

[Kit Collins]: In fact, this proposal recommends no dorms at all, and no sub-district all along the corridor.

[Kit Collins]: Neither would it create the conditions for pot shops, all marijuana commercial uses, including retail are prohibited along this corridor boarding houses are allowed only by special permit, they are disallowed in multi unit residential sub districts.

[Kit Collins]: I know there's some concern about historic buildings.

[Kit Collins]: Buildings over 75 years old are protected by the city's demolition delay ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: Buildings can be further protected by the establishment of historic districts, whereby changes can be regulated by the Historic District Commission.

[Kit Collins]: This council this term has been supportive of those districting measures.

[Kit Collins]: and I'm sure would welcome further collaboration on historic preservation along Salem Street and along other corridors.

[Kit Collins]: Broadly speaking, and this applies not only to historic structures, but to structures in general, if any use or structure is rendered nonconforming because of zoning changes, they can continue.

[Kit Collins]: There are specific rules that govern nonconforming uses, but right now, Salem Street and much of the city

[Kit Collins]: is peppered with nonconforming buildings and lots, which may remain in perpetuity except as outlined under Mass General Law, Chapter 40A.

[Kit Collins]: Lastly, I'll quickly speak to a concern that I know a lot of people have around traffic, traffic impact along Salem Street.

[Kit Collins]: First, I will note there are no parking changes proposed in this proposal.

[Kit Collins]: I know that a lot of folks have been concerned about impact on existing uses and structures through traffic on Salem Street and eager to see the impact on traffic because of changes that might come about through zoning.

[Kit Collins]: When we talk about zoning,

[Kit Collins]: We're talking about changes that will occur over the long term.

[Kit Collins]: Some changes might occur relatively quickly within the next five years.

[Kit Collins]: Some changes might not become manifest for decades.

[Kit Collins]: That is why in the review process, it is more effective, more beneficial to the community to keep traffic and impact mitigation studies where they currently reside, which is at the point of permitting.

[Kit Collins]: A traffic study done today or done this year might be completely outdated, irrelevant, unhelpful to the community when a new proposal is proposed under the current zoning in five years, in 10 years, in 20 years.

[Kit Collins]: Those type of impact studies are located at the time of permitting so that the community has the best information it can use when it's doing those negotiation, impact study, and community benefit negotiations with developers.

[Kit Collins]: I've spoken a lot.

[Kit Collins]: I want to pass the mic.

[Kit Collins]: I'll ask President Bears to next recognize Emily Innis from Innes Associates, a familiar face to most of us.

[Kit Collins]: She is going to walk us through a more detailed, more technical overview of the recommendations to this proposal that have come out of the Community Development Board.

[Kit Collins]: I thank my fellow councilors for giving me this time to give an overview of this proposal, and I look forward to our discussion.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: And before I begin, I want to say thank you to every person who attended and spoke and shared your perspective with us.

[Kit Collins]: I know it takes a lot to spend your evenings this way, and it's really appreciated.

[Kit Collins]: Not everybody will feel represented by this, but in listening to public comment over the past few hours I noted that many speakers, even when they were here to explain why they were not in favor of this proposal, affirmed that they agree that zoning in principle is needed.

[Kit Collins]: We also heard a lot about concerns about problems that zoning may worsen, or that zoning will not help us to make progress on.

[Kit Collins]: I again want to quickly restate and affirm that changing zoning is not the same as flipping a switch.

[Kit Collins]: Some lots may be developed very quickly.

[Kit Collins]: Many will not.

[Kit Collins]: Many will take years.

[Kit Collins]: This is a long-term plan.

[Kit Collins]: As we deliberate, I urge my colleagues and my fellow community members to not mistake standing still for moving forward.

[Kit Collins]: And I want to make really clear that neglecting to rezone for the 21st century

[Kit Collins]: will not allow us to improve parking enforcement, slow traffic, get cars off the road, improve sidewalks, improve crosswalks, improve infrastructure capacity, prevent businesses from getting displaced due to escalating commercial rents, prevent people from getting displaced due to escalating residential rents, make it easier to buy homes in Medford, improve heat islands or pollution, or force the MBTA to speed up the bus network redesign rollout.

[Kit Collins]: Zoning alone

[Kit Collins]: will fix none of these things.

[Kit Collins]: zoning is one part of a multi-part strategy.

[Kit Collins]: It must fit in with, and it does fit in with, linkage fees, impact fees, increasing our school capacity, improving our water and sewer infrastructure, improving our roads, holding electricity utilities accountable, expanding our tree canopy, holding developers to higher environmental standards citywide, making it easier for businesses to find a home in Medford, traffic calming, road improvements, holding the DOT and the DCR accountable to making state roads safer,

[Kit Collins]: All of these projects are currently underway.

[Kit Collins]: They occur parallel to the zoning effort at the same time as we contemplate rezoning and stopping a decades overdue zoning project will not help any of these projects that are occurring in tandem.

[Kit Collins]: They're also towards goals that I believe we all share.

[Kit Collins]: It will much more likely help us.

[Kit Collins]: I know a lot of people have tonight talked about the revenue that we will enjoy because of uptoning through permitting fees and for new growth.

[Kit Collins]: That is not the reason that we zone, or at least it's not the reason that I come to the zoning effort.

[Kit Collins]: I think that that's true for most people.

[Kit Collins]: We don't zone because of the revenue.

[Kit Collins]: But it is true that the development will raise our commercial tax base and help us pay for the things that we know we need, many of the things that were mentioned tonight, from infrastructure improvements to paying our public workers better,

[Kit Collins]: and attracting great new workers to City Hall, to stump removal and planting trees and parking enforcement, and being able to fund more school buses.

[Kit Collins]: We need funding to do these things, and this will help.

[Kit Collins]: I also want to touch again on studies because those were talked about a lot tonight.

[Kit Collins]: Not to be repetitive, but site plan review process and special permit process is governed by state law.

[Kit Collins]: Direct debuttors are always notified.

[Kit Collins]: These projects appear on public agendas.

[Kit Collins]: They're reviewed in public meetings of the ZBA, the CDB, or the city council, depending on the project.

[Kit Collins]: Impact studies such as traffic impacts reviewed by police and fire safety inspections.

[Kit Collins]: These are done.

[Kit Collins]: It is current practice for developers to take on the cost of their studies, which are then reviewed by city staff, including our public safety officials, boards and commissions.

[Kit Collins]: They are done on a project by project basis because that is the point of decision for the city and the community.

[Kit Collins]: A traffic study done in 2024 would not be useful nation.

[Kit Collins]: useful information when in 2020, sorry, would not be useful information when, for example, in 2034, a developer might want to develop on Salem Street.

[Kit Collins]: It would not be useful information for when we are negotiating with that developer for what parking and traffic mitigation they are going to do then to address the traffic patterns, congestion level, and parking needs for that development at that point in time.

[Kit Collins]: And finally, regarding gentrification and displacement.

[Kit Collins]: The displacement that people are

[Kit Collins]: so afraid of and offended by and saddened by is already happening commercially and residentially.

[Kit Collins]: Refusing change is not a solution to gentrification.

[Kit Collins]: The solution to increasing housing stock, the solution is increasing housing stock.

[Kit Collins]: while expanding public housing, while growing our affordable housing trust portfolio, while considering a residential property tax exemption, while doing first-time homebuyer support, while pursuing rent stabilization, because otherwise there is no backstop in the world that will prevent out-of-town corporate landlords from cheating tenants like numbers on a spreadsheet.

[Kit Collins]: It would be wishful thinking to say that rezoning is a panacea for housing affordability.

[Kit Collins]: That is why nobody behind this rail has said that.

[Kit Collins]: This is one piece of the puzzle.

[Kit Collins]: It is not our only strategy for increasing affordable housing.

[Kit Collins]: And to all those who are upset that this proposal is not bullish enough on affordable housing, I would welcome your partnership with this council on any and all of those other strategies.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, and I look forward to the discussion with my fellow councilors.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Now for a zoning proposal that will undoubtedly garner the same level of excitement as the prior.

[Kit Collins]: The green score proposal is a rubric for grading and essentially rewarding developers based on various requirements incentives that they meet for meeting environmental standards in their building projects.

[Kit Collins]: It does this by incorporating the new green score rubric

[Kit Collins]: into our site plan review process, and it defines new development waivers.

[Kit Collins]: Green Score is not a grading rubric that applies to every development.

[Kit Collins]: It applies only to projects that are located in certain zones within the FEMA National Flood Hazard Layer and projects that are subject to site plan review.

[Kit Collins]: The green score zoning proposal includes and then builds upon Medford's existing environmental standards for developers.

[Kit Collins]: It goes upon these existing standards such as stormwater management and permeable surfaces or open space and permeable surfaces to include additional flexible new ways for developers to meet environmental standards that we already know we want developers to be meeting in Medford.

[Kit Collins]: from meeting these specific and defined environmental and climate resiliency criteria.

[Kit Collins]: Developers may receive, I'm going to say quote unquote rewards, such as development waivers or bonuses.

[Kit Collins]: These waivers or bonuses are very clearly defined.

[Kit Collins]: It's not just anything, it's things that we have decided are worth trading for these specific environmental

[Kit Collins]: achievements that developers would probably not find it economically feasible or enticing to do otherwise.

[Kit Collins]: This is our way of encouraging developers to be more climate friendly than they would be otherwise, within this defined structure of waivers and rewards that still fit our vision, vision, sorry, long night, for our community.

[Kit Collins]: The incentive structure is a menu of different landscape and infrastructural elements that provide options that can be tailored to different building and site conditions.

[Kit Collins]: So it's designed to be flexible to different developers' needs and what conditions are on different lots, so that there's something that every developer can take us up on.

[Kit Collins]: They might include, just for example, planted areas, different types of plantings.

[Kit Collins]: green or blue roofs, vegetated walls, permeable paving.

[Kit Collins]: And there's quite a long list if folks are interested.

[Kit Collins]: This is laid out in the meeting materials that are linked on our public portal.

[Kit Collins]: And for the environmental set, you'll probably find it quite interesting.

[Kit Collins]: Lastly, I just want to clarify, green score does not allow developers to exceed our existing height or story maximums.

[Kit Collins]: Um, any incentives or waivers earned through green score or incentive zoning are still constrained by our total height maximums.

[Kit Collins]: Um, and I also want to clarify because we get this question a lot that green score is a separate process from building energy efficiency standards.

[Kit Collins]: We have already adopted the state specialized energy code, and this is different from that.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Yeah, thank you for the question.

[Kit Collins]: I think that's a really thoughtful one.

[Kit Collins]: The planners may know they might have studies that accompanied their study of the municipalities where this has been rolled out before.

[Kit Collins]: I would have to follow up and ask them.

[Kit Collins]: I believe they dropped off the call a couple hours ago.

[Kit Collins]: We can try and get that information for you.

[Kit Collins]: What I will say is that, and again, I would want to fact check myself on this, I

[Kit Collins]: Green score is so multifactorial because essentially what it is, and I know you understand what it is we're saying, over here are a fairly long list of environmental or climate resiliency improvements that we would have developers do on a quite broad constraint, but still quite broad type of structures on a quite broad type of surfaces, not all commercial, not all residential.

[Kit Collins]: And over here, we have a series of

[Kit Collins]: you know, again, quote unquote, rewards or waivers or bonuses that they might get in return.

[Kit Collins]: Those are the reason that they're doing the increased environmental stuff over here.

[Kit Collins]: Because of the level of permutations just in that kind of framework alone, if there's a study on the economic impact overall, I'd be really curious to see it.

[Kit Collins]: I'm sure if there's one, our planners have consulted it.

[Kit Collins]: But I think this entire project for developers is an exercise in saying,

[Kit Collins]: What should we do over here that will make this a net positive for us economically over here because of what we will get in return?

[Kit Collins]: I feel like the example of this that we talk about most frequently is kind of pick any environmental criteria.

[Kit Collins]: Okay, we'll do a green roof.

[Kit Collins]: And in addition, you get to build one more story than you would otherwise.

[Kit Collins]: I'm not pulling that from the proposal.

[Kit Collins]: I'm just using kind of like round numbers such as it were.

[Kit Collins]: The developer in choosing

[Kit Collins]: which kind of environmental add-ons can they feasibly do, do they think is worthwhile, they're doing that calculation to say what can I do to meet green score at the minimum or optimal level to meet the minimum waiver structure to try to level up for increased benefits.

[Kit Collins]: I feel pretty confident that

[Kit Collins]: put this another way.

[Kit Collins]: Developers are interacting with the system in a way to increase their net gain in a way that also increases our net gain in terms of climate resiliency benefits that we wouldn't see otherwise.

[Kit Collins]: We can look into if there's plans that augmented in associate's study of the topic.

[Kit Collins]: But I don't have a clear answer for you because this could go in so many permutations of ways when it's implemented.

[Kit Collins]: Sorry, I don't have a clear answer for you.

[Kit Collins]: I would motion to adopt the CDB's recommendations and approve the zoning ordinance amendment.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Motion to suspend the rules to take 25-042 out of order.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Councilor Lazzaro beat me to the motion but I just want to say thank you so much Superintendent Cushing especially for hanging with us to present this paper so late in the evening.

[Kit Collins]: And, you know, all of these projects happening at the same time and the prioritization efforts speaks to how diligent the school's administration is about making sure that

[Kit Collins]: what needs to happen on what timeline is being paid attention to so closely by the school's administration to make sure that students will enjoy the upgraded buildings that they need on the timeline, that they need to not be impacted by a building problem.

[Kit Collins]: So just thank you so much for your work and excited to get to vote on this.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Paris.

[Kit Collins]: It's exciting to get to this phase in the process.

[Kit Collins]: Just want to begin by thanking the community for advocating for a new charter.

[Kit Collins]: This advocacy has been going on for a long time.

[Kit Collins]: It predates the specific chapter in the charter review process.

[Kit Collins]: Community members, many of whom are in the room tonight, and I'm sure watching on Zoom,

[Kit Collins]: Council.

[Kit Collins]: Um have been advocating for this before.

[Kit Collins]: There was a charter study committee assembled by the mayor.

[Kit Collins]: Um I'm excited that I get to vote.

[Kit Collins]: Yes on a new charter twice in my time as a city Councilor first a couple years ago, and hopefully again in a couple weeks.

[Kit Collins]: I want to thank the Charter Study Committee, especially Chairman Donald for all of your hard work.

[Kit Collins]: The count the Collins Center for consulting with the Charter

[Kit Collins]: Everybody tuning into this process knows this already, but I think it bears repeating the council's role in this process is not to draft or craft the draft charter, but to review it and to make targeted improvements and adjustments the Charter Study Committee

[Kit Collins]: We know they worked really hard, diligently gathering community input, interpreting that as best as they could, creating this long and technical draft.

[Kit Collins]: That's no mean feat.

[Kit Collins]: And now it is our responsibility, it being passed off to us at this part of the process, to have given it a thorough and earnest review.

[Kit Collins]: Our review is not a rubber stamp.

[Kit Collins]: but a responsibility that we know we all, none of us take lightly to make adjustments that in our perspective, given our access, given our information, given our perspective as Councilors, to make this draft as strong as it can possibly be for the long-term good of the people that our body governs, for the good of the community.

[Kit Collins]: I believe that this draft

[Kit Collins]: Excuse me.

[Kit Collins]: I believe that this draft charter really does constitute a very major step forward towards a better functioning and more modernized guiding structure for our city.

[Kit Collins]: I especially want to shout out the simple fact that this charter would require a review of the charter every 10 years, which is really important.

[Kit Collins]: I'm so glad that the draft charter would include a review of itself for going forward, because I think that this process has illustrated how much we need that to happen on a regular cadence.

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Tseng, I think, gave a really helpful overview of the two most substantive changes that the Council made in committee.

[Kit Collins]: I do believe that these will make our governance better and stronger for the people of Medford.

[Kit Collins]: I've said this before in our committee meetings, but I do believe that moving from an all-at-large

[Kit Collins]: Councilor system to four district Councilors, plus three at large.

[Kit Collins]: I think this is a positive change.

[Kit Collins]: This is substantially more localized representation than Medford has ever seen before in its city council.

[Kit Collins]: Guaranteeing representation from all four quadrants of the city.

[Kit Collins]: while balancing against potential negatives that I do believe could come from having one Councilor from eight small wards such as uncompetitive elections and parochialism.

[Kit Collins]: We have had a really substantive back and forth about this issue in particular in these chambers.

[Kit Collins]: I'll speak as one Councilor.

[Kit Collins]: It's given me a lot to think about.

[Kit Collins]: I think that

[Kit Collins]: I'm so grateful that the community challenged us to think really, really deeply about this issue of representation.

[Kit Collins]: I know that we do not have consensus on this council about what the best system of localized representation will be.

[Kit Collins]: And I'm so grateful that my belief is no matter how we go forward, Medford will enjoy more localized representation on the city council than it has before.

[Kit Collins]: And that is what the residents deserve.

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Tseng has also outlined additional technical edits, which I do think shore up this legal document and resolve unintended ambiguities.

[Kit Collins]: That's again, that's a really important part of our responsibility here on the city council.

[Kit Collins]: And thank you Chair Tseng for your diligence in making sure that we caught all the nitty gritty.

[Kit Collins]: So I am grateful to my colleagues and all members of this process for such earnest participation.

[Kit Collins]: I second the motion from Councilor Tseng and I look forward to hearing further comment from my fellow councilors.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate the discussion from my colleagues on this.

[Kit Collins]: Um,

[Kit Collins]: in this question of who we're talking about, not the only change we've made to the charter, but one of the changes that I think a lot of the community that's paying attention to this issue at all is most delighted to.

[Kit Collins]: And I hear it being brought up a lot, what we don't know, what we can't know, what we do know.

[Kit Collins]: And I think some of my fellow Councilors have made the point quite well that we cannot purport to know what the community

[Kit Collins]: as a monolith knows or feels.

[Kit Collins]: I don't believe that we know what the majority of the community thinks about this particular issue specifically.

[Kit Collins]: I'm really grateful for the outreach that was done.

[Kit Collins]: I think that's informed this process very meaningfully.

[Kit Collins]: I'm glad that we have data from the residents that were polled through the Charter Study Committee's process.

[Kit Collins]: But I don't think that what we can say is that we know how the community feels about this proposal.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think that anybody can say that.

[Kit Collins]: I can't say that my fellow councillors have said that they don't feel that they can make that statement.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think that anybody can.

[Kit Collins]: However, I think what's important for this city council, what feels important to me as a councillor is to focus on what we can know for certain

[Kit Collins]: which is that what residents want out of this process is a governance structure that works better than before and gets us closer to what we can know will be better for this community, which is more localized representation that seeks to balance what it seems like what we can extrapolate from the community feedback that we've gotten, which is that most people favor a mixed system, and to balance that with the research and the data statistics that we've gathered in good faith,

[Kit Collins]: from various sources, including the Collins Center, including also supplementary studies and research from sources that are renowned and should be respected in the field and certainly shouldn't be condescended in this conversation that are enriching this process.

[Kit Collins]: Our responsibility is not to take a vote that will make

[Kit Collins]: people closest to us happy with us.

[Kit Collins]: Our responsibility is to take the votes that we think are right and best for the community long term, even if it will cost us politically short or long term.

[Kit Collins]: The responsibility is to outcomes and not popularity.

[Kit Collins]: That is why I have come down in favor of four district Councilors and five at-large Councilors.

[Kit Collins]: And I just think not exclusive to this issue, but in general, when we start talking about knowing for certain what the community as a whole feels and believes, the community feedback that we know that we have, the input that we know that we've gotten should always be considered and treated with all of the gravity and meaningfulness that it deserves and

[Kit Collins]: I think it does a disservice to the outcomes when we let ourselves believe that what we have heard from the people who are most tuned in and most easy to access and most plugged in to feedback channels in the city, when we let ourselves believe that that is the whole picture, I think we do a disservice to the greater outcomes.

[Kit Collins]: And the overall point to me of reinvestigating representation in the city council

[Kit Collins]: is to focus the consequences of those outcomes of the people who are least engaged in these processes already, the people that we are least likely to have heard from in this process and in others, people who are least likely to be represented or that we're hearing from in any form.

[Kit Collins]: And that's why I think it's so important to

[Kit Collins]: way what we know some people feel, many people feel, and to not diminish that feedback whatsoever, to not diminish it as an ingredient in this process whatsoever, but to balance it with what else we know about the consequences of these various strategies.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: So I know everybody knows how I feel about City Council composition at this point.

[Kit Collins]: I've been pretty clear.

[Kit Collins]: I've been pretty clear for several meetings.

[Kit Collins]: I'm not really interested in repeating myself.

[Kit Collins]: I'm sure everybody else is even less interested in me repeating myself.

[Kit Collins]: But I did hear a Councilor say that nobody has articulated concerns with the three system and that is just not true.

[Kit Collins]: And I do want to correct the record on that point.

[Kit Collins]: I won't speak for other Councilors, I know other Councilors have brought up other concerns, some of which will overlap with mine as one Councilor.

[Kit Collins]: I have brought up concerns with having one ward Councilor for each of eight small wards.

[Kit Collins]: Something I said back in January when we first talked about city council composition, my research has indicated to me that in small ward systems like ours would be, the pool of candidates would be very small.

[Kit Collins]: I also went on to say, wards do not deserve simple representation full stop.

[Kit Collins]: Wards deserve compelling and competitive elections each and every time.

[Kit Collins]: That's what they deserve.

[Kit Collins]: This is still my main concern with an 8-3 system.

[Kit Collins]: And just to reiterate my other concern is parochialism, I think I've never been shy that one of my two main issues on the council is housing and housing production.

[Kit Collins]: that by having the bulk of the council being small work Councilors, there would be some very real potential harms for strategies that by necessity have to be citywide, in which the city council would have to work across district boundaries and get ahead of the tendency to be protective of one's own home base.

[Kit Collins]: We've talked about that before.

[Kit Collins]: I've raised these concerns before.

[Kit Collins]: I don't bring that up because I want to relitigate that before.

[Kit Collins]: I know that people disagree with me about those concerns, but it's not accurate to say that we are

[Kit Collins]: It's not accurate to say that I have one Councilor.

[Kit Collins]: I'm forwarding a strategy, having cited no concerns with another approach.

[Kit Collins]: That is just not true.

[Kit Collins]: I've never been shy about saying what my concerns with H3 are.

[Kit Collins]: I will accept that my fellow Councilors will disagree with me when they disagree.

[Kit Collins]: I can accept that community members will disagree with me when they disagree.

[Kit Collins]: I can fully accept that community members may not want to support me in the future if I do things that they disagree with.

[Kit Collins]: That is your right, and I accept that.

[Kit Collins]: And I would not want to go forward.

[Kit Collins]: I would not think that I would earn this seat if I was supporting an approach that I did not think was best for the community just because I think it would make me more popular.

[Kit Collins]: But what I do not accept is being prescribed a reasoning for my vote that is not my own, and I don't think it is productive to this conversation.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think it's fair to the residents for us to, I don't think it is in any way additive for us to have this conversation.

[Kit Collins]: And we can disagree, and that's great, and I think that's really important, and I'm glad we're disagreeing out in the open, but I don't think it adds anything for anybody for us to be putting words in each other's mouths about why the way we feel the way that we do.

[Kit Collins]: I do not want to cut off discussion if there are any other members of the public who would like to speak, but if there are not, I would move the question.

[Kit Collins]: All right, why don't we get started?

[Kit Collins]: There will be a meeting with the Medford City Council Planning and Permitting Committee, February 26th, 2025.

[Kit Collins]: This meeting will take place at 6 p.m.

[Kit Collins]: in the City Council Chamber, second floor, Medford City Hall, 85 George P. Hassett Drive, Medford MA, and via Zoom.

[Kit Collins]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Kit Collins]: Yes, he'll be here shortly.

[Kit Collins]: Oh, she is on Zoom.

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Leming, that was to you.

[Kit Collins]: I can't hear.

[Kit Collins]: Beginning to speak into the mic for the folks on Zoom.

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Scarpelli.

[Kit Collins]: Present.

[Kit Collins]: Four present, one running late.

[Kit Collins]: The meeting is called to order.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you all for joining tonight in person and on Zoom.

[Kit Collins]: The action and discussion item for this committee meeting is 24-033, Zoning Ordinance Updates with the Innes Associates team.

[Kit Collins]: This is our fourth meeting of this committee of the year, and it's also our fourth meeting on the neighborhood and urban residential

[Kit Collins]: topic.

[Kit Collins]: So I know that Innes Associates will be walking through kind of the progression of this topic that we've seen over the past couple months in their presentation just shortly.

[Kit Collins]: But in a nutshell, this is the part of our citywide... Sorry, I'm going to turn my volume up.

[Kit Collins]: Now that I hear the fans coming on, this is the has my volume better.

[Kit Collins]: Okay, thank you.

[Kit Collins]: This is the part of the city wide review of our community zoning in which we are looking at zoning and specifically residential districts.

[Kit Collins]: We're looking at everything from the lowest density districts in the city up to the highest density districts where we currently see the highest density for residential uses and also those areas where it makes sense to prioritize denser residential housing because of new T stations in the community.

[Kit Collins]: The goal of the neighborhood and urban residential zoning proposal is to look at the areas of the city that are already residential and craft a

[Kit Collins]: updated and thoughtful proposal that responds to what is already there, what the geography and topography and characteristics dictate for what can go into each section of the city, and to create a more thoughtful gradient of housing options from the lowest density residential up to the highest density

[Kit Collins]: residential.

[Kit Collins]: So we have been workshopping and iterating on this for the past, the three prior committee meetings.

[Kit Collins]: And I know that Paola in just a minute is going to run us through kind of how this proposal has evolved over those past three meetings.

[Kit Collins]: What is new tonight, in my understanding, which we talked about last or two weeks ago,

[Kit Collins]: is that now that we have revised the district map, that bird's eye view of what residential subdistrict could go where throughout the city, we're now going to take a closer look at dimensional standards.

[Kit Collins]: And we are also going to look at different options for how to protect non-conforming structures in the potential updated residential subdistricts.

[Kit Collins]: And then we're also going to talk a little bit about what comes after this phase of the project.

[Kit Collins]: So with that, I will check and see if there are any Councilors who have initial questions or comments up top.

[Kit Collins]: And then I will hand it over to Ines Associates for a presentation and we can take things from there.

[Kit Collins]: And as usual, we will take all public comment at the end of the meeting.

[Kit Collins]: So bear with us.

[Kit Collins]: All right, seeing none, happy to pass it over to Emily or Paola to walk us through our presentation.

[Kit Collins]: Yeah.

[Kit Collins]: Paola, thank you for that, for the introduction to how the proposal maps have changed over the past three meetings.

[Kit Collins]: And just to highlight two things that I don't want to get lost in the discussion, or things that I want to clarify, you're saying that the only change for the Proposal 4 map from Proposal 3, which we looked at two weeks ago, is that the UR1, Urban Residential 1 subdistrict,

[Kit Collins]: now extends closer to Ball Square.

[Kit Collins]: And the colors have changed.

[Kit Collins]: That was in response to feedback that the different shades of yellow were just really hard to parse, hard for people to tell what was different.

[Kit Collins]: So if people are seeing a new teal or green on the map, that's not a new sub-district.

[Kit Collins]: It's just a new, more contrasting color for the same sub-district as we were looking at before.

[Kit Collins]: Did I capture the part about Ball Square sub-district correctly?

[Kit Collins]: Yes, that's perfect.

[Kit Collins]: Great.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: And I also just want to I forgot to say this up top.

[Kit Collins]: Um, but it's my understanding that this also has not changed from the original version of the proposal that when we're talking about these residential sub districts, the maximum by right height for all residential sub districts is three stories.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I'm going to recognize

[Kit Collins]: Go ahead, Paola.

[Kit Collins]: are allowed by rightness.

[Kit Collins]: It's great to hear that.

[Kit Collins]: It sounds like we won't have to make many, if any, further tweaks to make sure that if, should the noose of districts be approved, and this goes into effect, that people who live in existing single family homes in districts where maybe single family homes, new ones will not be allowed by right,

[Kit Collins]: will not suffer, you know, a burdensome and onerous and inconvenient permitting process when they want to make the kind of improvements to their homes that anybody should be able to do.

[Kit Collins]: Great to hear.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Any additional questions on that point, President Bears or other councilors?

[Kit Collins]: All right.

[Kit Collins]: Seeing none.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: So we have before us the updated draft zoning proposal for the neighborhood and urban residential.

[Kit Collins]: We ran through the zoning map that the text describes, the updated zoning map, the dimensional requirements, had a discussion about how that affects ADUs, and we know that at our next meeting in two weeks, we're gonna dive in a little bit deeper on the ADU issue, kind of a citywide approach, not specific to this proposal.

[Kit Collins]: And we'll also hear a little bit more about development standards for multifamily buildings in that one highest density residential subdistrict, UR2.

[Kit Collins]: So we have that to look forward to.

[Kit Collins]: And I believe that next phase of our process will also dovetail with us starting to get a little bit deeper into a kind of shifting out of residential sub districts for the moment, talking more about a commercial framework.

[Kit Collins]: which will guide our discussions later in the spring about the more commercial areas of the city, some additional corridors, squares.

[Kit Collins]: I know a lot of people are eager for us to talk about Medford Square.

[Kit Collins]: We're working hard to make sure that that conversation dovetails with the other work, RFP, other consultant work that's been in the works around Medford Square.

[Kit Collins]: So we have a lot coming up on the pipeline as folks, so on the timeline earlier in the process.

[Kit Collins]: I'll recognize President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: I will run through that timeline one more time before we adjourn tonight.

[Kit Collins]: But before we kind of give that overview and move to public comment, I wanted to ask if there are any motions on the proposal before us, any additional questions or comments from councilors.

[Kit Collins]: As we all know, but just to reiterate it, this is kind of the long first or second step in the zoning amendment process, depending on how you want to look at it.

[Kit Collins]: This is our fourth meeting on this proposal.

[Kit Collins]: After a new zoning or zoning amendment is referred out of this committee, it is then referred by the City Council to the Community Development Board for public hearings, one or more, where there may be more public comment.

[Kit Collins]: We are working with the zoning consultant and city staff to make sure that we host another public Q&A session for this proposal before the CBP public hearing or hearings on it.

[Kit Collins]: like we did for the Salem Street corridor.

[Kit Collins]: After review by the CDB and it puts forward its recommendations, it will then come back to the city council for another public meeting where we will take a vote on it.

[Kit Collins]: And that's again, just to like to say it at least once every meeting is the process that all zoning has to go through.

[Kit Collins]: I know there's a lot of moving parts, but we really do hope that everybody participates in as many pieces of that process as they can and want to.

[Kit Collins]: I'm sorry, I didn't catch that.

[Kit Collins]: Absolutely.

[Kit Collins]: this zoning, our updated zoning, encourages and incentivizes affordable housing wherever possible and where that is not possible within the confines of what zoning can do.

[Kit Collins]: The City Council, in collaboration with many City Hall departments, is working very hard on other parts, on other affordable housing strategies, such as supporting our affordable housing trust fund, a brand new community land trust,

[Kit Collins]: and other, for example, we were able to put online affordable housing incentives for veteran renters this year.

[Kit Collins]: It takes a lot to deal with this very, very gargantuan regional issue of housing unaffordability.

[Kit Collins]: We're trying to do that in zoning where we can, where we can't.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Really appreciate the big picture, the granular information.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for all this.

[Kit Collins]: Just want to go back to one clarifying question that I had from your presentation.

[Kit Collins]: And sorry, I'm sure that you made this very clear.

[Kit Collins]: I'm just trying to keep track of the numbers you mentioned.

[Kit Collins]: For example, there's a certain thousand number of

[Kit Collins]: lines that are classified as copper, for example, and you said of that number of lines, there's a percentage that we know to be, that gave me the impression that even the lines that already have a classification, we're going back and double checking.

[Kit Collins]: Is that the case?

[Kit Collins]: OK, so it sounds like the trends are things that we think to be copper, broadly are copper.

[Kit Collins]: Things we think to be lead, broadly are lead.

[Kit Collins]: And then it sounded like, and correct me if I misheard you, that most of the unknowns are turning out not to be lead.

[Kit Collins]: OK, thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I just wanted to make sure.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: This is something that has come up in a lot of recent discussions in the community lately, including but not limited to city council meetings.

[Kit Collins]: Such a measure if communities like Medford were allowed to institute mandatory institutional master plans would give us

[Kit Collins]: the greater latitude and authority that I think we all know that we need and deserve over the very large institutions that take up a lot of real estate and take a lot of land and footprint within our communities.

[Kit Collins]: I think a lot of people can recognize by gut instinct that a community should be able to have some level of mandatory at least conversation and co-planning with institutions that have such a large footprint in their communities.

[Kit Collins]: Currently we are very disenfranchised and being able to enforce that.

[Kit Collins]: This legislation around institutional master plans which is something we're not currently enabled to do this home repetition would be asking for the permission to set up that.

[Kit Collins]: mandate that regulation would allow us to equalize the playing field with community partners such as Tufts University, other very large institutions, so that we can do a better job of collaborating or do the collaboration that we've been wanting to do all along on these issues that affect both the institutions and the communities like ours that host them.

[Kit Collins]: So I motion to approve.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I'm just so glad we're having this discussion.

[Kit Collins]: And I think a lot has already been said about the point that I was kind of the thread that I was going to pick up next, which is, you know, I feel like the parents and the advocates in this discussion have described very, very clearly what success looks like.

[Kit Collins]: And we are really far way away from that because what you're talking about is a fully accessible community.

[Kit Collins]: The fun stuff, the programming for youth, and the boring stuff and the stuff you have to do and the stuff that everybody has to do.

[Kit Collins]: You know, the events, the job pipeline, meetings like this, as well as the festivals.

[Kit Collins]: And we know how far we are from being able to

[Kit Collins]: We know how far we are in terms of capacity and people who are able to in the scope of their work in the city be laser focused on making sure that we start filling every one of those many, many, many gaps where we're not thinking about accessibility in all of these spaces.

[Kit Collins]: And I feel like our discussion is going in the right place and that we're thinking about what solutions can we

[Kit Collins]: On board for families and youth and all people quickly like what solutions, can we work on this year and this budget cycle to start things getting better and I think it's so important to make sure that we're.

[Kit Collins]: when we're talking about a staff person or in how we're just framing this conversation overall to make sure that we don't lose sight of what you all know that real success looks like, because that has to be the yardstick.

[Kit Collins]: And if the yardstick for that is there's somebody central to the city's organizational chart that is holding every department and every venue accountable, even private spaces accountable to feeling fully accessible,

[Kit Collins]: that needs to be protected position and we need to build to a place where we can have somebody who's going to ensure that that's the case in all departments and all spaces.

[Kit Collins]: There's liaison for public businesses.

[Kit Collins]: And so I agree with everything that's been said.

[Kit Collins]: I think that we're thinking about this in the right way.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that we makes a lot of sense to be thinking about this in terms of short term.

[Kit Collins]: What can we do this year and what has to happen this year to kind of start that larger snowball in motion?

[Kit Collins]: Like what position do we need to get into the organizational chart this year that

[Kit Collins]: in five years is going to be a team of three and five years after that is going to be a team of 10.

[Kit Collins]: I wish that we, you know, obviously we would all like that in three months, we'd be achieving these goals because this is stuff that people deserve already and have deserved already and we know that that would be naive to say that that is possible because we have such a long way to go.

[Kit Collins]: But I do think that part of this process needs to be

[Kit Collins]: some role or some type of project that is around kind of like an instant a, uh, a master plan for accessibility in the city, and I'd love to see that, um, not rolled into the boots on the ground implementation role that you're speaking about, because that's different.

[Kit Collins]: Um, but I think that that has to be a protected mission statement in one of these roles as well.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Chair Tseng.

[Kit Collins]: I really appreciate this discussion.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate that this motion came out of a place of wanting to have us ever be improving avenues for participation in our city bodies, and I certainly appreciate the clarified conversation that we're having with the Collins Center about it.

[Kit Collins]: I am going to make a motion to strike this section, and I'll explain why.

[Kit Collins]: I think what's important

[Kit Collins]: whether it's in our council rules or in the charter or in the school committee rules, though I cannot speak to those, is... I think what's important is improving participation meaningfully and balancing that meaningful participation with guarding the council against opportunities to filibuster, because having a democratic process for the city council and other elected bodies has to mean also letting the council be a workplace so that councilors can do the work that they were democratically elected

[Kit Collins]: to do.

[Kit Collins]: I think the really critical context here is that this would not be the creation of a new sole opportunity for public participation, opportunity to be heard in front of the City Council.

[Kit Collins]: Opportunities for public participation do exist on our bodies.

[Kit Collins]: On the City Council, with a particularly low barrier to entry, we do have more lenient public participation policies than most councils in the state, is my understanding.

[Kit Collins]: And sometimes the council takes rapid and direct action on matters that are brought up during public participation, and sometimes it doesn't.

[Kit Collins]: But I think that as a representative democracy and not as a direct democracy, that is just how it is.

[Kit Collins]: And my litmus test for this section is, does this meaningfully expand public participation more than what we already have to offer residents?

[Kit Collins]: without having that adverse side effect of limiting the council's ability to do the work that we are elected to do, and I'm not sure that it would.

[Kit Collins]: I think that it would be more encumbering than it would meaningfully expand participation, especially given that Articles 8.3 and 8.4 are still on the table, and those are much more specific, much more constrained, and I think a more actionable way to do what this section is getting at.

[Kit Collins]: So that's my rationale, and I am making the motion to strike this section.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I can repeat if needed.

[Kit Collins]: Just in the meantime- They're saying, should I repeat myself?

[Kit Collins]: Sure.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I think what's important is improving participation meaningfully and balancing participation with guarding against the council against opportunities to filibuster.

[Kit Collins]: To me, having a democratic process for the city council has to mean also letting the council be a workplace so that the councillors can do the work that we were democratically elected to do.

[Kit Collins]: I think what's important context here is that opportunities for public participation already exist on this council with, or in our elected bodies, especially on the council with a very low barrier to entry.

[Kit Collins]: On the city council we have more lenient public participation policies than most councils in the state.

[Kit Collins]: Sometimes the council takes rapid and direct action on matters that are brought up during public participation and sometimes it doesn't.

[Kit Collins]: But as a representative democracy and not a direct democracy, that is just the case, that is how it is.

[Kit Collins]: My litmus test for this section is, will this be more expanding of avenues for public participation, meaningful participation?

[Kit Collins]: Then it will

[Kit Collins]: then it will limit our ability to do our jobs.

[Kit Collins]: And I believe that this will be more encumbering than it will meaningfully expand public participation, especially given that Articles 8-3 and 8-4 are still on the table, and I think that they are more specific and more actionable in a good way.

[Kit Collins]: So that is my rationale for the motion to strike Article 8-1.

[Kit Collins]: I will withdraw.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate these proposals put forward.

[Kit Collins]: We have talked not a lot, but more than usual, about compensation for elected officials over the past, I'd say, term and a half than I think we usually do.

[Kit Collins]: I think that this is something that electeds do not like talking about.

[Kit Collins]: I think this is something that the public does not like us talking about.

[Kit Collins]: I think that we have more important work to do than talk about how elected officials should be compensated.

[Kit Collins]: I think it goes without saying that a lot of electeds find it distasteful to have to talk about how much people in our roles are to be compensated.

[Kit Collins]: I know that many members of the public find it distasteful.

[Kit Collins]: If this is not done consistently by ordinance or by charter, then it is something that we have to talk about.

[Kit Collins]: For myself as one Councilor, I would feel much more comfortable if this was dictated by charter, not up to me or anybody else to vote on the compensation of myself or any other elected official while we're in office.

[Kit Collins]: I think that this would be a huge asset and that it would take it

[Kit Collins]: out of our hands, it would not affect elected officials while they are currently in their current term.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that this sets a new fair standard.

[Kit Collins]: And most importantly, it regularizes it, it takes us out of something that sitting electeds have to vote on that would affect other sitting electeds.

[Kit Collins]: and I would also be supportive of the, if it were to go forward, I would be supportive of the proposed amendment or, you know, amendment to the proposal put forward by President Bears, inspired by Councilor Scarpelli's comments about, you know, how we are, we're always conscious of other outstanding compensation contracts in the city at the same time.

[Kit Collins]: The action discussion item for this committee meeting is, as usual, paper 24-033, zoning ordinance updates with the Innes Associates team.

[Kit Collins]: This is our third committee meeting on the neighborhood and urban residential

[Kit Collins]: topic.

[Kit Collins]: We were introduced to this topic on January 15th.

[Kit Collins]: We got our first look at kind of a jumping off point proposal, um, around new categories for the residential areas of the city.

[Kit Collins]: We had some first impressions, questions, suggestions.

[Kit Collins]: Two weeks ago, we saw an updated draft from our zoning consultant and associates.

[Kit Collins]: Some of the boundaries had moved around.

[Kit Collins]: We were able to get a little bit more in depth

[Kit Collins]: On the differences between the various sub districts and Councilors also made a number of requests suggestions.

[Kit Collins]: On places where the boundaries between the various sub districts should move around to better accommodate the topography the geography, the types of residential types that are already existing in the various neighborhoods around Medford.

[Kit Collins]: So tonight being our third meeting on this topic, we have another amended proposal in front of us that I understand incorporates all of the questions and requests that were made over the past couple meetings.

[Kit Collins]: We're seeing for the first time kind of more specificity on the urban residential sub-districts under this topic.

[Kit Collins]: And just to quickly recap,

[Kit Collins]: the neighborhood residential sub districts and the urban residential sub districts.

[Kit Collins]: These propose five new ways of categorizing existing residential districts throughout the community, creating a more modernized and more thoughtful gradient from our lowest density areas, residential areas of the city, up to our highest density residential areas of the city.

[Kit Collins]: And this is informed by, you know,

[Kit Collins]: Topography, geography, what the land allows, what the streets allow, the types of houses and homes that are already built around the community, and proximity to things that encourage greater density, such as transit, places where there are many jobs concentrated together.

[Kit Collins]: So I understand that tonight we have a couple, a number of new diagrams to look at and respond to, new proposals for boundaries between the various neighborhood residential sub-districts and urban residential sub-districts, as well as a new map that superimposes the new sub-districts on top of existing residential types in Medford.

[Kit Collins]: And I think this is reflecting some of the requests that councilors made

[Kit Collins]: two weeks ago asking for some areas that were, for example, Neighborhood Residential 2 to become Neighborhood Residential 1 again to reflect existing neighborhood character suggestions of that nature.

[Kit Collins]: So unless there are any initial comments from city staff or Councilors, I'll first turn it over to NS Associates for a presentation as usual, and then we can discuss.

[Kit Collins]: First, that

[Kit Collins]: All of the sub-districts, the new sub-districts that are being proposed in this proposal reflect to some degree housing that is already on the ground in these areas.

[Kit Collins]: And that and that informs why they've been categorized the way that they have been.

[Kit Collins]: That doesn't preclude a conversation about you know what, what should the sub district, be what which type of existing residential housing should it most closely reflect that is a conversation we're going to keep having it.

[Kit Collins]: In this sub district and others like it that are so incredible that are so proximate to the brand new these year and a half old T stations.

[Kit Collins]: These neighborhoods are going to see change.

[Kit Collins]: Whether we update the zoning or not.

[Kit Collins]: And this is a really important conversation that we get to have as a community to try to exert some control over what type of change we see and how to try to maximize community benefit from that change.

[Kit Collins]: There's a conversation about do we want to see change in developers kind of

[Kit Collins]: you know, I would make the argument that I'm very concerned about developers maxing out lot sizes and dimensionals to build very expensive single family homes that people in Medford cannot afford to buy and live in.

[Kit Collins]: And so we can, I think that this conversation is around not will change happen or not, but what level of control, what levers do we want to use to try and exert our influence over making sure that that change is beneficial to the community.

[Kit Collins]: We will go next back to Zoom.

[Kit Collins]: Gaston, just your name and address for the record, please.

[Kit Collins]: You have three minutes.

[Kit Collins]: Great, thank you, Director Hunt.

[Kit Collins]: And as we discussed, I think for quite a long time earlier this meeting, as we're talking about recategorizing residential districts, I think that there's very shared consensus around not wanting to make your very normal, very regular renovations difficult for homeowners just because of the sub-district that they happen to be zoned in.

[Kit Collins]: And at the same time, we want to be using careful and nuanced language so that we're also closing loopholes through which developers would take advantage of our neighborhoods.

[Kit Collins]: So thank you so much for flagging that.

[Kit Collins]: All right.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much for the question, Jimmy.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for your years of investment in the city.

[Kit Collins]: And I think we're all sad to hear about another story of displacement from our community due to the regional horrible housing cost crisis.

[Kit Collins]: I'll go to my fellow councilors first.

[Kit Collins]: I'll go to Councilor Leming and then President Bears for responses.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I'll go next to President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Scarpelli, please go ahead.

[Kit Collins]: President Bears, is that a new hand or an old one?

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I'll go to Councilor Leming.

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Scarpelli.

[Kit Collins]: Question was about housing affordability.

[Kit Collins]: I think it is, I'll just say, I think it is really important that when we're talking about affordability policy that we recognize that that exists in an ecosystem that also includes housing production.

[Kit Collins]: We're talking about housing production, that also that conversation also includes housing policy.

[Kit Collins]: And housing policy has to include what we can do by right at the local level as a community.

[Kit Collins]: And it also has to include things that we're advocating for on the state and federal level, whether that is affordability protections that we are currently not allowed to do by the state and the government that we're advocating for the right to do to better protect people in our community.

[Kit Collins]: or advocating for better funding so that we can make the changes that our residents and our displaced residents would have liked to us to have done years ago that we have no empowerment and no resources to do.

[Kit Collins]: We are years into a regional housing cost crisis that has been pushing people out of Medford for years.

[Kit Collins]: Every time this happens, it's a tragedy.

[Kit Collins]: I do not agree that increasing housing in a reasonable and neighborhood specific way in every single neighborhood is a part of that process.

[Kit Collins]: Is it the same as enacting rent stabilization so that rents cannot go up astronomically and push people out in just a year's time, which is currently legal?

[Kit Collins]: No, it's not the same of that.

[Kit Collins]: It's a more indirect tool, but it is a part of the ecosystem.

[Kit Collins]: And I don't think that we should gloss over the nuances such as the affordable incentives in Greenscore and our building requirements that are baked into the zoning process that allow us to thoughtfully increase affordability, use the levers that we do have in this system so that our zoning, which is the only tools that we have to control what private property owners do on their private property, can also hopefully as often as possible lead to maximum community benefit, which includes more affordable units on the market.

[Kit Collins]: President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: I'll go to Councilor Leming, and then I will make a wrap-up point, and then I will entertain motions to adjourn.

[Kit Collins]: Councilor, I'll go back to you and then I'll wrap up.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Councilor Scarpelli, I think we're all extremely glad and grateful that the Affordable Housing Trust is finally on the books and becoming empowered.

[Kit Collins]: President Bears?

[Kit Collins]: Sounds like you remember.

[Kit Collins]: Is there a motion to adjourn before I make a final comment.

[Kit Collins]: Okay, I hear a motion to adjourn by Councilor Callahan seconded by Councilor Leming, before we take the roll call vote.

[Kit Collins]: I just want to note.

[Kit Collins]: I think it is incumbent upon us who are elected to find solutions to problems and not just to talk about them.

[Kit Collins]: I think it'd be irresponsible for any of us to say that any one strategy is a silver bullet that will solve the rapidly escalating regional housing cost crisis, and that's why nobody says that.

[Kit Collins]: I think it'd be equally irresponsible to say that we should do nothing at all.

[Kit Collins]: Because no solution is perfect.

[Kit Collins]: The reason that we are working on so many that many Councilors are working on so many strategies targeted afforded housing affordability is because we know that no one strategy is sufficient.

[Kit Collins]: And I.

[Kit Collins]: look forward to continuing to collaborate with as many Councilors as possible on creative solutions that can fit together to create a more affordable environment in Medford between increasing our housing stock, which we know to be necessary, to pursuing greater access to policies that will help renters stay in Medford.

[Kit Collins]: You know, this has gone on too long.

[Kit Collins]: On the motion to adjourn by Councilor Callahan, seconded by Councilor Leming.

[Kit Collins]: Five in favor, none opposed.

[Kit Collins]: Meeting is adjourned.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: I just wanted to thank Councilor Lazzaro for putting this forward.

[Kit Collins]: So thank you to you for that work.

[Kit Collins]: And thank you to the residents for organizing in the wake of this tragedy.

[Kit Collins]: As residents of the city, as residents of most cities, as representatives of any city, this is something that we have to fathom because it happens all of the time.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think it's at all an exaggeration to say that roads in America are

[Kit Collins]: paved in tragedy.

[Kit Collins]: It has incredibly normalized the level of road violence that we all have to live with and grieve from.

[Kit Collins]: And as a representative, it fills me with just disbelief and fury that municipalities like ours are so hamstrung when it comes to the level of discretion and capacity and resources that we are allowed to have because of how funding is allocated from our federal and state partners.

[Kit Collins]: and how hamstrung we are and things that we have to bottom line as a city, leaving us so disempowered to do the type of improvements that residents have been begging us to do for years.

[Kit Collins]: We need substantial, radical road redesign on most roads in Medford if they are going to be livable for the people that walk on them and bike on them and roll on them and drive on them.

[Kit Collins]: And if it was possible for us to do that amid our other statutory responsibilities, I think we would have done that.

[Kit Collins]: going to say, 50 years ago.

[Kit Collins]: And because we, for many reasons, could not, and for other reasons, would not, people continue to die.

[Kit Collins]: And so it's with this perspective that we have to go forward and use the levers that we have at our disposal.

[Kit Collins]: I'm really, really grateful to every resident who has been calling on us to meet with our delegation and with partners at DCR as often as possible to say,

[Kit Collins]: It is insane that this is normal.

[Kit Collins]: It is national gaslighting that people are supposed to just get over, people dying on roads.

[Kit Collins]: I think this is another incredibly sad example of how governments are not given the tools to

[Kit Collins]: kind of compete with the pace of technological advancement.

[Kit Collins]: Cars are getting bigger and bigger and bigger and bigger and faster.

[Kit Collins]: Roads are not changing.

[Kit Collins]: Municipalities are not given more tools to address this problem.

[Kit Collins]: And people keep dying.

[Kit Collins]: I don't really know how to wrap it up.

[Kit Collins]: It just never should have happened.

[Kit Collins]: And we have to keep working together until it stops happening.

[Kit Collins]: So again, thank you to the residents and to Professor Dill's family.

[Kit Collins]: We're very deep in sympathy for your loss.
