[Kit Collins]: But it has also been really critical to note what questions people have about what we started with phase one, we moved on to Mystic Ave corridor district, we moved on to Green Score.

[Kit Collins]: Green Score is kind of now closest to finalization of the topics that haven't yet been ordained.

[Kit Collins]: And Salem Street, its next procedural step is the CDB.

[Kit Collins]: And with each of these proposals, we learn more about what is interesting to people, what is confusing to people,

[Kit Collins]: Do we hear from not very many residents about what do we hear from a lot of residents about.

[Kit Collins]: And that gives us what I think is incredibly crucial and valuable information about how we need to be responding to those questions in our public facing communications.

[Kit Collins]: And we have been trying to really, you know, just sprint as fast as we can being responsive to that, while we are continuing this process of reviewing the whole zoning citywide, I really do think it is important that we

[Kit Collins]: you know, stay true to our promise to review zoning comprehensively this term.

[Kit Collins]: That's not like kind of getting into any timeline specifics, but just I do think it's incredibly vital to do that as a package because with zoning, if we were to end up with kind of a incomplete overhaul, having touched some quarters, but not others, some neighborhoods, but not others, some topics, but not others, that would create a really chaotic

[Kit Collins]: legal landscape for developers for residents for city staff.

[Kit Collins]: That's just, I don't think that we run the risk of getting into that kind of situation but that is that is kind of an overarching goal guiding this process that we have to make sure that at the end of this project, the zoning, quote unquote, agrees with itself so that we avoid any

[Kit Collins]: legal chaos that could come from having tables of uses that don't line up or neighborhood uses that are not compatible with other neighborhoods.

[Kit Collins]: Right now, we have no intention of singling out any neighborhood and we have to make sure that we proceed at a pace that allows us to stay true to that.

[Kit Collins]: Anyway, back to the stuff that I honestly really love talking about.

[Kit Collins]: Right.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: No, I appreciate you noting that of course we are associates is not an employee of the city, so we have to use them while they are available.

[Kit Collins]: I think that this work is necessary.

[Kit Collins]: I think it's really valuable.

[Kit Collins]: meetings that are baked into this process as a minimum.

[Kit Collins]: We've been working with them so that they can, for all zoning topics going forward, in addition to some other comm stuff that I'll talk about in just a minute, put out really short bite-sized, like two-minute explainer videos for each zoning topic, which I think will be really, really useful.

[Kit Collins]: Because reading about zoning is incredibly dry.

[Kit Collins]: So things like that I think will add a lot to the process for residents.

[Kit Collins]: But at the end of the day, we are still working with a consultant under the constraints of a contract.

[Kit Collins]: And that is a real constraint.

[Kit Collins]: So we've talked about this a little bit in the planning and permitting committee, but I thought it was just really salient what the Councilor said about residents noting, you know, that we need to, we need really, residents need help in simplifying what changes are proposed, what is proposed to change in the corridors and the neighborhoods that we're looking at.

[Kit Collins]: You mentioned bullet points, you know, my ears pricked up.

[Kit Collins]: When I heard that because so much of what I've been working on, you know, quite intensively for the past few weeks at this point is really at the same time as we're comprehensively reviewing the city zoning.

[Kit Collins]: I personally have been comprehensively overhauling the city zoning website.

[Kit Collins]: And the thing is, we really need we really need bullet points we really need diagrams.

[Kit Collins]: for myself as an individual reading a zoning proposal alone, I do not come away with it with a deep enough understanding of the zoning proposal that I can easily explain it to another person in a way that they can understand.

[Kit Collins]: and residents do not have the time and the responsibility that Councilors do to do that kind of deep dive.

[Kit Collins]: So I met with the mayor's communications director and communications associate actually just earlier this afternoon.

[Kit Collins]: We are getting really close on an overhauled version of the zoning webpage.

[Kit Collins]: And that is really built around having simplified summaries and bullet points for every single zoning proposal, the ones that are currently going on, the ones that have already been adopted so that it is completely unmissable for residents.

[Kit Collins]: What is this?

[Kit Collins]: What are you talking about?

[Kit Collins]: Explain it to me like I'm in fifth grade.

[Kit Collins]: When is the next meeting?

[Kit Collins]: What topic comes after this one?

[Kit Collins]: What does the zoning currently say?

[Kit Collins]: What can I do by right?

[Kit Collins]: What does by right mean?

[Kit Collins]: Under the proposed zoning,

[Kit Collins]: what would change, what would be doable by right under that new scenario, what would be different, answering frequently asked questions, including diagrams, because I think those are totally essential for understanding.

[Kit Collins]: There's a lot of things that really don't come across in text, even when the text is simplified.

[Kit Collins]: We will add those short explainer videos when they are available.

[Kit Collins]: I just think it's really important that we are trying to optimize every communication strategy

[Kit Collins]: that we have.

[Kit Collins]: I think that adding in a public Q and A for each topic is such a great idea.

[Kit Collins]: And I really want to extend my thanks to Councilor Scarpelli for beating that drum for a long time.

[Kit Collins]: And I'm really glad that that's going to be a part of every zoning topic going forward.

[Kit Collins]: In addition, the short form explainer videos, in addition, a city websites that people have a spot that they can go to, which I really don't think they had before, where they can just get oriented.

[Kit Collins]: What is this?

[Kit Collins]: When are they going to talk about it next?

[Kit Collins]: just give me a version of this that I can digest and I can understand it well enough that I can ask a question and let people know where they can go to ask a question who to email for reliable information and when the next public meeting is so that you and your neighbors can attend and get your get your questions answered and real time.

[Kit Collins]: So I am really excited for us to be onboarding all of that.

[Kit Collins]: And, you know, that's our responsibility to make sure that residents, it's our responsibility to pass here.

[Kit Collins]: First and foremost, I believe that it is our responsibility to update Medford zoning because residents have been asking us to do that for a very, very, very long time.

[Kit Collins]: And I know that there are a lot of Metro residents and business owners and local developers

[Kit Collins]: who have been very, very frustrated for a very, very long time, seeing neighborhoods not reflect the character that residents would like them to, seeing squares and areas with a lot of great commercial potential not reach their full potential, because we have not undertaken this project.

[Kit Collins]: We owe them

[Kit Collins]: thoughtful zoning, reasonable zoning, better zoning.

[Kit Collins]: And I feel really, really committed to delivering on that goal.

[Kit Collins]: And at the same time, we also owe residents good, reliable information that residents can understand without becoming zoning experts.

[Kit Collins]: And that has been my focus for the past month in collaboration with my fellow councilors and with city staff and with Innes Associates.

[Kit Collins]: All of our public meetings, the planning and permitting meetings, the CDB public hearings, the City Council regular meetings are always public and always forums where residents can ask questions and get their questions answered.

[Kit Collins]: We're going to continue to do that.

[Kit Collins]: We're going to continue to use

[Kit Collins]: all of the communications channels that are available to us as city councilors and in collaboration with the mayor's office to do our very best at making sure that people know about this topic that is interesting to and relevant to so many residents.

[Kit Collins]: And at the same time, you know, myself and all of the councilors also have a responsibility to understand the zoning as best as we can so that we can answer questions and dispel concerns and make sure that we are sources of reliable information to residents as well.

[Kit Collins]: I truly could talk about this for a long time.

[Kit Collins]: I've been spending a lot of working hours on it in the past few weeks.

[Kit Collins]: And I think the bottom line for me is this project is pretty unprecedented.

[Kit Collins]: So our communication strategy around it is going to be unprecedented as well.

[Kit Collins]: And I'm committed to making sure that as we go topic by topic, we just continue to do the best job as we can and onboard as many new tools as we have to, so that people know what's going on, know who to ask, know when to ask, know when the meetings are, and that this can be as inclusive of a project as it can be.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate that perspective, Councilor Scarpelli.

[Kit Collins]: And I just want to clarify on our collaboration with our zoning consultant.

[Kit Collins]: I don't want there to be any confusion.

[Kit Collins]: The city council runs no risk of some sort of legal ramification from straying outside the bounds of its contract within associates.

[Kit Collins]: It is just that we run the risk of running out of their time.

[Kit Collins]: They are not a city employee.

[Kit Collins]: We put out an RFP.

[Kit Collins]: I work as a consultant.

[Kit Collins]: That is my day job.

[Kit Collins]: I respond to RFPs.

[Kit Collins]: A consultant responds to an RFP with a proposal, and then a contract is signed.

[Kit Collins]: We run the risk of running out of their time.

[Kit Collins]: And it is really important.

[Kit Collins]: I don't want anybody to come away with the impression that it is not really important that we fulfill our task of reviewing all of our zoning citywide.

[Kit Collins]: because to fail to follow through on that would cause problems.

[Kit Collins]: It would cause problems for local developers.

[Kit Collins]: It would cause problems for businesses.

[Kit Collins]: I had what may just be a clarifying question on section 3-2.

[Kit Collins]: In subsection C, it says the mayor shall be by virtue of the office a member of every multiple member body of the city.

[Kit Collins]: I was hoping to get a definition of what that would mean in practice from the Collins Center or representatives from the Charter Study Committee.

[Kit Collins]: Does that mean any board or commission?

[Kit Collins]: The mayor may have an informal

[Kit Collins]: say on or vote in if he or she chooses, or does it mean truly any multi-member body, including the City Council?

[Kit Collins]: I'm just, I'm not, I don't really know what to glean from that term.

[Kit Collins]: And the Mayor has a voice but no vote.

[Kit Collins]: A voice but no vote on any board or commission.

[Kit Collins]: Yeah, great, thank you, that's very helpful.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Chair Sung.

[Kit Collins]: This again might be a comment or it might just be a clarifying question.

[Kit Collins]: In section 3-6, let me check the subsection number, subsection B. It reads, the mayor may call a special meeting of the city council for any purpose.

[Kit Collins]: I was just hoping to understand better like how this what this maybe tracked with most from our current charter right now, there's a provision for special meetings to be called for the city council when it's necessary.

[Kit Collins]: It can be done by a quorum of city Councilors or by the president of the city council, but I don't believe that we currently have it in practice for the mayor to be able to call a special meeting of the city council.

[Kit Collins]: So I'd like to understand a little bit more about the rationale behind that.

[Kit Collins]: So I can understand if I the reasoning for it being written into the city charter that that's a new power of mayor.

[Kit Collins]: Yeah, thank you.

[Kit Collins]: It makes sense is the rationale it's I think that there's going through this project, obviously, some stipulations are more major more consequential than others.

[Kit Collins]: I think some of my deliberations around the charter around which of those things are consequential that we should change and which of those things.

[Kit Collins]: are strategies that we want available to the mayor, the city council, other bodies, but don't necessarily need to be written into the charter.

[Kit Collins]: So this just strikes me as kind of a shift in the dynamic, potentially a symptom of a shifting dynamic.

[Kit Collins]: In the past, I think that the mayor has always been able to collaborate with city leadership when there's an emergency meeting that needs to be called.

[Kit Collins]: Again, I don't think that this is the most important thing before us.

[Kit Collins]: But it did strike me as a change and a new power of the mayor over the city council.

[Kit Collins]: So it's just something that I want to give due consideration to and think a bit more about.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you chair saying I appreciate you bringing that up it was something that I had highlighted in my initial read, and the last sentence as you noted and just, again, you know, doing us as, as we have to do reading this with a fine tooth comb kind of looking for areas where there could potentially be confusion, totally heard that I think with a lot of with many of the issues that we're bringing

[Kit Collins]: know, it's unlikely that these things would ever be issues, but you know, it is, in a way, our responsibility to look for things that could be so we can make this document as airtight as it can be.

[Kit Collins]: So I just I flagged that as well.

[Kit Collins]: I'm glad you brought it up.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that if there's a way to kind of maintain the purpose of this article and make sure that you know, we're not leaving a stone unturned with if there's a more straightforward way of organizing this paragraph that it doesn't

[Kit Collins]: there is no arbitrariness in how it could be, or there's no flexibility in how it could be read, I would be happy to consider that language at a future meeting.

[Kit Collins]: Maybe it won't end up changing, but in my initial read of it, I did read this paragraph, and at the end, I was like, in what condition may the mayor declare themselves able, and how does that interplay with the city council's

[Kit Collins]: unanimous vote mentioned earlier.

[Kit Collins]: So if there's no further clarification that's needed, that's great.

[Kit Collins]: But I would be interested in having this further clarified if possible.

[Kit Collins]: Sorry about that.

[Kit Collins]: It took me a second to find my notes.

[Kit Collins]: Again, sorry, another clarifying question for me.

[Kit Collins]: We're in Section

[Kit Collins]: 5-1 yes great.

[Kit Collins]: I was just hoping.

[Kit Collins]: If any examples could be given of the section that describes.

[Kit Collins]: This procedure where the mayor prepares and submits to the city council plan in the city that council then holds a hearing on it and it seems like there's a vote and this is obviously I'm trying to compare this to what we're familiar with.

[Kit Collins]: We're familiar with ordinances being promulgated by the city council and petitions and papers coming from

[Kit Collins]: the community via the mayor's office and city administration to the council.

[Kit Collins]: I'm trying to figure out if this describes something different.

[Kit Collins]: Is this like, is this a mechanism by which the mayor is proposing an ordinance, a new department, like a change to administration?

[Kit Collins]: Like when we say that the mayor is proposing a plan to the city council and then the city council may take a vote to disapprove of that plan.

[Kit Collins]: Could you give an example of what that might be about?

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I just, before we close out, I just want to thank the representatives from the Collins Center for being here.

[Kit Collins]: And again, thank you to the representatives from the Charter Study Committee for being with us through this process.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I just want to extend my gratitude to Councilor Tseng for taking leadership on this project I've reviewed it.

[Kit Collins]: It's even more thorough than it was last time we reviewed it in committee.

[Kit Collins]: I'm just I'm really glad that the city council is taking it upon itself to make sure that we are.

[Kit Collins]: making these protections just as airtight and as clear for our population as we possibly could.

[Kit Collins]: It's unfortunate that we're having to workshop this ordinance in a moment when federal actors are taking a regressive, frankly, ahistorical, oppressive

[Kit Collins]: politicizing approach to matters of reproductive health and gender expression.

[Kit Collins]: That baffles me on lots of levels, but what's important is that people in Medford, people who visit Medford, people who receive medical care in Medford, or people who give medical care at Medford

[Kit Collins]: should have every protection to get what they need and do what they do and receive care and provide care, and I think it's very important that the city council affirm that reproductive health care and all its forms and gender affirming health care and all of their forms are the farthest leg from legal, they are utterly banal.

[Kit Collins]: very pleased to see that this ordinance is so thorough and describing all of the forms of health care, to which people are entitled, and making it really clear that all city agents across all departments shall not deploy their resources or their time and service of agendas from other states or other jurisdictions that might want to waste time and energy.

[Kit Collins]: politicizing healthcare.

[Kit Collins]: So thank you so much.

[Kit Collins]: I've reviewed this.

[Kit Collins]: I think it's very thorough.

[Kit Collins]: I'm happy to wait to pass it out of committee until we have a legal review.

[Kit Collins]: I don't know that it's necessary if we do want to pass this along to the committee of the whole and just make further adjustments or tweaks there if it's necessary.

[Kit Collins]: I think that that would also be fine, but I'll leave that to the discretion of the ordinance sponsor.

[Kit Collins]: I think this is in a really good place.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Test one, two.

[Kit Collins]: There will be a meeting of the Medford City Council Planning and Permitting Committee, January 29th, 2025.

[Kit Collins]: The action discussion item for this meeting is, as usual, paper 24-033, zoning ordinance updates with the Innes Associates team.

[Kit Collins]: So this is going to be kind of a multi-topic meeting.

[Kit Collins]: Planning and permitting committee meeting, there's been calls from Councilors on this committee as well as requests from the public to enhance our messaging strategy around this entire zoning project in order to, you know, essentially to recalibrate at this point of year to take stock of

[Kit Collins]: how we're getting information out to the public about what's currently at what stage of the process, where current proposals are, when their next public meeting will be, in what body.

[Kit Collins]: We've been working on this zoning project since around this time last year, and in that time we've learned a lot about what people need in order to feel properly informed and updated on what we're talking about.

[Kit Collins]: community.

[Kit Collins]: Um so we're doing some things on the City Council side that associates is helping us out with and we're also trying to collaborate with the mayor's office as much as we can to enhance our online information and add in more public meetings so that people have more opportunities for.

[Kit Collins]: Um for learning, you know, in a way that works for more community members and for Q and A as well.

[Kit Collins]: So Emily will speak more to that.

[Kit Collins]: Um and after we run through those updates,

[Kit Collins]: zoning proposal.

[Kit Collins]: At a point in the year, we're working better together to make sure that we are trying to make progress on some of those goals that we share.

[Kit Collins]: what that has to look like, councillors and residents, both included.

[Kit Collins]: I'll recognize President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Certainly, thank you for your comments and I'm happy to go over that in brief.

[Kit Collins]: And I know that at our last meeting, there was specifically a motion for myself as chair to be working with the city, with the mayor's office and her communications office to make sure that

[Kit Collins]: we're doing all we can in collaboration to make sure that more and better information is reaching people more effectively.

[Kit Collins]: So specifically, what's that looking like?

[Kit Collins]: We're working on a lot behind the scenes now, and I'm excited for some of this to go live, hopefully within a couple of weeks.

[Kit Collins]: One part of this that I think is really important is overhauling the zoning page on the city website.

[Kit Collins]: As a quick reminder, the city council doesn't really have direct control over any part of the city website.

[Kit Collins]: So this is a collaborative project.

[Kit Collins]: Currently, I think, and this is by no means a pejorative or a criticism, but I think it is just a fact that the zoning page on the city website is very hard to navigate if you're a layperson, if you're an average resident who heard, who has a zoning question, heard about a proposal.

[Kit Collins]: and you Google Medford MA zoning, it's quite hard to find what you're looking for.

[Kit Collins]: And that's not the fault of the planning department or the communications team.

[Kit Collins]: Zoning is inherently wonky and technical and detailed and confusing.

[Kit Collins]: And to President Bears' point about us being a fairly under-resourced city, it would take more than a two-person communications department to sort and present that and design that in a way.

[Kit Collins]: that makes it be what people need it to be.

[Kit Collins]: So we're now working collaboratively to completely overhaul that webpage, which I am quite excited about as a visual person myself, with the goal being that this becomes more of a site where when people have a question, maybe they've heard about Salem Street, maybe they've heard about the residential neighborhood proposal, they can navigate to that site, and it is impossible to miss up-to-date and current information, summaries, bullet points, FAQs, and diagrams, but let them know what's being worked on

[Kit Collins]: who is currently talking about it, what body, and what the next public meetings are on that topic, when they can attend to ask questions and learn more.

[Kit Collins]: I hope that we'll also have, as Emily mentioned, there's also going to be very short-form digestible videos coming from Innes Associates.

[Kit Collins]: Those will be linked.

[Kit Collins]: And kind of the broader picture that we have for the website is not just to be very, very easily findable, digestible information about the current zoning proposals, but also to

[Kit Collins]: do a better job of reinforcing for residents that these are not individual proposals that we're just taking up Salem Street and that's the end of the story or we're not just taking up Mystic Avenue corridor district and that's the end of the story but this is a coordinated really more than a year-long effort this is a

[Kit Collins]: a citywide zoning review.

[Kit Collins]: So as people are finding out, okay, March 5, next meeting about Salem Street, good to know I can save that date, I can put it in my calendar.

[Kit Collins]: They're also seeing a timeline that reminds them that after Salem Street comes the neighborhood residential proposal.

[Kit Collins]: And after that, we'll be talking about squares and corridors, and letting people know that this is a citywide process that they can plug into any time between now and June, or they can kind of mark a month on their calendar and make sure to tune back in if there's a particular area that they're interested in.

[Kit Collins]: So I am looking forward to those updates to the zoning page on the website.

[Kit Collins]: I think that's a major one.

[Kit Collins]: We have the series of explainer videos from Innes Associates.

[Kit Collins]: We're working to, kind of in concert with all of this, be putting out more frequent updates in the form of fresh releases, collaboration between the city council and the mayor's office.

[Kit Collins]: Essentially, we're trying to make sure that our announcements about these are touching all of our existing communications channels.

[Kit Collins]: We know that some people go on the website.

[Kit Collins]: We know that some people are signed up for the e-alerts.

[Kit Collins]: We know that some people do reverse 911.

[Kit Collins]: We know that some people have social media.

[Kit Collins]: So we're trying to make sure that we are consistently creating information that's short form.

[Kit Collins]: What do you need to know?

[Kit Collins]: When is this going to be talked about?

[Kit Collins]: Information for each of the zoning proposals that can be shared on all of these communication channels.

[Kit Collins]: so that anybody who's interested at the very least can know where they can go to learn more and they can go to that place and actually learn more instead of getting confused and overwhelmed and then clicking away, or they can know where to watch a video or where to attend a meeting.

[Kit Collins]: That's the short form.

[Kit Collins]: I feel like there's probably something that I forgot.

[Kit Collins]: but the overall structure being that vastly improved web page on the city website, more frequent press release and social media updates paired with more frequent use of reverse 911 to let people know about upcoming meetings.

[Kit Collins]: With that, are there, oh, thank you, Councilor Callahan.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you very much, Councilor Hilliam.

[Kit Collins]: And I agree.

[Kit Collins]: really simple, really effective diagram showing, comparing the current zoning to what the current built environment actually is and showing what we love that's currently non-conforming that couldn't be built today with the current zoning, those heights and those densities, because of course that's a lot of what we talk about and a lot of what residents want us to be focusing on when we're talking about zoning.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much for the overview.

[Kit Collins]: And I appreciate that note.

[Kit Collins]: As with any other zoning proposal, this is about balance.

[Kit Collins]: I think that there are a lot of goals of reevaluating our zoning.

[Kit Collins]: Obviously, one of those goals is to say, where is incremental more density or more height or more this or more that appropriate?

[Kit Collins]: Another way of looking at it is to say, where are there a lot of non-conforming lots already that we should not make further out of compliance, that we should update the zoning so that it reflects what's already there?

[Kit Collins]: And I think that some of the neighborhood residential proposal

[Kit Collins]: kind of centers those two questions at the same time.

[Kit Collins]: I was saying, where does it make sense that we should, where in the city is the transit proximity and the existing density and the roadways and the topography make it so it makes a lot of sense to incrementally up-zone here?

[Kit Collins]: And what are those areas where we actually, as we're trying to unify and make consistent,

[Kit Collins]: One thing I heard is that I think that one of the, in a way, one of the amendments from two weeks ago might actually make a lot of what's existing on the ground in some single family two districts out of conforming with the proposed zoning.

[Kit Collins]: So we wanna make sure that we're making things more coherent as opposed to less as this advances.

[Kit Collins]: So I know I have some questions.

[Kit Collins]: I'll note for myself, I think that

[Kit Collins]: As one councillor, I think that this map that we're focusing on is probably the most important one of the presentation, kind of overlaying current land uses, current building types, and superimposing on top of that the proposed new sub-districts.

[Kit Collins]: And I really encourage everybody, councillors and the public, to focus on this one specifically as we continue to workshop this proposal.

[Kit Collins]: For me, it's very useful to be able to say okay what are the corresponding number of units between the proposed new sub districts and current building uses.

[Kit Collins]: letters and numbers for the proposed new sub districts.

[Kit Collins]: And we have color coded residential types for what's existentially on the ground.

[Kit Collins]: So for me, as I was looking at this map, I was saying, okay, anywhere that any section that is predominantly magenta means that the nine or more units that should probably be our urban residential number two sub district because it should be reflective of the density that's already there.

[Kit Collins]: And I feel strongly as we already said that we should be down zoning nowhere in the city because that's counter to I think all of our goals.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that this is very instructive for those, most areas of the city, well, maybe not most, a lot of areas of the cities are mixed, which makes sense.

[Kit Collins]: That's why our neighborhoods are cozy and feel human scaled is because they're not just the same type of building over and over.

[Kit Collins]: And I think a lot of what we're talking about in this discussion is those neighborhoods where there's a mix of, you know, on this map, turquoise and orange and purple.

[Kit Collins]: you have some single family, you have some two family, maybe you have some condo conversion, you have a couple three families here and there.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that is really the frontier where we're thinking, we're thinking of zoning, I think it's, it's accurate to think of it as a 30 year map, not a next year map.

[Kit Collins]: I think when we look at economic trends and building trends, we're building out the map that we want to see on the ground and in 30 or 40 years.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that's the ground where we have to be making those decisions about

[Kit Collins]: for example, is that an NR3 or is it a UR1 or is it an NR2?

[Kit Collins]: I think for myself, there's a lot of areas in the city where you do see that mix of turquoise and purple, which is to say two family and three family.

[Kit Collins]: I would probably like those to be an NR3 or potentially even a UR1.

[Kit Collins]: in some of those zones that are especially proximate or bordering on the transit hubs.

[Kit Collins]: Because it's reflective of the density that we already enjoy and because we know that we need to add density and we should be putting it in the places where there's the greatest demand for it and the most supports for it.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much, everybody.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, NS Associates, for your thoughtful stewardship, as always.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears this was a meeting of the planning and permitting committee to have our first look at the neighborhood residential topic it will be continued at our next planning and permitting committee meeting which is tomorrow and for future meeting dates after that motion to approve on the motion of Vice President Collins to approve seconded by Councilor Callahan all those in favor.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: I just wanted to thank Councilor Tseng for putting this forward and join with him in wishing all of our residents a very happy Lunar New Year.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears, and I appreciate this conversation.

[Kit Collins]: I think that a lot of... I'm really glad to see the progress that we've made over the past couple of weeks in seeing the assessor's office do such good work in sharing information about potential abatement programs with any and all residents who need it.

[Kit Collins]: I know this is an incredibly busy time of year for the assessor's office, but this is a really critical function of their work as well to connect with residents.

[Kit Collins]: who need assistance.

[Kit Collins]: And when it comes to the questions that have been coming in from the community, you know, when a person says, hey, I don't understand this.

[Kit Collins]: I'm confused.

[Kit Collins]: I need more information.

[Kit Collins]: That's not a political question.

[Kit Collins]: That's just a really human question.

[Kit Collins]: And so I'm really grateful for the assessor's office for making so much time and freeing up so much energy to

[Kit Collins]: field those questions as they come in.

[Kit Collins]: I'm grateful to my fellow Councilors for helping direct people to the resources that they really need at this time.

[Kit Collins]: Of course, I think that, you know, this change in our property tax structure was needed, and the process to make sure that everybody understands what comes next is vitally important, and we can't afford to have that be any less robust than it absolutely can be.

[Kit Collins]: The same goes for

[Kit Collins]: you know, all of these parts that make up our ecosystem of how we deal with property tax bills in the city, whether that's our exemptions, our abatement programs, and then the communications that come, you know, before and after all of this, making sure that people know what their options are, and how to understand and take steps on their property tax bills, regardless of the year, because abatements and exemptions are something that people need year in and year out, whether there's an override or whether there isn't one.

[Kit Collins]: just due to the economy that we're in and the nature of rapidly escalating, you know, assessed home values in Medford before or after the override.

[Kit Collins]: So I really am glad for the opportunity to focus on that and thank the assessor's office and talk about what the city council can continue to do to make sure that we are supporting city staff in connecting residents with resources.

[Kit Collins]: and making sure that all of that information about what to do gets out to the people who it's intended to connect with.

[Kit Collins]: I also think that this is the right time to start talking about a residential exemption.

[Kit Collins]: This is really complicated.

[Kit Collins]: A residential exemption would not benefit all residents.

[Kit Collins]: It would not even benefit all homeowners.

[Kit Collins]: But I do think that we have a responsibility to discuss it and to discuss it seriously.

[Kit Collins]: I think that's something that we should start to do in committee at the whole or the administration and finance committee as well.

[Kit Collins]: So all that being said, I'm grateful to the councilor for bringing this forward.

[Kit Collins]: I think that there's a lot of really, really important and timely topics here.

[Kit Collins]: And I would like to put forward a lightly amended version of the paper that I'd be comfortable voting yes on tonight.

[Kit Collins]: So I put this forward as a friendly amendment or as a B paper, if the councilor is more amenable.

[Kit Collins]: That would be, whereas the city of Medford has expanded all tax exemptions for members of vulnerable communities, including our senior, disabled, and veteran neighbors to the maximum extent allowed under state law.

[Kit Collins]: And whereas in the past, state and federal grants have been utilized in the city of Medford to support our local businesses, such as the 2024 Massachusetts vacant storefront program and the 2022 small business facade improvement grant program.

[Kit Collins]: Whereas implementing a residential exemption would decrease the tax burden for some residential property owners, be it resolved that the City Council continue to work with the Assessor's Office and the Mayor's Communications Office in sharing information about debatement processes with any and all residents who could benefit.

[Kit Collins]: Be it resolved that the City Council craft a Home Rule petition to ask the state to allow us to further expand our tax exemption options for these rural-local groups so that we may offer even greater tax exemption programs than what we are currently allowed to offer.

[Kit Collins]: be it further resolved that the City Council meet in the Administration and Finance Committee to discuss a potential residential exemption, and be it further resolved that the City Administration continue to prioritize and pursue any and all state, federal, and private grant opportunities targeted at assisting our business opportunity.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Councilor Scarpelli for putting this forward.

[Kit Collins]: I think that this is a really important resolution.

[Kit Collins]: I think this is another issue where we can do a lot of good by doing a better job at getting to the community the information that is out there.

[Kit Collins]: I've also been communicating with residents about the GLX parking zone.

[Kit Collins]: I live in that zone.

[Kit Collins]: I know I'm not the only councilor who does.

[Kit Collins]: I have seen both the pros and the cons firsthand, most especially when I try to park my car after getting home from a city council meeting at 1 a.m.

[Kit Collins]: and then circling down the block three to five times and then parking on a cross street, which is now legal to do, which is great, but the circling is not the fun part.

[Kit Collins]: Anyway, I've been communicating with residents who have been noticing the types of changes that I have.

[Kit Collins]: And it's been helpful for me to the extent of my knowledge, explain the pros and the cons and the why of the new program.

[Kit Collins]: But obviously this is something that our parking department should be doing.

[Kit Collins]: This is something that our communications department should be doing.

[Kit Collins]: And there are a lot of residents who still have questions and still have a hard time finding what the policies are and where they are on the website.

[Kit Collins]: Recently, a resident came to me with a parking policy that was indeed on the city website that I had never heard of before.

[Kit Collins]: So I think this is a good thing.

[Kit Collins]: It would be great for the council to meet the new parking director.

[Kit Collins]: I'd also be happy for this to be a committee of the whole.

[Kit Collins]: 2-5-0-2-0 offered by Mayor Breanna Lungo-Koehn, transfer and conveyance of McCormick Avenue parcels.

[Kit Collins]: Dear President Bearss and members of the City Council, I respectively request and recommend that your honorable body approve the following transfer and conveyance of city property which will transfer

[Kit Collins]: to the mayor, the care, custody and control of two vacant parcels of vacant land on McCormick Avenue that have remained unused since the city acquired said parcels in 1950 pursuant to a tax title taking, and authorize the mayor to convey said parcels in compliance with General Laws Chapter 30B, the Uniform Procurement Act.

[Kit Collins]: The city will benefit by putting the unused parcels to productive and tax-producing uses, and further, the city may, subject to appropriation by the City Council,

[Kit Collins]: for the purpose of promoting affordable housing or for such other purposes as the City Council determines is in the best interest of the city.

[Kit Collins]: A resolution to transfer and authorize the sale of McCormick Avenue parcels.

[Kit Collins]: Whereas the city is the owner of two parcels of land located on McCormick Avenue, each containing 3,600 square feet, more or less, identified in the assessors as parcels F13-37 and F13-38,

[Kit Collins]: and described in certificate of title number 166463 filed with the Middlesex South Registry District of the Land Court together the city property.

[Kit Collins]: Whereas the city property has been vacant and unused since the city acquired the city property in 1950 pursuant to a tax taking and is surplus to the needs of the city.

[Kit Collins]: Whereas there is an urgent need to promote and develop affordable housing in the city of Medford and in the region.

[Kit Collins]: Whereas the sale of the city property will benefit the city by putting the city property to productive and tax generating uses.

[Kit Collins]: And whereas the sale of said sale, the proceeds of said sale may be used by the city for the purpose of promoting affordable housing.

[Kit Collins]: Now, therefore, be it that the city council hereby declares that the city property is surplus to the needs of the city and available for disposition.

[Kit Collins]: and that the city council hereby transfers the care, custody, and control of the city property from the tax custodian for tax settle purposes to the mayor for general municipal purposes and or for the purpose of disposition on such terms and conditions as is in the best interest of the city, and that the mayor may be authorized to convey the city's right title and interest in said city property provided that said sale is in compliance with the provisions of General Laws Chapter 30B, the Uniform Procurement Act,

[Kit Collins]: and to take any and all other action as may be necessary or appropriate to accomplish that disposition and that this resolution shall take effect upon passage.

[Kit Collins]: Attorney Everett will be in attendance via Zoom to provide the council with guidance on this matter.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for your kind attention.

[Kit Collins]: Sincerely, Brianna Lugar-Curran, Mayor.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Yes.

[Kit Collins]: Yes.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Chair Sine, I appreciate that.

[Kit Collins]: I really appreciate the discussion on this.

[Kit Collins]: So far, I know that this is, you know, we come to this discussion after months of work and outreach and diligence and research by the members of the Charter Study Committee and the Collins Center.

[Kit Collins]: And I just want to, again, state how much I appreciate all of that hard work and that collaboration so far.

[Kit Collins]: So my thoughts on this issue, again, going to restate some of what was already said by my fellow Councilors.

[Kit Collins]: Of course, we could see from the data that respondents who did respond to the survey favored ward-based representation when compared to all at large.

[Kit Collins]: I do think that it is significant that district based and other models were not given as options for comparison.

[Kit Collins]: That's not a criticism.

[Kit Collins]: It's just simply that I don't think that that means that this council should have this discussion as though those options are not also on the table because we have a responsibility to do our due diligence and make amendments or approve.

[Kit Collins]: or approve the proposal based on what we think will be best for the long-term future of this community.

[Kit Collins]: My bottom line is I think that the proposed amendment regarding composition still represents a very, very big improvement towards more localized representation, making representation much more localized than it has been in a very, very long time, perhaps ever.

[Kit Collins]: I know

[Kit Collins]: I think we all know, we all concur that running in a smaller pool in some ways reduces the barriers to running for office, especially financially.

[Kit Collins]: You have to fundraise less.

[Kit Collins]: Fundraising is very difficult.

[Kit Collins]: But I don't think that we should discuss this as if that is the whole story.

[Kit Collins]: to improving representation and making representation more proportional to demographics.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think that ward-based representation is a panacea.

[Kit Collins]: I certainly don't think that it's a panacea for making marginalized populations more equitably represented.

[Kit Collins]: I think that for us to pursue that as though it's a silver bullet,

[Kit Collins]: would be a misguided reason to pursue a ward-based representation.

[Kit Collins]: Running is inherently difficult for millions of reasons, and I do believe that it will take decades or more to truly equalize the playing field.

[Kit Collins]: And I think my bottom line on this is that wards do not deserve simple representation full stop.

[Kit Collins]: What wards deserve is compelling and competitive elections each and every time.

[Kit Collins]: And I have concerns that the proposal that we're currently looking at from the Charter Study Committee, I'm very concerned that those elections would not result in compelling and competitive elections each and every time.

[Kit Collins]: My research has indicated to me that in quite small wards like we have in Medford, the pool of candidates tends to be very small.

[Kit Collins]: It's very common for incumbents to go unchallenged.

[Kit Collins]: And for incumbents, when they do decide that they want to retire from those elected positions, to privately appoint a successor, put off their announcement until the last moment, which all but ensures that other challenges do not have the time to jump in the race and have a real shot at participating in that competitive election.

[Kit Collins]: And I don't think that that is democratic.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think that that is our shared goal for more competitive and more locally representative offices.

[Kit Collins]: Lastly, I'll just say, you know, I know that this is this is a big deal because this is the guiding document for the city.

[Kit Collins]: And hopefully I am really confident that we will arrive at a document that all of us can feel, you know, like any product of compromise that we can all feel a little bit good about and a little bit wistful about.

[Kit Collins]: But as city councilors, it is our responsibility to apply our perspective and our good faith opinions to this process, even in perhaps especially when it's unpopular.

[Kit Collins]: It's certainly

[Kit Collins]: It's certainly more politically expedient to do what is popular, but our job is to research and advance what we think would be best for the community in the long run, regardless of the impact on us as individual electeds and individual future candidates.

[Kit Collins]: And that's the reason for my opinion on this matter.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Chair Tseng.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate that.

[Kit Collins]: I have some comments that I wanna add, and then I'm going to also make a motion at the end.

[Kit Collins]: You know, I would love to get back to a place where this conversation is productive and civil, like it was at the beginning of the meeting.

[Kit Collins]: But first, I do have to say, I find it a little rich that one Councilor will start the meeting talking about maturing and being open minded.

[Kit Collins]: And then the instant that their colleagues start to disagree with them, the conversation turns to personal attacks and blaming colleagues for rending the city apart.

[Kit Collins]: I just wish that we could have civil and productive conversations about this.

[Kit Collins]: and I don't think that's productive.

[Kit Collins]: I'm really respectful to the conversation at all, not after all of the work that has been put into this topic.

[Kit Collins]: No one said that some wards do not need representation.

[Kit Collins]: What was said, not by me, is that some wards are so low turnout and some wards are so high turnout that it would create a huge disparity in some residents' votes among others, counting some very, very highly, and other votes would matter much less numerically, and that's not fair.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think that we should be trading one form of unrepresentativeness for another.

[Kit Collins]: And if we're going to, I at least think that we should be able to acknowledge it and acknowledge that it matters and talk about potential mitigating solutions.

[Kit Collins]: I hope that people will take it to heart that I am willing to potentially disagree with people with whom I share values because I have honest concerns about the current charter provisions as proposed, and I am willing to face criticism over that.

[Kit Collins]: I simply think that we should prioritize genuine representation and genuine efficacy over well-intentioned, but I think less effective, appearances of representation.

[Kit Collins]: And I don't think that we can accomplish that by simply adding numbers to the council.

[Kit Collins]: And for reasons that have already been stated by me and by others, I don't think that the simple ward-based system is the best way of doing that.

[Kit Collins]: I know that we have received a lot of feedback about the award-based versus all-at-large options.

[Kit Collins]: Again, I think that we need to consider that these were the only two options presented in the survey, and we should consider those data points in the context of that.

[Kit Collins]: There weren't other data points on the table or on the survey.

[Kit Collins]: Something that guides all of my decisions on the council is knowing that people, all people, myself included, it's human nature to overly weight feedback that is visible to us, like opinions that we happen to have heard, people that we happen to have heard from, and forget that other opinions that we happen to happen to have heard, that we didn't ask for, that are not as visible, that didn't hear about a survey, that don't have opportunities to come to city council meetings.

[Kit Collins]: It's human nature to overweight the information that we have heard.

[Kit Collins]: and kind of forget that other information exists.

[Kit Collins]: I bring this up not just because for me it is a really useful reminder when I'm making any decision on the City Council, but also because I think it's incredibly relevant to this project, because the work of the City Charter, especially talking about composition,

[Kit Collins]: is about better representation for those people in the community who are not as visible, who don't have access to our normal communication channels, who don't know how to get in contact with their city councilors, who do not vote.

[Kit Collins]: To me, that is the goal of this section of the city charter, is try to get better at that exact mechanism.

[Kit Collins]: I believe that a district model is our best option for lifting up and better representing people who are currently underrepresented, even in light of the feedback that we have seen, which was based on the two options presented in the survey.

[Kit Collins]: And I think it's very relevant that this is a project that has been worked on by people who are highly involved.

[Kit Collins]: And it's our job to approve a product that will work the best and the most fairly for people who are already highly involved and for people who have not been able to be highly involved, for people who are underrepresented.

[Kit Collins]: All that being said, I do think that this is a good moment for compromise.

[Kit Collins]: I think that a lot of good points have been made.

[Kit Collins]: I've been very clear that I think that the district-based model makes the most sense.

[Kit Collins]: I'm also not opposed to a larger council, not at all.

[Kit Collins]: It's not my preference, but I'm not opposed to it.

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Leming earlier entertained the idea of sticking with four district councilors, but expanding the number to five at-large councilors.

[Kit Collins]: I would be happy to offer that in the form of a motion to President Bierer's proposed amendments if he is willing to accept it as a friendly amendment.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Chair Tseng.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate that.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate those comments from President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: I think that gets right to the heart of the issue as I see it.

[Kit Collins]: One last point on this through the chair.

[Kit Collins]: If my fellow councilors' opinions earlier were in good faith about outcomes and not about politicking and taking shots to make perceived opponents look bad, I think that then he would be sticking to the substance at hand and not derailing this conversation.

[Kit Collins]: With lies about us voting in lockstep and other false narratives, I also encourage people to run the tape or look at our duly promulgated council records.

[Kit Collins]: And people will find that the Councilors on this body who share an endorsement just disagree with each other all the time, which I believe is how it should be.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate the discussion so far.

[Kit Collins]: I have made a motion that the five district Councilors and five at large Councilors be considered as part of President Bear's amendment.

[Kit Collins]: I would request that we move on to public comment and then take votes on motions.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Yes, that is what I meant to say.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Second.

[Kit Collins]: 15th, 2025.

[Kit Collins]: This meeting will take place at 6pm in the City Council Chamber, second floor, Medford City Hall, and via Zoom.

[Kit Collins]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Kit Collins]: present, five present, zero absent.

[Kit Collins]: The meeting is called to order.

[Kit Collins]: The action discussion item for this committee meeting is again, 24-033, zoning ordinance updates with the Innes Associates team.

[Kit Collins]: This is the first planning and permitting committee meeting of the new year.

[Kit Collins]: We have seen a lot of work in this committee so far.

[Kit Collins]: A lot of that is still ongoing.

[Kit Collins]: the fall.

[Kit Collins]: We shepherded through the Mystic Avenue Corridor District proposal.

[Kit Collins]: The Salem Street Corridor District proposal is still being considered in public meetings by the Community Development Board.

[Kit Collins]: The Green Score proposal is still being considered in public meetings by the Community Development Board.

[Kit Collins]: There's a lot of things in the pipeline.

[Kit Collins]: Tonight, we are beginning our consideration, just the very beginning of the conversation on a new topic, which is the neighborhood residential topic.

[Kit Collins]: So before I turn it over to our zoning consultant, I just kind of want to orient us to the goal of this meeting, what we're gonna be looking at.

[Kit Collins]: This topic, which we're calling neighborhood residential, is just a jumping off place for adjusting the zoning rules for the areas of the city that are currently residential and zoned as single family one or single family two.

[Kit Collins]: There are districts like this throughout the city, as everybody knows, but they're especially concentrated in North Medford, West Medford, with some pockets in Glenwood, Wellington, and Hillsides.

[Kit Collins]: So why are we looking at SF1 and two districts now?

[Kit Collins]: You know, the same goals that carry us through the rest of the city for the rest of our zoning overhaul.

[Kit Collins]: We know that there are areas of the city where the zoning does not reflect what is currently built on the ground.

[Kit Collins]: We know that there are areas of the city where the zoning isn't allowing us to use our property or land the way that we know community members want us to, where it could better affirm our goals or where it could better affirm just what's already there.

[Kit Collins]: And we also know that we have a need to allow for more housing development in Medford to keep pace with high demand, high scarcity, and increasingly high property valuations.

[Kit Collins]: And zoning can offer tools to help us with all these problems.

[Kit Collins]: So with a lot of the current SF districts, we know we'll have to let geography and context guide the way.

[Kit Collins]: For example, in North Medford, narrow winding streets and steepness affect what is appropriate and possible.

[Kit Collins]: We also do have areas that are next to, for example, some brand new transit hubs, and it doesn't make sense to not take advantage of those areas of the city for greater density in a thoughtful way.

[Kit Collins]: So in just a minute, I'm going to turn it over to Paola from NS Associates for slides about what we're going to be considering tonight.

[Kit Collins]: This presentation

[Kit Collins]: will walk us through a jumping off point for considering some new neighborhood residential approaches and existing SF and GR.

[Kit Collins]: It also incorporates what new state law dictates around allowing ADUs by right in single family districts.

[Kit Collins]: So just to recenter on the goals for tonight before we get into the weeds, and I know that pal is also going to reorient us in kind of the where this falls in the overall trajectory of, you know, what topics have come before this and what topics will come after this.

[Kit Collins]: Tonight we're not looking at a proposal that we're going to be voting on or approving.

[Kit Collins]: This is to serve as a jumping-off point that's based on the current zoning of SF1 and 2 districts.

[Kit Collins]: We're very much not going to do this all in one fell swoop.

[Kit Collins]: My goals for tonight is for this to be councilors' chance to put their initial thoughts, concerns, questions, requests for changes on the record.

[Kit Collins]: Then we'll come back at our next meeting in two weeks, and as associates, we'll have taken all of that feedback and put together an amended proposal that we'll look at again before it is then referred for further review in more public meetings by the CDB.

[Kit Collins]: So at this point, I see President Bears has his hand up, and then I'll turn it over to Paula.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: All right, I will now recognize Paola.

[Kit Collins]: Thanks as always for being here.

[Kit Collins]: So I'm going to take your time.

[Kit Collins]: Is the screen frozen?

[Kit Collins]: Are you not able to share, Paola?

[Kit Collins]: Like, is it not reflecting what's on your screen?

[Kit Collins]: OK.

[Kit Collins]: I can share on my side if that is easier, but you'd have to tell me when to switch.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much for the presentation, Paola.

[Kit Collins]: Really appreciate it.

[Kit Collins]: I think that this gives us a pretty substantive jumping off point for talking about, you know, kind of the why and what next of developing amended zoning rules for these types of neighborhoods.

[Kit Collins]: new, more appropriate gradient from our most single-family, our most classic single-family lots, a lot of which will be kind of maintained exactly as they are.

[Kit Collins]: I think a lot of the zoning that currently exists makes sense.

[Kit Collins]: Maybe the terminology needs to be updated, but a lot of that will remain that way and has to remain that way, but we can affect the gradient from smallest, least dense up to the most dense parts of the city in a way that creates that range of housing that we know that we really need and kind of fill in some of those

[Kit Collins]: gaps where people need types of housing that aren't being built because they either can't be developed under our current zoning or we haven't encouraged it enough.

[Kit Collins]: broadcast and communicate well with the community to answer their questions easily and quickly so that people can know exactly what's going on, be informed, and ideally be as excited as we are about implementing the goals that the community put into the comprehensive plan.

[Kit Collins]: Just to quickly respond to a couple of those, and I know, sorry, we're not supposed to go back and forth, but just since you brought it up, on the linkage piece, I think that's a really reasonable question.

[Kit Collins]: I think that when we look at the zoning overhaul in totality,

[Kit Collins]: That issue becomes less because in some areas like the proposed NR1 districts, we're not encouraging developments that would be large enough to kick in the linkage fees.

[Kit Collins]: In other areas, for example, the places that are really close to the very, very high transit stations, we might be encouraging developments that would kick into the linkage fees.

[Kit Collins]: So I think it would have an equalizing effect, maybe not when we're just considering the neighborhood residential as a single project, but citywide,

[Kit Collins]: I know Councilor Leming, in particular, has been making sure that we're updating our linkage fees so that when we do create new zoning, especially along places like Mystic Ave, where we're encouraging big new developments, that they're gonna be paying their fair share and that their fair share is calculated correctly.

[Kit Collins]: And people who live here are struggling to stay here.

[Kit Collins]: People who want to live here, people who grew up here and want to buy a home, people who want to stay here are struggling to find housing to do so.

[Kit Collins]: And I know this is really just the tip of the iceberg of the advocacy that you're doing on behalf of not just your own families, but of the entire disability community.

[Kit Collins]: Every time you advocate for your own families and your own youth's outcomes, you're advocating for the entire community.

[Kit Collins]: So I'm very grateful to you for that and to the years of effort that have gone into this.

[Kit Collins]: It's like anything else, we fund what's important to us.

[Kit Collins]: So I look forward to continuing to work with the administration to make sure that we are putting dollars where they need to be for that to be the case.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: As you just noted, we took our first vote on this loan order on December 17.

[Kit Collins]: We had a committee of the whole to talk about it more in depth with climate planner Brenda Pike as well as Assistant Superintendent Cushing immediately before the 7pm meeting tonight to really go over it in detail and hear more about their extensive plans for how this will facilitate the

[Kit Collins]: repair of the McGlynn School roof and HVAC improvements at the Andrews and McGlynn.

[Kit Collins]: So this loan order would enable the funding for those roof repairs at the McGlynn and extensive HVAC at Andrews and McGlynn on a timeline that would enable the work to be completed.

[Kit Collins]: over summer vacation so that when middle schoolers return in the fall, they're doing so to buildings with repaired roofs and functioning AC and then heat in the winter.

[Kit Collins]: Really, really basic stuff that unfortunately has not been guaranteed to our middle schoolers for a long time because the HVAC has been in such dire need of repair.

[Kit Collins]: So very grateful to the hard work by those in MPS and the school department to

[Kit Collins]: to be aligned so that this funding could come together and that the work could be done on a timeline that would allow it to be completed over the summer with minimal disruptions to education.

[Kit Collins]: So I'd motion to approve for third reading.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: So the Community Control over Public Surveillance Ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: I'll give a super brief recap because this is the third reading.

[Kit Collins]: I don't wanna bore residents and Councilors who heard a very similar spiel on December 17th.

[Kit Collins]: The Community Control over Public Surveillance Ordinance or CCOPS for short, was workshopped extensively by the 2022 to 2023 City Council, the Mayor's Office and Chief Buckley over about a year and a half period that was following I think three years of advocacy.

[Kit Collins]: by civil liberties and privacy community advocates in the city of Medford, asking for such an ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: The point of this ordinance in a nutshell, is to protect privacy and civil liberties for Medford residents by creating a robust public process through which the community has a voice.

[Kit Collins]: in decisions about when and for what reasons surveillance technology will be used by the city and for what purpose.

[Kit Collins]: These are expensive and nascent technologies.

[Kit Collins]: It is no small thing for any city agency to use them.

[Kit Collins]: There are reasons to use them, but this is really important stuff.

[Kit Collins]: They're really expensive.

[Kit Collins]: They're really new.

[Kit Collins]: They're being aggressively marketed to communities such as ours.

[Kit Collins]: For that reason, I think it's incredibly important for the public to have a very structured, very defined, very transparent role in those discussions about if and when they should be used.

[Kit Collins]: And the CCOPS ordinance sets up that process.

[Kit Collins]: It sets up a reporting process so that the community and the city council can have an active role in those decisions.

[Kit Collins]: To that end,

[Kit Collins]: These tweaks are to fix some weaker areas or holes in the ordinance that were discovered in the first year or so of its implementation.

[Kit Collins]: It was passed in I think March of 2023.

[Kit Collins]: I guess that was two years ago now.

[Kit Collins]: And these are to fix those weaker points, which is, I think, a fairly normal thing to do for a new ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: We put it into practice.

[Kit Collins]: We see what's working really well.

[Kit Collins]: We see what we can shore up to make even stronger so that we can fulfill this ordinance's goal of maintaining really strong protections and public process for privacy and private data in Medford.

[Kit Collins]: And specifically, they resolve omissions dealing with how improperly collected data should be disposed of to maintain the same privacy protections and closes a loophole that would allow for surveillance data to be bought or sold from or to private or commercial entities.

[Kit Collins]: With that, I would motion to approve for three reading.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: I want to again thank Councilor Tseng and Councilor Leming for their work on this really important and positive ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: And I want to also thank all of the community advocates for pushing the City Council to do this, for insisting that we do this, for insisting that we be a City Council that stands up at the right time and says,

[Kit Collins]: our community really is for everybody, and we're going to make sure that our ordinances and our policies reflect that.

[Kit Collins]: I'm also proud that we're a city that can pass a welcoming city ordinance and have a change policy.

[Kit Collins]: Not at all, because we know from the conversations that the lead sponsors have had with administration and the chief of police that this is merely codifying the MPD's existing

[Kit Collins]: And I'm really proud that to pass a welcoming city ordinance actually changes our MPD policies, not one bit.

[Kit Collins]: That makes me feel proud of the public safety program that we do have in Medford.

[Kit Collins]: I think I, personally, I feel really touched by that.

[Kit Collins]: And I also feel really touched as a city council that the community has rallied around this to say at this moment, let's make sure that we're doing all that we can to make sure that Medford is a place that people can feel comfortable

[Kit Collins]: identifying as an immigrant, identifying as not being born here and still seeking out every public service that they're entitled to, including knowing that they can go to first responders, knowing that they can go to public safety officials, knowing that they can go to the MPD and be safe because they're not going to be asked about their immigration status.

[Kit Collins]: They're not going to be asked for their paperwork.

[Kit Collins]: And to know because it's broadcast, because it's codified as an ordinance, that we care about public safety.

[Kit Collins]: We care about putting our public dollars towards public safety.

[Kit Collins]: not about complying with the agendas of other states or with federal actors.

[Kit Collins]: We want to put our dollars towards public safety in our community.

[Kit Collins]: We mean that for everybody.

[Kit Collins]: So I am really excited to ordain this tonight.

[Kit Collins]: And again, I want to thank my fellow Councilors for working closely with the administration, including working closely, I know, with the chief of police on this.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much for being here, Teresa and Amanda on Zoom.

[Kit Collins]: just to echo what's already been said, shared sentiments, you know, obviously there's been so much work and effort and community input and staff effort poured into the car park renovation over many, many years at this point.

[Kit Collins]: So I'm really happy to see a unanimous recommendation come out of the CPC so that we can continue the good work of manifesting those goals and continuing the renovation project.

[Kit Collins]: So I'll be really happy to support this tonight and motion for approval after any other comments or questions from my fellow Councilors.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: I want to thank you so much for being here and for collaborating with Councilor Leming on this just really proactive, creative, common sense solution.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for being so willing to do your job, not just by the letter, but also creatively and do this kind of problem solving to utilize your existing resources to create just a really simple incentive.

[Kit Collins]: I'm really glad that we have a voice in City Hall, not just for

[Kit Collins]: veterans in general and housing veterans, but also for calling out and not being willing to speak directly to the stigma that veterans face in their housing search along with other areas of life.

[Kit Collins]: So really grateful to be able to vote on this tonight.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you again so much for your work.

[Kit Collins]: And also thank you, Councilor Leming, for putting this forward.

[Kit Collins]: And I would second the motion.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate the thorough discussion around this.

[Kit Collins]: We've heard a lot of concerns.

[Kit Collins]: We've also heard a lot of context from the mayor and members of the administration.

[Kit Collins]: I wanna thank the department heads for staying on the call quite late to be on hand to answer questions around this.

[Kit Collins]: Based on what I have learned so far and heard tonight, I'm not ready to endorse the wholesale return to the status quo.

[Kit Collins]: Some things I honestly find pretty shocking.

[Kit Collins]: I'm shocked to hear that a timesheet system wasn't in place for hourly employees.

[Kit Collins]: I'm really glad that's been fixed.

[Kit Collins]: It's probably about 30 years late.

[Kit Collins]: That's something that's for everybody's protection, employees included.

[Kit Collins]: Based on what I'm hearing, it's not clear to me that the new system is any less safe or more expensive, or that there's been cases where qualified decision makers haven't been available, or that it means less availability for qualified inspectors when they're needed.

[Kit Collins]: This sounds to me like a case of new best practices being promulgated by our new building commissioner.

[Kit Collins]: I am very grateful that there are contingencies for when Commissioner van der Waal isn't available to field calls, and I find it hard to get angry about

[Kit Collins]: former Commissioner 40 being paid $240 over the past year to be a knowledgeable backup.

[Kit Collins]: With that in mind, I'm gonna find it hard to vote yes on the paper as submitted this evening.

[Kit Collins]: I have a suggested amendment that I'd like to offer instead, or if the councilor is not amenable to it, I'll offer it as a B paper.

[Kit Collins]: I think that we've gotten some helpful info to serve as context for this issue tonight, and I think it'd be helpful to have it in writing.

[Kit Collins]: So that amendment or B paper.

[Kit Collins]: would be, whereas public safety is a priority for the City Council, be it resolved that the administration submit a report detailing new overtime policies within the building department, as well as a report on current policies relating to building department and fire department hierarchy of oversight and decision making on incidents involving building structures after business hours, along with written answers to Councilor Scarpelli's questions.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Sure.

[Kit Collins]: Yeah, I'll read it again.

[Kit Collins]: Whereas public safety is a priority for the city council, be it resolved that the administration support, submit a report detailing new overtime policies within the building department, as well as a report on current policies relating to building department and fire department hierarchy of oversight and decision-making on incidents involving building structures after business hours, along with written answers to your questions.

[Kit Collins]: Okay, I'll submit it as a B paper instead.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for considering.
