[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Well, zoning wasn't literally the only thing that we did in this committee, but it was overwhelmingly the work of this committee so far this year and will remain the case next year.

[Kit Collins]: We had, I honestly, I gave up on counting the number of zoning meetings that we had.

[Kit Collins]: I think President Bears might have the number.

[Kit Collins]: 16 so far.

[Kit Collins]: I would have guessed even higher.

[Kit Collins]: We began meeting with Innes Associates very, very close to the top of the year, initially kind of mapping out our work plan for the comprehensive review of the city's zoning ordinances.

[Kit Collins]: And that was kind of a project in and of itself, because we knew that we wanted to talk about some citywide zoning approaches, some tweaks that would affect

[Kit Collins]: the whole community, and that we also wanted to go neighborhood by neighborhood or geography by geography, as the zoning consultants often refer to it in their language of planning consultants, so that we could consider both, you know, on really a street-by-street, neighborhood-by-neighborhood level, what do we know that the community wants for this neighborhood based on all of the research and community feedback that we have gathered?

[Kit Collins]: in the past, and especially through projects like the comprehensive planning process?

[Kit Collins]: How do we make these more localized changes to manifest what we know people want?

[Kit Collins]: And then what are the changes that it makes sense to consider as a unit citywide, things around housing incentives,

[Kit Collins]: parking, et cetera.

[Kit Collins]: So breaking down how those pieces might work together so that we could get through all of our goals.

[Kit Collins]: We got our feet wet with some technical changes at the beginning of the year, updating our definitions, making some changes around site plan review that were really important on the city side.

[Kit Collins]: And one of my personal favorites, taking the vote so that the official zoning map of Medford is no longer paper and colored pencil, but an actual GIS digital file, which I think is

[Kit Collins]: pretty cool for 2024.

[Kit Collins]: Since then, in July, we really dove into kind of the meat of the project.

[Kit Collins]: We had a really cool mapping workshop

[Kit Collins]: in July, which I think set us up for our kind of geography by geography work that will carry us through June of 2025 or later.

[Kit Collins]: The zoning consultant prepared a lot of different kind of aerial views that showcase different characteristics around Medford.

[Kit Collins]: We looked at topography, we looked at flood zones, we looked at density, we looked at demography, we looked at traffic, so many different ways to think about what our places feel like and got a lot of interesting feedback there.

[Kit Collins]: We've been applying all of this to our geographies work.

[Kit Collins]: We started with the Mystic Ave Corridor District, which we just ordained last night.

[Kit Collins]: We had many, many meetings on that in committee.

[Kit Collins]: I went to City Council, I went to the Community Development Board, came back to the City Council last night, and it's been ordained.

[Kit Collins]: The Salem Street Corridor District was the next geography in the queue, and that one is about midway through.

[Kit Collins]: Well, a little bit more than midway.

[Kit Collins]: We've had a couple meetings about it in committee.

[Kit Collins]: It was just referred to the Community Development Board last night.

[Kit Collins]: They'll be holding public hearings on that as well.

[Kit Collins]: Abutters, I think, should be getting notices in mid-January.

[Kit Collins]: I know the planning staff is planning to send out those notices after Christmas so that doesn't get lost in Christmas mail.

[Kit Collins]: So there'll be more public hearings about the Salem Street Corrector District, and then I'll come back to the City Council.

[Kit Collins]: And towards the end of this year we've also been mapping out our plan for for what's next for what geographies, what neighborhoods will be turned to next, I don't have this memorized off the top of my head, but I'm pretty sure that at the beginning of the year, we will be looking at, I think we'll be turning to South Medford and hillsides.

[Kit Collins]: And then later in the year, we'll be turning our focus towards North Medford, West Medford, Wellington, Medford Square, not in that order.

[Kit Collins]: But we are going to make sure that we keep a pace so that we can do a really thorough review and update of the zoning in all of Medford's neighborhoods, and then kind of widen the scope again and consider those broader topics that we really want to not consider piece by piece, but think about the whole community in one discussion.

[Kit Collins]: So that's zoning where that's, you know, that's a three minute version of zoning.

[Kit Collins]: President Bears, would you mind scrolling down?

[Kit Collins]: I think there were a couple other ordinance projects that I wanted to, oh, right, sorry.

[Kit Collins]: Green score also subsumed within zoning.

[Kit Collins]: This was something that we reported out kind of in between Mystic Avenue Corridor District and Salem Street.

[Kit Collins]: This is one of those citywide strategies.

[Kit Collins]: Um, Greenscore is, in a nutshell, it's a rubric that, um, is comprised of our existing building development standards, you know, when you develop in Medford, you know, what, what you have to do, specifications that you need, um, to build by, to be acceptable, to be approved.

[Kit Collins]: Um, and it also encompasses some newer and more ambitious environmental standards.

[Kit Collins]: And it also includes, um, not just environmental standards, but also community amenities.

[Kit Collins]: So that we can be encouraging developers to be adding in more of the things that we want to see into their projects, things like sidewalk improvements, things like parks, things like shade, hydration stations, and rewarding them when they do add those amenities into their projects.

[Kit Collins]: And then I'll also mention transportation demand management is an ordinance that's been brought up by councillors Leming and saying so that we can kind of this is a policy where we're in we can take a holistic look at transportation options in the city and also in the region.

[Kit Collins]: and set up a community-wide policy to be making sure that as new development comes in, development options are streamlined and that we can be encouraging developers to help us further streamline and build our transportation system as they're adding to our built environment.

[Kit Collins]: If you'll scroll down just a bit, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: permitting and building related projects that I think could all cohere pretty well with the zoning work that we're doing, such as energy disclosure, benchmarking ordinance, which kind of go along with us trying to better work hand in hand with especially large developers to make sure that they're doing their part to help us know

[Kit Collins]: how we are doing at progressing towards our energy efficiency goals and our climate mitigation and adaptation goals and give us the data that we need to hold these large developers in these large buildings accountable.

[Kit Collins]: There was also the rental licensing ordinance referred into this committee.

[Kit Collins]: I think that this is a really valuable proposal that would help city staff do a lot of the work that we're talking about when it comes to making sure that we're having good communication with property owners in the city so that we can be working together on everything from energy efficiency to retrofits to making sure that tenants are getting the information that they need from the city.

[Kit Collins]: So we haven't had a chance to work on this in committee yet, but I'm hopeful that we will.

[Kit Collins]: I know this is important to many folks in the community, as well as blasting and earth removal regulations, which I think the goal of that would be to prohibit future Winthrop Street style disturbances where developers are able to do really loud, disruptive earth removal and blasting without a lot of controls on the city side.

[Kit Collins]: Obviously, so much skill so much knowledge so much experience to run the library and she's been doing this for four decades and she's made sure that our library remains contemporary over the years and she really fought to make sure that we can now enjoy a public modern contemporary public library and.

[Kit Collins]: You know, some people know really well just how, just how much hard work and advocacy and how many risks it took to make it the incredible, you know, really model library that it is today.

[Kit Collins]: the education that Medford Public Schools offers.

[Kit Collins]: Because I do understand, you know, I think anybody who has any passing familiarity with projects of this scale, you know, I know that we have a really tight timeframe that you're trying to get this done in so that these improvements are up and running for the beginning.

[Kit Collins]: of the next school year.

[Kit Collins]: And if we miss that window, that manifests in unhappy students and unhappy educators and unhappy families.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Before we vote.

[Kit Collins]: to make clear just because of the way that it's being talked about.

[Kit Collins]: This is a request for a loan order for $5 million.

[Kit Collins]: I don't want people to come away with the impression that the city is, after this vote, writing a check for $5 million.

[Kit Collins]: That's not the case.

[Kit Collins]: The loan order, you know, this is a process that we very, very, very commonly use for large capital expenses like this.

[Kit Collins]: This is normal to take out a loan order for this.

[Kit Collins]: It's like the way this is normally done.

[Kit Collins]: We're not just writing a check from some

[Kit Collins]: city checking account.

[Kit Collins]: That's not how this works.

[Kit Collins]: Um, and I just, you know, I've had so many conversations with constituents about heating and cooling in MPS buildings for so many years that I really would be remiss to not just affirm that this is not a new project.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: illicit, fraudulent buyout going on, I think that this is normal.

[Kit Collins]: Correct.

[Kit Collins]: Yes.

[Kit Collins]: Great.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: And I do appreciate the discussion, the clarity around the noticing.

[Kit Collins]: I think especially with these zoning ordinances, I think the process is clear, but it's complicated.

[Kit Collins]: It's one of those things that is wonky and technical and it has to procedurally, legally, it must kind of go from body to body.

[Kit Collins]: So I think it's really understandable that, you know, there's for

[Kit Collins]: folks who aren't intimately familiar with the zoning referral process.

[Kit Collins]: It's not intuitive, and that makes a lot of sense.

[Kit Collins]: And due to, you know, continued collaboration, especially between members of the planning and permitting committee,

[Kit Collins]: We're kind of continually trying to make sure that we're messaging these meetings ever better and making it easier for folks to know where we are in the process and I think that this is an easy thing that we can add to kind of the increased levels of communication and flyering that we're doing around our ongoing zoning work just to try and do what we can to make this important, technical, complicated, you know, very interesting process a little more legible for

[Kit Collins]: just regular folks in the community.

[Kit Collins]: Having said that, just if you'll indulge me for just a little bit of retrospective before I make a motion, really excited that Mystic Avenue Corridor District zoning proposal has come back to the City Council tonight.

[Kit Collins]: It's taken, you know, as with any zoning proposal, it's taken a thorough and storied road to get here.

[Kit Collins]: We had a mapping workshop back in July.

[Kit Collins]: We decided that Mystic Avenue Corridor District was going to be one of the first things that we took a deep dive into because, you know, between our housing production plan, between our comprehensive plan, from so many comments that me and my colleagues have received from constituents over the years talking about just, it's so visible, I think for so many people, the untapped potential on Mystic Ave.

[Kit Collins]: I think that the kind of, there was a very clear vision for how we could do more.

[Kit Collins]: even more with this really valuable property in Medford and Leverage.

[Kit Collins]: It's a transit corridor.

[Kit Collins]: There's some really big lots.

[Kit Collins]: It's good for a lot of things and we should be doing more with it.

[Kit Collins]: This council has been really focused on doing what we can to try and set the stage for more commercial development so that we are building our commercial tax base as much as possible and having that trickle into things like schools and roads and public services.

[Kit Collins]: So we began our discussions of the Mystic Avenue Corridor District in August.

[Kit Collins]: We workshopped it for a couple months with city staff, with our zoning consultant in committee, receiving feedback from the community.

[Kit Collins]: We looked at a lot of different options.

[Kit Collins]: We took in feedback.

[Kit Collins]: We made tweaks after committee.

[Kit Collins]: It was referred to the Community Development Board.

[Kit Collins]: It came back to us tonight with some recommendations to just further tweak it and make it

[Kit Collins]: more legible for developers, make more sense, be easier to understand, and just be easier to achieve some of the requirements, incentives that we're really hoping that developers will take us up on on Mystic App, so that we'll both get great development along Mystic App that's in the line of what the community really wants to see there, but is also, you know, simple and clear enough that

[Kit Collins]: People can look at it.

[Kit Collins]: Residents can look at it and developers can look at and say, OK, it's obvious to me what they want.

[Kit Collins]: It's obvious to me how to meet these requirements so that we can partner with the city to do more on this to have.

[Kit Collins]: Having said that, I think, you know, happy to have more of a discussion on the specific amendments that the CD board is recommending that we adopt tonight.

[Kit Collins]: They are in our packets.

[Kit Collins]: I think they're pretty straightforward and intuitive tweaks, but I would motion to approve for first reading the Mystic Avenue Corridor District zoning proposal and adopt the recommended amendments.

[Kit Collins]: by the Community Development Board, as well as to change the special permit granting authority on cannabis uses to the ZBA and to change the special permit granting authority on adult uses to the City Council to maintain consistency with the rest of the zoning ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much.

[Kit Collins]: I'll keep it brief.

[Kit Collins]: I have a lot to say about this proposal.

[Kit Collins]: I'm really proud of it, really grateful to all of the staff, the Planning, Development and Sustainability Office that worked on it with us and the zoning consultant and continues to work on it with us and really laid the groundwork for this and other zoning proposals with work in the community over the course of years to really gather the information and the desires from the community that inform

[Kit Collins]: what we're doing here, what we know that people want to see around Medford, and how to articulate that in the, yes, rather sterile, but incredibly impactful language of zoning, which when you look at the proposals, looks, you know, if you were like me, not a zoning lawyer, it looks like nothing at first.

[Kit Collins]: But if you're one of those people who wants to know more and wants to know how our community values, or just you know what you want to see in your community is showing up in the zoning proposals I really do implore you to join us at our planning and permitting committee meetings where this work will be will continue throughout the rest of the fiscal year and possibly beyond that.

[Kit Collins]: We usually meet twice a month.

[Kit Collins]: Please do join us.

[Kit Collins]: I also, and I'm sorry, but just a really minor point.

[Kit Collins]: In the commercial district, you could apply for a special permit through the CDB.

[Kit Collins]: So just a, I believe a very minor fact check to round out this agenda item.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for indulging me.

[Kit Collins]: And with that, I would move the question.

[Kit Collins]: Well, I was gonna make a motion that might supersede the poll that you're about to take.

[Kit Collins]: Great, I'll move to suspend the rules to take 23055 and 24502.

[Kit Collins]: On the motion to suspend to take 23055 and 24502 by Vice President Collins, seconded by Councilor Tseng.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: I want to first start by thanking the community members that have been advocating this for a very long time, and then Councilors Tseng and Leming for leading on this.

[Kit Collins]: To me, what this ordinance project says is the city's existing policy of non-cooperation with federal ICE agents is so good and makes so much sense and is so common sense that we should enshrine that as a city ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: And I just agree with that wholeheartedly.

[Kit Collins]: To me, what this says is we want to protect Medford resources for the purpose of taking care of Medford residents, not for carrying out orders or agendas that were promulgated somewhere far away from here, not in our community.

[Kit Collins]: Our resources, our personnel, the expertise and the time of our public safety officials, people doing that work in our community, that should be for us, not for a national agenda.

[Kit Collins]: and not for the agenda of any other state or entity.

[Kit Collins]: So for that reason, I think it's really the right time.

[Kit Collins]: I think any time would be a good time to enshrine that existing policy as an ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: I think this is, I think the moment is now.

[Kit Collins]: I'm really proud of my fellow Councilors for putting this together and making sure that

[Kit Collins]: you know, this policy that the current administration and city staff and public safety officers have been doing just because it's the right thing to do.

[Kit Collins]: And it was obviously the right policy to have that we can make sure that that is protected for the future, come what may.

[Kit Collins]: With that, I'd motion to approve for our first reading.

[Kit Collins]: Yeah, I'm sorry.

[Kit Collins]: I lost track of the 5013C.

[Kit Collins]: Sorry, couldn't hear that.

[Kit Collins]: I'll just finish my sentence.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I'd be happy to make the motion to approve

[Kit Collins]: Sorry, late.

[Kit Collins]: Take a vote for approved for first reading with the amendments presented tonight adopted with the exception of that one amendment that Councilor Leming knows the number of.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears genuinely appreciate all the discussion around this item I'm glad that we're putting in the work to get this done this month I think this really is urgent I'm really proud of us for doing the hard work to move this from policy to an ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: Um, I'd like to move the question.

[Kit Collins]: I also did just want to note just just again for the record that undocumented immigrants like do have tax ID numbers.

[Kit Collins]: So, um, you know, that's just wanted to correct the record on that.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I move the question.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: I'm going to try to keep this brief, but I do think that this project, like any other ordinance, benefits from just a teeny bit of exposition.

[Kit Collins]: So let me just orient these proposed amendments in the context of this ordinance and how long it's been on the books.

[Kit Collins]: These proposed amendments are tweaks to the Community Control over Public Surveillance Ordinance, which was passed by the City Council

[Kit Collins]: in March of 2023, and the amendments are proposed to make sure that the ordinance does a better job of reflecting its original intent.

[Kit Collins]: So this ordinance was worked on in City Council from 2022 to 2023.

[Kit Collins]: It was collaborated on

[Kit Collins]: by city councilors, residents, city staff.

[Kit Collins]: The police chief was present with us at many, many subcommittee meetings throughout the process of crafting us.

[Kit Collins]: We had sit downs in subcommittee with the mayor, chief of staff, and the chief of police was really grateful to them for putting so much time and conversation into this ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: It's not in a way, it's really simple.

[Kit Collins]: In another way, there was a lot to talk about, and I'm really grateful for them for doing that work with us over the course of months, which was predated by literally years of advocacy for such an ordinance by residents in the community.

[Kit Collins]: So what is the Community Control over Public Surveillance Ordinance?

[Kit Collins]: This is an ordinance that is in no way unique to Medford.

[Kit Collins]: They've been passed in many communities around Massachusetts and elsewhere throughout the country.

[Kit Collins]: They provide a way for local communities to have oversight over what surveillance technologies may be used by our municipal governments.

[Kit Collins]: They empower city councils and through the venue of the council, the public, to essentially ask the questions, why does the city want to use surveillance technology in our community?

[Kit Collins]: What problem is this supposed to solve?

[Kit Collins]: How will it solve it?

[Kit Collins]: How will it help?

[Kit Collins]: What are the potential risks?

[Kit Collins]: What are the costs?

[Kit Collins]: The City Council may then through the ordinance make a determination of whether the benefits outweigh the potential costs and whether to improve the technology or that use of surveillance data.

[Kit Collins]: Or not, or you know potentially condition it or put certain stipulations on it, etc.

[Kit Collins]: It creates a forum to have these discussions over this extremely new rapidly proliferating

[Kit Collins]: form of technology that has known, demonstrated, documented bad implications for civil liberties, for privacy, especially for marginalized populations, but not only for marginalized populations.

[Kit Collins]: creates a way for the community to have more of a listening ear and more of a voice in these conversations that often have to do with incredibly expensive things that cities are being lobbied to purchase from private corporations.

[Kit Collins]: A lot of these technologies are being very, very aggressively marketed to municipalities like ours by the corporations that develop them.

[Kit Collins]: And, you know, as one Councilor my goal with this ordinance is to make sure that in in one year and five year and 25 years, we're still spending public dollars on things that actually truly help Medford's public safety, more than they enrich the bottom lines of technology corporations.

[Kit Collins]: So that's, that's the briefest overview I can give, but if anybody wants to talk at length about surveillance technology and civil liberties with me hit me up.

[Kit Collins]: The amendments that we're putting forward tonight that we workshopped in community that came from suggestions, sorry, that we workshopped in committee.

[Kit Collins]: that came out of suggestions from the community.

[Kit Collins]: These are two amendments that just constitute two ways that we can further tighten up this ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: I also want to note just again for background, it's not at all unusual to return to a fairly recent ordinance or an old one and make amendments to it.

[Kit Collins]: We did this with our kind of technical zoning tweaks over the past couple years after we put forward some like technical amendments, we put them into use and that putting it into use alerted us to things that

[Kit Collins]: We're having unintended consequences.

[Kit Collins]: So we go back and you know now that we've like put it on the road a little bit we go back and fix it, tighten the screws.

[Kit Collins]: I see that as being part of this process, making amendments that help us to better embody the original intent of the ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: So there are two sections that I'm proposing changes to tonight that we worked on in public health and community safety committee that was circulated to Councilors.

[Kit Collins]: The proposed addition to section 5079, which covers enforcement, remedies, penalties, and whistleblower protections.

[Kit Collins]: That is to, that's additional language.

[Kit Collins]: That says, I read this all out of the committee meeting last week.

[Kit Collins]: To the extent permitted by law, including but not limited to, the requirements of the Massachusetts Public Records Law or the Municipal Records Retention Schedule, any video footage or other data recorded or obtained illegally or in violation of this ordinance shall be immediately destroyed and not introduced as evidence in any criminal or civil proceeding, except in those proceedings related to violations of this ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: What's the point of that?

[Kit Collins]: I think, yeah, I think that is comprised within it.

[Kit Collins]: I can go faster, but I can.

[Kit Collins]: So you can just say that.

[Kit Collins]: Section 59, there is an oversight in the original ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: It states how surveillance data can and cannot be used.

[Kit Collins]: It doesn't say what happens if we find ourselves having surveillance data that we oughtn't.

[Kit Collins]: This says it's got to be deleted.

[Kit Collins]: Similar to how if evidence is obtained without a warrant, it can't be used in a trial, the similar principle.

[Kit Collins]: In Section 5080, this covers

[Kit Collins]: uh, contracts that might result in surveillance data being generated elsewhere, being used by a municipality.

[Kit Collins]: Um, this is to remove an exception, um, that bulk commercially generated surveillance data may be used if it's in service of law enforcement.

[Kit Collins]: Um, it's, it's still being wrestled with by state and federal courts, um, if it's constitutional for this to happen at all.

[Kit Collins]: But by removing this exception, we're just making this section consistent with the intent of the rest of the ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: No carve-outs, just one process.

[Kit Collins]: If we're going to use surveillance tech or surveillance data, it's going to be subject to a public process.

[Kit Collins]: And I do have one really small tweak to make to the section in 5080 that is really just a semantic change.

[Kit Collins]: But I can, well, I'll just say it now.

[Kit Collins]: The change to 5080 would be to strike the word bulk.

[Kit Collins]: That appears bulk surveillance data.

[Kit Collins]: We don't need the word bulk.

[Kit Collins]: We're going to strike that.

[Kit Collins]: And I would also add the phrase or any information derived from such data after the words surveillance data.

[Kit Collins]: In the first sentence and then in the last sentence, which is an addition.

[Kit Collins]: Same change.

[Kit Collins]: It's just to clarify that we're talking about both surveillance data or any information that might be derived from such data.

[Kit Collins]: And I will email that to the clerk right now.

[Kit Collins]: I would motion to, after consideration by my fellow councillors, I would motion to approve for first reading.

[Kit Collins]: A couple points to clarify.

[Kit Collins]: One, I didn't state that the chief wasn't involved.

[Kit Collins]: I reached out to him.

[Kit Collins]: He didn't respond.

[Kit Collins]: I know he's a busy guy.

[Kit Collins]: We involved him every step of the way when the 99.9% of the ordinance that isn't changing was crafted between 2022 and 2023.

[Kit Collins]: And another thing that I do remember specifically from those months of meetings in the previous term was that the chief repeatedly emphasized that the city of Medford currently does not have a practice of purchasing surveillance data targeted or in bulk, and also has no plans to do so in the future.

[Kit Collins]: So this would have, unless that is no longer correct or wasn't correct at the time, this would have no impact on the work of public safety in our community.

[Kit Collins]: All right, paper 24513 offered by President Bears's resolution to request changes to propose Tufts Dormitory Project.

[Kit Collins]: Whereas Tufts University has proposed a new dormitory project at 401 Boston Ave, and whereas the City Council strongly supports legislative efforts to pass fairer state laws

[Kit Collins]: to encourage collaboration and partnership between large nonprofit institutions like Tufts and municipalities like Medford, and whereas the City Council also strongly supports the goal and intent of providing significant additional on-campus housing by Tufts, and whereas the City Council thanks area residents for voicing their concerns and attempting to have more robust and collaborative public input on the Tufts dormitory proposal, and whereas the City Council does not have a decision-making role regarding this project,

[Kit Collins]: Now therefore be it resolved by the Medford City Council that we request that Tufts University use an alternative site plan or add another site to the project to reduce height and impact of shadows on the surrounding neighborhood while also increasing the tree canopy and adding additional streetscape improvements to their project.

[Kit Collins]: be it further resolved that we request that Tufts University drop opposition to and or state their support for state legislation to implement the Institutional Master Plan Home Rule petitions proposed for nearly a decade by the cities of Medford and Somerville and state legislation to create a mandatory pilot payment in lieu of taxes law for large educational and medical nonprofit institutions.

[Kit Collins]: Be it further resolved that we thank the Community Development Board and our city staff team for their work as this proposal moves through the public process.

[Kit Collins]: President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: I'll go next to Councilor Tseng and then Councilor Scarpelli.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Councilor Sheng.

[Kit Collins]: Seeing no additional public comment on zoom or in the chambers.

[Kit Collins]: Is there any additional comment by city councilors?

[Kit Collins]: I would just say for myself as one Councilor, I am a staunch proponent of Tufts working to take more responsibility for housing the students that it enrolls.

[Kit Collins]: And I very much resent this process, which has led so many neighbors and abutters feeling so left out and unconsidered in this process.

[Kit Collins]: I think we're all aware that Tufts is a very large, very wealthy institution, and there are many ways to solve this problem of needing to house more students on campus.

[Kit Collins]: On the motion of President Bears, seconded by Councilor Callahan, Mr. Clerk, when you're ready, please call the roll.

[Kit Collins]: Yes.

[Kit Collins]: Seven in favor, none opposed.

[Kit Collins]: The resolution passes.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much to all the constituents who wait on us.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: I want to restate the timeline that you just laid out.

[Kit Collins]: And this is really just a midway point in the process.

[Kit Collins]: We'll go to the Community Development Board for public hearings.

[Kit Collins]: They will promulgate recommendations.

[Kit Collins]: We will hear those before the City Council again before we take a vote.

[Kit Collins]: So I have a motion to refer this to the Community Development Board.

[Kit Collins]: Sorry, motion to refer this to the Community Development Board.

[Kit Collins]: Oh, sorry, my mic was on before.

[Kit Collins]: I'm not sure if logistically it'll be possible to have a CDB meeting or a city council regular meeting at the Roberts School, but I think it's in the spirit of making sure that we're continuing to improve our efforts of involving local abutters and neighbors in the process.

[Kit Collins]: The meeting is called to order.

[Kit Collins]: The action discussion item for this meeting is once again 24-033 zoning ordinance updates with the Innes Associates team.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much for being here.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, City staff for being here.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you to members of the public for joining us.

[Kit Collins]: This is, I believe, the 16th, the agenda says, the 16th Zoning Updates Project Meeting with Innes Associates.

[Kit Collins]: This week we are again talking about the Salem Street Corridor Zoning Proposal discussion.

[Kit Collins]: We touched on this topic last week, last Tuesday as well.

[Kit Collins]: Really glad to be talking about this with you all again.

[Kit Collins]: I'm just going to briefly reintroduce this specific topic and then I'll hand it over to

[Kit Collins]: and we'll have a presentation by Innes Associates and commentary by city staff, and then we'll proceed with our discussion.

[Kit Collins]: But just to quickly reintroduce what we're talking about today, this is our second time having a full meeting devoted to the Salem Street Corridor District.

[Kit Collins]: This is just one part of the City Council's systemic review and update of citywide zoning over the course of this term.

[Kit Collins]: We've been working with Innes Associates, thank you for being here, which also assisted the city on the years-long comprehensive plan process.

[Kit Collins]: So this corridor proposal, like other aspects of the zoning project, have been crafted by Ennis in consultation with, oh, thank you for letting me know.

[Kit Collins]: So these zoning proposals crafted by the zoning consultant in consultation with this committee and city staff, all of these are guided by citywide goals and community feedback as articulated in the comprehensive plan, the housing production plan, the climate action and adaptation plan.

[Kit Collins]: and the community input and feedback that we're very fortunate to have throughout this process.

[Kit Collins]: And just because I take every opportunity to say this, after these proposals leave this committee, they go back to the city council, they then are procedurally must be referred to the community development board for their review and recommendations, and then come back to the city council once again, before those votes to ordain are taken.

[Kit Collins]: It's a complicated process, so I like to repeat it as often as possible, because I know it took me a while to internalize it.

[Kit Collins]: So like I said, the initial draft of the Salem Street corridor zoning proposal was presented to this committee on December 3rd for some initial feedback, questions and comments.

[Kit Collins]: The project proposes new zoning for the corridor along Salem Street, which includes the roughly two to four parcels extending north and south of Salem Street, beginning at the Route 60 roundabout and extending up to Haines Square.

[Kit Collins]: So this proposal does not include the greater Salem Street neighborhood outside of those boundaries, though of course it does touch them and is adjacent to them.

[Kit Collins]: for getting further into the weeds than that.

[Kit Collins]: I will pass it off to Innes Associates for a presentation, which I understand we saw a really similar presentation to this last week, but I think you're going to highlight some of the tweaks and changes that have been incorporated since last week based on feedback that we got from the community as well as feedback from councilors and city staff.

[Kit Collins]: Before I turn it over, any initial comments or questions from councilors?

[Kit Collins]: Okay, great.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: like councillors are for the first time as some members of the public, maybe.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you very much.

[Kit Collins]: And I think the way it was phrased in the suggestion, the way you phrased it just now, that we're doing this in a geography by geography basis, knowing that all of these geographies are really close together and the changes we make in one neighborhood will affect, they all affect the context.

[Kit Collins]: So I think it can make a lot of sense when we do visit Medford Square in a couple of months.

[Kit Collins]: think about these questions of where we know we need density, where does it make the most sense where should we do that, where should we prioritize for densification or any of the other goals that we have.

[Kit Collins]: This is kind of like the most unique lot on the corridor I think and I'm just wondering if we can while that window is open if we can continue if there's any other sub districts that we could carry in from the MACD so that we can capture all of those goals on this one very unique lot the ground floor commercial the residential and

[Kit Collins]: We have the benefit here of a lot of space, which isn't present elsewhere on the corridor.

[Kit Collins]: Do I hear a motion?

[Kit Collins]: On the motion by Councilor Leming to report out of committee, seconded by Councilor Callahan.

[Kit Collins]: Roll call votes, no longer necessary.

[Kit Collins]: All in favor?

[Kit Collins]: Motion to adjourn by Councilor Callahan, seconded by Councilor Leming.

[Kit Collins]: All in favor?

[Kit Collins]: All opposed.

[Kit Collins]: Meeting is adjourned.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much for being with us.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, city staff.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Ennis, for this proposal and for continuing to workshop it with us and to continue to take in our feedback and the feedback for the community.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Great.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much, Chair Lazzaro.

[Kit Collins]: So I'm the sponsor of these technical amendments to the CCOPS ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: I thought I would just start with a little bit of a background.

[Kit Collins]: Can folks hear me?

[Kit Collins]: Okay, great.

[Kit Collins]: Just thought I would start with a little bit of a background on the CCOPS ordinance because this was passed in the previous term.

[Kit Collins]: when some members of the Council were not yet part of the Council.

[Kit Collins]: So just as a super quick background, this is an ordinance that the City Council worked on between 2022 and 2023.

[Kit Collins]: I think it was being workshopped by constituents for a long time before that, but that's when it was on the Council's plate and being worked on in committee.

[Kit Collins]: We collaborated with residents, the public health and community safety committee at that time, city staff, the chief of police to create it.

[Kit Collins]: And it passed about a year and a half ago, maybe a little bit more now in 2023.

[Kit Collins]: So this ordinance stands for community control over public surveillance.

[Kit Collins]: In a nutshell, this is a way that provides for local communities to have oversight over what surveillance technologies and data may be used by different branches of their municipal government.

[Kit Collins]: It's a structure that is not unique to Medford.

[Kit Collins]: It's been passed in a lot of other communities and including other communities in Massachusetts that empower communities through the city council to ask to have an opportunity to ask the questions.

[Kit Collins]: Why do we want to use the surveillance technology in our city?

[Kit Collins]: To what ends?

[Kit Collins]: What are the proposed benefits?

[Kit Collins]: What problem is this supposed to solve?

[Kit Collins]: Will it cost us how much?

[Kit Collins]: What are the possible negative effects?

[Kit Collins]: And to be able to ask those questions and have those conversations and weigh those pros and cons.

[Kit Collins]: in public transparently.

[Kit Collins]: So I think this was a really big win for the community when we passed this last year, because that was the city being proactive and responding to residents who said, hey, we have a privacy and civil liberties concern around these surveillance technologies proliferating.

[Kit Collins]: Wow, proliferating.

[Kit Collins]: Damn, I gotta stop talking.

[Kit Collins]: Responding to this very real perceived danger, because we know the effects that surveillance technologies have, we know the dangers that they pose, we know the dangers that they really have posed in other communities around the U.S.

[Kit Collins]: and around the world, and to proactively say, before these take root in our community, let's set up a public, transparent process for us to have that conversation.

[Kit Collins]: in public.

[Kit Collins]: So that's the CCOPS ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: It's been on the books for about a year and a half.

[Kit Collins]: And at this point, some community advocates have come forward with ideas for how to strengthen the ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: And I also just want to say that it's not unusual for us to do this.

[Kit Collins]: It's not unusual for us to go back to an ordinance that either maybe was passed a long time ago or that was a recently

[Kit Collins]: added or updated and say now that this has been in play for a little bit, that implementation has shown us some cracks that we can go back and fill.

[Kit Collins]: We did this recently.

[Kit Collins]: The zoning recodification that was done before I was a part of the council two terms ago.

[Kit Collins]: when those zoning tweaks were put into effect, that gave the planning staff the opportunity to say, now that we've put this into practice, now that we're working with this, we've actually noticed a couple of things that we missed, that were misstated, that we should just go back and fix so that this works the way that we mean it to.

[Kit Collins]: So this is just part of our legislative process as I see it to say, now that we've got the wheels on this thing, we can see it in motion, we can see what we wanna tweak so that it actually operates the way that we always intended it to.

[Kit Collins]: So if I may go on, that brings us to the two suggestions from the community on how to tighten this up.

[Kit Collins]: And I am happy to just go through and walk us through those two technical amendments unless other councilors want to cut in first with questions or comments or anything else.

[Kit Collins]: Let me just get my windows in order.

[Kit Collins]: All right.

[Kit Collins]: Okay, that seems to be working.

[Kit Collins]: I also wanna note if folks are looking for the full ordinance, the ordinance that was passed in 2023, that is on Muny Code.

[Kit Collins]: It's in the municipal documents section, not in the code of ordinances.

[Kit Collins]: That's because we just have a bit of a backlog with getting past ordinances uploaded into Muny Code.

[Kit Collins]: So it's up there, it's under municipal documents.

[Kit Collins]: Yep.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Okay.

[Kit Collins]: So I'm just going to quickly walk us through the two proposed changes to the ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: So the first one, this would be in addition to section 5079, and that's the section that goes over enforcement, remedies, penalties, and whistleblower protections.

[Kit Collins]: Actually, let me just quickly scroll up to that section so that we can kind of

[Kit Collins]: ground ourselves in context, not going to read the whole thing.

[Kit Collins]: But this is the set, this is the ordinance that's currently on the books.

[Kit Collins]: So this essentially says who enforces this ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: The mayor's office or the mayor's designee edges the case with all of ordinances, essentially.

[Kit Collins]: If violations occur.

[Kit Collins]: What then, if violations are reported, what then protections for whistleblowers so that people are empowered to speak up if they think the ordinance is being violated?

[Kit Collins]: And nothing in this ordinance shall be conscrued to limit or affect any individual's rights under state or federal laws.

[Kit Collins]: That's the section currently.

[Kit Collins]: The proposed addition reads any video footage or other data recorded or obtained illegally or in violation of this ordinance shall be immediately destroyed and not introduced as evidence in any criminal or civil proceeding, except in those proceedings related to violations of this ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: So just to explain that, this proposed tweak is to essentially fix an oversight.

[Kit Collins]: The original ordinance in its many sections states how surveillance data may and may not be used, but the penalties are for not adhering to use of surveillance technology or data throughout the ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: But what it is silent on is what should happen to surveillance data that is obtained outside the bounds of the ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: So this tweak is to say, you know, any surveillance data that is gathered in a way that does not conform to the regulations put forth in the ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: If we didn't, for example, if we didn't approve a surveillance technology, that technology went into use anyway.

[Kit Collins]: It was used to protect, it was used to collect people's private data.

[Kit Collins]: And then we realized that we're like, oh, sorry, that should never have been in use.

[Kit Collins]: We never got permission to use that.

[Kit Collins]: What happens to that data?

[Kit Collins]: Well, it shouldn't be kept around because that could compromise people's privacy.

[Kit Collins]: It should be deleted.

[Kit Collins]: It should be destroyed.

[Kit Collins]: This is kind of, to me, I'm not a lawyer, but this sounds to me like a similar concept to how if an agency were ever to obtain evidence without a warrant, that evidence can't be used because it was obtained illegally.

[Kit Collins]: We did pass these proposed amendments to legal prior to this meeting.

[Kit Collins]: Legal counsel brought up that some municipal data must be maintained according to public records law.

[Kit Collins]: I believe the public records law would supersede this ordinance in any case, but I do have a little bit of extra language to propose just to make that point really clear.

[Kit Collins]: I'll pause there.

[Kit Collins]: Great.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for, yeah, thank you for that point.

[Kit Collins]: This is something that I'm glad you brought that up.

[Kit Collins]: This is something that we

[Kit Collins]: that like understandably was raised when we were going over the ordinance the first time around, because of the you know there's there's ring and nest cameras you know everywhere everywhere everywhere you look people have that kind of technology now.

[Kit Collins]: I think we can certainly look at making that clear.

[Kit Collins]: I think elsewhere in the ordinance, we took pains to make it clear that we're talking just about surveillance technology that's used by the city, surveillance data collected by the city.

[Kit Collins]: And explicitly, this is not about surveillance technology that people might be using.

[Kit Collins]: to surveil their own private property on their own private property.

[Kit Collins]: So I think that's been made pretty clear.

[Kit Collins]: I don't wanna, my only hesitation is if we start adding clarifications in specific sections, I don't want people to then say, oh, so this doesn't affect my nest camera, but what about this other part?

[Kit Collins]: That would be my only concern with adding language somewhere in addition to what's kind of at the top of the ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: Yeah, I think that's a good question.

[Kit Collins]: I feel pretty comfortable that the ordinance throughout is, in the language, very targeted at municipal use of surveillance technology and surveillance data.

[Kit Collins]: I'm doing a, as you can see, because I'm still screen sharing, I'm kind of scrolling through the sections, and I feel pretty comfortable with how the language, you know, it's talking about municipal use,

[Kit Collins]: Um, so for myself, I don't feel the need to add a disclaimers at this time, but I think it's, um, I'll pass it back to Councilor Callahan.

[Kit Collins]: Yes.

[Kit Collins]: This proposed addition, yeah, all the stuff that we're going to talk about tonight has been reviewed, was reviewed by legal this past week.

[Kit Collins]: Yeah.

[Kit Collins]: And they had a couple of small amendments that I'll mention as well and can put on the screen.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: So just while we're on this, while we're on this section, this proposed addition, the comment from legal counsel on this section specifically, which just came in earlier today,

[Kit Collins]: was, again, just to many of the comments that we received when we were working on the initial ordinance was to say, we want to make really sure that this comports with state and federal law, to which, to be totally candid, my response is usually, of course it does.

[Kit Collins]: State and federal law supersedes city ordinances by definition.

[Kit Collins]: But I also don't think that it changes the intent or impact of the city ordinance to add some of the language or version of the language that was proposed, which would be to add

[Kit Collins]: to the extent permitted by law, including but not limited to the requirements of the Massachusetts public records law, the municipal records retention schedule, et cetera, any video footage or other data recorded or obtained illegally or in violation of this ordinance shall be immediately destroyed and not introduced as evidence in any criminal or civil proceeding except in those proceedings related to violations of this ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: because that's essentially stating what should go without saying, but doesn't because we don't all have GDs.

[Kit Collins]: So that would be one addition that I would propose for this, in addition to the addition.

[Kit Collins]: Let me see if I can.

[Kit Collins]: Or maybe an email.

[Kit Collins]: I'll repeat it, and I'll also email it to the clerk.

[Kit Collins]: Great.

[Kit Collins]: Of course, I can't copy over from a Word document.

[Kit Collins]: I will email it to the clerk.

[Kit Collins]: The change would be proceeding the language that's on the screen, it would say to the extent permitted by law, including but not limited to the requirements of the Massachusetts public records law and the municipal records retention schedule.

[Kit Collins]: And then proceed with that paragraph.

[Kit Collins]: So this change again.

[Kit Collins]: Let me scroll up here just so we can

[Kit Collins]: Look at the original.

[Kit Collins]: Section 5080, well, I mean, it's what we're looking at.

[Kit Collins]: This is the entirety of Section 5080 currently.

[Kit Collins]: Current title is certain public-private contracts prohibited.

[Kit Collins]: Just one paragraph.

[Kit Collins]: So my proposed change would be to keep the first section.

[Kit Collins]: It shall be unlawful for the city to enter into any contract for monetary value or engage in any financial transaction with a commercial entity that provides the city with the mass acquisition of privately generated and owned bulk surveillance data.

[Kit Collins]: Any contracts or agreements signed prior to the enactment of this ordinance that violate the section shall not be renewed after the completion of the term of said contracts or agreements.

[Kit Collins]: And then we would strike the following existing line from the ordinance, which reads section 5080 shall not apply to any contract or agreement executed for law enforcement operations or purposes, then we would add the language.

[Kit Collins]: Further, it shall be unlawful for the city to acquire or enter into an agreement to acquire or exchange bulk surveillance data that the city is banned from generating on its own with any other government entity or policing agency.

[Kit Collins]: It would be also to replace the word contracts in the section title with the word transactions, which is broader.

[Kit Collins]: Um, so the proposed change here is to remove that exception.

[Kit Collins]: You know, throughout the rest of the ordinance, we say if you're going to use surveillance tech, if you're going to use or procure or sell or do anything with surveillance data, it has to go through this public transparent process where we talk about it before the city council decides this is worth it or this is not worth the potential harms.

[Kit Collins]: With this one exception for a carve out for procuring bulk surveillance data where it's commercially available for the purposes of law enforcement.

[Kit Collins]: So this tweak is just to remove that one exception and make it coherent with the rest of the ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: This is something that I didn't say at the top of this meeting, but it's something that we talked about a lot when we were going through the initial stages of the ordinance, that this policy does not, this policy is about surveillance tech and surveillance data, but it doesn't outright ban or enable any one use or technology.

[Kit Collins]: It doesn't single anything out.

[Kit Collins]: It just puts forward this public process that should govern all of it.

[Kit Collins]: So removing this exemption would just bring that in line with the rest of the ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: I also think that kind of bringing this section into the fold and into consistency with the rest of the ordinance is especially topical right now.

[Kit Collins]: State and federal courts have not

[Kit Collins]: yet landed on the constitutionality for any government agency to purchase surveillance data that was gathered commercially or privately.

[Kit Collins]: So in lieu of a ruling on this, in lieu of a precedent on this, communities like Medford have the chance to be proactive and make sure that upper levels of government, any government agency can access their constituents' private personal data without a warrant.

[Kit Collins]: Um, and I think that this is especially topical right now, because there are a lot of changes at the federal level.

[Kit Collins]: I think it's always a good time to make sure in this, like increasingly increasingly surveilled and digital world that we're doing the best that we can to keep pace with regulations and protections with the incredibly fast pace of technology development.

[Kit Collins]: And this is a way for us to be proactive and say we're not going to wait.

[Kit Collins]: For these slow moving like upper bureaucracies and upper jurisdictions to weigh in on

[Kit Collins]: If our community members' public and private data should be able to be bought and sold and used, we're just going to say, you need a warrant.

[Kit Collins]: No exceptions, no carve-outs, you need a warrant.

[Kit Collins]: So in a nutshell, there's more to, you know, obviously all this stuff is very nuanced, but in a nutshell, that is the intent behind removing this exemption.

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Collins.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Chair Lazzaro.

[Kit Collins]: I also just wanted to note another, there were a couple minor points that came back from legal on this proposed change as well.

[Kit Collins]: One of them was, again, I think what I characterize as kind of like a, you know, it's dot RIs cross RTs kind of suggestion that noted that the limitations set forward in this section.

[Kit Collins]: should not apply to surveillance data that's already exempted from the ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: I see the intent behind that language.

[Kit Collins]: I do kind of think that goes without saying.

[Kit Collins]: I, you know, kind of personal preference, I sometimes think that stating things too many times in too many sections can actually reduce clarity instead of making things more clear.

[Kit Collins]: So I'm comfortable with where we have the exemption stated so far in the ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think that that language is necessary.

[Kit Collins]: Just to make that more clear, there was a suggestion to say this section does not need to apply to surveillance data that was exempted from the provisions of this ordinance as set forth in section 5071.

[Kit Collins]: Section 5071 says this ordinance does not apply to these technologies.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think, I feel like if I were to read this ordinance, I would assume that that was true in all sections.

[Kit Collins]: So I always appreciate a legal counsel's thoroughness.

[Kit Collins]: I'm not myself proposing that as an amendment just because I do think it's unnecessary, but I just wanted to state that for transparency.

[Kit Collins]: However, they did note that the term bulk surveillance data is not defined.

[Kit Collins]: I think that could be worthwhile.

[Kit Collins]: So after we hear from all questions and Councilors, I'm sorry, from all questions and comments, I'll make a couple of motions and included in that, I would ask KP Law to provide a suggestion for a definition of bulk surveillance data that we could add to the first section of the ordinance just to keep everything super clear.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I would motion to incorporate the discussed amendments.

[Kit Collins]: And I just emailed those to the clerk, that would be the addition to section 5079 with the new first sentence that we discussed in committee pertaining to Massachusetts public records law and municipal records and retention schedule.

[Kit Collins]: and in Section 5080 to change the title to say transactions instead of contracts, and to make those line item changes to Section 5080, as well as to request guidance on a definition for the term bulk surveillance data.

[Kit Collins]: And then I don't want to state Councilor Leming's motion for him, but pending that, I would also motion to incorporate those amendments and report this out of committee.

[Kit Collins]: Yes.

[Kit Collins]: Test 1-2, test 1-2.

[Kit Collins]: And then what I think is really key and I think something that's really bothered a lot of residents for a lot of time is, what do we need to do to make Haines Square, more we want it to be and start using those big parcels in a way that will be more, more of an advantage.

[Kit Collins]: for the folks who live around there and shop there and just want to see more for the community in that space.

[Kit Collins]: Director Hunt, go ahead.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Alicia, and thank you so much, Councilor Callahan.

[Kit Collins]: I think that's a great reminder.

[Kit Collins]: I think it's something that I remind myself throughout this process, even though we've been talking in quite a lot of depth about zoning, you know, for more than a full calendar year now, is that zoning is counterintuitive because it seems like we're talking about what's going to happen when we're talking about what's going to be allowed.

[Kit Collins]: And I think Salem Street is a really great example, and there are examples all over Medford, but it's a great example of where what is currently there

[Kit Collins]: might be allowed under our current zoning, or maybe not, and we're having a conversation about what that's currently there, do we still want to be allowed, and we're done with this, but we'd not want to be allowed, like, I think there's broad consensus against the 12-story hotel, I think.

[Kit Collins]: I think everybody's in favor of that.

[Kit Collins]: And what do we want to be allowed that isn't allowed currently, so that the businesses are there, are even more thriving, that the residences are there, it's an even cozier neighborhood for the folks that live there.

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Callahan.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much for that clarification, Councilor Galleon.

[Kit Collins]: Seeing no further public participation on Zoom or in person and no further questions or comments from Councilors, we do have a regular meeting to get started.

[Kit Collins]: So just to once again restate our next steps, we're going to be talking about this exact zoning proposal again next Wednesday at 6 p.m.

[Kit Collins]: Please feel free to help us in spreading the word and we're glad to have the collaboration of the mayor's office and spreading the word on social media and through robo calls to residents.

[Kit Collins]: You know, this process has been informed by the past several years of public participation on what they like and what they want to see for Salem Street and other areas around the city.

[Kit Collins]: and these conversations, you know, in the here and now have to be informed by all of our voices as well.

[Kit Collins]: So thank you for being here.

[Kit Collins]: So we're going to see this 6 p.m.

[Kit Collins]: next Wednesday, whenever it gets referred out to the City Council, it will then be referred to the Community Development Board, and then it will be referred back to the City Council.

[Kit Collins]: And I just say that over and over again every meeting to remind you of all of the opportunities that we welcome you to be a part of this process.

[Kit Collins]: Anyway, I am moving to send the existing Community Control of Public Surveillance Ordinance, which was passed last term, to the Public Health and Community Safety Committee.

[Kit Collins]: This ordinance was crafted and collaborated on

[Kit Collins]: in the previous term because the city, the council, and residents had a shared concern and a shared interest in the civil liberties of residents, transparency in our governmental decisions, and a shared interest in making sure that our very precious city dollars are spent on true public safety and not on expensive gadgets and softwares that enrich corporations more than they actually help communities and residents.

[Kit Collins]: So to that end, some residents have identified potential changes that we could make to this rather new ordinance that would make it even stronger and even more in line with those shared goals.

[Kit Collins]: So I look forward to reviewing those comments, perhaps making some tweaks and having this discussion in committee where we can really get into the details and make this even stronger than it already is.

[Kit Collins]: I heard a couple speeding complaints from residents twice in the past two days, and that was before the meeting started.

[Kit Collins]: So we really need the state's help in creating a culture of safe road speeds here in Medford and around the region, because it's just intuitive, you know, people whip on the roads in Medford, they whip on the state roads, and they bring that speed to the neighborhoods, and it's incredibly dangerous, it's incredibly scary.

[Kit Collins]: And I think for me, you know, based on the data that's been presented,

[Kit Collins]: Where I come down is similar to in previous years when we hear about that breakeven point we know that a residential exemption would benefit a lot of people who really deserve it, and we know that it would disadvantage a lot of people that would also really deserve it.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that we should absolutely continue to gather more information about what exactly this would mean.

[Kit Collins]: for our community and as, you know, the character of our parcels evolves gradually each year.

[Kit Collins]: I'm a fellow councilors.

[Kit Collins]: November 20 is the date that's been penciled in to review this zoning proposal before it comes back to the city council.

[Kit Collins]: But just before I make the motion to refer to the Community Development Board which again is just procedurally the next step that we have to take before we consider taking a vote on any zoning change to our zoning ordinances.

[Kit Collins]: As president bear said we've had many meetings on this district in the planning and permitting committee.

[Kit Collins]: This is a really exciting juncture for me personally as one Councilor because over so many years.

[Kit Collins]: with people in Medford, you know, not just people in City Hall, but just folks out on the street.

[Kit Collins]: It comes up so often, how much potential Mystic Ave has and how people look around and say, you know, what's here is really great, but we know this can be so much more.

[Kit Collins]: We see a lot of flatland, we see some vacant buildings, we see some lots that seem underdeveloped, and people can see the potential there for things that it's interesting for residents to go to, lots that will be really interesting for developers to want to develop.

[Kit Collins]: And in, you know, a lot of potential new commercial growth for our city which I know is really important to all of us and a really shared value for all of us to grow our commercial tax base though so that we can grow without.

[Kit Collins]: having to levy all of that burden onto our residential tax base.

[Kit Collins]: So with a lot of the goals, those goals in mind, and with the comprehensive plan, you know, guiding our beginning of this process, we took a look at this district, our zoning consultant was able to propose kind of a slate of sub districts that would make sense for different parts of this corridor.

[Kit Collins]: Of course, this corridor is very heavily commercial, heavily commercial, heavily commercial industrial.

[Kit Collins]: ended about some residential areas.

[Kit Collins]: So we took a lot of care in discussing what parts of that corridor, the north side closer to Medford Square, what type of mixed use involving commercial but not explicitly commercial makes sense for that zone as you get down further south towards Somerville, towards some of the more residential areas, what makes sense there, what's going to be good for development, what will buffer those residential areas from the commercial development that we hope to see there.

[Kit Collins]: So we took a lot of time with those questions

[Kit Collins]: And I'm very proud of the collaboration and the updated proposed zoning map that's come out of that as well.

[Kit Collins]: Of course, all those nitty gritties, the dimensional standards that inform what we're proposing that developers can develop there in each sub-district, depending on the conditions of the sub-district and other incentives that they may or may not take advantage of.

[Kit Collins]: All that to say,

[Kit Collins]: There's a lot of weeds for people to dig into and I really do recommend that folks watch the meetings of the planning and permitting committee where this was discussed, or attend the Community Development Board meeting on what I believe is going to be November 20, if you want to have an even closer look at some of those details.

[Kit Collins]: But I do want to thank the committee for going through this process I think this is a really important part of the zoning overhaul that this council has been really working very hard

[Kit Collins]: to make progress on for this entire term and the previous two councils including the one that I wasn't on yet was working really hard to do this zoning work so that the, the things that residents of the community and business owners of the community have been asking the city to move on for such a long time that we're, you know, starting to make some real progress.

[Kit Collins]: So on that, I would motion to refer this to the Community Development Board.

[Kit Collins]: Great.

[Kit Collins]: The, the board members who will again look through this for a fine tooth comb but just on the, on the community engagement piece.

[Kit Collins]: I just didn't want to speak to that again, quickly, just to note that I think, I think it's really important.

[Kit Collins]: And when I speak to what we're what we're doing and what we've done.

[Kit Collins]: And that's on any topic not just the zoning it's it's not because I'm trying to make the point that, you know, we're doing a B and C so you know we got a 100%.

[Kit Collins]: and we're perfect and we shouldn't do anything more.

[Kit Collins]: I think as public servants we always aspire to, you know, in our fantasy version of our jobs we would talk to every single person and of course we can't do that, but I think it's really important that we always aspire to be catching more people, to be going into these projects with the assumption that everybody might have an opinion and if they do then it should be heard.

[Kit Collins]: I think what is, you know, it is genuinely challenging and this project and many others is that we take that ideal that responsibility to incorporate as much public feedback as we possibly can.

[Kit Collins]: And we have to reconcile that with what we can do and what we can say to residents that we are doing so that we're consistent, and so that they have

[Kit Collins]: realistic expectations about where to find us and how we'll find them.

[Kit Collins]: So when I say you know I think after the last meeting we had some conversations with the zoning consultant to say, Okay, we've gone through, you know, kind of one and a half zoning packages now we have this proposal we have the proposal of kind of more technical tweaks that we put forward around the end of the fiscal year.

[Kit Collins]: Now we're kind of in our groove.

[Kit Collins]: You know it's really time to bolster this what what more can we do so that it is so that it is as it should be easier for folks to get involved easier for more people to know what's coming up further ahead of time because that's really important, that is really important.

[Kit Collins]: And to me, you know what it says, when it comes to, you know, the one proposal to what's ahead of time let's make a schedule for what we're talking about in which month, so that we know so that the city staff knows so that residents can know essentially kind of have this more save the date type format, so that folks can know and really prepare and say okay I have that date in my mind if I want to attend.

[Kit Collins]: I'll be sure to attend, which is not to say that that's the perfect forum for feedback or that it should be the only forum.

[Kit Collins]: Knowing that.

[Kit Collins]: We are a city council in a city that does not yet have the resources for robust public engagement that we want to model ourselves off of that other neighboring communities do.

[Kit Collins]: I think that gives us the opportunity to at least be expanding our reach by being able to say ahead of time, here's the meeting on this topic.

[Kit Collins]: If it's relevant to you, please save the date.

[Kit Collins]: If this format isn't doable for you, you have at least a month to let us know.

[Kit Collins]: If you can't get to this meeting,

[Kit Collins]: Let us know send us an email call us if you're a person who has to be engaged in your community.

[Kit Collins]: Let us know so that we can find a way to accommodate and come to you.

[Kit Collins]: What I'm trying to say is, I know that in the scope of this project with so much to cover it might not be, we might not be able to do what I think we all want to do, which is to have multiple community meetings in every neighborhood for every topic.

[Kit Collins]: We can aspire to that I hope that we can do that especially in some of our more residential neighborhoods, where a lot of care has to be taken.

[Kit Collins]: But especially to me as committee chair it is very important that we are able to tell people what to expect and that do that consistently because I think that is really important for access as well.

[Kit Collins]: So just to note that for going forward.

[Kit Collins]: I'm excited about the, you know, expanded messaging that we're going to be doing as we head into the new year.

[Kit Collins]: And just to reiterate that, you know, we're, I'm really grateful to be guided by so many plans that were created in collaboration with the community over the course of years that lay the foundation for everything that we're doing.

[Kit Collins]: And that, you know, it shouldn't go without saying that having the community involved in this process is really important.

[Kit Collins]: And I think as public servants, we're always trying to think about realistically how to do that better and better every year.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I'll just keep this pretty brief and high level because the City Council has had a lot of meetings about the issue of private roads.

[Kit Collins]: City Council has had quite a lot of meetings about the issue of private roads in particular over the past three years that I've been part of the Council.

[Kit Collins]: What I have learned is that for the city to adopt what is currently a private road is an incredibly expensive process.

[Kit Collins]: Obviously, the cost of private roads is expensive to residents, while it's still a private road.

[Kit Collins]: For it to become a city on a public road, it has to be fully bought up to par, which is incredibly expensive on the order of millions, so that it can be maintained according to the status quo.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that we all know that to improve the city's street canopy, to do that stuff removal that residents have been asking for, that city staff have been trying to do over so many years.

[Kit Collins]: The point I'm trying to make is that we know that these needs that they're not being filled.

[Kit Collins]: We've been trying to make headway on them for such a long time.

[Kit Collins]: The reason that we're not making the headway that residents are really dying to see is because they are so expensive.

[Kit Collins]: And to me, that underlines the need to

[Kit Collins]: use this as a pivot point to try and begin making the investments that will result in visible improvements in our community.

[Kit Collins]: Because we know that there are a lot of residents who would love to at least be on the path towards progress, who would love to see a new private road, be eligible for adoption, and would like to see a more actionable plan for bringing some of those tree stumps down to earth and actually see our tree county expanding in these things.

[Kit Collins]: and then the two votes to codify it into our into our code of zoning ordinances.

[Kit Collins]: Zoning updating process.

[Kit Collins]: You know, there's really no way to avoid a lot of eyes on this highly technical, very important, very consequential changes, and I'm really glad that that is written into the procedure of how this gets done because, of course, we

[Kit Collins]: This step is important.

[Kit Collins]: I'd like to thank Councilor Tseng for moving this project forward.

[Kit Collins]: to make sure that Medford was doing all it could do to protect reproductive reproductive health care is wonder, as well as gender affirming health care.

[Kit Collins]: And of course this is a very new draft and we're going to continue to revise this in committee but just for my initial review.

[Kit Collins]: I think that.

[Kit Collins]: One of the parts of this that really stands out to me that I hope that residents kind of, that I think is very salient and I hope that residents, you know, hear about and understand in this proposed ordinance is the section and again, like draft section C that says no city resources, materials or funds shall be used to facilitate or aid any person seeking to prohibit criminalized sanction, et cetera, the person seeking this kind of care.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that's really the point to me here.

[Kit Collins]: is that we, I think we know implicitly that it's not appropriate for city resources to be used towards such, you know, essentially extra legal purposes.

[Kit Collins]: And that includes the time of our city employees as well.

[Kit Collins]: So I'm really proud that we're crafting a policy that enshrines that, and I look forward to continuing to revise this in committee.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, and sorry, just a clarifying question.

[Kit Collins]: I think you already described this, but is the point of that new idea to ensure that pharmacies are complying with providing all of the reproductive health-related medication?

[Kit Collins]: Yes.

[Kit Collins]: Okay, cool, great.

[Kit Collins]: I mean, I think that seems part of the theme of these three papers, so I'd be happy to take it up as part of the package.

[Kit Collins]: Oh, sure.

[Kit Collins]: Just to jump in with, again, preliminary reflections.

[Kit Collins]: Should we go forward where?

[Kit Collins]: How much would it cost?

[Kit Collins]: and using that people power.

[Kit Collins]: And if this is a difficult project to implement, if it could take five to seven years to put together, maybe it'll take shorter, but maybe it'll take five years to put together.

[Kit Collins]: the will and the buy-in and the plans and the money to make this sustainable, then it is good that we're starting now.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: health issue and engages with.

[Kit Collins]: We want your patronage.

[Kit Collins]: We don't necessarily want to be a restroom facility for people in public, though they need one.

[Kit Collins]: Yeah, I think that we can.
