[Kit Collins]: Move for approval.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: So I've been in conversation with, among other people within City Hall, our Board of Health Director, Health Director, Director O'Connor, about some amendments to the rodent control ordinance that she and her team are seeing on their side that they believe could help them better implement best practices and rules for residents and businesses to be part of our multi-pronged approach at mitigating

[Kit Collins]: the growing rodent population in the city.

[Kit Collins]: They've identified some changes that we could make within the text of the ordinance that would give them more latitude to enforce, such as how trash receptacles are placed and maintained on property.

[Kit Collins]: I've talked to a lot of people in the city and outside about this, and they say one of the problems that we're running into is just that we need to

[Kit Collins]: keep it tighter when it comes to how trash and recycling and things that attract rodents, how those are stowed around residential and business areas.

[Kit Collins]: So they've identified some changes in the ordinance that they would like for the council to consider that will just make enforcement easier on their side.

[Kit Collins]: We're considering a committee meeting date for next week just to get the ball moving on that quickly.

[Kit Collins]: And at the same time, I believe we're also going to consider a paper that's already before the council, an overgrowth ordinance,

[Kit Collins]: which will have some same hopeful goals of giving the city more tools to where we see those problem areas in the city that are places where rodents are congregating, where the threat population is concentrated, give the city more tools to do enforcement around making sure those are cleaned up so that we're not harboring rodents where we don't need to be.

[Kit Collins]: So I would motion to move this to the Public Health and Community Safety Committee.

[Kit Collins]: I would motion to suspend the rules to take papers 24463 and then public participation out of order.

[Kit Collins]: A motion to approve.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much for coming tonight I really appreciate it, especially knowing that there is a another even more star studded event that you could have been at tonight thank you so much for coming and speaking to us and, you know, continuing to raise the profile of Australia and in addition to all the work that you and the rest of the board is doing every week and every month we really appreciate it.

[Kit Collins]: And I appreciate the, you know, kind of the reminder the call to action of how much this team is doing behind the scenes week in and week out.

[Kit Collins]: I know as a Councilor, one thing that I'm that I think we're always keeping an eye on kind of on an annual basis is making sure that the casino mitigation funds I know that there's a portion of that that's earmarked for the Chevalier, we want to make sure that that

[Kit Collins]: remains because it's so important for this very uniquely Medford institution to be able to stay important, stay special, and stay competitive when these like very large corporate venues such as Encore do come into the region.

[Kit Collins]: In addition, I've always really valued getting those like snapshots of progress and whenever the Chevalier comes forward with the CPA application,

[Kit Collins]: It's always like this incredible pamphlet of what's been going on and how much more there is to do, whether it's restoring the building.

[Kit Collins]: I know there was a big organ restoration project that was wrapped up the past couple years.

[Kit Collins]: Anyway, I know that's just really scratching the tip of the iceberg when it comes to how much is going on behind those doors.

[Kit Collins]: every year.

[Kit Collins]: So thank you for, you know, platforming the membership drive, the annual meeting.

[Kit Collins]: I would love to get more involved and get a little bit more into the details about what you all are working on all the time.

[Kit Collins]: I think as Councilors, and especially as, you know, as residents, whenever the Chevalier is bringing in, you know, another great act every weekend, you see the cars.

[Kit Collins]: I know there's so often that I'm like walking down Forest Street.

[Kit Collins]: I'm like, wow, they got that person?

[Kit Collins]: Amazing.

[Kit Collins]: What a pull.

[Kit Collins]: So it's visible.

[Kit Collins]: what an incredible theater this is here in Medford.

[Kit Collins]: And, you know, it shouldn't go without saying how much work goes into keeping it that way.

[Kit Collins]: So thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I just wanted to thank you for appearing tonight, and I think my fellow councilor's suggestions are good ones.

[Kit Collins]: When we consider special permits like these, we wanna make sure that we're staying within what's been afforded to other nearby residents that we're keeping with precedent that's been established.

[Kit Collins]: But I'm sure that we can, like we have in the past, work together with yourself, city staff, residents, to make sure that we seek some sort of compromise that's still an improvement for everybody.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Of course, thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for being present to me.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for your presentation.

[Kit Collins]: I'm feeling a little confused about what's changed since, well, I'm not confused about what's changed.

[Kit Collins]: I'm a bit confused about why there's been a change since the agreement that the council and the city department came to.

[Kit Collins]: With National Grid last fall, I think that you know we had a essentially a contract between the city and National Grid stating the agreement curb to curb and stating these conditions that there would be an equivalent square footage or whatever the proper terminology is in this case that would be restored on

[Kit Collins]: adjacent seats close to the affected area.

[Kit Collins]: Those are the stipulations that this council added to the special permit.

[Kit Collins]: And we've had that in place since November.

[Kit Collins]: So I admit I'm a little surprised to hear that characterized as a non-starter now, many months later.

[Kit Collins]: To be honest, I still think that the stipulations are very reasonable.

[Kit Collins]: I'm a little surprised to hear the notion of this affecting utility rates for Medford ratepayers because we know that rates are not set on a

[Kit Collins]: granular city by city basis like that so that strikes me as a surprising thing to hear put forward in a public meeting I don't think that we should be making a decision based on that because we know that's not true.

[Kit Collins]: And if I recall correctly from our discussions about this last term.

[Kit Collins]: Part of the context around this conversation is National Grid did work in a similar area of Long Main Street quite recently, within five years, so this is asking the Butters to, you know, of course it's all for good reason, but it's asking the Butters to go through that inconvenience, again, in a relatively short timeline, and I think that's why it's important to make sure that if the Butters are to be put through that,

[Kit Collins]: that, you know, we get back an appropriate public benefit in the term of that curb-to-curb restoration.

[Kit Collins]: And as long as there's work being done, you know, disrupting traffic and neighbors in the area, I think it's appropriate to stick with the original stipulation that we have equivalent square footage restoration in those other areas that the Council stipulated back in November.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Is there work currently scheduled?

[Kit Collins]: Yes.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate the councilor for bringing this forward for lots of reasons, including we have so many discussions inside these chambers about the pretty vast budgetary needs facing so many of our city departments, including the four that are specifically targeted by linkage.

[Kit Collins]: And we need to be keeping pace with other communities in adopting and evolving to those best practices for how to have sources of revenue that don't just come from sales tax and property tax because our needs are too great.

[Kit Collins]: We do have a comprehensive plan, the city of Medford comprehensive plan was put together over the course of several years with a ton of resident feedback.

[Kit Collins]: It is on the city website.

[Kit Collins]: And there's a lot of really big, beautiful lofty goals for how to evolve the Medford that we love today into the community that we're already striving to become.

[Kit Collins]: And we know how much funding and resources those goals take to manifest.

[Kit Collins]: And so,

[Kit Collins]: I think it's about time that we update this mechanism so that these large developers, the only ones that are targeted by linkage are paying their fair share.

[Kit Collins]: And that's really all that this is.

[Kit Collins]: And I think it's heartening to know that some of this research was based on the city of Watertown, which in recent years, if anybody's gone down Arsenal Street, they've seen a huge development boom, heartening to see.

[Kit Collins]: And I lost the second place that I was going with that font.

[Kit Collins]: In terms of the developer experience, I think that, you know, this creates a highly predictable increase that developers can know about.

[Kit Collins]: So I don't have any fears attached to this.

[Kit Collins]: I'm really glad that we're doing it.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Councilor Leming, for your leadership on it.

[Kit Collins]: And I know that City Hall staff were very helpful in the research as well.

[Kit Collins]: So I'll second the motion to approve.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: So this is a... We're at the...

[Kit Collins]: culmination of an ordinance project that began last year in 2023.

[Kit Collins]: The idea for a wildlife feeding ordinance was first brought up to me by constituents who were kind of facing this problem firsthand, which I know many people in the city and other cities face, which is there's the wrong kind of animal on my property.

[Kit Collins]: It's not a pet.

[Kit Collins]: It's not domesticated.

[Kit Collins]: I don't want it here.

[Kit Collins]: It's a nuisance.

[Kit Collins]: It's potentially a health hazard.

[Kit Collins]: And

[Kit Collins]: Part of the reason that it might be on private property in a residential area in an environment that is not appropriate for humans or for the animal is because there are wildlife attractants out, namely food sources for wildlife.

[Kit Collins]: So I discussed this matter with our code enforcement officers, with our health director, Director O'Connor.

[Kit Collins]: with other city hall staff and received a lot of really helpful guidance on how to take a model of wildlife feeding ordinances from other cities and environments such as ours and create a mechanism so that city staff have a way to enforce around only inappropriate and problematic feeding of wildlife, the type of which is drawing wildlife.

[Kit Collins]: animals that shouldn't be there onto residential areas.

[Kit Collins]: What this is not is an ordinance that says you can't have a bird feeder.

[Kit Collins]: We specifically say you can have a bird feeder.

[Kit Collins]: The health director said we should put in language on there to make sure that bird feeders are

[Kit Collins]: constructed properly, that they're not just squirrel feeding devices, because that's also a problem.

[Kit Collins]: But this is not an anti-bird feeding ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: This is not an anti-pet feeding ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: The subcommittee on, or the Committee on Public Health and Community Safety really took its time with this ordinance to make sure that we thought through all the nuances and got the right language with advice from

[Kit Collins]: legal counsel on how to make sure that this is targeted, just so that when there is problematic wildlife feeding going on the city has a mechanism to step in first to say, Hey, that's a problem.

[Kit Collins]: Please clean up your act.

[Kit Collins]: And then if the problem willfully persists to issue a ticket or a fine, and this is all towards the end of making sure that our

[Kit Collins]: beautiful private residential spaces in Medford can stay safe for wildlife and also stay enjoyable for the people that live there.

[Kit Collins]: So I welcome questions from members of the council, especially those that were not on the committee where this is discussed, but otherwise I would want to thank especially our code enforcement officers, building director and health director, Mary Ann O'Connor, most of all for their guidance and a motion for approval.

[Kit Collins]: to thank you so much for all of your work on this program and so many other initiatives.

[Kit Collins]: It's great to see Medford beginning to give, you know, our climate and climate adjacent policies the priority that they really deserve and that, you know, our residents deserve and that we need.

[Kit Collins]: It's great to see that we're, you know, taking a really granular look at our EB program and say, you know, we need to make sure that this

[Kit Collins]: program, you know, kind of reaches that flywheel effect where we are getting the revenue that we need to expand it further and make it ever more easy and convenient to drive an EV in or through Medford.

[Kit Collins]: So I really appreciate seeing this before us tonight.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much for your work and I'd motion for approval.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for putting this together.

[Kit Collins]: I'm looking for approval.

[Kit Collins]: Gaston, if you're interested, I'm happy to share a little bit of the thought that went into this ordinance if you totally hear you.

[Kit Collins]: This was kind of the main question that we were keeping in mind when we were crafting this, because for me,

[Kit Collins]: The goal is to have an enforcement mechanism for when accidental feeding is going awry without saying, hey, this benevolent thing that you're doing that isn't currently causing a problem, we don't wanna penalize that stuff.

[Kit Collins]: So we worked hard to phrase this in such a way under prohibited activity, that section, to say there's no violation occurring until a problem occurs.

[Kit Collins]: So for example, if there's a fruit tree, if there's fruit on the ground,

[Kit Collins]: If it's not attracting wildlife at such a level where anybody's ever gonna notice or file a complaint, then it's not in violation of the ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: Does that make sense?

[Kit Collins]: If it's happening and it's not problematic, it's not in violation.

[Kit Collins]: If there's a problem going on and the board of health director or the court enforcement offer or the animal control officer visits and says, yikes, this is causing some problems, then if it's not ameliorated, it's a violation.

[Kit Collins]: If that doesn't occur, it's not a violation.

[Kit Collins]: So I just offer that.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: This latest meeting of the Planning and Permanent Committee was once again held with the City Council's zoning consultant.

[Kit Collins]: This was kind of a fun and unusual meeting.

[Kit Collins]: They arranged for us a mapping workshop where their GIS specialists printed out a whole range of zoning-related maps showing different characteristics of the city from a zoning perspective.

[Kit Collins]: everything from lot frontage to average income in different neighborhoods.

[Kit Collins]: We spread them all out in tapers in City Hall.

[Kit Collins]: We had a lot of department heads, members of the public joined us.

[Kit Collins]: It was really interesting.

[Kit Collins]: And that discussion and the takeaways and questions that came out of it are going to inform our further committee meetings with the zoning consultant, beginning with the next one, which is tomorrow at 7 p.m.

[Kit Collins]: to review the findings and questions from that committee and start going over some of our corridor strategies as well as global strategies for the zoning overhaul throughout the city.

[Kit Collins]: So I move for approval.

[Kit Collins]: I would motion to suspend the rules to take papers 24-455, 24-453, and 24-454 out of order.

[Kit Collins]: On the motion, I have Vice President Collins to take papers 24-455, 24-453, and 24-454 from the table.

[Kit Collins]: Seconded by?

[Kit Collins]: Second.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: asking the Elections Commission to add another layer to redouble their existing efforts to make sure that people know when to get out and vote.

[Kit Collins]: Yes, for the September 3rd primary.

[Kit Collins]: Through the chair.

[Kit Collins]: I want to thank Councilor Scarpelli as well as President Bears for bringing this forward and for being so responsive to, you know, really just the latest wave of resident outreach about this.

[Kit Collins]: And I think Councilor Scarpelli is exactly right, you know, I think that the city has been

[Kit Collins]: Working hard with the available tools to try to stem the tide of increasing rat populations over the past several years, but it's always seemed to me that our approach is, you know, fundamentally reactive and everybody can everybody can see with their eyes, you know that that isn't doing enough.

[Kit Collins]: I think that the idea of a task force is potentially a great idea because there have been so many disparate approaches either tried already in the city or things that have been floated.

[Kit Collins]: I think it'd be great to collect some of the topics of discussion from the Solid Waste Task Force, which I was a member of a couple of years ago talking about.

[Kit Collins]: you know, how can we make sure that our evolving trash and compost receptacles are getting better and better at being rodent-proof, which is something that they are getting better and better at being rodent-proof, but it's important to share that information with the community whenever we can.

[Kit Collins]: I know that there's a lot of pioneering rodent innovations going on in neighboring cities that

[Kit Collins]: hear about time to time from residents.

[Kit Collins]: One, because they seem more effective than just sending somebody out when we get that latest call about where it's getting especially bad, and because we do want to mitigate the effects on other members of the ecosystem.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that we're all aware that just putting out a lot of rat poison is really harmful to the other animals that we do treasure in Medford.

[Kit Collins]: So everything takes resources, investing in the right tools and the right systems to really attack this.

[Kit Collins]: It's not going to get better without these major institutions pitching in to help us have a more systemic approach.

[Kit Collins]: So I would absolutely support this.

[Kit Collins]: I thank my fellow councilors for bringing it forward.

[Kit Collins]: Not more, but just I think in terms of what, and I agree, I think that this was a lot of what was kind of negotiated while this new contract was being formed between the city side and waste management.

[Kit Collins]: I think that a lot of the provisions and goals, since it just went into effect July 1, are probably still being formulated.

[Kit Collins]: But I think in terms of what residents can expect to see, especially in the square specifically, is consolidation, because absolutely when you have

[Kit Collins]: one business that has overflow trash cans on the sidewalk, and another that has a dumpster, and then the other one doesn't use that dumpster, they just have a receptacle, and the next one just has a bag.

[Kit Collins]: It looks messy, and the more we can just keep everything in one container that really is solid and reinforced, hopefully that'll be, you know, one piece of the puzzle in getting trash off the streets, rats off the streets.

[Kit Collins]: I don't have a question on the resolution specifically.

[Kit Collins]: I thank the councilor for bringing it forward.

[Kit Collins]: I think that a lot of what we've heard in terms of premises for this conversation, I have an honest disagreement with at the same time.

[Kit Collins]: I think that there's a lot of ways for us to have really productive conversations about settlements and liabilities before the city.

[Kit Collins]: These sometimes occur in public session.

[Kit Collins]: These sometimes occur in executive session.

[Kit Collins]: Anytime we are getting more information from the administration as opposed to less when it comes to the city side of things, we have no jurisdiction over the schools.

[Kit Collins]: I think that is a good thing.

[Kit Collins]: I think that always leaves us better off.

[Kit Collins]: That often leaves the atmosphere more productive and collaborative than it was when we were feeling under-informed prior to, you know, whether it's a meeting or a memo or just a substantive update.

[Kit Collins]: I think for myself, I feel, I think, across many issues we've all had the experience of feeling under informed on various issues and then we get that bolus of information it's like wow, now we can really have a conversation about this, that leaves me feeling pretty open and flexible when it comes to what type of format or venue we receive

[Kit Collins]: information about settlements and liabilities in going forward.

[Kit Collins]: This, like a lot of our resolutions, when it comes to making resolutions to the administration, they are essentially requests.

[Kit Collins]: We cannot compel reports or requests to be filled by the administration just because of the nature of the way our government is set up.

[Kit Collins]: That being said, I hope that the administration takes this request for more information as a

[Kit Collins]: in the best faith possible to say, it is better for us when we put our issues out on the table and we're able to have these conversations when there's fewer surprises.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that, you know, there's a lot of cliche ways to put this, but I think that we're better when fewer things are in the dark.

[Kit Collins]: I think that it's better to shine a light on things that people are hearing about than to,

[Kit Collins]: to speculate until kind of a belated information.

[Kit Collins]: So that being said, more information is always better.

[Kit Collins]: I know that a lot of this is very sensitive, like we saw earlier today.

[Kit Collins]: A lot of this has to be discussed in executive session.

[Kit Collins]: Some of it, you know, there's some litigations, there's some settlements that always come to the council as a matter of course, we saw that earlier this evening.

[Kit Collins]: I always want to correct the record when it comes to what information, you know, the city council does get

[Kit Collins]: certain settlements do come before us, we do appropriate.

[Kit Collins]: You know, I wouldn't want to put forward a request and also forward the story that, you know, we're in this complete and total information desert in the same way that I, you know, wouldn't want it to go by that, you know, an unusual number for free cash is in some way evidence of financial mismanagement.

[Kit Collins]: It's not.

[Kit Collins]: We know from communities across the street that this was a banner year for free cash surpluses for many communities.

[Kit Collins]: But in the same way, I don't think that we should need to treat settlements and liabilities like something that we cannot talk about and we cannot ask about.

[Kit Collins]: I think to the extent that we are able to have a freer flow of information about this with the administration, leave us better off, leave us better able to communicate with the community when there are concerns, be able to say, this is what it really is.

[Kit Collins]: you know, and help us dial in on what our real problems are.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I do wanna underline the point, which is reflected in city paperwork, most of which has already been reviewed by the council in public session.

[Kit Collins]: If one of the points that this conversation is about is,

[Kit Collins]: Is there secret money being spent on settlements that is not known to Councilors, that is not known to the public?

[Kit Collins]: I would offer an amendment or a B paper that this information, if it's provided by the administration, also include legal department, budget to actuals for this fiscal years that are being asked about so that we can, we don't have to,

[Kit Collins]: I mean, I was going to say we don't have to take it on faith, but it's on the city website already.

[Kit Collins]: We get to see it on paper in the packet that we will receive how much money was budgeted for the legal department and how much was spent.

[Kit Collins]: And with that, President Perez, that was the question.

[Kit Collins]: I would put that forward as an amendment if the councilor is open to it.

[Kit Collins]: If I may?

[Kit Collins]: I just want to note,

[Kit Collins]: I obviously strongly disagree that there's anything fraudulent going on, but my point with the, including the budget to actuals as context in this information is to illustrate, if we talk about managing money, what does that literally mean?

[Kit Collins]: Where the money comes from, where it goes, the budget to actuals, we don't have to talk about how much money is being spent and where does it come from, we can literally see it.

[Kit Collins]: And I don't see why that shouldn't be a part of the conversation.

[Kit Collins]: And again, we do already have that information, but I think it makes sense to put all the context next to each other.

[Kit Collins]: I'm gonna split your paper, George.

[Kit Collins]: I have a motion to approve.

[Kit Collins]: 24452, resolution to support question four, limited legalization and regulation of certain natural substances on the November 5, 2024 general election ballot offered by President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Whereas one in three Massachusetts residents struggle with mental health challenges, and whereas pioneering research from Johns Hopkins and Harvard Medical School find that natural psychedelics can be effective in managing treatment-resistant depression and other forms of mental illness, and whereas the FDA recently granted psilocybin, one of the psychedelics, a, quote, breakthrough therapy, unquote, designation for treatment-resistant depression,

[Kit Collins]: And whereas the ballot question would create a regulated framework for psychedelic-assisted therapy for adults 21 and older, now therefore be it resolved by the Medford City Council that we support question four, limited legalization and regulation of certain natural psychedelic substances on the November 4, 2024 general election ballot.

[Kit Collins]: Good to go.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much for that overview.

[Kit Collins]: Very interesting to consider these two corridors in parallel.

[Kit Collins]: I'll go first to President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Pamela.

[Kit Collins]: Yeah, I think, I think in general and I, this is comes from personal preference and also I think from what we're heard from the community and various forums over the years.

[Kit Collins]: I think that broadly our instinct to try and consolidate commercial especially light industrial

[Kit Collins]: uses is super intuitive, makes a lot of sense.

[Kit Collins]: I also think that where I see the most enthusiasm is for that mixed use.

[Kit Collins]: And so even in, you know, kind of what we're considering our commercial nodes, you know, like we mentioned along the stick, the stick out for order, I'd be really excited to see, you know, that flexibility for mixed use.

[Kit Collins]: So that

[Kit Collins]: existing commercial uses can continue to have on there, continue to cluster with other uses, that makes sense.

[Kit Collins]: But that we are kind of leaving a, having our zoning leave a very warm welcome open, a very open door towards that mixed use.

[Kit Collins]: And for these nodes being

[Kit Collins]: functional commercial hubs without being so obviously commercial that other uses can't picture themselves there.

[Kit Collins]: And it's my hope that some of those kind of

[Kit Collins]: Unappealingly resolutely industrial areas I'm in care thinking about the bus depot which I think nobody is really happy about.

[Kit Collins]: It's just something that we don't have control over right now.

[Kit Collins]: I'm hopeful that through zoning the adjacent areas we can hopefully entice the partners that we don't have jurisdiction over to kind of conform with how the neighborhood is changing around that depot and other

[Kit Collins]: another outdated uses like it that we'd like to see go somewhere else or be converted into something more useful and more modern.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for that, Councilor Tseng.

[Kit Collins]: Director Hunt?

[Kit Collins]: Thank you very much, Danielle.

[Kit Collins]: Yeah, I think this is an important discussion to have.

[Kit Collins]: But I think in general, on the issue of how much height can a particular corridor or block support, typically the way I enter into that kind of question is like,

[Kit Collins]: I think we all agree on the basic premise of, we need more housing units.

[Kit Collins]: We want to do that in a way that's appropriate and sensitive and thoughtful.

[Kit Collins]: And when it comes to considering cases that are right now notably higher than average, the question is, what are we getting out of it?

[Kit Collins]: What's the value to the community beyond just the units themselves?

[Kit Collins]: And that makes me curious to contemplate, what feels like a new,

[Kit Collins]: what feels like an appropriate new normal that we can say we feel like this is a slam dunk, we're always comfortable with this, and then for those cases above that, whether that normal is four or five, if not six, maybe it's six, what do we want to get in return if we are going to contemplate letting a developer build above that?

[Kit Collins]: And I think that there's a lot that

[Kit Collins]: Probably a lot that we have in common that we find intriguing, whether it's parking underneath or some of those public space uses towards the front.

[Kit Collins]: President Bears?

[Kit Collins]: Yeah, I appreciate this discussion.

[Kit Collins]: I think that more so than Mystic Ave, Salem Street Corridor is a scenario where we kind of have to

[Kit Collins]: have a bit more of a confronting conversation around what we'd really like to see here, what is the zoning we could write that could bring that about, what is likely to happen.

[Kit Collins]: and make our best studies and guesses at what developers are going to take us up on and what's likely to result from the zoning that we do propose and pass.

[Kit Collins]: And so I'm happy that we're having this conversation because I would like us to take a really serious look at what could setbacks do for us?

[Kit Collins]: What is our best guess of what could arise in 5, 10, 20 years from that?

[Kit Collins]: Is there a meaningful community value that we can expect to get from that in the long term?

[Kit Collins]: If it seems like the geography of the corridor that we just can't change unless there's a mass eminent domain campaign, which obviously it's just a joke, I don't mean that, then what is the next best

[Kit Collins]: um, strategy for maximizing community value on this corridor.

[Kit Collins]: I would love to see more usable public space on this corridor.

[Kit Collins]: And everyone, um, I'm glad that we have Innis to help us take a, you know, a really sober look at what's our best chance of achieving that.

[Kit Collins]: Um, if it's really hard to do that through the geography, then, you know, we'll continue along our other goals for maximizing, um, residential usage of this corridor.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that, um,

[Kit Collins]: I'm really excited about the step backs being a component of making the height feel friendly and welcoming and hospitable along this corridor, because we know this is such a dense area of the city already and, and yet it's not enough for all the people that want to live there.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that could be a really great tool in our toolbox.

[Kit Collins]: So just a quick time check.

[Kit Collins]: It is almost 8.40.

[Kit Collins]: Paola, I want to pass the mic back to you before we go to public participation and just ask what else you'd like for us to hear to round out the presentation before we close out the meeting.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much, Paola.

[Kit Collins]: appreciate that.

[Kit Collins]: Yes.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you all, meeting is adjourned.

[Kit Collins]: Present.

[Kit Collins]: Sure, thank you, Chair Lazzaro.

[Kit Collins]: So I, again, wanna thank the Board of Health Director, Director O'Connor, and Officer Hogan, as well as the Code Enforcement Officers for, I know Director O'Connor is on the call tonight, and other city staff gave some really helpful insight onto this ordinance between,

[Kit Collins]: this meeting and our last one when the committee reported out some specific questions for them.

[Kit Collins]: So just thank you so much for being here.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for your time and your thoughts on this.

[Kit Collins]: Um, at our last committee meeting on this ordinance, which I was, I want to say was in June.

[Kit Collins]: It's either late May or June.

[Kit Collins]: Um, we had just received the legal review of the draft ordinance, which just as a recap, I, uh, this committee authorized me as lead sponsor to write that, um, which I did pulling from example ordinances from a couple

[Kit Collins]: communities, which it sought to create local ordinances towards the same purpose, which is essentially, you know, not to penalize anybody accidentally leaving some, you know, something tasty out for a critter one time, not to penalize your bird feeder, but just to create a legal mechanism so that if there is really inappropriate

[Kit Collins]: intentional repeated wildlife feeding going on in inappropriate areas, such as in a backyard in such a way that it is creating a nuisance or creating a health hazard that the city essentially has cover to go and help out residents in those cases where it is getting problematic.

[Kit Collins]: So the initial draft of the ordinance came from other communities that created ordinances along the same goals.

[Kit Collins]: At our last meeting, we reviewed some initial feedback from city staff.

[Kit Collins]: We also reviewed

[Kit Collins]: the legal opinion on that draft ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: At the last meeting, we also motioned to ask several further questions of city staff, just to kind of run some of that legal feedback by them to get their take on it from an implementation standpoint.

[Kit Collins]: So what I have prepared for tonight is a, I did a tracked changes version of the most recent draft

[Kit Collins]: of the draft ordinance, which does have the suggestions from legal in there.

[Kit Collins]: I also incorporated several of the suggestions that legal made, but didn't draft that city staff then went on to endorse.

[Kit Collins]: So what I'd like to do, if this sounds good, is to, I'd be happy to walk us through the track changes version of the ordinance, just so we can see what was suggested by whom.

[Kit Collins]: And then at the end, I'd be happy to, you know, entertain motions to adopt as much of the changes the committee agrees.

[Kit Collins]: you know, we'd like to include.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that, you know, we've had a really robust process so far of getting city staff feedback on this and hearing from residents about why they want this in the first place.

[Kit Collins]: So I'd love it if we could kind of review all of the final tweaks and additions tonight, and then hopefully report this out to be reviewed by the full body of the council.

[Kit Collins]: Yes, I will share my screen.

[Kit Collins]: Please let me know if this is visible.

[Kit Collins]: All right, looks like it is.

[Kit Collins]: Okay, I will just start running through this top to bottom.

[Kit Collins]: I mean, the ordinance is not terribly long start to finish.

[Kit Collins]: Please feel free to interrupt me with any questions or if I should slow down or speed up.

[Kit Collins]: So once again, this is the original version of the ordinance with modifications by KP Law and then further additions based on the legal feedback that city staff said they liked and endorsed and thought would find useful.

[Kit Collins]: So I'll just go from the top, the purpose section.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think this is meant to be deleted.

[Kit Collins]: Purpose and intent.

[Kit Collins]: I think Attorney Braun from KP Law thought that we should start with a really high level statement of intent.

[Kit Collins]: The intent of this ordinance is to protect the health, safety, and welfare of the community via curtailing the inappropriate feeding of wildlife.

[Kit Collins]: We then have some just slight language tweaks to the rest of that section, which was present in my initial draft of the ordinance, just kind of laying the groundwork.

[Kit Collins]: We're doing this because, you know, obviously we share permeable boundaries with the fells, many other natural areas, but we want to make sure that wildlife are staying where is appropriate for them, where they are safe, and we are not doing things to inappropriately entice wildlife into residential areas.

[Kit Collins]: We talk about the nuisances and health hazards that can be created for residents, how it can hamper residents' enjoyment of their outdoor spaces when wildlife are inordinately or inappropriately attracted onto those spaces.

[Kit Collins]: And Attorney Braun included some additional color into that section here, saying it can interrupt their normal feeding patterns, cause nutritional issues, threaten their health, promote the spread of diseases.

[Kit Collins]: So this is for the sake of animals, not just for the sake of residents and their enjoyments of their backyards.

[Kit Collins]: Attorney Braun also added, this ordinance should not be interpreted in any way to interfere with the authority of Massachusetts Division of Fisheries and Wildlife or any other state agency with jurisdiction over wildlife.

[Kit Collins]: I think for a lot of us that goes without saying that city ordinances are subservient to state level laws.

[Kit Collins]: We have added a couple definitions into the definitions section.

[Kit Collins]: You can see there's some minor language changes from Attorney Braun.

[Kit Collins]: I'm just adding some other commonly found wildlife in Medford into our list.

[Kit Collins]: We have definitions of what wildlife means, what feed or feeding means, and then what we've added.

[Kit Collins]: Because further down in the ordinance, we reference bird feeders and that we exempt them.

[Kit Collins]: KP Law, as well as Director O'Connor, thought it'd be very helpful to have a definition of what we mean when we say bird feeder.

[Kit Collins]: We also later in the ordinance will add a section that has to do with the treatment of feral or stray cats or exceptions that make sense for people who are taking care of feral or stray cats and seeking to domesticate, neuter, and spay them.

[Kit Collins]: So we also added a definition of pets just so that it's crystal clear what we're talking about.

[Kit Collins]: Then we get into the meat of the ordinance, what is prohibited.

[Kit Collins]: This is substantively the same as it was in June.

[Kit Collins]: I just want to highlight two substantive comments that Attorney Braun from KP Law had on this.

[Kit Collins]: Attorney Braun mentioned, it might be helpful to add an intent section.

[Kit Collins]: I think something that you probably heard me emphasize verbally in previous committee meetings was that the point of this is not to, you know, create a way to ticket somebody who like accidentally leaves out something that an animal construes as feed and eats on one time.

[Kit Collins]: We're not looking to

[Kit Collins]: police people's behavior, or trying to distinguish between repeated inappropriate intentional wildlife feeding and stuff that just happens one time or accidentally.

[Kit Collins]: And so following that suggestion, we added subsection B, whenever the animal control officer becomes aware that wildlife has been found feeding on any substance.

[Kit Collins]: and the resident for the property has been notified thereof, any subsequent feedings shall be evidence that the feeding was with the knowledge or intent of the resident or the person responsible for the property.

[Kit Collins]: So essentially that's saying it happens one time and it's enough of a problem that the animal control officer hears about it, he or she will first say, hey, it seems like this is becoming a problem, don't do it again.

[Kit Collins]: And then if it happens again, when we know that notice has been given, then we can start that kind of enforcement ladder.

[Kit Collins]: Attorney Braun also suggested, in addition, having to do with if animals are feeding on substances found within outdoor trash or compost receptacles.

[Kit Collins]: And here it's, you know, a very similar theme.

[Kit Collins]: If animals are getting into, if a trash or compost receptacle is compromised and it's causing enough of a problem that the animal control officer or director of health hears about it, first they will just get in contact with the resident or property owner and say, hey, it looks like this is causing a problem that's escalated to the level of a nuisance, please fix it.

[Kit Collins]: Then if they have the opportunity to do so and they don't,

[Kit Collins]: you know, then the city does have a mechanism to intervene again, again, just to make sure that wildlife are not making a habit of inappropriately feeding in residential areas.

[Kit Collins]: We then get into exceptions, and this is largely unchanged for the last time we reviewed this ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: Nothing in this section shall be interpreted to prohibit bird feeders.

[Kit Collins]: However, if a bird feeder is determined to be the cause of a public safety threat or nuisance, then the animal control officer, health director, or code enforcement officers can intervene to have it removed.

[Kit Collins]: But again, like the standard here is bird feeders are okay.

[Kit Collins]: Bird feeders are not often an issue.

[Kit Collins]: We also add

[Kit Collins]: or also we kept the exception that this has nothing to do with normal appropriate feeding of pets.

[Kit Collins]: Again, it's the same thing as if your trash bin has a huge hole in it and raccoons are getting into it, that's an issue.

[Kit Collins]: Ditto if you keep your dog food outside and raccoons are getting into it, that's an issue too.

[Kit Collins]: But if it's not an issue, it's not an issue.

[Kit Collins]: This is a new section that we talked about at length in our last committee meeting in June on stray or feral cats.

[Kit Collins]: I think Chair Lazzaro raised an important point that she had heard from some residents essentially saying like, hey, there are people who, you know, for years have volunteered in the community to do the work of, you know, essentially trying to humanely bait stray and feral cats so that they can be neutered, vaccinated, hopefully domesticated, adopted as pets.

[Kit Collins]: Attorney Braun had some helpful language around this, and Officer Hogan and Director O'Connor also gave a lot of great insight on this, endorsing this exception and pointing to the feral cat caretaker ordinances in Medford's Code of Ordinances.

[Kit Collins]: So we came up with this language to say explicitly no person shall feed any feral or stray cats with the following exceptions.

[Kit Collins]: If you are registered as a feral

[Kit Collins]: cat caretaker per this ordinance, you know, there's an exception for you, that work is registered, that work is fine, this ordinance will not interfere with you continuing that work.

[Kit Collins]: It says explicitly this section is in no way intended to hinder the work of duly registered feral cat caretakers, and I think this is the language suggested explicitly by

[Kit Collins]: Officer Hogan or Attorney Braun, this section shall not apply to persons feeding feral or stray cats with the express purpose of adopting and domesticated said cats.

[Kit Collins]: I think that these specific timetables and citations came from Attorney Braun, which points to mass general law on the topic of vaccination and domestication of feral cats.

[Kit Collins]: And I know that Officer Hogan ran this section past, I believe it's Medford Kitty Connections, if I have that right.

[Kit Collins]: leader from that organization did mention, you know, occasionally, depending on the situation, we do have to sometimes feed feral cats for more than 14 days, depending on the situation.

[Kit Collins]: So we just included here, if, if there's a litter where the feeding has to go on for more than 14 days before the next steps are taken, I know that the officer control officer and Medford Kitty Connections or other federal cat caretakers are always in communication about situations like these anyway, so that can go on at their discretion.

[Kit Collins]: And I'll pause because I see Councilor Callahan has a hand up.

[Kit Collins]: Yeah, thank you for mentioning that, because I definitely said that out loud, and I think I probably just assumed that spaying and neutering is something that is always done.

[Kit Collins]: I'm not sure.

[Kit Collins]: I've never, I'm not deeply familiar with the trap neutering.

[Kit Collins]: I know there's an acronym, I believe it's TNR, but I'm forgetting what the T and the R stand for.

[Kit Collins]: Release, trap neuter release.

[Kit Collins]: Oh, trap, neuter, release.

[Kit Collins]: Oh, thank you, whoever that was.

[Kit Collins]: I think in this case, I don't think that this ordinance should prescribe what goes on after the cats are fed and vaccinated, but I appreciate you flagging that, because I wouldn't wanna, I don't wanna say something inaccurate on record, not knowing what the protocols are after they are vaccinated.

[Kit Collins]: So that's a major new section.

[Kit Collins]: The rest of this is pretty true to what we reviewed a couple months ago.

[Kit Collins]: In terms of enforcement, the animal control officer, health director, code enforcement officers, and Attorney Braun also added police officers, are all authorized to administer and enforce the ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: It is enforced according to MGL Chapter 40, which is true of, I believe,

[Kit Collins]: all kind of non-criminal disposition of many of our regulatory ordinances at the city level.

[Kit Collins]: We have the same kind of offense letter that we had from our earlier reviews of the ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: The first offense is just a written warning.

[Kit Collins]: The second offense, that's again, after the problem has been raised and discussed with whoever is deemed to be committing the violation, the $50 citation, and then the third and each subsequent defense is $100 citation.

[Kit Collins]: We've also added the effective date of immediately upon passage.

[Kit Collins]: So I'll pause there.

[Kit Collins]: Thanks for bearing with me through that.

[Kit Collins]: And I, again, want to thank Director O'Connor and Officer Hogan and the code enforcement officers for reviewing this a couple of times as this was going through some suggested edits.

[Kit Collins]: I'd be happy to pull it up.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Chair Lazzaro.

[Kit Collins]: I'd be happy to make those motions.

[Kit Collins]: I did just want to, again, recognize Director O'Connor

[Kit Collins]: and I'm not sure if Officer Hogan is on the call, but if there's any city staff who were very helpful in crafting this, if they'd like to speak to any aspect of this or raise any final ideas or adjustments, I'd love to hear those before making the motions I planned.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Director O'Connor.

[Kit Collins]: I'm glad you brought that up.

[Kit Collins]: So this is kind of interesting, because I believe in a lot of our other city ordinances, we do include, you know, ex-city staff member or their designees.

[Kit Collins]: Attorney Broad, in this case, offered a legal opinion that, in their opinion, according to, I believe it's MGL Chapter 40, Section 21D, is a, oh wait, I'm not sharing my screen anymore, hang on a sec.

[Kit Collins]: Attorney Brown said, specifically, though attorney general review is not applicable to city ordinances, the AG has clarified that under chapter 40, section 21D requires that the bylaw identify the enforcing persons, this decision number 1096 from 2021.

[Kit Collins]: If an ordinance allows a party to designate an enforcing person at a later time, it therefore does not identify the enforcing persons in the ordinance itself and fails to put the public on notice of such enforcing.

[Kit Collins]: persons.

[Kit Collins]: So essentially, this was also, let me try and frame that in human English.

[Kit Collins]: A lot of our ordinances do use the language of, you know, say, for example, the director of

[Kit Collins]: director of public health or their designee, this opinion says that's actually generally disapproved of.

[Kit Collins]: I don't know that it's illegal or out of bounds, but it sounds like recent decisions have discouraged that so that it's crystal clear for the public who exactly the enforcer is to list all of those persons by title in the ordinance itself, instead of saying this department head or their designees.

[Kit Collins]: So that's, you know,

[Kit Collins]: I kind of like being able to assign it to a department head and say, you know, whoever they want to delegate it to.

[Kit Collins]: I think that is really streamlined from an implementation standpoint.

[Kit Collins]: But by way of explanation, that's why that was taken out.

[Kit Collins]: Yes.

[Kit Collins]: Is there any other titles from your office that we should add to that list?

[Kit Collins]: Sanitarians instead of health inspectors?

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Yeah, I'm gonna do a quick search for where it identifies the animal control officer as the administrator and make sure that the health director and sanitarians are included and code enforcement officers are included in that list as well.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Yeah, unless there are any other, I would certainly welcome any further comments or questions from members of the public or city staff.

[Kit Collins]: But barring that, I'd be happy to make a motion to adopt all of the changes reflected in this draft changes document that we've reviewed tonight.

[Kit Collins]: to adopt the additions, the deletions from city staff and legal review that were present in this draft, and then report that amended draft out to the city council.

[Kit Collins]: Anna's here.

[Kit Collins]: I'm sorry.

[Kit Collins]: Councilor is saying that was present as a non-voting member last time.

[Kit Collins]: Yeah, I'll kick us off and then I'll throw it to you for if there's anything you want to add.

[Kit Collins]: Just let me know whenever you're ready.

[Kit Collins]: Okay.

[Kit Collins]: There will be a meeting of the Medford City Council Planning and Purbanning Committee, Wednesday, July 24th, is that right?

[Kit Collins]: 5.30 p.m.

[Kit Collins]: The purpose of this meeting is to go for paper 24-033, which is comprehensive zoning updates in collaboration with the city council's

[Kit Collins]: Zoning consultant.

[Kit Collins]: The format of this committee meeting is going to be a little bit different than usual.

[Kit Collins]: We have arranged to have a zoning mapping workshop prepared by Innes Associates.

[Kit Collins]: So for the first give or take 90 minutes, councillors, committee members,

[Kit Collins]: City staff, members of the public are going to be circulating, looking at the zoning maps which were presented by Innes Associates at a couple previous committee meetings, asking questions, making notes on sticky notes for further review and discussion.

[Kit Collins]: All of this will inform our future work on tweaks to the zoning map, housing strategies and other strategies.

[Kit Collins]: Then around 7 p.m.

[Kit Collins]: I'm going to reconvene us to our typical format, where we'll have a discussion about the main threads to come out of this discussion, questions we'd like to pose to experts, to department heads, to the public, based on what came out of the mapping workshop discussion and the questions on the sticky notes.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that this conversation about where the conversation goes from here can be part of the record.

[Kit Collins]: So we've had, I think, a very substantive 90 minutes in our, what we're calling our mapping workshop.

[Kit Collins]: I know I contributed a lot of sticky notes to the maps that NS Associates created and laid out for us.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much.
