[Kit Collins]: The intent for the second half or the final third of this meeting was to kind of briefly recap the mapping workshop.

[Kit Collins]: If anybody feels called to, you know, kind of shout out a thread that they heard or discussed or saw very often, or if there's any major bottom lines that they wanted to articulate that they wrote down or talked about with other attendees.

[Kit Collins]: I think we can speak to that.

[Kit Collins]: And then the other intent for this part of the meeting was to discuss our kind of most immediate next steps on the housing strategies piece of this work, as well as our most immediate next steps on our two priority corridors, those being Salem Street and Mystic Ave.

[Kit Collins]: So like for Innes Associates, department heads, Councilors, feel free to speak to any part of that.

[Kit Collins]: I think that all of these are obviously very intertwined.

[Kit Collins]: I think that a lot of our comments from the mapping workshop are going to touch on those priority issues.

[Kit Collins]: So if any of my fellow Councilors would like to raise any thoughts, questions that came up during the mapping workshop, I'm happy to turn it over to Emily and Paula to discuss our next steps on the corridors and housing.

[Kit Collins]: Seeing none, we can popcorn around.

[Kit Collins]: Great.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much.

[Kit Collins]: I know for myself as one Councilor, I think we've been talking about a lot of the same priorities for a lot of this term and prior to that.

[Kit Collins]: you know, including when you were assisting the city of Medford in a previous role, helping us with our comprehensive planning.

[Kit Collins]: And so it's, it's exciting to get to the point where, you know, we're kind of visualizing and articulating a lot of these goals in various ways.

[Kit Collins]: And our next step being to, you know, use our use you as our technical assistance in bringing these goals into language into the zoning changes.

[Kit Collins]: First,

[Kit Collins]: in these priority corridors, expanding into the squares and kind of having these global strategies inform corridor strategies and vice versa.

[Kit Collins]: And I think it makes a lot of sense procedurally to focus on certain geographic areas, have those discussions of what do we know that we want for this zone?

[Kit Collins]: What are people already asking for?

[Kit Collins]: What have people been asking for for Mystic Ave, for Salem Street, for Medford Square for years?

[Kit Collins]: What changes need to be made that make sense for this area?

[Kit Collins]: what makes sense for the area adjacent to that, adjacent to that, what strategies make sense for the community overall.

[Kit Collins]: So I think this is the beginning of an exciting process.

[Kit Collins]: In terms of our next steps, I know that several of these strategies are already in the works.

[Kit Collins]: We've talked before, for example, one out of many for making ADUs by right.

[Kit Collins]: I know that there are several items in the queue that we might expect to see.

[Kit Collins]: We might be able to review language at a meeting soon.

[Kit Collins]: Are there any updated thoughts on what pieces of language you might like the Council to review and give feedback on at our next meeting or the one after that, whether it's a global strategy or, you know, addressing the corridors first?

[Kit Collins]: I'm so sorry, could you repeat the last part?

[Kit Collins]: The sound is very loud.

[Kit Collins]: that's great.

[Kit Collins]: President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for that discussion.

[Kit Collins]: I'm inclined to agree that if we have a window of opportunity to, in a reasonable baseline that seems unproblematic, I like taking opportunities to make improvements when they avail themselves, knowing that, knowing and telegraphing that an opportunity for more tailored tweaks and further amendments will be shortly forthcoming as well.

[Kit Collins]: And kind of towards the same point, I think that

[Kit Collins]: It would be great to, even if it evolves over the course of the year, to have that draft timeline of when we're going to be discussing particular corridors, neighborhoods, to be able to broadcast that early and also broadcast when those meetings get shuffled around.

[Kit Collins]: I think that that will sort of help reinforce for people.

[Kit Collins]: through another way, what this project is all about, which is hitting all of our priority areas, having this comprehensive approach and breaking down when different pieces of it are going to happen.

[Kit Collins]: That'll help keep us on schedule as well.

[Kit Collins]: Any other questions or comments from Councilors in this department heads about our next steps for August?

[Kit Collins]: and they're on afterwards, or any other threads that we want to call out from the mapping workshop earlier?

[Kit Collins]: There's a lot of great stuff, but I know we discussed it very in-depth around the tables.

[Kit Collins]: Yeah, I'll echo that.

[Kit Collins]: It was great to have that discussion include people who aren't, you know, always a part of these conversations.

[Kit Collins]: And I hope we can, you know, have that again at our conversations that are more neighborhood and corridor and other specific focuses.

[Kit Collins]: Yep, totally agree.

[Kit Collins]: I think it's just a value add.

[Kit Collins]: Great, well, thank you so much for your hard work that went into the format of this meeting.

[Kit Collins]: I'm excited at our meeting in August to begin to dig in deeper on the corridors, begin that granular moving outward kind of conversation and to sketch out a plan for how to approach that through next spring.

[Kit Collins]: Any other closing comments from councilors or other attendees?

[Kit Collins]: Seeing none, thank you all so much for a really productive conversation, a really productive exercise.

[Kit Collins]: Really grateful to everybody for being here.

[Kit Collins]: Moved to adjourn.

[Kit Collins]: Seconded by President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: All those in favor?

[Kit Collins]: Aye.

[Kit Collins]: All opposed?

[Kit Collins]: Meeting is adjourned.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much, everybody.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: At our June 25th meeting of the Planning and Permitting Committee, we met once again with the City Council's zoning consultant.

[Kit Collins]: The topic this time was to go over in more detail a work plan for the remainder of the year and the term.

[Kit Collins]: With that zoning consultant, moving plans and goals that have been placed in Medford's comprehensive plan, housing production plan

[Kit Collins]: climate action and adaptation plan and other public city plans into pieces of legislation that the council can consider debate and vote on.

[Kit Collins]: And at that meeting, we determined that the next meeting of the planning and permitting committee, which happens to be tomorrow, Wednesday, we would go over detailed zoning maps with the zoning consultant, followed by a discussion of housing related topics to further our work on global and district level zoning changes in the city.

[Kit Collins]: and to begin talking about housing-related issues.

[Kit Collins]: I move approval.

[Kit Collins]: President Bears, did Councilor Scarpelli move the question or is debate still out on the floor?

[Kit Collins]: I'll happily defer to Councilor Callahan while I collect my thoughts.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Councilor Scarpelli for bringing forward this topic of discussion.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Councilor Callahan for your words.

[Kit Collins]: Pardon me while I get my thoughts together.

[Kit Collins]: I'd like to...

[Kit Collins]: You know, I agree that the words accountability and transparency are used so often that they tend to lose meaning.

[Kit Collins]: And I think in this case, we're kind of having a community-wide discussion about what does transparency look like?

[Kit Collins]: Are we currently seeing it?

[Kit Collins]: Where aren't we seeing it that we would like to?

[Kit Collins]: I think if we want the city council to be transparent, then we have to be the forum that states the facts where there's misinformation going around.

[Kit Collins]: It is true that the city gets audited every year.

[Kit Collins]: That is a fact.

[Kit Collins]: I would not want to be untransparent and pretend that that is not the case.

[Kit Collins]: That is the case.

[Kit Collins]: The city is audited every year.

[Kit Collins]: It makes me saddened as a member of this council, as a colleague,

[Kit Collins]: to see our discussion and debate behind the rail go to this place.

[Kit Collins]: I see bodies like this as

[Kit Collins]: enacted for the purpose of having disagreement.

[Kit Collins]: We have had a lot of disagreement this year.

[Kit Collins]: We've had a lot of disagreement the previous term, my first term.

[Kit Collins]: There was plenty of disagreement the term before that.

[Kit Collins]: That is not a bug.

[Kit Collins]: That is a function.

[Kit Collins]: That is what democracy looks like, is getting people from the community who disagree with each other to represent the community, to have disagreements and try either by compromise or by vote

[Kit Collins]: to find a path forward.

[Kit Collins]: And hopefully a lot of the time we'll find our way to the best path forward.

[Kit Collins]: And if we don't, that's why we have elections and new people take these seats and they'll have a disagreements again, and maybe they'll arrive at different

[Kit Collins]: decisions by compromise or by vote.

[Kit Collins]: I think it's worth noting that the invoking of, I know that there's a couple issues at play here behind what was explicitly written about in the letter.

[Kit Collins]: I think it's worth noting that some of the inflammatory motions here that predated Councilor Scarpelli's communication to our partners at the state level,

[Kit Collins]: the invoking of Rule 21 and the suspension of Rule 21.

[Kit Collins]: I just want to state a few things.

[Kit Collins]: One, council rules are council rules.

[Kit Collins]: We've amended the council rules in the past.

[Kit Collins]: That can be put forward by any councillor.

[Kit Collins]: That's a thing that councillors are allowed to do and that we vote on them.

[Kit Collins]: I also think it's worth noting that rules have been suspended for time immemorial, at least as long as I've been paying attention.

[Kit Collins]: That's not new.

[Kit Collins]: Rule 21 has been invoked since I started paying attention.

[Kit Collins]: That's not new.

[Kit Collins]: Rules have been suspended for various reasons.

[Kit Collins]: For as long as I've been watching these meetings, that's not new.

[Kit Collins]: And I think, you know, when I look at the current climate,

[Kit Collins]: behind this rail at this team of people who were elected to work together and disagree together and take votes together, makes me wonder what's changed that instead of taking votes and moving on, taking votes and trying to find compromise and using the forum of the debate to try to be persuasive, try to listen in good faith and talk in good faith, you know,

[Kit Collins]: This is hard for me to do.

[Kit Collins]: But a lot of people behind this rail are speaking my mind, so I think that it's only fair that in the spirit of productive disagreement, you know, we do the same.

[Kit Collins]: I think it's important.

[Kit Collins]: that any member who finds themselves on the losing side of any vote to see that for what it is.

[Kit Collins]: And I think they owe it to this body to continue in the spirit of productive disagreement, not to gum up the works of the body through

[Kit Collins]: making allegations or accusations of inappropriate behavior, of breaking of the rules, of inappropriateness.

[Kit Collins]: I think that is harmful to what this body does.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think it's fair.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think it's good sportsmanship.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think it helps this community.

[Kit Collins]: I hope that

[Kit Collins]: after this spate of, frankly, misinformation that this community has been weathering and conversing about for the past couple of months, we can get back to a place where we say, we want this body to be productive.

[Kit Collins]: We don't want to sling mud at each other.

[Kit Collins]: We don't want to use our state-level partners as a forum for trying to bring each other down by claiming inappropriateness.

[Kit Collins]: Let's debate, let's discuss, let's disagree, let's yell at each other if we have to.

[Kit Collins]: That's nothing new.

[Kit Collins]: And then let's take the votes and move on and let's remember that we're all here because of votes that were cast.

[Kit Collins]: And that happens every two years.

[Kit Collins]: And I don't think it is helpful for our community at all to let

[Kit Collins]: these accusations of inappropriateness and illegality or allegations that heavily imply inappropriateness and illegality into the conversation.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think that is in the best interest of this body, which continues as a body after all of our terms are over.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Beasley.

[Kit Collins]: I think that being behind this rail carries a lot of responsibility, collectively and individually.

[Kit Collins]: When I speak about allegations, part of what I mean is that the narrative that we perpetuate as individuals and as a collective, we are responsible for that.

[Kit Collins]: It's very powerful in the community.

[Kit Collins]: The allegation, I think, is the narrative that has been created to draw a link between some of these events that a councilor is mentioning in past meetings.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think it is responsible to further a false narrative that actions taken by this council are towards the goal of silencing an opinion.

[Kit Collins]: I wanna briefly walk through a few items.

[Kit Collins]: One, and what I mean by the narrative is I think that what we're kind of all talking around is this narrative of one Councilor is being willfully silenced by collective actions of another.

[Kit Collins]: That is a very compelling narrative.

[Kit Collins]: That's a very compelling story.

[Kit Collins]: I'm gonna keep talking.

[Kit Collins]: The first meeting, Rule 21 was invoked to delay the free cash paper by one meeting.

[Kit Collins]: I want to remind people that Rule 21 is an undebatable motion.

[Kit Collins]: It is not the case that this is a collective action taken to silence that idea.

[Kit Collins]: Frankly, not that it matters.

[Kit Collins]: I wasn't in favor of tabling

[Kit Collins]: the free cash.

[Kit Collins]: I didn't like that that happened.

[Kit Collins]: It didn't matter.

[Kit Collins]: It's undebatable.

[Kit Collins]: It happened.

[Kit Collins]: It wasn't a collective action.

[Kit Collins]: I don't know the councilor's intentions in doing it, but it doesn't fit this narrative of collective action to silence one group, one person, or a constituency.

[Kit Collins]: At the next meeting, yes, I suspended the rules to say that we can't do rule 21 at this meeting.

[Kit Collins]: In general, I am not a fan of rule 21.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think it's productive.

[Kit Collins]: I think that it's something we should discuss as a council, whether it's worth keeping inside of our council rules.

[Kit Collins]: My explicit reason for doing it at that meeting was not to be a part of a coordinated effort to silence one person, group, or constituency, but because

[Kit Collins]: It was my understanding, and I believe this is true, that if we were to delay the budget past, if we were to not vote on the budget at that meeting, that would have pushed us past the deadline of issuing pink slips to teachers.

[Kit Collins]: And so if rule 21 had been invoked and we had tabled the budget, a lot of teachers would have gotten pink slips.

[Kit Collins]: I didn't have to, because the budget wouldn't have been finalized.

[Kit Collins]: That was my understanding, and that was my motivation for taking Rule 21 off of the table.

[Kit Collins]: You can disagree with it, but it doesn't fit the narrative of just being a coordinated effort to silence one person, group, or constituency, and I won't further that narrative.

[Kit Collins]: One other thing I want to say while I have the floor,

[Kit Collins]: I think it's a perpetual thorn in our side, this issue of free cash.

[Kit Collins]: One, because it's called such a confusing and inaccurate term, free cash.

[Kit Collins]: That's right.

[Kit Collins]: It's the community's cash.

[Kit Collins]: I'm going to finish.

[Kit Collins]: I'm going to finish my point.

[Kit Collins]: Free cash occurs when money that was budgeted to be spent was not spent.

[Kit Collins]: It's true that we have allocated up until our last city council meeting when we appropriated some of that free cash, that it is amassed to a very large number.

[Kit Collins]: Why are some neighboring communities have a balance of four or five million in free cash at a given time and we had 34?

[Kit Collins]: Because we were one of the,

[Kit Collins]: 3% of cities and towns in Massachusetts that had never ever set up a stabilization fund, which is a savings account.

[Kit Collins]: And that's why ours was growing and growing and growing, essentially in a checking account, a checking account that you can't use most of the year, instead of being appropriated into funds and departments where it can actually go to work for you, the taxpayers, for us, for our city departments.

[Kit Collins]: That's why that number grew so large, because we never appropriated it into a stabilization fund or a capital stabilization fund, both of which are mechanisms that we set up at the last meeting in June.

[Kit Collins]: And I just wanna add a little bit of, I just wanted to add that context to the discussion, because I can totally understand that it sounds egregious to say we have $34 million.

[Kit Collins]: And again, my analogy, I'm not a finance expert, is to say we have $34 million in a checking account,

[Kit Collins]: Why the heck would that be?

[Kit Collins]: Well, now we don't.

[Kit Collins]: Now we've put it into funds where it can actually go to use for the city, for the schools, for the taxpayers because of votes taken at the last meeting in June.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that's important because now it can actually be put to use for the residents and taxpayers of Medford.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Paris.

[Kit Collins]: I had finished my point.

[Kit Collins]: Sorry, there's just so much to talk about.

[Kit Collins]: You know what I mean?

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: You know, I think this is one of those issues where I think we really do agree in what we want.

[Kit Collins]: And we see it, we see what's happening differently.

[Kit Collins]: What really nettles me is we have so much, it's not like what we say, people in the community believe, because obviously that's not the case.

[Kit Collins]: But I think we, having one of these microphones is really powerful.

[Kit Collins]: It comes with a lot of influence.

[Kit Collins]: And I think every person behind this rail is in their way, in their different ways, really sensitive to the role that they occupy, the voice that they have, how people hear them, how they're framing the issues, how they're hearing the issues from the committee.

[Kit Collins]: I know that every Councilor behind this rail is very sensitive to the type

[Kit Collins]: of leader and listener and speaker and representative that they are perceived to be by the community.

[Kit Collins]: And that's why it is so upsetting to me when behind this rail, we further narratives and binaries that I think are both not true, but actively harmful to our ability to come together and work together.

[Kit Collins]: For example, setting up a binary between

[Kit Collins]: talking about your assumptions and opinions as though they are fact in a city council meeting versus meeting with department heads who are duplicitous to further your own agenda.

[Kit Collins]: That binary does not exist.

[Kit Collins]: And I don't think it is helpful to put that forward as your two options.

[Kit Collins]: That's not what happens.

[Kit Collins]: That's not what happens.

[Kit Collins]: I also don't think it's helpful

[Kit Collins]: to set up a binary between winning a vote and being actively silenced, we've all been on the losing side of the vote.

[Kit Collins]: And whether we feel maligned by that or victimized by that, I don't think it's fair to how we talk about these issues to get to pick and choose when we're going to waive that as a flag.

[Kit Collins]: And it's not that I want to minimize the experience of having something that you ardently believe in and getting shot down.

[Kit Collins]: I know that sucks.

[Kit Collins]: I've been there many times, my first term especially.

[Kit Collins]: But I think it is deeply unhelpful to the community, to this body being able to function at what it's supposed to do for us to broadcast that our two options are

[Kit Collins]: be a winning vote for some nefarious agenda or be a stymied, silenced constituency.

[Kit Collins]: Because I think that, you know, we talk about that's why we're divided.

[Kit Collins]: There's nothing more dividing than being told we're divided.

[Kit Collins]: I wish that we came into these conversations not already mad at each other, but willing to say what's happening here and being willing to listen to the answers.

[Kit Collins]: We had a conversation with the finance director

[Kit Collins]: before the budget about free cash projections, what it's been in the past, what is projected to be, why free cash accumulates the way that it does.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think it's fair to residents to keep having this conversation about how our accumulation of free cash, which has now been put into funds where it can be used for purposes throughout the year.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think it's fair to the residents to keep talking about this like it was some scheme.

[Kit Collins]: I don't get why it's fair to the people of this city to keep beating a drum that misinforms people.

[Kit Collins]: It's okay if you disagree.

[Kit Collins]: I just wish that we were able to talk about it.

[Kit Collins]: That's all.

[Kit Collins]: Hopefully this will be the last time I speak on this paper.

[Kit Collins]: I just wanted to note two things.

[Kit Collins]: I hear you that you wish there had been minutes coming out of the financial task force.

[Kit Collins]: You know, maybe the next time this is necessary, it'll be formed by committee instead of being a flexible ad hoc group.

[Kit Collins]: thing is that any decisions that came out of this task force were put to a vote in a public meeting.

[Kit Collins]: And I also think it's really relevant to note, I think it's a very critical distinction that any proposals came out that were discussed in the financial task force, of which I was a member, put forward to the city council, we approved them.

[Kit Collins]: Any residents who feel

[Kit Collins]: skeptical or uncomfortable or just disapproving of the proposals or of the process.

[Kit Collins]: What do you do?

[Kit Collins]: You go to the polls and you vote no.

[Kit Collins]: And that's the difference.

[Kit Collins]: You can do that.

[Kit Collins]: That's your right.

[Kit Collins]: That's your right.

[Kit Collins]: From now until the election, residents who happen to be in favor of the proposals

[Kit Collins]: we'll be making the case for them.

[Kit Collins]: There will be a lot of answers coming out.

[Kit Collins]: That's the process, because this is a thing that everybody gets to vote yes or no on.

[Kit Collins]: We will not be making that case from the podium because this is a matter that's going to be voted on, that would be improper.

[Kit Collins]: But this information, this case will be made.

[Kit Collins]: We will have a chance to discuss and debate the answer to those questions by we, I mean the community, in the community.

[Kit Collins]: Let's see if I can remember the second point I was going to make.

[Kit Collins]: I might have lost it.

[Kit Collins]: It's been a long day.

[Kit Collins]: We'll come back to you.

[Kit Collins]: Thanks.

[Kit Collins]: I agree.

[Kit Collins]: Okay, I agree.

[Kit Collins]: I'm sorry, I remember the point I was gonna make.

[Kit Collins]: I know, you're all thrilled.

[Kit Collins]: I do just want to,

[Kit Collins]: highlight, remind folks that the council did take a vote to have a committee of the whole, maybe sometime in the summer, early in the fall, to meet, to have a public meeting where the administration is present and we discuss the use of funds in our stabilization account.

[Kit Collins]: Just to let that be known, that's a vote that was already taken so that we can have a public discussion about free cash, where it went, how it's going to be used, because I know the administration has had a,

[Kit Collins]: ton of capital needs that a lot of that funding is already in demand for these capital projects that were already in the queue, paving, sidewalk repair, city infrastructure, and so on.

[Kit Collins]: I also think it's worth noting that the difference between saying, let's not even propose an override versus putting an override on the ballot and it fails,

[Kit Collins]: Same outcome.

[Kit Collins]: And lastly, I wanna note, again, I was not in favor of the Rule 21 motion to delay the vote on Councilor Scarpelli's free cash paper.

[Kit Collins]: The fact that we set up a stabilization fund and a capital stabilization fund and moved some of our 34 million reserves of free cash into the stabilization funds means that we can now use it

[Kit Collins]: Because of that, we could now use that money.

[Kit Collins]: And if we hadn't done that, that money would be unusable to the city.

[Kit Collins]: That's a fact, you can shake your head, but that's a fact.

[Kit Collins]: While the state is certifying free cash, we cannot touch it.

[Kit Collins]: And I still have not heard a compelling reason why making that surplus, that cash reserves unavailable to the community for the needs that we know we have, I fail to see

[Kit Collins]: why that is a better outcome than having it in funds where it is available to be used for the needs that we know we have.

[Kit Collins]: And I'm sorry, I really will shut up now.

[Kit Collins]: No.

[Kit Collins]: There will be a meeting of the Medford City Council Committee of the Whole, June 26, 2024.

[Kit Collins]: This meeting will take place at 6 p.m.

[Kit Collins]: in the City Council Chamber, second floor, Medford City Hall, 85 George P. Hassett Drive, Medford MA, and via Zoom.

[Kit Collins]: Madam Clerk, please call the roll.

[Kit Collins]: And President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Five present, two absent, the meeting is called.

[Kit Collins]: By present to absent, the meeting is called to order.

[Kit Collins]: The action and discussion item for this meeting is 24-006 offered by President Bears, review of the 2024-2025 council governing agenda.

[Kit Collins]: So as a brief refresher, this term, for the very first time, Medford City Council, at the beginning of the term, put together a governing agenda which lays out submissions from each councilor who chose to submit proposals, either that were already in committee from previous terms or new ideas, things that the City Council would like to work on over the course of this term.

[Kit Collins]: The process for putting together this document

[Kit Collins]: was paper 24-006 proposing the same.

[Kit Collins]: After that, there was a period during which councilors submitted proposals to council leadership, myself and President Bears, which were then organized into this document.

[Kit Collins]: We had a committee of the whole, like this one, we were discussed which committee each project ought to go into.

[Kit Collins]: And each project, if it didn't already have a paper number, has been,

[Kit Collins]: assigned a paper number as it's been proposed.

[Kit Collins]: So in this meeting, we are going to have our first check-in on this document.

[Kit Collins]: Now that's halfway through this year.

[Kit Collins]: It's a quarter of the way through the term.

[Kit Collins]: So this is a status meeting to review all of the papers currently in the governing agenda.

[Kit Collins]: And so the process for this meeting, we have about,

[Kit Collins]: 45 minutes, we're not gonna go past 7 p.m.

[Kit Collins]: to review the overall document.

[Kit Collins]: It's a long one, as people remember, that's quite a lengthy document.

[Kit Collins]: We're going to go section by section.

[Kit Collins]: We're going to have the chair of each committee, if they're present, do an overview of the papers in their committee.

[Kit Collins]: They can give a status update, they can give the highlight reel, just a brief overview of what's being worked on and any future plans to take up papers in that.

[Kit Collins]: committee your next steps for papers that have been worked on.

[Kit Collins]: I will ask my fellow Councilors to try not to take more than three or four minutes, five at the most, to go over the works in your committee so that we can all center around a general update across all committees and have a brief discussion at the end.

[Kit Collins]: Since President Bears will be joining us a little bit later on the meeting, I'm going to start three sections down with the education and culture

[Kit Collins]: committee, and then we can go clockwise from there.

[Kit Collins]: The chair of the Education and Culture Committee is Councilor Scarpelli, who I believe has to be absent tonight, reviewing the table of contents for this section.

[Kit Collins]: There were no major projects yet proposed in this committee, none of this draft, as with all of the other

[Kit Collins]: City Council committees.

[Kit Collins]: There are relevant city ordinances and regulations that are assigned to this committee, which it can sort of, you know, if there's free time that the committee has or it doesn't have an active legislative project, it can be reviewing those.

[Kit Collins]: I do not believe that the Education and Culture Committee has met yet to do any of this kind of maintenance work in order to take up any legislative projects so far.

[Kit Collins]: So we'll proceed to the Governance Committee, chaired by Councilor Tseng.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much, Councilor Tseng.

[Kit Collins]: We will proceed next to the planning and permitting committee of which I am the chair.

[Kit Collins]: So the update on this committee, I'll try to be brief.

[Kit Collins]: This is the committee that meets most often, been meeting twice a month since I believe February.

[Kit Collins]: Our major project, our most major project is zoning reform, which the Council has been working towards for longer than I have been on City Council.

[Kit Collins]: The City Council completed a phase one of recodification at the very beginning of my first term dealing with tweaks and cleanups to the zoning code.

[Kit Collins]: building code that were recommended by Attorney Bob Roski and city staff.

[Kit Collins]: Paper 24-033 represents phase two of our zoning reevaluation.

[Kit Collins]: The city council secured funding for a zoning consultant in 2022 and 2023, and that, with the help of the Planning, Development, and Sustainability Department, is manifesting in our contract with Innes Associates.

[Kit Collins]: We have been meeting with them at least monthly since March,

[Kit Collins]: on a work plan to overhaul the city zoning and bring it into alignment with the comprehensive plan, the housing production plan, and the climate action and adaptation plan, which were created collaboratively

[Kit Collins]: between city staff, the city council, and residents over the past several years.

[Kit Collins]: And we've gotten through kind of the initial tweaks, definitions, streamlining, kind of low-hanging fruit aspect of that process with the first package of zoning amendments that we passed earlier this month.

[Kit Collins]: And our next batch of work, I believe, is around using the mapping analysis, which was just completed by Innes Associates.

[Kit Collins]: We reviewed it last night.

[Kit Collins]: to develop a global approach to zoning changes, things that we want to see throughout the entire community and also neighborhood by neighborhood, district by district, corridor by corridor changes to bring smaller areas of the city into alignment with what residents want guided by those plans.

[Kit Collins]: So that is the, I think, most major project of this committee.

[Kit Collins]: There are other ordinance projects that go along with it.

[Kit Collins]: For example, transportation demand management

[Kit Collins]: proposed by Councilors Leming and Tseng, which also comes from the Climate Action Adaptation Plan.

[Kit Collins]: I know this has been brought up to city staff.

[Kit Collins]: There are other proposals in this committee, which have not yet been taken up at a super granular level, such as Green Score, which also has to do with the building code and making new developments more energy efficient and holding developers in Medford to a better environmental standard.

[Kit Collins]: This ordinance under the ordinances section, the condo conversion ordinance was recently subsumed into the zoning overhaul bucket of work.

[Kit Collins]: This aligns with our affordable housing goals that are very prominent in the goals of the zoning

[Kit Collins]: revaluation that we're doing so will be pursuing the condo conversion ordinance which was begun in 2022 within the context of the zoning overhaul.

[Kit Collins]: This committee is also where we have referred several housing home rule petitions, including rent stabilization we held one meeting on that.

[Kit Collins]: I'm the sponsor of that paper, I don't plan for us to meet on that until at least the fall.

[Kit Collins]: We also referred into this committee the housing home rule petition around the real estate transfer fee.

[Kit Collins]: The future of this local option at the State House is looking uncertain, I would say bleak, and so I think it's a discussion that I would like to have with my fellow councilors, what the fate of that home rule petition should be in this community.

[Kit Collins]: There are several other projects in this committee, including reviewing the fee schedule, which we have already begun, making sure that our administrative fees are brought into alignment with best practices from other neighboring committees to make sure that we're not charging way, way less than other communities are charging for things like marriage licenses, dog licenses, vehicles, just making sure that we're keeping up with best practices and updating things that haven't been updated in a very long time.

[Kit Collins]: The cycling safety ordinance, this has not been formally proposed yet.

[Kit Collins]: idea that I would like to put forward later in the term.

[Kit Collins]: And I know that our PDS department has already kind of included the goals of a cycling safety ordinance into our existing complete streets set of goals.

[Kit Collins]: Finally, some proposals that have not yet been formally introduced that have to do with energy efficiency for new and existing buildings, energy disclosure, the benchmarking ordinance,

[Kit Collins]: And finally the rental ice licensing ordinance also needs to be given a paper numbers.

[Kit Collins]: This was proposed.

[Kit Collins]: In March of this year we have not yet had a meeting on a specific proposal for the ordinance itself in this committee.

[Kit Collins]: Finally pesticide regulations and the blasting earth removal regulations these are 2 of the ordinance projects that we have not yet met on to go over language and perhaps they are things that will meet on later in the term.

[Kit Collins]: If our other priorities left for it.

[Kit Collins]: I also want to note that the Licensing, Permitting, and Signs Subcommittee exists within this committee.

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Scarpelli is the chair of this subcommittee, and he has held meetings with certain signs appeal applicants so far in the term.

[Kit Collins]: And that brings us to the Public Health and Community Safety Committee, which is chaired by Councilor Lazzaro.

[Kit Collins]: This is the February 2024 version, so yes, it's not up to date.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much, Chair Lazzaro.

[Kit Collins]: And just to reinforce, you know, I think that was an

[Kit Collins]: exceptional highlight reel of some of the work done so far in this committee and reconciling those headlines with the list of topics in the governing agenda.

[Kit Collins]: There's even more that has been referred into that committee that we have met on.

[Kit Collins]: We've been holding more committee meetings this year than ever before by quite a large magnitude.

[Kit Collins]: I see President Bears has raised his hand.

[Kit Collins]: Go ahead, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: or I'll unmute you, then I'm glad.

[Kit Collins]: I think this is my co-host.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much.

[Kit Collins]: We're just going in order of the governing agenda right now.

[Kit Collins]: So I thought we could come back to those right at the end and end on a high note.

[Kit Collins]: Next, we come to the Public Works and Facilities Committee, chaired by Councilor Callahan.

[Kit Collins]: Not in the chambers.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much, Councilor Callahan, really appreciate that overview.

[Kit Collins]: Next, we will go to Councilor Leming for an overview of the Resident Services and Public Engagement Committee.

[Kit Collins]: We will go back to the beginning of our document, and we can loop back to projects in committee of the whole, and then the administration and finance committee, and I believe President Bears is going to present on both of these.

[Kit Collins]: President Bears, I can relinquish screen sharing if you would prefer to do it yourself, or if that's not additive.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much President Bears for presenting on projects and committee of the whole and the administration and finance committee.

[Kit Collins]: Before we go to general comment, I also want to extend a note of gratitude to all of my fellow Councilors, including those who couldn't be here tonight for helming such productive committees.

[Kit Collins]: I said it earlier in the meeting that this is far and away the busiest council that certainly that I've been on, but also that I've observed as a constituent and especially to new Councilors who are just joining this term.

[Kit Collins]: I really want to applaud you for diving into your first year of service and leading

[Kit Collins]: on major legislative projects in committee, meeting regularly, pushing things forward.

[Kit Collins]: And of course, these are not ideas that simply come out of the clear blue sky.

[Kit Collins]: These are projects that residents have been asking for, sometimes for years.

[Kit Collins]: These are things pulled from our comprehensive plans, our comment plans, our housing plans.

[Kit Collins]: These are things that have come from city staff and the constituents that we know would make Medford a better place to live, to work, to raise a family.

[Kit Collins]: and I'm very grateful to this council for working together to have the most productive and collaborative term that we possibly can.

[Kit Collins]: President Bears, go ahead.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears on the motion by President Bears, seconded by Councilor Lazzaro.

[Kit Collins]: Madam Clerk, just let me know whenever you're ready.

[Kit Collins]: Six in favor one absent the motion for all committee chairs to submit updates to the President and Vice President and for the President and Vice President to accordingly update the governing agenda.

[Kit Collins]: also pulling from the council newsletters as guides to upload to the governing agenda and include a short summary of what committees have been meeting and overall takeaways.

[Kit Collins]: Passes.

[Kit Collins]: We were just speaking about that in the last committee meeting.

[Kit Collins]: What does it allow us to do by a special permit, which until this permit was withdrawn, applied to this permit, what do we wanna see on these corridors and how should we update our zoning so that we get what we want and we don't have to worry about what we don't want

[Kit Collins]: here.

[Kit Collins]: And I do want to note, I've been hearing this, you know, over and over for the past couple weeks, and I'm really heartened to hear it from so many people in the community saying, it's not that I think we shouldn't have this in Medford.

[Kit Collins]: It's just that the location has to be right.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that something I'm really certain we all share is that, you know, we know that this is something that people need.

[Kit Collins]: This is a service that people need, that people in Medford need, that our neighbors need.

[Kit Collins]: We want it to be successful.

[Kit Collins]: And in order to be successful, it needs to be in the right location.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that we can, I would love to prioritize this issue within our existing zoning work to make sure that as we're reevaluating our zoning already in progress, we're taking a look to say, where's the right spot for this use and how can we make sure that it can occur here and not in locations where it's going to be less successful and less supported by residents for understandable reasons.

[Kit Collins]: issue of affordable housing and doing it right in our community.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Beas.

[Kit Collins]: I want to thank everybody who spoke.

[Kit Collins]: I think that this is, you know, with any issue that we don't have consensus on, you know, lately, it seems like it's pretty easy for things to get polarized.

[Kit Collins]: When I listen to almost, not everybody, but almost everybody who's spoken on this issue at this meeting or who's emailed or called me or spoke at our last meeting, when I listen to almost all of those comments without any exception, I really do think that we all want the same thing.

[Kit Collins]: I've heard

[Kit Collins]: Very, very few number of people say, I actually don't want this anywhere in Medford.

[Kit Collins]: I think this has no place in Medford.

[Kit Collins]: I've heard a very few number of people say that.

[Kit Collins]: I personally don't believe that.

[Kit Collins]: I think this has a place in Medford.

[Kit Collins]: That doesn't mean it should go any place in Medford.

[Kit Collins]: I agree with that.

[Kit Collins]: The success of the mission depends on where we put it.

[Kit Collins]: And I think everybody who's come forward and said, I'm really concerned about where this was proposed to go, that's totally reasonable.

[Kit Collins]: If anybody's felt vilified for having that opinion, I'm sorry.

[Kit Collins]: I would never want anybody to feel that way.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think that you should be made to feel bad for voicing your opinion about where this should go or where it's going to be most successful.

[Kit Collins]: I know some people are motivated by their neighborhood concerns and other people are motivated by, I don't think this is gonna be most successful here, this doesn't make sense.

[Kit Collins]: If this should go in a commercial or industrial area, why don't we have the tools currently in place to put it there?

[Kit Collins]: That's actually under the jurisdiction of this body.

[Kit Collins]: That's what we have the power to do we've been working for a very long time, more terms that I've been on the council to get to a point where we have the resources to make those changes.

[Kit Collins]: When it comes to medical offices when it comes to many other uses so we can start finally start making decisions.

[Kit Collins]: That could be answers to the question of why don't we have X here?

[Kit Collins]: Why don't we have Y here?

[Kit Collins]: Why doesn't Medford look more like XYZ the way I want it to, the way it used to?

[Kit Collins]: We're finally amassing the resources to make those changes.

[Kit Collins]: They're not fast to make.

[Kit Collins]: We can't make them quickly.

[Kit Collins]: It's too technical.

[Kit Collins]: It's too detailed.

[Kit Collins]: That's a very unglamorous, but I think well-known thing about government is if you do it fast, you might do it wrong.

[Kit Collins]: And this is too important to not get right.

[Kit Collins]: But I just want to reinforce that when I hear people talk about this, I really think that we all, with some very, very few exceptions, we know that this has a place in Medford.

[Kit Collins]: We know that we want to take excellent care of the people whose lives will be better off for having this available.

[Kit Collins]: We know that there are people in Medford who do need this available.

[Kit Collins]: We know that we should find the best possible place for this to go.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think that this shared cause is advanced by

[Kit Collins]: using this forum to spread disinformation, such as there being a backroom deal to bring this into or to target a residential neighborhood.

[Kit Collins]: Of course that didn't happen.

[Kit Collins]: That would never happen.

[Kit Collins]: That's nobody's goals here.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think this conversation is advanced by being resolute to be at war over this.

[Kit Collins]: We're all on the same team here.

[Kit Collins]: If we want to be at war about this, if people in this room or people in this conversation are resolved to be at war about this,

[Kit Collins]: we can drag this congregation down into the mud.

[Kit Collins]: That's optional.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that's completely, completely orthogonal to everybody's goals here.

[Kit Collins]: know, in the role that we inhabit on the City Council, especially with something as longstanding as an ordinance, we can feel incredible about how a current Board of Commissioners takes up their mission and implements it, and certainly I feel great about the work that

[Kit Collins]: to go over the details of the questions raised by councillors before we move forward, unless there's an alternative proposal raised by my fellow councillors.

[Kit Collins]: If I'm being totally candid,

[Kit Collins]: If I'm being candid, part of the reason for my desire to have more of this discussion in a separate meeting is because we have five or six major financial papers to take up after this, and I don't want to have that conversation right now.

[Kit Collins]: That said, if there's another motion to approve it outright, we just take the votes, and I wouldn't take that personally.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: I think it's always helpful to have kind of a refresher on what free cash is and where it comes from, and the instability of that as a revenue source.

[Kit Collins]: I was thinking about it today.

[Kit Collins]: I was thinking about different ways to articulate it, and I think this is probably an imperfect way of conceptualizing it, but I was thinking of free cash as money that we did not intend to save, and that's partly true.

[Kit Collins]: But in part, our free cash is amassed because of positions that we intended to fill and pay people salaries for that because of various reasons, we didn't.

[Kit Collins]: And I think the responsible thing to do with public resources when we intended to use it for one source and we for some reason couldn't spend it on, for example, a salary, is to use that as revenue for paying for a capital need.

[Kit Collins]: where we otherwise wouldn't be able to amass the resources to, you know, we know that we have great capital needs in the city of Medford on so many of our public buildings.

[Kit Collins]: I mean, I could list them, but we don't even really need to between our public buildings and our roads and sidewalks and the high school, you know, on the topic of analogies.

[Kit Collins]: We don't need more, we don't need more analogies tonight.

[Kit Collins]: I think what's what's what feels like a central fact to me in making any decision about where to appropriate a free cash is that, you know, to rephrase, it's in no way a sustainable or predictable revenue source I think that we can certainly expect to responsibly to have.

[Kit Collins]: less free cash certified at the end of this fiscal year than we did at the end of this one, because a lot of those areas where we weren't spending as much as we were budgeting in FY 24, I know the administration worked really hard to get those out of the budget so that we could make the most use of every dollar that we are budgeting for.

[Kit Collins]: And I think it's incredibly irresponsible to spend funds that have a really clear

[Kit Collins]: floor at the bottom of that bank account on needs that are not going away because they're part of our operating budget and they pay for the school experience and pay for teachers.

[Kit Collins]: Because what are we going to do when that money is gone?

[Kit Collins]: It's not a sustainable revenue source.

[Kit Collins]: But then I'm getting onto a future topic here.

[Kit Collins]: On the topic of the MSBA feasibility study, and we're talking about transparent government and, you know, leading in a way that manifests the will of the public.

[Kit Collins]: I know that a

[Kit Collins]: better, safer, more vibrant, more appropriate.

[Kit Collins]: Medford High School is something that so many people in the community have been crying out for for such a long time.

[Kit Collins]: And this appropriation is a necessary step in the process of maintaining our eligibility for getting the funding that could get us there.

[Kit Collins]: And so this vote is crucial.

[Kit Collins]: And I think this is an unambiguously good use for this $3 million.

[Kit Collins]: And I'll motion to approve.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Pierce.

[Kit Collins]: I want to preface by saying I haven't always been fully, in the past, I haven't felt fully comfortable with the volume of free cash that the city has amassed, but I think that this type of plan really puts data to the intuition that there's things, important, unskippable projects that this money is being saved and appropriated for, things that we do not have other sustainable ways of funding.

[Kit Collins]: whether it's, you know, fleet replacements in the fire department, stabilization funds, which are essentially, you know, a piggy bank for the city in the same way that a person or a household has a savings bank.

[Kit Collins]: Communities need them for the same reasons of responding to emergencies responsibly.

[Kit Collins]: liabilities for pensions and insurance.

[Kit Collins]: I think it's really helpful to have a draft of this plan for how this, you know, you just look at the number 25 million, 34 million now, you think, wow, that's a lot of money.

[Kit Collins]: Like, why, what are we sitting on that for?

[Kit Collins]: And I think it's so important to have a draft plan for how it's going to be appropriated, because that number gets whittled down very, very quickly when we take stock of the

[Kit Collins]: stabilization funds that we ought to get in line with best practices in terms of how much we are saving for those rainy days and emergencies and for the major operating capital expenses that we need funding for that we're not going to fund out of our operating budget.

[Kit Collins]: So I think that this is a great start.

[Kit Collins]: I'm very happy to approve this tonight.

[Kit Collins]: I would also want to put forward a B paper to schedule a committee of the whole to discuss the free cash plan in more detail with the council and with the administration.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for presenting on this.

[Kit Collins]: And it means a lot to me that the school committee, you know, the majority of them thought that this was

[Kit Collins]: worth moving forward and, you know, this does not, in my understanding, passage of this does not automatically, of course, it doesn't automatically consolidate any functions between the city and the schools department.

[Kit Collins]: What it does is it allows us to have those discussions about what functions might be advantageous to consolidate, might help us

[Kit Collins]: streamline things that both the cities and Metro Public Schools are doing might help us save money on things that we're currently doing in two places, would allow us to have those discussions and then be able to act on them if we come to decisions that some departments are worth combining.

[Kit Collins]: So I will be happy to approve this tonight.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Motion to approve.

[Kit Collins]: Council and city staff and community initiatives into topics that can be broken down then into actual language changes to apply to our code of zoning ordinances to bring Medford zoning more in line with what the community has been articulating that it really wants over the past few years.

[Kit Collins]: I'll echo that last comment specifically.

[Kit Collins]: So knowing exactly where we are in that process will be critical to accomplishing as much of this as possible.

[Kit Collins]: Just some quick reactions from me.

[Kit Collins]: You know at this time, I'm really heartened to hear of the priority list that we've drafted and of course all of this is going to shift and evolve as projects tend to do over the next year.

[Kit Collins]: But it's been clear to me from our previous conversations in this committee and hearing feedback from

[Kit Collins]: City staff and of course from the community that, you know, that Mystic F corridor is one of the areas of the city that I hear the most about from just regular average people when it comes to why is this the way that it is and what are we going to do to make it what we really want there.

[Kit Collins]: Same for Salem corridor.

[Kit Collins]: So I think it's really right that we're thinking about how to approach that geography first.

[Kit Collins]: And in reviewing that kind of off the cuff list of priorities from Councilors at our previous committee meeting on the 12th, I know we all agreed that each one of these topics is urgent and critical, but that doing what we can around affordable housing, really implementing what we've already resolved to do around affordable housing absolutely has to come first.

[Kit Collins]: So I am,

[Kit Collins]: excited to address those starting in the summer.

[Kit Collins]: So let's plan for that.

[Kit Collins]: Paola, go ahead.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Paola, and I think that that matrix of importance and urgency will be really helpful to us in determining exactly what to talk about when, kind of to the point of what we were just talking about and the point that Director Hunt raised with the example of the uses currently allowed by Right on Mystic Ave, or sorry, in industrial zones.

[Kit Collins]: with that being said, just one thing.

[Kit Collins]: Yeah, agree.

[Kit Collins]: I'll add that as a note.

[Kit Collins]: I'm not really stepping in.

[Kit Collins]: Just taking a quick note.

[Kit Collins]: Right.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I think, to my mind, kind of to wrap up to talk about our next steps for the 26th, totally hear you.

[Kit Collins]: I know that's an important conflict.

[Kit Collins]: I think what might be additive for Councilors to follow up with the consultant about ahead of our next meeting is if Councilors feel moved to kind of further embellish the priorities that we talked about just now with doing a version of that importance versus urgency matrix that Paola showed earlier.

[Kit Collins]: If that hasn't already, you know, if there's anything that city staff have to

[Kit Collins]: care to add along those lines, especially since you won't be present at our next committee meeting or actually scratch that last part because this is going to be completed by that committee meeting anyway.

[Kit Collins]: We'll just be reviewing it.

[Kit Collins]: But I think that making sure that all of those, all of those thoughts, you know, are kind of on the record ahead of our next meeting in terms of what's our priority and also what's a priority because it really needs to be done sooner rather than later.

[Kit Collins]: President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for that suggestion.

[Kit Collins]: I was actually thinking along similar lines earlier, and I know this committee meets a lot, but we're doing some of the most substantive work that the council is gonna do this year.

[Kit Collins]: So if that can help move the ball forward to a place that we're all comfortable with, that sets us up with the information and context that they need to have a really ideally functional work plan for us, I think it's time well spent.

[Kit Collins]: So we can work on that over the next week to make sure, you know, to assess how valuable that would be and make sure that people would be free at that time.

[Kit Collins]: I could circulate that to committee members with the invitation to fill that out.

[Kit Collins]: you know, within the next week, through me, I could send that back to you as some additional context for building out the work plan, just to make sure that, you know, again, all of those strongly held opinions about importance and urgency are on the record when we put forward this work plan.

[Kit Collins]: We're looking forward to having the completed mapping analysis to review on June 26th, and then we can also make sure that the spreadsheet of

[Kit Collins]: recommended zoning changes pulled from the cap and the comp plan is updated along the lines that we discussed at the beginning of the meeting.

[Kit Collins]: You know, adjusting that template so that it looks a little bit more similar to the implementation matrix that we're used to from the cap.

[Kit Collins]: You know, kind of having it flow from global to strategy so that they're not in the same column.

[Kit Collins]: Having it sortable by district based strategy versus global strategy versus strategies that could apply in either case.

[Kit Collins]: Great.

[Kit Collins]: And when is the work planned for?

[Kit Collins]: Motion to approve pending the public comment period with the conditions recommended by the city engineer.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: This has come before City Council at a regular meeting once before when we procedurally had to refer it to the Community Development Board before it can come back to us for a formal vote.

[Kit Collins]: This is the first package of zoning change proposals to come out of the Planning and Permitting Committee.

[Kit Collins]: That committee has been working all year so far with the City Council's new zoning consultant on a host of zoning-related goals.

[Kit Collins]: And this is that first set.

[Kit Collins]: These are namely

[Kit Collins]: What I would characterize as formatting, streamlining, and procedural changes.

[Kit Collins]: We'll get to our discussions of more of those bigger themes and bigger changes later in the year.

[Kit Collins]: These are simpler.

[Kit Collins]: The first is to, as was stated, just to quickly restate that we all know what we're talking about, changing the format of the table of uses and parking regulations so that that table is more readable.

[Kit Collins]: The intent of this is to put the parking and loading requirements into a format that is more

[Kit Collins]: intuitive, easier to understand switching away from a code based model.

[Kit Collins]: And so that it's all on the same page.

[Kit Collins]: So people who would like to do business in the city of Medford don't have to flip through our rather long code of ordinances to find what they're looking for.

[Kit Collins]: The second is many definitions were amended or added into the definitional tables that these could be made useful later in the zoning process or to just update and modernize the definitions that we're currently using.

[Kit Collins]: All of these changes were rigorously considered with city staff as well as zoning consultants over the course of several meetings in April and May.

[Kit Collins]: We are also taking a vote to adopt the GIS digital version of our zoning map.

[Kit Collins]: There are no substantive changes being proposed to the zoning map.

[Kit Collins]: This is just to make it so the official on-the-book zoning map for the city of Medford is the one that is digital, is the one that has GIS letters, and is not the one that is quite literally paper and colored pencil.

[Kit Collins]: A good step for year 2024.

[Kit Collins]: Finally, the last proposal in this package is to exempt certain municipal uses from the table of use in parking regulations and the table of dimensional requirements.

[Kit Collins]: This is to streamline the process for the building of certain city infrastructure so that those buildings, for example, hypothetically, a new fire infrastructure, wouldn't have to go through the cumbersome zoning ordinance, zoning, sorry, zoning variance regulations that it would otherwise potentially be subjected to.

[Kit Collins]: I would motion to take the first vote to be ordained after a comment from my colleagues.

[Kit Collins]: Need I make a motion to adopt the recommendation from the CDB in my motion?

[Kit Collins]: Motion to approve with the typographical suggestion from the CDB.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I would motion to suspend the rules to take papers 24-415, 24-045, 24-410, 24-413, 24-414,

[Kit Collins]: out of order to join those papers for consideration and to suspend Rule 21.

[Kit Collins]: Yes.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Mayor.

[Kit Collins]: Nice to see you.

[Kit Collins]: I want to thank you for the comprehensive proposal.

[Kit Collins]: I also want to thank you for presenting each of these pieces in context of one another.

[Kit Collins]: For me, that is the theme and the precondition for this budget season is all of these pieces have to work together.

[Kit Collins]: This is my third budget season that I've had as a councilor.

[Kit Collins]: This is the least chaotic one so far.

[Kit Collins]: Let me put that another way.

[Kit Collins]: We're facing some really big difficulties here.

[Kit Collins]: The budget process has always been difficult.

[Kit Collins]: It's been difficult while I've been on the council.

[Kit Collins]: I know it's been difficult before.

[Kit Collins]: We're coming off of a really difficult period.

[Kit Collins]: I've always made it clear what my red lines are.

[Kit Collins]: This collaborative process has allowed us to reach a budget plan that I am

[Kit Collins]: comfortable and happy to put forward tonight.

[Kit Collins]: We have known for a while that Medford has a funding problem.

[Kit Collins]: This has been the topic of so many conversations between me and my colleagues in these chambers, outside of these chambers, the school funding problem and infrastructure funding problem, the capacity building problem, the problem of weaning off of one-time funds.

[Kit Collins]: These are not problems that are unique to Medford.

[Kit Collins]: They're problems that we have to work through.

[Kit Collins]: In the two and a half years that I have been on the council, we have discussed, I think, every mechanism that could contribute towards the solution.

[Kit Collins]: As a council, we've made zoning changes that could promote new growth, and we're working on more in our continuing zoning work that we'll put to votes later in the term.

[Kit Collins]: We've discussed the city's ARPA strategy.

[Kit Collins]: President Bears and I even proposed an override back in 2022, though it did not move forward, and that was robustly discussed in the previous term.

[Kit Collins]: This year, everybody is well aware that countdown clock on our strategy for the future is hitting zero.

[Kit Collins]: ARPA and ESSER are going offline.

[Kit Collins]: So since last fall, the financial task force, which was convened last year as a condition of the FY24 budget, has been meeting to talk about what's next.

[Kit Collins]: I've been really proud to be a part of that process, which I joined when I joined city council leadership at the beginning of this term.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that that has been part of that

[Kit Collins]: that really important critical pivot towards greater collaboration, which has also been affirmed by you and your staff's participation in the budget ordinance process, as well as this collaboration on meeting the needs of this budget season.

[Kit Collins]: This is the culmination of many meetings over many months discussing precisely what

[Kit Collins]: our needs are and how to meet them.

[Kit Collins]: We have rigorously considered the needs facing Medford public schools and city infrastructure.

[Kit Collins]: Among these branches of government, we certainly don't always agree, but the bottom line is that there's a set of facts and a set of goals that we are completely aligned on.

[Kit Collins]: then I also believe that the community fundamentally is aligned on.

[Kit Collins]: We need to maintain at least level service at MPS, we need to staff it properly, and we need to enable public education to start getting better.

[Kit Collins]: We need our roads and sidewalks to start getting better.

[Kit Collins]: We need to be in a position

[Kit Collins]: to pay our city and school staff competitively, and unless we take action, those things will not happen.

[Kit Collins]: Our schools will not be what we want them to be, what we need them to be.

[Kit Collins]: We will lose students to private schools, and those who cannot afford that type of expense will suffer the most.

[Kit Collins]: Our infrastructure will depreciate.

[Kit Collins]: Those costs will get passed along to individuals at even higher rates, and we will lose good city workers to other municipalities or the private sectors.

[Kit Collins]: There's always been a lot to discuss in how we solve these problems, but I truly believe that, for the most part, we are aligned on these facts and these goals, because we all know that those outcomes are unacceptable.

[Kit Collins]: And I think a hallmark of this proposal on how to pivot towards the future hinges on a combined approach of coming out of the reason that we're

[Kit Collins]: Sorry, can you tell I'm nervous?

[Kit Collins]: This is only the biggest vote that we take all year.

[Kit Collins]: Pardon me.

[Kit Collins]: Just breaking the fourth wall here for a sec.

[Kit Collins]: You know, we only had ARPA and ESSER to wean off of in the first place because we're coming off of such a hard time.

[Kit Collins]: And now we're adapting to that new normal, figuring out what it will require of us, and taking the affirmative steps to gain the revenue that we need to keep Medford a place that supports the people that live here.

[Kit Collins]: So for me, this budget is conditioned on its context.

[Kit Collins]: We are considering it in the context of two override proposals, one from President Bears and I, one from you, Mayor, totaling $7.5 million, which if they pass, will start stabilizing our school and city operating budgets in quarter three of this fiscal year.

[Kit Collins]: We're considering that in the context of a $1.75 million appropriation to stabilize the school department in quarters one and two of this year.

[Kit Collins]: And to me, that's critical.

[Kit Collins]: That is what my sense of confidence in this plan is hinged on.

[Kit Collins]: That gives us the breathing room to get to the override vote, which we put to residents in November without devastating effects happening to the school's department in the meantime.

[Kit Collins]: And then the overrides should they pass will allow us to start investing in things getting better and bringing up that baseline year over year.

[Kit Collins]: I know that a lot of people are frustrated that we have to be here at all contemplating overrides.

[Kit Collins]: I think that totally makes sense.

[Kit Collins]: I really do.

[Kit Collins]: I also wish that we were, I wish that this was something that no municipality had to contemplate.

[Kit Collins]: But I think it's important context to note that since 1990, 300 of the 351 cities and towns in Massachusetts have advanced at least one override.

[Kit Collins]: And many of them have done them lots of times.

[Kit Collins]: There have been over 4,500 individual overrides on ballots in municipalities since 1990.

[Kit Collins]: For debt exclusions, that number is even higher.

[Kit Collins]: There's been 313 cities and towns that have advanced debt exclusions since 1989.

[Kit Collins]: totaling over 4,000 individual debt exclusions.

[Kit Collins]: So I just put that out there to say, it is really serious to do this.

[Kit Collins]: It is really serious.

[Kit Collins]: And that's why I'm glad that this is a mechanism that goes on the ballot so that residents of Medford will choose by popular vote.

[Kit Collins]: It is serious, but it is not an aberration to do this.

[Kit Collins]: I think that the fact that Medford is one of those few municipalities that has never done this is part of the reason that

[Kit Collins]: Our budget seasons have been so hard lately.

[Kit Collins]: And I'm proud that we're advancing proposals to start pivoting towards a more sustainable future.

[Kit Collins]: So I will close by saying I am happy that this year we get to vote on not just a budget, but a plan to advance Medford out of underfunding and into a future where we can reliably provide better services for all students and all residents in our community.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: I went pretty long earlier.

[Kit Collins]: I'll try to keep this short, bring my average down.

[Kit Collins]: First thing, about the financial task force.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that there's some people who don't need to hear this, but when we talk about the press release that was released on Friday, that we all collaborated on, city council leadership, mayor and the mayor staff, school committee leadership,

[Kit Collins]: What that press release contained was the budget that was already made public, line by line, department by department, that the city council had already reviewed in budget hearings that the entire community was privy to if they cared to read those agendas or attend the meetings.

[Kit Collins]: those same numbers, very minor, essentially all the numbers that we already had plus one and three quarters million dollars from ARPA to the schools proposed and the two overrides and debt exclusion that everybody gets to vote on.

[Kit Collins]: So just to clarify what was presented on Friday

[Kit Collins]: and how transparent or untransparent it was, was all the numbers that the city council and the school and the public already had, plus an appropriation of one-time funds, which many people, including myself, were hoping to see and working to secure.

[Kit Collins]: And then three things that we get to put to the voters.

[Kit Collins]: So I just want to set the record straight on that, because I think there's a lot of editorializing going on.

[Kit Collins]: Second, we have discussed free cash a lot on this council, last term, this term.

[Kit Collins]: I have had, you know, it's no secret that we disagree on a lot of things.

[Kit Collins]: We agree on a lot of things.

[Kit Collins]: I've had some pretty sincere concerns about our free cash strategy in the past.

[Kit Collins]: I have my own wishlist for how I'd like to see some of that money appropriated, which I know is different than the strategy that the mayor has.

[Kit Collins]: To me,

[Kit Collins]: That is irrelevant here.

[Kit Collins]: I do not see the end game in appropriating large sums of our free cash reserves towards operating costs.

[Kit Collins]: What is the end game of that?

[Kit Collins]: We end up back here.

[Kit Collins]: we can wish upon a star that we're going to see new growth accelerate at such an incredible rate that we are going to be able to fill that gap exactly in 12 months.

[Kit Collins]: But I don't think that we should be budgeting on wishful thinking.

[Kit Collins]: Again, I've had sincere concerns and grievances about how we're using free cash in the past.

[Kit Collins]: I have my own preferences.

[Kit Collins]: It is not the path forward that I think the community wants and needs to

[Kit Collins]: allocate money towards the problem that we may never ever see again.

[Kit Collins]: It pushes the can down the road.

[Kit Collins]: I also think that finding these proposals divisive is completely a choice.

[Kit Collins]: That's one of the wonderful things about this being a ballot question.

[Kit Collins]: I think, you know, we're a room full of people who have

[Kit Collins]: voted differently on things in the past, we will again in the future.

[Kit Collins]: And that doesn't have to make us any less of a community.

[Kit Collins]: We can talk about it and discuss it and debate about it.

[Kit Collins]: And some people will campaign one way and some people will campaign another way.

[Kit Collins]: And it does not have to divide us.

[Kit Collins]: That is a choice.

[Kit Collins]: And I think when people are telling you that you're being divided,

[Kit Collins]: You should pay attention to what the motives behind that imperative might be.

[Kit Collins]: You don't have to be divided by this.

[Kit Collins]: This can actually bring us together in a city with a future that is going to be brighter and more supportive because of what we might do with these investments if we pass them.

[Kit Collins]: Not willing to pass a budget based on wishful thinking.

[Kit Collins]: We can wish that new growth was different in the past.

[Kit Collins]: We can wish for dramatic new growth over the next 12 months that'll solve all of our problems.

[Kit Collins]: That wouldn't be responsible.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think that what we want as duly elected leaders of the community is for the ability to point the finger and blame somebody else for our problems.

[Kit Collins]: I think we're all here to solve problems.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.
