[Kit Collins]: We're taking it from the table.

[Kit Collins]: How's it going?

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears, and thank you for co-sponsoring this resolution with me.

[Kit Collins]: I'm very happy to recognize and celebrate Caribbean American Heritage Month.

[Kit Collins]: We have many community members that are part of this vibrant community here in Medford, and it's great to have an opportunity to acknowledge these folks who hail from the Caribbean and have landed in Medford.

[Kit Collins]: sometimes for a short time, sometimes for many generations, and to celebrate the ways that their culture and their contributions add so much to our community here in Medford.

[Kit Collins]: So a happy Caribbean American Heritage Month to us all.

[Kit Collins]: Present.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Chair Lazzaro.

[Kit Collins]: Just to recap, I believe we had our first substantive discussion about this ordinance in February.

[Kit Collins]: At that time, the committee approved a motion for me as sponsor of the paper to draft a, actually I believe we motioned to have an ordinance be drafted in February, I believe we discussed it in March.

[Kit Collins]: I based the draft off of wildlife feeding ordinances that are present in other of our, you know, nearby or neighboring

[Kit Collins]: communities in Massachusetts and beyond.

[Kit Collins]: To quickly recap on the intent and goals of this ordinance, this is not an ordinance to illegalize bird feeders or to prevent any sort of normal

[Kit Collins]: activity that we do with, you know, household animals or songbirds.

[Kit Collins]: This is in response to problems that residents have noted in the community with

[Kit Collins]: food scraps being inappropriately left out as kind of deliberate lures for wild animals or inadvertent lures for wild animals that are creating the presence of, you know, a kind of destructive presence of wildlife.

[Kit Collins]: In our residential neighborhoods, a couple residents have come to me and said, you know,

[Kit Collins]: My neighbors have this practice of leaving out XYZ unopened containers.

[Kit Collins]: It's really a lot of food, it's a lot of peanuts, it's a lot of seeds, what have you.

[Kit Collins]: And it would be one thing if the raccoons or the pigeons would stay on their side of the fence, but obviously animals do not observe private property.

[Kit Collins]: And our code enforcement currently does not have a mechanism for enforcing

[Kit Collins]: this type of nuisance.

[Kit Collins]: So the intent of this ordinance is not to legalize any sort of harmless animal related activity, but just to be able to provide a recourse for Code Enforcement or Board of Health to issue warnings or tickets in the case of inappropriate animal feeding that really is creating a nuisance for other people.

[Kit Collins]: So at our last meeting on this topic in March, we passed several motions to receive feedback on the ordinance from department heads, code enforcement, from the Board of Health, from the animal control officer, and to receive a legal review.

[Kit Collins]: So we have received some feedback from department heads on the ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: I don't know if any of them are on the call tonight.

[Kit Collins]: I have some comments in my email from department heads.

[Kit Collins]: We also did receive a legal review from KP Law yesterday midday.

[Kit Collins]: So this is the first chance that the council has to consider legal opinion on the ordinance as well.

[Kit Collins]: So that's the recap of where we are so far and I have

[Kit Collins]: comments that I can offer about where I think we should go next with this, but I'll pause there.

[Kit Collins]: No, I was just gonna make a comment, but I wanted to wait for you to recognize me.

[Kit Collins]: Oh, go ahead, please.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I just wanted to, I think that, so this is the first time that we're seeing the legal review and just to recenter on, you know.

[Kit Collins]: possible avenues for this committee.

[Kit Collins]: We have the feedback from department heads that we could review on the draft ordinance, and most of that has been positive and affirming.

[Kit Collins]: There's been some suggestions for how to just firm up the language a little bit, but no contesting of the goals.

[Kit Collins]: There are some comments from residents that I've received that I'd like to at least put on the record.

[Kit Collins]: And then this is our first opportunity to review the legal review together.

[Kit Collins]: So I think that it's possible that there might be some language changes that this committee might want to consider before we report this out to committee of the whole, just because we haven't had a chance to consider this legal opinion until doing it live.

[Kit Collins]: Great.

[Kit Collins]: So I am happy to, because we don't have council with us here tonight, I'm happy to kind of run through.

[Kit Collins]: Um, this overview of the legal review of the ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: And then I would also at the end, I would motion to circulate the legal review to committee members that we can, um, review.

[Kit Collins]: Yes.

[Kit Collins]: Uh, one second.

[Kit Collins]: Great.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Excellent.

[Kit Collins]: So I'm gonna go over this kind of, I'm gonna try to go over this briefly.

[Kit Collins]: There was a recommendation to, I think, disaggregate intent from purpose and intent, or there was a recommendation that

[Kit Collins]: Here, Attorney Braun says, some municipalities seek to add an intent element to distinguish between accidental feedings and intentional misconduct.

[Kit Collins]: As written, the section A just reads, the intent of this ordinance is to protect the health, safety, and welfare of the community.

[Kit Collins]: That does seem to me like a good suggestion in the intent section to say the point of this is to target intentional inappropriate feeding, so that it's very clear that I've received some questions from residents around

[Kit Collins]: What does this mean for the garden in my backyard?

[Kit Collins]: What does this mean for my beehive?

[Kit Collins]: What does this mean for my bird feeder?

[Kit Collins]: And I do think it's important to make it clear that this is really targeting inappropriate feeding and not accidental feeding that does not result in nuisance.

[Kit Collins]: Though I think it is also true that this is an ordinance that will only be enforced when a problem actually occurs.

[Kit Collins]: And so I think that's an important part of that remedy as well.

[Kit Collins]: So there's a suggestion, i.e., whenever the animal control officer becomes aware the wildlife has been found feeding on any substance, dot dot dot, and the resident or person responsible has been notified of the occurrence thereof, any subsequent feeding shall be evidence that the feeding was with the knowledge or intent.

[Kit Collins]: So that's, again, to focus on when somebody was given the opportunity to know better and kept doing it anyway.

[Kit Collins]: We have a comment about

[Kit Collins]: if, you know, garbage or compost centers unintentionally being the source of wildlife feeding.

[Kit Collins]: Again, this is kind of around making sure that nuisances don't accidentally arise.

[Kit Collins]: I think that there's a section later in this ordinance that kind of takes care of this in other language that essentially says, you know, the first penalty for violating this ordinance should it pass is never simply getting a fine, but rather

[Kit Collins]: you know, the enforcing officer saying, it looks like this is a source of a problem on your property, please remedy it.

[Kit Collins]: And then failure to remedy it, of course, might require a further remedy.

[Kit Collins]: There's a recommendation to define what a bird feeder is, just so there's no ambiguity there.

[Kit Collins]: always count on attorneys to point out to us what seems specific that might actually not be.

[Kit Collins]: Likewise, a recommendation to define pets, and this brings up a comment that was made earlier in this process, where do feral cats or stray cats fall?

[Kit Collins]: Consider whether we want to specifically address cats, such as no person shall feed any feral or stray cat, or this section shall not apply to persons feeding feral or stray cats with the express purpose of adopting and domesticating them within a certain set number of days.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that might be something of interest to this committee based on comments that were made in earlier meetings.

[Kit Collins]: Going further down to enforcement and penalties.

[Kit Collins]: Attorney Braun says, in my opinion, the non-criminal disposition statute requires that an ordinance must specify the enforcing authority to place residents on notice and may not delegate a designee to do so.

[Kit Collins]: I have a question about this because this seems dissimilar from how some of our other ordinances are written.

[Kit Collins]: We often put X department head or their designee into our ordinances.

[Kit Collins]: So I think this is certainly something that I'd want to double check.

[Kit Collins]: So to summarize, it appears to me that many of the comments are around defining with more specificity those terms around bird feeder pets.

[Kit Collins]: So it's very clear, you know, what is an allowable use in the case of bird feeders, which I think is a very common allowable use.

[Kit Collins]: Making sure that it's clear

[Kit Collins]: what I'm going to put in air quotes, what sanctioned animals, you know, are and are not included.

[Kit Collins]: And I think the exception for feral cats where there's the intent to domesticate and vaccinate them is one that might be relevant to Medford residents.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that there's a way to perhaps synthesize the suggestion around clarifying, you know, unintentional

[Kit Collins]: Nuisance creation via compost containers or garbage.

[Kit Collins]: I think there's a way to just like dovetail that more specifically with the language that's already in the ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: And perhaps shoring up the intent section.

[Kit Collins]: I have Most of the comments from residents that I have gotten apart from those who tell me that we really need this ordinance because they really need a remedy for

[Kit Collins]: the nuisances that are finding their way onto their property because of foodstuffs that are adjacent to their homes.

[Kit Collins]: A lot of those center around, you know, what does this mean about, again, what does this mean about my vegetable plot?

[Kit Collins]: What does this mean about my outdoor barbecue?

[Kit Collins]: What does this mean about my bird feeder?

[Kit Collins]: What does this mean about my beehive?

[Kit Collins]: Should I ever get one?

[Kit Collins]: And I think that the intent section could help to clarify, or sorry, excuse me, could help to clarify one, that

[Kit Collins]: This is an ordinance that seeks to correct for nuisances when they occur.

[Kit Collins]: We're not trying to outlaw any, we're not trying to regulate something that isn't causing a problem, but also to give more clarity around this is not,

[Kit Collins]: This is not something that's trying to eradicate any possible source of foodstuffs from somebody's backyard.

[Kit Collins]: It's just simply trying to create the mechanism by which when there's a problem, code enforcement actually has an ordinance to point to so that they can enforce about it.

[Kit Collins]: Because right now residents don't really have a recourse.

[Kit Collins]: So I'll pause there.

[Kit Collins]: Yeah.

[Kit Collins]: And just to add on to what you're already saying, and I can say this with some authority because I was on a

[Kit Collins]: has a number of.

[Kit Collins]: the former Solid Waste Task Force when we spoke quite at length about the role of the composting program and understandable resident concerns about the composting containers.

[Kit Collins]: They're actually harder for animals to get into than the trash and recycling residential containers that residents are used to because most of them are actually locking.

[Kit Collins]: They're a thick plastic, they're locking, they have lids, and they have been shown in other communities to actually reduce the extent to which

[Kit Collins]: waste receptacles are an attraction to wildlife.

[Kit Collins]: So I certainly wouldn't want to give off the impression that composting is expected to be a greater attraction for wildlife.

[Kit Collins]: And I think this again gets into not specific to trash and compost receptacles in particular, but rather, if anything, anything mundane happens to become an attraction for a nuisance, what then?

[Kit Collins]: And I think

[Kit Collins]: I think this is in line with how the ordinance is currently written, and perhaps there's a clarification we can make.

[Kit Collins]: But just to shore up that, if something is attracting a nuisance, the first step is to, for if neighbors can't work it out amongst themselves, for a city designee to say, this is attracting a nuisance, it's time to fix it.

[Kit Collins]: And then if a remedy doesn't occur, then we have the same recourse that we do for any other nuisance that's going unremitied, which is a warning, a ticket, and then a fine.

[Kit Collins]: I think my recommendation, and if there's assent for this, I'm happy to offer it as a form of a motion.

[Kit Collins]: I think that I personally would benefit from some time offline to digest the legal review, which again, I apologize, I haven't had time to look deeply at it before it came in yesterday midday.

[Kit Collins]: As ordnance sponsor, like I created the first draft, I'm happy to create a revised draft that incorporates those suggestions around the bird feeder language from Director O'Connor and Animal Control Officer Hogan around the bird feeder to incorporate those suggestions from the legal review, provided that the rest of the committee agrees.

[Kit Collins]: And to include, that would be adding the intent section, adding that language around the definitions of bird feeders and pets,

[Kit Collins]: you know, contemplating the exception for feral cats, depending on the will of the committee, and just making sure that all of the comments from the legal review that the committee agrees with are incorporated.

[Kit Collins]: Personally, I think I'd do that more effectively offline than during this committee.

[Kit Collins]: My motion would be to authorize myself as lead sponsor to do that work.

[Kit Collins]: And then I would really prefer to bring a revised draft back before this committee as early as possible in July.

[Kit Collins]: Just because I know that I really appreciate the support on this ordinance that that has been expressed by Director O'Connor and Animal Control Officer Hogan and our code enforcement officers.

[Kit Collins]: And I know there's a lot of eagerness for this enforcement ability in the community from folks who are

[Kit Collins]: currently suffering nuisances, so I would love to be able to incorporate those and then expedite that in a July committee meeting.

[Kit Collins]: Okay, understood.

[Kit Collins]: Great.

[Kit Collins]: Chair Lazzaro?

[Kit Collins]: Yes.

[Kit Collins]: If we could, I don't know if we're getting to the end of our discussion, but if we are, I just would like to hear opinions from my fellow councilors and any city staff or interested residents who are

[Kit Collins]: On the call on the feral cat exception specifically just to make sure that I am editing in the right direction for our revised draft that will contemplate in July.

[Kit Collins]: When I read over the legal review, I thought that the exceptions mentioned seem reasonable to me, sort of that it's fine to do that sort of like very limited baiting for the express purpose of capturing feral cats where the full intent is to

[Kit Collins]: domesticate, spay, neuter, and vaccinate them.

[Kit Collins]: I think there's nothing wrong with leaving food out for wildlife in that case when the intent is to make them cared for pets and no longer wildlife.

[Kit Collins]: Clearly that's a very different issue than leaving, you know, lots of peanuts out that are attracting a horde of pigeons.

[Kit Collins]: But I just wanted to make sure that there was remit around that before I incorporate that exception into the next draft.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I apologize for speaking over your council member.

[Kit Collins]: Yeah, I think those points are well taken.

[Kit Collins]: I also appreciate your perspective around not wanting to over litigate this because, of course, and I think that this is an important thing to remind ourselves and the public of when we're considering any ordinance with an enforcement mechanism, which is theoretically all of them, is enforcement kicks in when something is noticed to be in violation of the ordinance or creating a problem.

[Kit Collins]: So I do think it's true what you say that

[Kit Collins]: If baiting for wild cats so that they can be domesticated is going on and it's not creating a nuisance, then

[Kit Collins]: the ordinance is not being violated and the ordinance does, you know, then it's not creating a nuisance, it's a non-issue.

[Kit Collins]: And that is true whether or not the ordinance says so.

[Kit Collins]: So I think it might be kind of a wash whether we put it into this language or not.

[Kit Collins]: I would maybe propose that we, since this suggestion is new as of the legal review, I would maybe suggest that we run this exception by the animal control officer who I don't think could be on the call tonight just to get his two cents.

[Kit Collins]: And then that could be something that we,

[Kit Collins]: dispense with one way or another at our follow-up meeting in July when we hopefully finalize the ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Chair Lazzaro.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate that.

[Kit Collins]: And I think it's always a good point to make that ordinances

[Kit Collins]: for setting policy or creating a remedy for problems, but it's also important to take the time to make sure that the language doesn't have unintended consequences.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think that that is an issue here, but I certainly appreciate the feedback that we've gotten from residents on this and just clarifying notes raised in the legal review to make sure that the language is really clear in what this ordinance is about and what it isn't about so that we have a recourse for solving problems when they arise and when there is a problem that people can

[Kit Collins]: feed birds and keep bees in peace.

[Kit Collins]: So I want to thank our department heads for their comments on the ordinance and for their support of this ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: And I appreciate all the residents that have advocated for this and weighed in on it from any direction.

[Kit Collins]: Present.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: This council has for a long time been a forum for residents when they are in a time of need.

[Kit Collins]: I think it's fitting that former Councilor Caraviello is here tonight because in my first term, you know, he was the liaison that bridge that made that connection with

[Kit Collins]: a whole group of tenants that were in a time of need and I think early 2022 with the Bradley Road tenants and made sure that Councilors were informed of what was happening in their building and could offer whatever support we could as they sought their next safe haven in Medford.

[Kit Collins]: And I'm glad that this council can be a forum to hear from

[Kit Collins]: residents in any occasion of need.

[Kit Collins]: Over the past several months, tenants at the Brooks Park apartments have been keeping councilors informed of their situation, which includes, you know, the property changing hands, and unfortunately, a wave of displacement and evictions.

[Kit Collins]: I understand that they've been seeking to converse and discuss and negotiate with their property owners that they can remain in this community, and I am grateful to them for

[Kit Collins]: appearing tonight so that we can hear an update directly from the source about the status of their tenancies.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for being here.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: I want to thank again everybody who's spoken so far, everybody who's spoken as a member of the Tenants Association, and to the people who have come here to stand in solidarity with them, or the people who found themselves here and are supporting them nonetheless.

[Kit Collins]: I think that

[Kit Collins]: That seems like a really Medford thing to me to say, you're my neighbor and I want you to be able to stay here and I want you to stay a part of this community.

[Kit Collins]: I wanted to keep it brief at the beginning to pass the mic to the folks who are really going through this, but I just want to give a little bit more context about how I came to know about this issue that these tenants are facing.

[Kit Collins]: I think it's been almost a year since I heard about the sale of the Brooks Park Apartments for the first time.

[Kit Collins]: It was actually somebody who lived, who owns a condo up the road who first reached out to me and said they had seen the for sale sign and they were really worried because they knew that this was naturally occurring affordable housing and they were worried about what would happen to the tenants after it was sold.

[Kit Collins]: It was shortly after that that myself and President Bears, together with the planning department, started spending a few days just on the phone, all the time talking to an interested affordable housing developer and trying to see what we could do to make sure that this building would be competitive to sell to an affordable housing developer instead of to a for-profit housing developer.

[Kit Collins]: And that didn't happen, unfortunately.

[Kit Collins]: The offer just wasn't competitive with what the corporate property owner could offer.

[Kit Collins]: And I remember thinking, it's going to happen again.

[Kit Collins]: What happened on Bradley Road is just going to happen again.

[Kit Collins]: And we're just waiting for it to happen.

[Kit Collins]: You know, and then several months later, it happened.

[Kit Collins]: And we saw that wave of notice to quit notices go out to these two, we're hearing about that wave of evictions.

[Kit Collins]: And you know that just it, it breaks my heart as a representative of neighbors in this community.

[Kit Collins]: When people from up the street or people who are going through this come to me as a city councilor and say, what are you doing about this?

[Kit Collins]: How can you stop this?

[Kit Collins]: How can you how can you keep these people in our community?

[Kit Collins]: How can you help me to stay in this community?

[Kit Collins]: And it breaks my heart because

[Kit Collins]: There's not a lot we can do.

[Kit Collins]: We had this conversation when Bradley Road was happening, we said we can stand with you, we can support you, and we can platform what you're going through, we can platform your testimony, we can stand with you when you rally outside the building, when you try and try and try to get your property owner just to talk with you, just to try and recognize you as a

[Kit Collins]: a group of residents that are trying to collectively bargain.

[Kit Collins]: But the state doesn't give us any other tools for keeping our residents who want to stay here in our community.

[Kit Collins]: We don't have those tools that other states have.

[Kit Collins]: You know, I think that I'm so glad that we're talking about what it will take to put the city in a position where we can in the future buy a building like this and say,

[Kit Collins]: We got this.

[Kit Collins]: We'll protect you.

[Kit Collins]: That building's up for sale.

[Kit Collins]: We're going to buy it so that Medford residents can stay there in perpetuity.

[Kit Collins]: We're not at that place.

[Kit Collins]: I think they're growing an affordable housing trust fund.

[Kit Collins]: The analogy that comes to mind is it's like planting a tree.

[Kit Collins]: Right now we're planting that tree.

[Kit Collins]: That sapling is in the ground.

[Kit Collins]: It's been in the ground for three months.

[Kit Collins]: It's going to be decades before we can turn that into

[Kit Collins]: purchasing buildings that will be affordable housing for members of this community, unless we start planting immediately.

[Kit Collins]: And that's what's so sad.

[Kit Collins]: We're behind the eight ball.

[Kit Collins]: So we need to be thinking about growing that forest so that this doesn't keep happening again in the future.

[Kit Collins]: But in the short term, we need more tools to help people like the tenants that are before us this evening, whose problem is right here and right now.

[Kit Collins]: It can't wait 20 years.

[Kit Collins]: So I want to thank you so much for being here.

[Kit Collins]: And every time that a tenant speaks out for themselves and their neighbors, they're speaking out for all tenants who don't want to be moved around the region like pawns.

[Kit Collins]: They want to stay here in their community where they work and have friends and have family and have invested and want to keep investing.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: This is the first package small package of updates to come out of the planning and permitting committee and its work with the zoning consultant that the city council hired at the beginning of this term.

[Kit Collins]: So we're starting it off with.

[Kit Collins]: some proposals that I think will be, you know, relatively minor procedural compared to the scope of work that we will be continuing on for the rest of this term, which will be, you know, kind of encountering those bigger questions that constituents have been coming to us with for years around residential development and commercial development and mixed use development and incorporating the goals and themes of our comprehensive plan, climate plan, housing production plan.

[Kit Collins]: These are less sexy.

[Kit Collins]: We've been working with the zoning consultant and planning staff and the new building commissioner to make

[Kit Collins]: What's the word I'm looking for kind of some like formatting changes to the table of use and parking regulations, so that all of the relevant information is on the same page and updated so that it's more readable, so that when city staff and potential developers are looking for this information, they don't have to go flipping through our very low court ordinances to find it.

[Kit Collins]: We have also added and made some adjustments to the definitions in the zoning code to bring that up to best practice and to include some definitions that we might need to include later when we do tweak the zoning.

[Kit Collins]: We would like to adopt the new digital GIS zoning map.

[Kit Collins]: There's been no material changes to the zoning map proposed.

[Kit Collins]: We'd just like to move away from the literally colored pencil version and have the official version be the digital version instead, which I think is a great step.

[Kit Collins]: And finally, the proposal also includes certain municipal exemptions from the zoning code ordinances so that major city projects, for example, a new fire headquarters will be able to proceed in a more efficient, streamlined manner.

[Kit Collins]: So procedurally, this has to be referred to the Community Development Board before this council can take a vote to codify it.

[Kit Collins]: So I'd motion to send it to the CDB.

[Kit Collins]: Great.

[Kit Collins]: recommendation.

[Kit Collins]: Of course, as has been stated, you know, the City Council has no jurisdiction when it comes to line items, when it comes to how the Schools Department chooses to spend whatever appropriation that's given each year.

[Kit Collins]: That is beyond our scope, but still I find it really helpful context for understanding the number that comes before us, so thank you so much for that.

[Kit Collins]: Um, speaking of individual line items, you know, for myself as an individual Councilor, like anybody else in the city, I hold individual opinions about particular positions or programs that to me seem really vital and important, that seem like they must be protected.

[Kit Collins]: But as a Councilor in this role, it is deeply important to me that we advance a budget, advance a budget plan that gives our school's administration the latitude to do right by students, families, educators, all school staff.

[Kit Collins]: And it's my understanding that that's the number that was just explained to us.

[Kit Collins]: This year, I am optimistically expected to cast a yes vote for a budget that includes this school's appropriation for the 79 million that puts students and families' minds at ease, that's fair to teachers and school workers, and that gives our public schools the ability to start doing more rather than less.

[Kit Collins]: And that isn't a reflection whatsoever on the district, I don't think.

[Kit Collins]: We're coming off of a pandemic.

[Kit Collins]: We know we're in a really difficult fiscal situation.

[Kit Collins]: But based on what I hear,

[Kit Collins]: from the community.

[Kit Collins]: I think that there's this widespread consensus that we have to start improving, and we have to be really serious about what that takes.

[Kit Collins]: Personally, I think that education is one of the most important services that a city provides, and our budget should reflect that by meeting the school committee request.

[Kit Collins]: President Bears spoke a little bit about the need for additional revenues to make that manifest and about the work that the financial task force has been doing around that question for months.

[Kit Collins]: That's still being worked out.

[Kit Collins]: We've been having some really

[Kit Collins]: you know, some tough conversations, some good, some productive conversations, but I believe that this community is ready to do what it takes to say, you know, this is the fiscal year and we're going to pivot towards making public education better in Medford and better for everybody who interacts with that system and competitive with the other options that are out there.

[Kit Collins]: You know, when it comes to

[Kit Collins]: talking about, you know, the prop two and a half override that is probably, well not, I don't think it's probably likely, I think it's definitely needed to maintain level service in the city and start making strides towards not just level service but improved service.

[Kit Collins]: This is something that I have been, you know, publicly advocating for, for, you know, the last two budget cycles, because we need to start preventing exactly the type of

[Kit Collins]: cuts that are being talked about that are in the realm of possibility if we don't change course.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that many people in the community are at the point of saying this chronic underfunding can't go on any longer.

[Kit Collins]: I don't want to turn this into a conversation about increased revenues, but

[Kit Collins]: with the number that's before us and knowing that the, you know, it's not an invisible asterisk.

[Kit Collins]: I think it's a very obvious asterisk next to that number is what will it take to get there?

[Kit Collins]: I know that the conversation about that should be comprehensive.

[Kit Collins]: It should take as long as it needs to.

[Kit Collins]: I know that something that will come up in that question is what will it cost?

[Kit Collins]: to do that, to fulfill this request and all that it will mean for students and teachers and families?

[Kit Collins]: What will it cost people to do that?

[Kit Collins]: And what I think about when I think about that question, what I think about with the various versions of the school department budget that have been put before the community is, what does it cost the community when we don't do that?

[Kit Collins]: What does it cost in tutoring fees?

[Kit Collins]: What does it cost in private school tuition?

[Kit Collins]: And the people who simply can't afford to augment the public school experience, it costs them most of all.

[Kit Collins]: So I thank you very much for this presentation.

[Kit Collins]: As one Councilor, you know, President Bears has, I was planning to start my spiel with, again, hammering home what role we do have in this process and what role we don't have at this point.

[Kit Collins]: the mayor's office with my fellow colleagues, both behind the rail and as a member of the financial task force to come up with a plan to pass a budget that meets this request and maintains level service across all of our critical areas in the city.

[Kit Collins]: Everybody knew that.

[Kit Collins]: That was out in the open.

[Kit Collins]: We knew that we were coming into a year.

[Kit Collins]: We would have to transition from a lot of really important, often critical positions being funded by this one-time funding, which is now going away because of how this national act, national grant funding worked.

[Kit Collins]: And now we're doing the work of figuring out how to transition away from that.

[Kit Collins]: And I feel really confident that every player in this dynamic shares the same goal of coming out of this budget season with a budget that includes a school department appropriation that gives the school department the latitude, the ability to put that money where it is going to best support students and teachers and all school staff and families.

[Kit Collins]: And I really do think that that is a value that everybody behind this realm, school committee, mayor's office, your team, administration, I think that is really shared.

[Kit Collins]: And that sounds to me like a number that will help us achieve our shared goal of doing right by Medford Public Schools.

[Kit Collins]: This is what that hard work looks like.

[Kit Collins]: Making recommendations and reconciling them with what's possible.

[Kit Collins]: We don't get there by fighting with each other.

[Kit Collins]: We get there by working together.

[Kit Collins]: And I am, I think like everybody in the community, knowing for not just one year, but for several years, that there is going to be an Esser cliff.

[Kit Collins]: There being a lot of transparency around that.

[Kit Collins]: Knowing that, coming into this budget season, feeling really anxious, feeling really worried, because this is too important.

[Kit Collins]: But I think if we continue to collaborate and say, what can we all do so that we get as close to that number as possible, so that we don't have to cut things that we don't want to cut, that's how this should work.

[Kit Collins]: there isn't a third bar or something like that.

[Kit Collins]: And we have to say, well, it's not up to us.

[Kit Collins]: In terms of what we're kind of doing here in general with the issue of vacant storefronts, I would really like to have a conversation about what, I'd like to continue the conversation that the director started about what really helps

[Kit Collins]: And also assessing, you know, when's the right moment for something like this?

[Kit Collins]: Um, is this on our list of top five things to do to get storefronts filled?

[Kit Collins]: coordinated strategy.

[Kit Collins]: So I do understand that if the premise is, why don't we nix both?

[Kit Collins]: This is a compromise from that starting position, but from the starting position of we want to be competitive with other cities to fill both positions, this is a pretty big change.

[Kit Collins]: Just wanted to put that out there for the record.

[Kit Collins]: You know, that's how I'm absorbing this proposed change.

[Kit Collins]: We have many more opportunities to talk about this, to discuss and negotiate.

[Kit Collins]: What are we investing in and what's the return that we get from those investments?

[Kit Collins]: And I know in a year where there's a really emergent need, that conversation gets a lot harder.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you also, Attorney Austin, for being with us tonight and also for your work on this matter.

[Kit Collins]: I have reviewed this complaint with Attorney Austin prior to this meeting, being the party that was named specifically in the complaint.

[Kit Collins]: And I know that she and her colleagues have reviewed this and reviewed my Reddit post in question very thoroughly.

[Kit Collins]: I was pleased to read their very thoroughly researched response and their

[Kit Collins]: They're finding that that does not constitute an OML violation.

[Kit Collins]: I myself have, you know, looked over the draft response.

[Kit Collins]: I've given it some time.

[Kit Collins]: I'm comfortable submitting this.

[Kit Collins]: I think the response is thorough.

[Kit Collins]: It's adequate.

[Kit Collins]: It backs up all the relevant points, which are that the Reddit post in question contained no open meeting law violation.

[Kit Collins]: I will indulge myself to say that as an elected, as the named party in the complaint,

[Kit Collins]: I am fully aware and respectful of the fact that the things that I say might not always be popular, but I know that always doesn't necessarily equate with a rule or regulation being broken, and I appreciate having legal clarity around the difference between those two things and the attorney's attention to detail in helping us articulate what the Reddit posts, what my Reddit posts did and did not include.

[Kit Collins]: forward a motion to acknowledge the complaint and approve this draft response after my fellow Councilors have had time to review and ask any questions that they might have.

[Kit Collins]: And I have more I could say on the topic, but I think that the top lines are, you know, for myself as an elected, when I first gained office, I immediately researched the open meeting law to make sure that I understood it, understood the parameters, the point of open meeting law.

[Kit Collins]: is to ensure that all issues of public import that are before a public body only ever take place among a quorum of that body in public session.

[Kit Collins]: And that's so that the community can be there whenever a quorum of that body is debating things that are important to the community, things that are public matters.

[Kit Collins]: I take that really seriously.

[Kit Collins]: I think it's a really important rule.

[Kit Collins]: We have open meetings for a reason, and those conversations should happen in open meetings.

[Kit Collins]: I do these Reddit posts to be informative.

[Kit Collins]: Community members have asked me to do them because I think it is understandably really hard to keep up with the nuts and bolts of what's going on in City Council and elsewhere in City Hall.

[Kit Collins]: And that was the intent of these Reddit posts, continues to be to just be informative, to share these on a popular online platform that people use.

[Kit Collins]: not to be a forum for debate amongst members of the body.

[Kit Collins]: And, you know, of course, I appreciate, you know, the opportunity for a legal mind to take a look and say, I confirm there is no deliberation.

[Kit Collins]: That's never my intent.

[Kit Collins]: And that has never been the case in the post that I have been sharing on Reddit.

[Kit Collins]: So thank you, Attorney Austin and my fellow Councilors for their time in considering this.

[Kit Collins]: I was going to make a similar motion to table or convene in planning and permitting to determine.

[Kit Collins]: Great, thank you.

[Kit Collins]: This was tabled from our last regular meeting because the report in the packet missed the crucial first two pages, which differentiated this report from a separate report, which was the annual surveillance report submitted by city agencies that use surveillance technology.

[Kit Collins]: In contrast, this is the City Council's reporting requirement under the Community Control over Public Surveillance Ordinance, which passed in.

[Kit Collins]: the city of Newark, which is the city of Newark, which is the city of Newark, which is the city of Newark, which is the city of Newark, which is the city of Newark, which is the city of Newark, which is the city of Newark, which is the city of Newark, which is the city of Newark, which is the city of Newark, which is the city of Newark, which is the city of Newark, which is the city of Newark, which is the city of Newark, which is the city of Newark, which is the city of Newark, which is the city of Newark, which is the city of Newark, which is the city of Newark, which is the city of Newark, which is the city of Newark, which is the city of Newark, which is the city of Newark, which is the city of Newark, which is the city of Newark, which is the city of Newark, which is the city of Newark, which is

[Kit Collins]: We passed this somewhat proactively and that there isn't a lot of surveillance technology currently being used by the city.

[Kit Collins]: Um, at the time of the passage of the C cops ordinance, there's only one surveillance technology being used by the city.

[Kit Collins]: It was by the police department.

[Kit Collins]: It's body worn cameras.

[Kit Collins]: Um in hashing out the details of the ordinance in, um,

[Kit Collins]: We exempted body-worn cameras from some of the reporting requirements and oversight requirements and approval requirements to which all new surveillance technologies will be subject.

[Kit Collins]: Other main things to know about the ordinance under it, if a new surveillance technology comes before the council, or if a new technology is proposed to be used, it will come before the council.

[Kit Collins]: the council will discuss it, hold public meetings, ask questions about how much it will cost, what are the pros, what are the cons, what is the use for which this is being proposed, and then make a determination, do we approve this use, or do we deny it, or do we ask for changes to the proposed policy in order to approve it?

[Kit Collins]: This annual public report is something that the city council owes to the community to say, in the preceding calendar year,

[Kit Collins]: These are all the requests for new surveillance technology that were approved.

[Kit Collins]: These are all the new requests for surveillance technology that were denied.

[Kit Collins]: These are all the requests that we made changes to.

[Kit Collins]: And here are all of the annual surveillance reports that we received from the departments that actually use them.

[Kit Collins]: And that is why this report is so short.

[Kit Collins]: because we made no approval in 2023.

[Kit Collins]: We made no approvals.

[Kit Collins]: We made no rejections.

[Kit Collins]: We made no changes, and that is because the only surveillance technology being used in the city in 2023, which, in fact, was only for, I think, about three weeks in December, was the body-worn cameras.

[Kit Collins]: And per the ordinance that we passed earlier that year, body-worn cameras are exempted from City Council approval process until 2028.

[Kit Collins]: So

[Kit Collins]: This report just sums all of that up, and it also includes a copy of the annual surveillance report on body-worn cameras that the Medford Police Department submitted to us, and we discussed in a meeting of the Public Health and Community Safety Committee.

[Kit Collins]: So that's the brief report that we're looking at.

[Kit Collins]: There will be a meeting of the Medford City Council Planning and Permitting Committee, May 8th, 2024.

[Kit Collins]: This meeting will take place at 6 p.m.

[Kit Collins]: in the City Council Chamber, second floor, Medford City Hall, 85 George P. Hassett Drive, Medford MA, and via Zoom.

[Kit Collins]: To submit written comments, please email ahertabase at edfordma.gov.

[Kit Collins]: have this discussion and wait until we can package all of the definitions together with the table of uses, maybe with site plan review, if that's ready in a couple of weeks, and the GIS zoning map.

[Kit Collins]: I think one of our earlier conversations was around CDB capacity for not trying to load the schedule with multiple meetings.

[Kit Collins]: And that is kind of, to me, that's part of the decision on my mind.

[Kit Collins]: Packager?

[Kit Collins]: Yeah.

[Kit Collins]: I agree.

[Kit Collins]: I mean, I certainly am very sympathetic to not wanting to deliver a gigantic packet for review all in one meeting.

[Kit Collins]: At the same time, I think, also thinking about keeping this coherent for residents that are following along in this process, I like the idea of

[Kit Collins]: getting through the definitions, even if it takes a couple of meetings, and then updating the definitions.

[Kit Collins]: I think it'd be an overreach to say in one fell swoop, but doing that in one meeting as opposed to two, along with the use, the GIS, the site plan review.

[Kit Collins]: And that keeps us with our goal of getting those pieces dispensed with prior to the end of the fiscal year.

[Kit Collins]: And I think it would be a great start to hit that, to do that as one package.

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Callahan, I think I saw your hand go up.

[Kit Collins]: In that case, I would recommend that maybe we rest on the, for now, dwelling multifamily definition, since we're going to, I think, it'd be advantageous to get some proposals back from Innes Associates in two weeks based on this discussion.

[Kit Collins]: I think we should come back to this at the end of the meeting, but for now, I would recommend that we put a pin in this, work our way through some of these other definitions,

[Kit Collins]: enjoy the ones that are a little bit simpler and then maybe come back at the end of the meeting to this and any other definitions that are a little bit stickier and figure out exactly what we want to request of the consultant in terms of our next steps for reviewing this in two weeks.

[Kit Collins]: How's that sound?

[Kit Collins]: Great.

[Kit Collins]: Let's go to doggie daycare.

[Kit Collins]: Yes.

[Kit Collins]: I'm sorry before.

[Kit Collins]: I'm sorry to cut you off.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I mean, it also strikes me, and I apologize for cutting you off, but on the same thread, I think one way to look into this is like, when is the question coming up?

[Kit Collins]: And I know what I often hear is people having a legitimate concern about,

[Kit Collins]: safety when it comes to number of people in a house.

[Kit Collins]: You know, there were those very high profile tragedies like maybe a decade ago at this point about overcrowded housing in student areas.

[Kit Collins]: Obviously, we don't want to, I don't think that these rules are widely abused, but we don't want to create loopholes where people feel there is an invitation to as many people as want can live in this house and people are sleeping in attics.

[Kit Collins]: Obviously, that's not the intent.

[Kit Collins]: But I think like maybe one way of asking this question, it's like, where is this coming up in City Hall?

[Kit Collins]: Like, when is this question coming to us?

[Kit Collins]: And from there, is it the number of occupants that we ought to try to define and then regulate because that regulation is being negotiated or is it the size of the building?

[Kit Collins]: I think that's a really helpful illustration of some of what we're talking around here.

[Kit Collins]: What's on my mind after that kind of example, and I'm trying to think of how to phrase this, because I think it's

[Kit Collins]: It's widely known, I care a lot about tenant protections.

[Kit Collins]: But I'm wondering if there's some parallel between overcrowding not being what we're solving for in zoning and that type, obviously we're trying not to create zoning definitions that invite in bad behavior or things to take advantage of.

[Kit Collins]: But in the same way, I don't want to overcorrect for problems that are also

[Kit Collins]: shouldn't be adjudicated through zoning, but should be adjudicated through a supportive service that City Hall offers, whether it's Board of Health or the Housing Planner or the multilingual support line.

[Kit Collins]: Do you know what I mean?

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Councilor Leming.

[Kit Collins]: I think that approach could make sense.

[Kit Collins]: I was thinking along similar lines that it strikes me that some of the concerns that were

[Kit Collins]: talking about here.

[Kit Collins]: And I think just to lay the foundation first, I think it's, I feel pretty comfortable with the current definition as is for the moment while we're contemplating this bigger question, because I think that does still reflect the intent of the council and city staff in allowing people to define for themselves what their household is.

[Kit Collins]: And I do have some, I will admit I have some skepticism about our ability to frame zoning language in a way that helps us get at the enforcement piece of when that is taken advantage of.

[Kit Collins]: I do think it gets into that,

[Kit Collins]: It gets into that issue that we have been talking about mainly with the short-term rentals, where this is more an enforcement issue and building up our capacity to run down those complaints when property owners are doing things with their property that they're not allowed to do, and making sure that tenants or boarders are okay and get the support that they need in those cases where that is happening.

[Kit Collins]: And so I think that in terms of the definition, it makes sense to consider this alongside other more similar

[Kit Collins]: definitions like the boarding house, the dormitory, and I think the rest of it might get into a conversation that's slightly outside of the scope of zoning, or at least blurs outside of the scope of zoning, such as with, of course, the complaints about, the fears about overcrowding of parking on residential streets, and when homes are becoming busier.

[Kit Collins]: I think it's familiar to all of us, and for example, one way the city has been thinking about addressing that is through

[Kit Collins]: mechanisms like zoned parking.

[Kit Collins]: So I think there's some latitude that we have in zoning and there's others that we have through other mechanisms that kind of go alongside it.

[Kit Collins]: Right.

[Kit Collins]: Also worth noting that occasionally individual rooms are rented out, and that's wanted and desired and unproblematic.

[Kit Collins]: older brother was a Medford resident for a long time in a situation like that, so just to state that for the record as well.

[Kit Collins]: I think it makes sense to consider, you know, what's the language that captured, I think that this language captures our current intent comfortably.

[Kit Collins]: And maybe there's a new definition to add to the roster to capture this one.

[Kit Collins]: household.

[Kit Collins]: And I actually want to start with an apology because I didn't notice until just this moment that the, oh, thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I didn't notice until just this moment that the first two pages of the annual surveillance report that I submitted are actually missing from our agenda packet.

[Kit Collins]: They don't add anything particularly substantive, but what is included is just the surveillance report from the Medford Police Department and not the city council surveillance report that actually summarizes the data.

[Kit Collins]: That's what our obligation is to submit at this point.

[Kit Collins]: It doesn't add anything substantive.

[Kit Collins]: It tallies up the number of approvals and denials of surveillance technology that we did in the preceding calendar year, which in this report is zero.

[Kit Collins]: That being said, I still don't

[Kit Collins]: feel comfortable putting forward a motion for my fellow councilors to vote upon, having not seen the document in its entirety.

[Kit Collins]: So I would motion to table this until our next regular meeting, and I will make sure that those first two pages that contextualize the data are included on the agenda at that time.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: So this is a motion to support the aforementioned bills that are currently in the State House.

[Kit Collins]: I received outreach about this from several people that work with the Massachusetts Action for Pilot group.

[Kit Collins]: This comprises workers and representatives of various social service and educational, et cetera, workers from across the state, all in support of this legislation, which kind of comes up year after year.

[Kit Collins]: The context for this is that currently in Massachusetts, large nonprofits that meet certain criteria are exempt from property tax.

[Kit Collins]: We have several of those here in Medford, most notably Tufts, my alma mater.

[Kit Collins]: As an alumnus of Tufts, I've always felt my particular responsibility to advocate for changing that rule so that cities such as ours can implement

[Kit Collins]: more fair, essentially compensation systems with these institutions that take up such a large footprint in our communities, but don't have to pay property taxes like everybody else does.

[Kit Collins]: So this bill would enable a local option that communities can choose to adopt.

[Kit Collins]: that would require that these large nonprofit organizations pay really only 25% of the tax obligation that they would otherwise have to submit if they weren't tax exempt.

[Kit Collins]: So it's really, in my opinion, it's not even going as far as it should, but so many of our conversations behind this rail are talking about the various infrastructural projects and personnel and services

[Kit Collins]: that we ought to be able to provide to our residents that we can't because of a lack of funds.

[Kit Collins]: So any action that this council can take to level the playing field, I think is a worthwhile one.

[Kit Collins]: And I ask my fellow Councilors for their consideration in lobbying the state house to allow us to give us one more leverage when we're looking for fair compensation from these large, well-endowed institutions that we host in our community.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: President Bears a motion to suspend the rules and take two four zero nine two at order on the motion to spend the rules.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Just want to quickly thank, uh, manager manager DuPont Ryan Roberta for your work on this.

[Kit Collins]: I think this is one of those projects in the community, um, where the CPC is really successfully.

[Kit Collins]: Leveraged funding over several rounds to get us to this phase of the park improvements.

[Kit Collins]: my fellow councilors, but I'm really excited to see this progressing.

[Kit Collins]: I've always enjoyed working with you, and I respect you enough to want to correct the record when things are being said that I think are a bad faith attack on my character.

[Kit Collins]: I think that anybody who's willing to engage in this in good faith knows that there is a difference between me

[Kit Collins]: as an individual, using my name and my title to speak as an individual, using my petition, signing a letter in support of something, being crystal clear, it's me as an individual endorsing something.

[Kit Collins]: I do that all of the time, on many platforms, on letters, on social media, and individual phone calls with various administrations saying I'm speaking as myself.

[Kit Collins]: Every councillor here

[Kit Collins]: Every Councilor here has the opportunity to do that.

[Kit Collins]: Some exercise it more than others.

[Kit Collins]: Everybody in any role has an opportunity to say that, to say, this is the experience that I'm speaking from.

[Kit Collins]: I'm not speaking for my constituency, necessarily, when I'm signing a letter saying, I endorse this as a public official.

[Kit Collins]: This is concurrent with our public process.

[Kit Collins]: We are going to have publicly noticed committee meetings about the real estate transfer fee.

[Kit Collins]: At the same time, just like everybody here, I retain the right to say, I as an individual endorse that process.

[Kit Collins]: I also want to bring up, well, there's a lot to say about this.

[Kit Collins]: I think it's really regrettable that there has been so much consternation about, you know, this is a polarizing issue, and I get that.

[Kit Collins]: And maybe that's not even worth regretting, because polarizing issues are always going to be polarizing.

[Kit Collins]: And it's how we move on from that that's really important.

[Kit Collins]: I really take umbrage with the assertion that having some people in office who are supportive of one thing and other people also in office and also out of office who don't agree and going through that process of friction and tension and talking about it and arguing about it in public session

[Kit Collins]: I disagree that that's harmful.

[Kit Collins]: And I take umbrage with the fact that being in support of something that doesn't have consensus is harming this community.

[Kit Collins]: We are going to talk about this in public session, as we have been doing, until it gets to the time we're going to put it to a vote.

[Kit Collins]: And when we put it to a vote, I want to remind everybody, what we put to a vote is simply asking the state for the authority to again meet in public session to deliberate on what we should do as a community.

[Kit Collins]: I don't believe that perception is reality, actually.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that when people are telling us how something should make us feel, we should follow the money.

[Kit Collins]: And I hope that, I know we're gonna continue to talk about these issues in committee, these polarizing issues, these issues that leave many of us feeling extremely passionate.

[Kit Collins]: but I think we should all come with our own opinions and a mutual respect and an unwillingness to believe that anybody in the room is out to get the other person.

[Kit Collins]: And whoever's telling you that somebody in the room is out to get the other person, they're probably wrong, because we all live here.

[Kit Collins]: Thanks.

[Kit Collins]: Or oppose.

[Kit Collins]: Or oppose.

[Kit Collins]: And there is a separate process by which we come together as a city council in committee meetings to collectively, in public session, craft what we are actually putting forward to the state house to say,

[Kit Collins]: the majority of city councilors voted for this, that we would like for you to put forward as state legislation.

[Kit Collins]: And I hope that, I'm trying to find the words to make this more clear, because I understand that it's confusing for a lot of people, that the Affordable Homes Act, which is a massive housing bond bill that also includes a proposal for a local option for real estate transfer fee, encounters the same topic as our proposed real estate

[Kit Collins]: transfer fee home rule petition that is currently in the permitting and planning committee.

[Kit Collins]: I understand that those are easy to conflate because there's that Venn diagram overlap.

[Kit Collins]: And I just want to reinforce for people who are not as deeply intimate with this issue as all of us behind the rail are and the people who most frequently show up to the public meetings, I just want to make it crystal clear that these are two separate processes.

[Kit Collins]: They're related by topic.

[Kit Collins]: They're two separate processes, and I just think that's really important to make clear.

[Kit Collins]: And if I may, while I have the floor, as we're talking about the processes with possible home rule petitions, I think the most important part of this conversation already happened, which is how do these actually happen?

[Kit Collins]: What's the process?

[Kit Collins]: City Council goes to the mayor.

[Kit Collins]: They could full stop at the mayor.

[Kit Collins]: If they don't, they go to the delegation.

[Kit Collins]: They get put forward as a legislation.

[Kit Collins]: I don't like to talk about this often because I think that we should do them anyway, but yeah, I have no optimism that the Home Rule petition that we may or may not craft here in Medford City Council will become law because traditionally they don't.

[Kit Collins]: I've been a member of home, I've been a participant in home rule petition efforts in my first term on the Medford City Council.

[Kit Collins]: Did any of them become law or get even close?

[Kit Collins]: No, absolutely not.

[Kit Collins]: But, you know, to use the words of somebody who spoke just earlier, I don't think that this is a slight issue at all, the housing crisis.

[Kit Collins]: I think that it's a major issue.

[Kit Collins]: And that's why I think that's it.

[Kit Collins]: That's why I think it's so important that we have the conversation with every mechanism possible, including lobbying for state-level legislation, as well as having the conversation about if we should lobby for this, essentially, with a home rule petition, because the issue of displacement and housing unaffordability is so large and so rampant in Medford that I really think it's worth having that conversation anyway.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears and Councilor Callahan.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate you refocusing us on the actual text of our discussion.

[Kit Collins]: And that gets brought up a lot.

[Kit Collins]: Along with President Bears, I've also been made aware of the situation by protesters on Tufts campus and people working with them, supportive of their cause.

[Kit Collins]: This is, it would be a insupportable use of city resources to deploy Medford police to break up what has been a peaceful and unproblematic student demonstration.

[Kit Collins]: This is not germane to the use of our city resources, but as a Tufts alumnus, I'm very proud to see the students there joining into this cascade of peaceful demonstrations across the nation.

[Kit Collins]: And speaking as a community representative, I am deeply concerned about the safety of students and other community members on campus should the Tufts administration decide that a forcible removal of protesters is the objective that they are going to accomplish by use of force and by use of Tufts University Police.

[Kit Collins]: I hope that it doesn't come to that.

[Kit Collins]: I pray that it doesn't come to that.

[Kit Collins]: I think that that would end badly.

[Kit Collins]: I think that we've seen on other campuses that this is an extenuating event that should be allowed to remain a peaceful demonstration, a gathering place, a place for students and community members to process what's going on, to gather together and to show their solidarity.

[Kit Collins]: I think that it would be, I would hate to see something so benign

[Kit Collins]: speaking here as an individual community member, and again, speaking as a Jewish person, I would hate to see something so benign be escalated because of the use of police force in breaking up a peaceful protest.

[Kit Collins]: And so I'll reiterate my message to our administration and Tufts administration that I unequivocally would condemn the use of police force, whether Tufts or Medfords, especially Medfords, to forcibly decamp the protesters

[Kit Collins]: from where they have been camping out, gathering, making food, celebrating Passover on the Tufts University academic quad.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Sorry, just one thing to add.

[Kit Collins]: As we often say, the city council instructs and commands no city staff.

[Kit Collins]: There's very little that we can, there's nothing that we can do to interfere formally, or sorry, I shouldn't say interfere.

[Kit Collins]: There's nothing that we can do directly.

[Kit Collins]: to affect what happens on Tufts campus, but I would say to constituents that are observing this meeting, if you are of the opinion one way or the other on how Medford police resources should be deployed, if you feel that they should not be used to disperse a peaceful encampment on the grounds of a private university, if you feel that's inappropriate, now would be a good time to let the administration know.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much for bearing with us during our quick, short recess to take a meeting of the Public Works Committee, and now we're back.

[Kit Collins]: I suggested

[Kit Collins]: as opposed to we approved completely the new leaf blower ordinance, sending it to the mayor for the final approval.

[Kit Collins]: This ordinance will phase out gas-powered leaf blowers in favor of electric ones over a four-year period.

[Kit Collins]: And I just want to emphasize, I think it's helpful to not assume that people know what it means to pass an ordinance completely or incompletely, just to sort of use kind of specific language for what we mean by that, to kind of imply that there's two votes, rather than to use general language.

[Kit Collins]: And a lot of our ordinances are, of course, are very complicated.

[Kit Collins]: They're hard to boil down into one or two sentences.

[Kit Collins]: So I think that

[Kit Collins]: I think it'd be great for us to include hyperlinks wherever we can so that, you know, to sort of help people with their inevitable questions of what do you mean, what do you mean specifically, where can I read more about this, so that people can click to immediately get their specific questions answered to read more about it.

[Kit Collins]: But wherever possible, I would love to use language like giving the final vote of approval so that it's more clear what we mean by that.

[Kit Collins]: Similarly, in the planning and permitting committee section,

[Kit Collins]: I've been trying to use language of this committee began the process of updating and amending our zoning ordinances.

[Kit Collins]: 24082 resolution to acknowledge April 30, 2024 as National Animal Therapy Day in the city of Medford.

[Kit Collins]: Whereas there are thousands of pet partners therapy animal teams serving communities across the United States.

[Kit Collins]: And whereas pet partners has designated April 30 as National Therapy Animal Day.

[Kit Collins]: And whereas scientific research shows that interacting with therapy animals can reduce stress, relieve depression, slow the heart rate, lower blood pressure and strengthen the immune system.

[Kit Collins]: And whereas therapy animal teams in the city of Medford play an essential role in improving human health and well-being through the human animal bond.

[Kit Collins]: And whereas therapy animal teams interact with a variety of people in our community, including veterans, seniors, patients, students, and those approaching end of life.

[Kit Collins]: And whereas these exceptional therapy animals who partner with their human companions bring comfort and healing to those in need.

[Kit Collins]: And whereas we encourage more pet owners to consider becoming pet partners, volunteers,

[Kit Collins]: to help our community by creating greater access to meaningful therapy animal visits.

[Kit Collins]: Now, therefore, be it resolved by the Medford City Council that we acknowledge April 30th, 2024 as National Animal Therapy Day and encourage our citizens to celebrate our therapy animals and their human handlers.

[Kit Collins]: Be it further resolved that we publicly salute the service of therapy animal teams in our community and in communities across the nation.

[Kit Collins]: be it further resolved that we request that Mayor Lungo-Koehn issue a formal proclamation of National Animal Therapy Day in the city of Medford.

[Kit Collins]: We know that it will take multi-millions of dollars to make good on this investment, to bring ourselves out of the rear of all cities and towns in Massachusetts when it comes to our water infrastructure.

[Kit Collins]: I believe that Commissioner McGibbon told us during our budget hearing last year that we're one of the

[Kit Collins]: The three cities with the oldest water infrastructure in the state.

[Kit Collins]: That's that's not a

[Kit Collins]: end of the ladder that any of us want to be on.

[Kit Collins]: And we know that this is multi-millions of dollars in the fixing.

[Kit Collins]: That mutual respect within the DPW leadership

[Kit Collins]: We need to look for assets wherever we can find them with this big of an infrastructural project ahead of us.

[Kit Collins]: As was stated earlier, we were the first council to vote to keep retained earnings within the Water and Sewer Department so that it could go towards funding infrastructure repairs and improvements.

[Kit Collins]: Obviously that is a small first step.

[Kit Collins]: we have a ways to go.

[Kit Collins]: I am glad for any steps in the right direction that were taken by ARPA, that were taken by Superintendent Stone King during his tenure, and that I know that Commissioner McGivern is working hard on every day.

[Kit Collins]: between bringing our water infrastructure up to par and our roads infrastructure up to par.

[Kit Collins]: You know, we got at least 500 million on the water side.

[Kit Collins]: I believe it's maybe even at least 200 million if we really wanna get every road where we know residents want them.

[Kit Collins]: These things have to be done in concert, be done efficiently to make sure that we're making the best use of every dollar because we have to use so many of them.

[Kit Collins]: that's going to benefit.
