[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: you know, we had a robust discussion about the water and sewer department earlier in the evening.

[Kit Collins]: I think the compensation and classification study was brought up.

[Kit Collins]: Personally, as one Councilor, I'm very much looking forward to the season whenever that arrives, when we can take a holistic look and see the analysis that we know is being worked on with the Collins Center in consultation with the city staff.

[Kit Collins]: to get that overall picture of.

[Kit Collins]: We know that some of these roles have salaries that are no longer competitive with our neighboring communities, maybe have not been for a long time.

[Kit Collins]: The point of this, the ultimate point of making sure that our positions are kind of accurately and up-to-date compensation-wise salaried, is to make sure that we are as competitive as any other municipality at attracting the best talent.

[Kit Collins]: because of the downstream effects that that has on our residents.

[Kit Collins]: All that to say, it's not my preference to do these CAF changes one at a time, but we also know that this position is incredibly critical.

[Kit Collins]: This is a point of inflection for our water infrastructure, and I don't want us to lose any time at all.

[Kit Collins]: Even if it's just a couple of weeks, that could make the difference.

[Kit Collins]: If making this position more competitive will bring somebody on faster, I think we should do that.

[Kit Collins]: So I'm gonna motion to approve for first reading.

[Kit Collins]: I'm happy to defer to other suggestions at this time, but what's on my mind is,

[Kit Collins]: I said earlier, I feel a sense of urgency around this.

[Kit Collins]: I would prefer not to wait two weeks to take the first vote.

[Kit Collins]: I feel like an advantage here is that we can ask for information and if it's relevant, we

[Kit Collins]: We have the third reading to take an additional vote on.

[Kit Collins]: I'd be happy to, I actually don't know if there's a way to attach a B paper to an ordinance, but I would like the information on this union issue attached to the, sorry,

[Kit Collins]: I don't actually know if there's a way to attach a B paper to this particular vote, like we do with resolutions.

[Kit Collins]: I would like the answer to Councilor Scarpellioli's question.

[Kit Collins]: I would prefer to vote on this tonight, but I'd be happy to put your question as a B paper to the vote, if that is an option.

[Kit Collins]: Motion to take paper 21057 off the table for third reading.

[Kit Collins]: That's the leaf floor ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: I'd like to put forward a motion to receive and place on file the following papers that are under reports due slash deadlines.

[Kit Collins]: I can read them off.

[Kit Collins]: It's 17-606.

[Kit Collins]: 20-086, 22-007, 22-009, and 22-039.

[Kit Collins]: That motion is to receive and place all of those on file.

[Kit Collins]: Present.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Paris, and yes just to underline that point.

[Kit Collins]: That was the one of the motions from our last committee meeting on this topic was for Councilors to send any preliminary suggestions that they wanted to see included in this kind of bird's eye view demo of what we're going to do over the next year and a half.

[Kit Collins]: But this is certainly going to be an evolving document and I think that we can, President Bears and I, together with NS Associates Director Hunt and her staff, can work together to keep information flowing, you know, from individual Councilors through myself and Director Hunt to the zoning consultant to make sure that as new ideas are raised, that's getting added and, you know, looking out at this project,

[Kit Collins]: This is a we have an ambitious slate of topics and themes to work through between now and next summer and fall.

[Kit Collins]: And so I really appreciate having this benchmark for kind of the, the version number zero of this memo and looking forward to seeing how it's going to be.

[Kit Collins]: Updated in coming months I think it'd be really helpful for this committee, you know, with its five different viewpoints for the council with it seven different viewpoints for the residents for city staff to be able to say hey I raised this as a priority.

[Kit Collins]: A month ago six months ago where we at with this I think this will be really helpful for tracking progress.

[Kit Collins]: And just to just to color in that picture a little bit, you know, to, to adhere to my.

[Kit Collins]: our last committee meeting, I did send ahead some of my own priorities and suggestions to Director Hunt and Innes Associates for ideas that I'd like to see included at the juncture.

[Kit Collins]: It's exciting to see Innes Associates is already beginning to incorporate some of the really specific policies and goals from the comp plan, the housing production plan, the climate action and adaptation plan.

[Kit Collins]: into this memo, I know that that'll probably be fleshed out more we fleshing out that more with ideas from the governing agenda to make sure that everything that ought to be in here is in here and is on the to do list for myself and I already conveyed this to our zoning consultant, the email but just to mention it in the setting.

[Kit Collins]: Three of the role.

[Kit Collins]: projects that I want to make sure that we're aligning with as we get through this is making sure that the areas of the draft tree ordinance that touch zoning, want to make sure that we're working on those at the appropriate time, ditto the draft condo conversion ordinance, and as with a lot of our other things that are more on the level of like themes and goals as opposed to discrete projects and policies, making sure that we are, you know, prioritizing our complete streets and Vision Zero

[Kit Collins]: goals as we're working through the map and the districting processes and a lot of these layout, you know, kind of at the district court or a neighborhood level, I think, whether it's transit related use related.

[Kit Collins]: you know, where those goals, resiliency, housing, commercial development hit the road.

[Kit Collins]: We'll be looking at those in abstract and also at kind of at the neighborhood level.

[Kit Collins]: So all that to say, I think this is a structure that will greatly advantage us as we try to touch on all of this in the coming months.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Paula, for being here today.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: This is a comment, not a motion, but I just wanted to reflect that I think this

[Kit Collins]: stage of the process kind of encapsulates a lot of what we're trying to do here which is both taking the visions and goals of the plans that we've the city is, you know, collaboratively created over the past three to five years, and putting those into a zoning code where they can actually be implemented and residents can start to see changes like the type they've been requesting for.

[Kit Collins]: you know, in some cases, decades, depending on the topic at hand.

[Kit Collins]: And at the same time, it's also a process that is meant to streamline how, you know, the work of the city gets done and how development gets done and make this a city where the type of development that we do want to be happening can happen more efficiently, more easily with less burden on city staff and also the people that are trying to build and work and contribute to our community.

[Kit Collins]: So it's great to see

[Kit Collins]: you know, both facets of many represented in this meeting.

[Kit Collins]: And thank everybody for their participation.

[Kit Collins]: This is going to be a long project, but it's exciting to be formulating how exactly, you know, we're going to try to roll out as much of this as possible.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: So moved.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you to Councilor Tseng for co-sponsoring this with me.

[Kit Collins]: Just wanted to take a quick moment during this special time of the year for many people in Medford to acknowledge our Muslim community and wish all celebrants a happy Ramadan during this special time for their faiths.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: At this meeting of the Planning and Permitting Committee, we discussed two resolutions, one from the previous term about amending the short-term rental ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: to include a monthly report from the short-term rental platforms such as Vrbo or Airbnb so that we can better reconcile the post-reported and platform-reported number of short-term rentals in the community and make sure that we're in compliance with the short-term rental ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: We also discussed a resolution from this term to review the fee schedule for like across city departments and boards to make sure that

[Kit Collins]: we go through the process of asking city departments for feedback on which of those fees are updated or out of step with our neighboring communities so that we can make sure those fees are covering the relevant administrative costs and brought into the modern age.

[Kit Collins]: Motion for approval.

[Kit Collins]: I'll defer to that.

[Kit Collins]: I'll second your motion.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: As I said last week in committee, I appreciate Councilor Leming for bringing this forward.

[Kit Collins]: I think that even if all we were doing was updating the technical aspects of this ordinance that are out of step with how it's actually utilized, that would be a productive thing to do.

[Kit Collins]: And I think it's in keeping with where we're at as a community and this modern moment.

[Kit Collins]: to be adding, as we discussed at length last week, the point of the linkage fees is to associate certain costs from developers for the things that they affect in our community when they come in and build here.

[Kit Collins]: Things like parks, things like roads, sewer.

[Kit Collins]: I think it's appropriate to be adding an affordable housing bucket at this time.

[Kit Collins]: And I look forward to reviewing the recommendations that the city board comes back to us with.

[Kit Collins]: So I'd motion to refer to the community development board

[Kit Collins]: Council.

[Kit Collins]: 24059 offered by Councilor Callahan resolution to create a rental registry.

[Kit Collins]: Whereas the city of Medford has climate sustainability, affordable housing and other goals that would be easier to accomplish if we could reach either renters or landlords or both in our city, and whereas a lack of a registry of rental properties means that we currently miss opportunities to reach either our renters or our landlords or both.

[Kit Collins]: Be it so

[Kit Collins]: with energy efficiency standards as described in the Climate Action and Adaptation Plan, Section 2.2.D.

[Kit Collins]: Be it further resolved that members of the Planning and Permitting Committee submit questions to the chair, clerk, and city staff ahead of the committee meeting scheduled for the subject.

[Kit Collins]: and be it further resolved that the council work with the building department and the Office of Planning, Development and Sustainability on the drafting of this ordinance to ensure that it best serves the city of Medford and our climate and affordable housing goals.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I think that's...

[Kit Collins]: I think that's a great question and we should look at okay, what really needs to be added to augment already already have, I think the most salient thing for me, all the folks in this room that are property owners.

[Kit Collins]: I think Councilor Callahan made it really clear at the beginning, that's not who we're talking about.

[Kit Collins]: people said, we know that there are property owners in this community that are hurting neighbors as well as tenants.

[Kit Collins]: They're not the folks who are here talking about how much work they're putting into their properties.

[Kit Collins]: Those are the folks that we can't reach.

[Kit Collins]: And those are the folks that we need to be able to reach that we make sure that they are contributing to the community the way that all of you are.

[Kit Collins]: I think this is, I know we're coming up on my time limit.

[Kit Collins]: That's why I think this is worth considering further so that we can get into the concerns that were raised tonight.

[Kit Collins]: and elucidate them and get that clarity and have those discussions with everybody who we already know is interested in this conversation and all the people that we didn't hear from tonight, because those perspectives need to be- Thank you, Vice President Collins.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate my fellow Councilors for bringing this forward.

[Kit Collins]: I also appreciate the motion on the floor to amend it from two minutes to three minutes.

[Kit Collins]: I think that's welcome change.

[Kit Collins]: Two minutes feels a bit too much of a cut right off the bat.

[Kit Collins]: I think three minutes is more reasonable.

[Kit Collins]: I think that for myself is supportable.

[Kit Collins]: My reasons are the following.

[Kit Collins]: I think that this is a tweak that will

[Kit Collins]: help more people to participate in our meetings.

[Kit Collins]: I can hear the response in my head and also slightly from the chambers of another way of looking at this, which is, you know, gosh, those jerks are really tired of long meetings.

[Kit Collins]: We know the job that we signed up for.

[Kit Collins]: Sorry, I'll speak for myself.

[Kit Collins]: I know the job that I signed up for.

[Kit Collins]: We have a lot of long nights.

[Kit Collins]: I know how to prep for it.

[Kit Collins]: I drink coffee in the afternoon.

[Kit Collins]: I eat before the meetings.

[Kit Collins]: I'm paid to listen to you.

[Kit Collins]: I'm gonna do that if we have to be here till 1 a.m.

[Kit Collins]: every night.

[Kit Collins]: That's the job, committed to it.

[Kit Collins]: What I think is not okay is we're experiencing a tension between wanting to optimize for the number for people being able to speak at the length that they choose and wanting to make it possible for more people to speak at all.

[Kit Collins]: And I think for a lot of meetings in a row, we've experienced people not being able to say their piece, people showing up and tending to speak and having to leave early because they have to get up for work.

[Kit Collins]: They have to go put their child to bed.

[Kit Collins]: any other reason, they can't stay up until midnight with us all.

[Kit Collins]: I just saw it happen.

[Kit Collins]: I know there are some folks here to speak on a later resolution who said, I could speak if it comes up before 9.30, it's 9.40, they can't be heard.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that that is, I think that that leaves people out of the process.

[Kit Collins]: I think that this is a way that we can make a small tweak to finesse this one avenue for participation that could have the result of allowing more people to participate.

[Kit Collins]: concurrently, I think that we can always do a better job of publicizing the various ways, other ways that residents can let their feelings be known with Councilors, which as Councilor Tseng noted, we still have the public participation section at the end of every agenda.

[Kit Collins]: Our information is public on the city website all the time, and I'm always really grateful to people who make use of that and always encourage more people to do so.

[Kit Collins]: People can submit comments to the president, to the city clerk to have them entered into the minutes or to be read aloud into the record.

[Kit Collins]: I also do want to note that like all of our other rules that are governing this body, this is enforced at the discretion of the chair, whoever that may be, which gives us the option to make exceptions where the need arises or where the space arises.

[Kit Collins]: For example, when we have a short agenda and aren't under time pressures, we can give everybody a little bit more breathing room in the event of, you know, I've heard from other communities, you know,

[Kit Collins]: using that discretion to allow more time for people with speech disabilities who do need more time to say their piece.

[Kit Collins]: And I think this gives us a tool to allow more people to come to the podium, if that's the avenue that they want to share their feelings with the council, while still giving us the flexibility and doubling down on our other ways for having residents communicate with the council.

[Kit Collins]: So I'll support the motion to move this forward tonight.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Any further comment from councilors?

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Callahan.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I'll try to keep this brief, but I think that we are touching on what seems to me to be an important topic kind of underwriting this council right now.

[Kit Collins]: I think that

[Kit Collins]: You know, as we have stated tonight and many other times, we're doing things a little bit differently this term.

[Kit Collins]: We have more in different committees where meeting in committee is way more often.

[Kit Collins]: We put out a governing agenda, which we'll continue to revise and update, which we've never done before.

[Kit Collins]: The council is going through growing pains.

[Kit Collins]: what that looks like and how to plug into it.

[Kit Collins]: And I just want to acknowledge that as a thing that I think is going on and that it makes sense to be going on.

[Kit Collins]: I think that this is an important topic because I think that a lot of what people are wanting, we are trying to do.

[Kit Collins]: And I know that there's some breakdowns in trust because I think that there's some

[Kit Collins]: messaging about what we're here to do, that is unfair and untrue, but has legs.

[Kit Collins]: And I think, I hope we're going to work through that.

[Kit Collins]: I think that this council is trying to, for example,

[Kit Collins]: make committees a place where people really do come together and get into the weeds with us.

[Kit Collins]: Historically, they haven't been that.

[Kit Collins]: The fellow Councilors are right.

[Kit Collins]: Usually attendance is super low.

[Kit Collins]: I think we all really want to change that.

[Kit Collins]: Are we there right now?

[Kit Collins]: No, absolutely not.

[Kit Collins]: Does it need to get better?

[Kit Collins]: Absolutely.

[Kit Collins]: you know, here's how we need to do this differently so that the energy and the input that we get at these meetings, what can we do differently and what just needs time so that that energy and that level of input is occurring in the place where it is on the schedule for us to get into the weeds together.

[Kit Collins]: I think we have some co-evolving to do to get to that place.

[Kit Collins]: And I hope that we'll get there.

[Kit Collins]: And for myself as one Councilor for this group, I think that's an honest effort in good faith and to anybody from the community who is willing to bring that energy and that frustration and that irritation to help us get there, that's welcome.

[Kit Collins]: And just as an illustrative example, because for me as one Councilor, it is frustrating to hear people say, we know this is a done deal or see what is sometimes a consensus and call it a conspiracy

[Kit Collins]: I think it's fairly intuitive that people running, committing to do similar things, similar people voted for similar ideas.

[Kit Collins]: And so now there's plurality of that opinion on the council.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think that's a conspiracy.

[Kit Collins]: I think that's statistics.

[Kit Collins]: So it's frustrating to me to hear, this is a done deal, this is something shady, for an example of, I think what we're trying to, I wish that we got more,

[Kit Collins]: attention all the times when we're stuck in the weeds.

[Kit Collins]: We'll go to Councilor Shang and then Councilor Callahan.

[Kit Collins]: Any further comment from councilors on the B paper?

[Kit Collins]: Hearing none, I will relinquish the chair.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate you reading out the full text of the resolution.

[Kit Collins]: I am really proud to have put this on the agenda today.

[Kit Collins]: The reason that this resolution is before us is because we have a really strong, robust, energetic climate and environment community here in Medford.

[Kit Collins]: A couple of those groups have formed a coalition that came to me with the idea for this resolution, which is one of advocacy to say, we as a community,

[Kit Collins]: We see how climate change is already affecting our community.

[Kit Collins]: We see how it is going to affect our community in the future.

[Kit Collins]: We look around, we see reality for what it is.

[Kit Collins]: We know that we need resources greater than we can muster in a city's operating budget to adequately contend with how climate change is going to affect our community here on the banks of the Mystic River in a way that will protect residents of all backgrounds who live in all neighborhoods,

[Kit Collins]: of all the various geographies of Medford in a way that we can all continue to enjoy quality of life and safety here in Medford, both right now and a year in 50 years because of what we know about how our local environment is going to change because of the global weather trends that we are all experiencing and all projecting in different ways.

[Kit Collins]: This is a bill that was proposed this legislative session.

[Kit Collins]: And again, to sort of reiterate what was stated in the text of the resolution, this is a bill that would enable the state of Massachusetts to create a fund that the largest corporate polluters would pay into, that money would then be earmarked for local climate change resiliency projects.

[Kit Collins]: for cities like ours, who are on the banks of rivers, who are already suffering from heat islands, extreme weather, so that we can do the work that we already know we need to do, that people already need and actually don't have the access that they need quite already in our community, so that we can do those projects adequately.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think that eight-hour heating and cooling centers in the coldest and hottest days of the month in Medford are cutting it already, let alone what we're going to be feeling

[Kit Collins]: in five or 10 or 20 years.

[Kit Collins]: This state level legislation would try to create a stream of money to combat that at the local level in communities like ours from the corporations that are responsible for creating these conditions in communities like ours.

[Kit Collins]: So to be super, super clear, this is a tax on no consumer.

[Kit Collins]: This is a tax on no resident.

[Kit Collins]: This is going to your Exxon mobiles and saying,

[Kit Collins]: We can't undo history, but now you have to help us.

[Kit Collins]: You have to help us stay alive.

[Kit Collins]: You have to help us stay safe.

[Kit Collins]: You have to help us preserve our communities with what we know is to come.

[Kit Collins]: As was noted in the text of the resolution, this was given a study order in this legislative session, which means that most likely the legislature will not take action on this section.

[Kit Collins]: They won't be able to.

[Kit Collins]: They've decided to consider it for the rest of the year instead, which means slower action.

[Kit Collins]: And this is, you know, in some cases, this is a way of taking the wind out of the sails of a legislative project or slowing the momentum.

[Kit Collins]: But I think that this presents, you know, a really urgent opportunity for communities like ours to step in and say, you know, it's all the more important to be advocating because we know the clock is ticking.

[Kit Collins]: It was ticking before, it's certainly ticking now that the legislature has declined to take action on it in this session.

[Kit Collins]: And I'm really proud to stand with many Medford residents who reached out to me to say, we can't afford to add any more years to this timeline.

[Kit Collins]: We need to start funding climate resiliency now.

[Kit Collins]: So I'd like to thank the coalition that brought this before me and thank my Councilors as I asked them for their support.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much for being here, especially for waiting such a long time.

[Kit Collins]: And it's really helpful to hear it straight from MTA representatives, people who work in the schools like yourself.

[Kit Collins]: So just thank you as always for being here, especially when it takes a really long time to take a turn.

[Kit Collins]: Just wanna echo a lot of what my fellow Councilors have said, and also just, you know, acknowledge, like I know it's been, I know it's always hard.

[Kit Collins]: I know it's been an especially alarming couple of weeks with numbers coming out and then quickly saying,

[Kit Collins]: Sorry, there was an error.

[Kit Collins]: This is the number now, because that affects your day-to-day.

[Kit Collins]: So I just want to acknowledge that.

[Kit Collins]: My fellow Councilors have spoken to our role in this process, which I know for folks pretty intimately familiar with the budget process, is already familiar.

[Kit Collins]: It is tough being so invested in the outcome in the school department budget specifically and having such an abstract role in the budget process at the same time.

[Kit Collins]: I think it really is important to state for the record that while I think, speaking only for myself, we never have as direct of a hand as we want to have in the school department budget or really any city department's budget.

[Kit Collins]: I think it's important to state for the record what

[Kit Collins]: we are trying to do within our city council jurisdiction year round and indeed over the past term into this term to try to lay the conditions where we can get away from this model where around every time this year, it's a scary time and it's an uncertain time and everybody is feeling concern or just feeling disappointment that we're not able to guarantee the things that we all know should be guaranteed.

[Kit Collins]: Really recently on the council side, we approved another PDD

[Kit Collins]: we're already doing on the zoning side to bring up that baseline in terms of our permitting, in terms of our commercial tax base.

[Kit Collins]: One of the three major projects that we're gonna be working on the city council this term is that total zoning reevaluation overhaul.

[Kit Collins]: I feel like I bring this up all the time, but that undergirds everything that we can directly do to get to a city budget where we can reliably fund the things that students deserve, families deserve, teachers deserve,

[Kit Collins]: This is stuff that we have been working on as a council for advocating for that, fighting for that, for longer than I have been on the council.

[Kit Collins]: Now we're at a stage where we are going to start actually making the literal amendments that will allow us to do what we can within our jurisdiction to increase that pie.

[Kit Collins]: And that's not to say that things are the way that they are and that's okay.

[Kit Collins]: They're not okay.

[Kit Collins]: And I think I've made it really clear that I think it's not okay.

[Kit Collins]: Nobody thinks that it's okay.

[Kit Collins]: I am also, I think that it is our responsibility to do everything we can with what's currently on the table to get the best outcomes this year and next year with the tools that we have.

[Kit Collins]: That's why I voted for the budget last year after negotiating procedural improvements that would allow us to, this year, hit the ground running with the financial task force that we did announce last June so that we can have these conversations about

[Kit Collins]: stability measures for how we're going to get away from this kind of crisis model of budgeting.

[Kit Collins]: It's why I'll never hold potential funding opportunities hostage to administration change, because I think that our students deserve more than that, and our teachers deserve more than that, and I think that all of the budgeting improvements that we need to see are already so overdue, and I think that every single person agrees with that, but

[Kit Collins]: we just have to do everything that we can at every single opportunity.

[Kit Collins]: And that's how we have to approach this year.

[Kit Collins]: And I really appreciate everybody from the MTA bringing their perspective to the city council and to the school committee, which of course is always able to answer these questions probably in more granular detail, though I think President Pierce does a great job for a non-school committee member.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that it's up to this council to, in these meetings, talk the talk,

[Kit Collins]: and hold our administration to account, like we said, level service.

[Kit Collins]: That's got to be the floor every year that we have to improve from there.

[Kit Collins]: And then we have to walk the walk in terms of doing what's within our power to increase the pie.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: 24061 resolution to oppose landfill that endangers MWRA water supply.

[Kit Collins]: Be it resolved by the Medford City Council that we join with neighboring communities, environmental protection activists, and the residents of Hardwick MA in opposing the proposed construction of a landfill by Casella Corporation near the Quabbin Reservoir watershed due to the incredible danger it poses to our regional water supply.

[Kit Collins]: Be it further resolved

[Kit Collins]: that a copy of this resolution be forwarded to the Massachusetts Water Resources Authority leadership and the Medford State Legislative Delegation.

[Kit Collins]: President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Any further comment by members of Council?

[Kit Collins]: Any members of the public who would like to speak?

[Kit Collins]: Hearing none, on the motion by President Bears, seconded by Councilor Callahan.

[Kit Collins]: All those in favor?

[Kit Collins]: Aye.

[Kit Collins]: All opposed?

[Kit Collins]: Motion passes.

[Kit Collins]: All in favor?

[Kit Collins]: Aye.

[Kit Collins]: All opposed?

[Kit Collins]: Motion passes.

[Kit Collins]: There will be a meeting of the Planning and Permitting Committee, March 27, 2024.

[Kit Collins]: This meeting will take place at 6 p.m.

[Kit Collins]: in the City Council Chamber, second floor, Medford City Hall, 85 George B. Hess Drive, Medford MA, and via Zoom.

[Kit Collins]: Mr. Clerk, would you please call the roll?

[Kit Collins]: Vice President Collins?

[Kit Collins]: Present.

[Kit Collins]: Five present, none absent.

[Kit Collins]: The meeting is commenced.

[Kit Collins]: The purpose of tonight's meeting is to discuss two papers.

[Kit Collins]: 23-427.

[Kit Collins]: This is proposed by President Bears in the previous council term.

[Kit Collins]: It is a resolution to amend short-term rental ordinance to include a monthly report from short-term rental platforms.

[Kit Collins]: And by that, we're talking about platforms such as Airbnb.

[Kit Collins]: The second action item for tonight is paper 24-008, also offered by President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: That is a resolution to review the fee schedule

[Kit Collins]: I will read out the description of each resolution, then I will pass it over to President Bears to further describe these projects.

[Kit Collins]: 23427, be it resolved by the Medford City Council that the former Zoning Planning and Development Subcommittee need to discuss amendments to Section 8.4 of the Zoning Ordinance regarding short-term rentals to require a monthly report from all short-term rental platforms

[Kit Collins]: to ensure that short-term rental units in Medford meet all requirements of this section.

[Kit Collins]: And then resolution 24-008, be it resolved by the Medford City Council that the fee schedule of the city of Medford, appendix A to the city ordinances be reviewed and updated.

[Kit Collins]: I will now pass it off to President Bears as soon as he is ready to further orient us to these two topics.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears, I appreciate that overview, and I, as one Councilor, certainly I've been at meetings where the nuisance issue that occasionally comes up with short-term rentals has been discussed, and others in which, you know, the effect of taking rentals off of the housing market to turn them into, you know, for example, Airbnb units, or HomeAway units, or Burbo units,

[Kit Collins]: We feel that effect in the availability of rentals citywide.

[Kit Collins]: So I think that this makes sense as part of our overall efforts to keep tabs on activity of the short-term rental platforms in Medford and making sure that at least we have an accurate picture of what's going on.

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Callahan.

[Kit Collins]: Any further comments or questions from Councilors?

[Kit Collins]: I think in that case, we can proceed along to if you have any next steps in mind or care to share that sample language from the city of Boston.

[Kit Collins]: President Bears, whenever you're ready, I think it makes sense to look at the language that other communities have used to mandate that platforms are reporting to the city on how many units they have in operation.

[Kit Collins]: Certainly.

[Kit Collins]: And if I'm happy to screen share if you want to send me a link or if you'd like to do so, whatever is easier.

[Kit Collins]: I will share with you.

[Kit Collins]: Great.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bearson.

[Kit Collins]: Just to sort of paraphrase that back to you, the fellow Councilors and residents, this is essentially mandating a report from the short-term booking platform.

[Kit Collins]: that tells the city, you know, we have listings, we have rooms and buildings available within the city of Medford, this is where they are, this is if it's a room or a whole building or a whole unit, and this is the number of nights that each of the units was reported by the renter as being rented to somebody during the month to help us get a picture.

[Kit Collins]: I see this as helping us reconcile

[Kit Collins]: We're hearing from some of the people that rent rooms on the short-term booking platforms.

[Kit Collins]: Yes, this unit is a rental and I rented it for this number of nights.

[Kit Collins]: Reports such as this would capture from the platform side, this is the overall number of units that we know on the back end was rented in the city during this month.

[Kit Collins]: We could see if there's a discrepancy.

[Kit Collins]: Any other comments from councilors at this time, having looked at this draft language?

[Kit Collins]: This would be an amendment to the zoning ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: Hearing none, President Perez, I want to kick it back to you for next steps, if you had any before I share my thoughts.

[Kit Collins]: Great.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Actually, let me...

[Kit Collins]: Are there any further comments or questions from councilors or members of the public before we take a vote on the motion?

[Kit Collins]: Yes.

[Kit Collins]: Five in favor, none against.

[Kit Collins]: The motion passes.

[Kit Collins]: So this draft language will be referred to the building commissioner, IT director, and PDS director, and we'll get their expert feedback on it before we make any moves to fold this into our comprehensive zoning update so that this can also be updated while we're doing potentially other zoning changes.

[Kit Collins]: Is there any other discussion on this topic before we move on to our second paper for the night, either from councilors or from members of the public?

[Kit Collins]: All right.

[Kit Collins]: Hearing none, let's proceed along to paper 24008.

[Kit Collins]: This is the resolution that the city council review the fee schedule.

[Kit Collins]: of the city of Medford and look for areas to modernize and update.

[Kit Collins]: My understanding is that the intention of this resolution is to look across many departments, like any departments for whom it's relevant.

[Kit Collins]: Many departments charge fees for various things that they do in the city, such as issuing a marriage license or registering your car, getting residential parking permit.

[Kit Collins]: And in many departments, it's been a long time since those fees were updated and changed.

[Kit Collins]: And it's my understanding that in many departments, the fees that we charge are perhaps lower than they should be to correlate with the administrative cost of doing those functions.

[Kit Collins]: And they might also be very out of step with what similar municipalities are charging for the same functions.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think the intent here is to make any astronomical changes, but just to do a standard review

[Kit Collins]: since one has not been done in, I think, many years, to see where are those glaring spots where things really need to be updated.

[Kit Collins]: And I think one of the questions before us at this early stage is to say where all of the fee schedules for all of the departments are on the table, what departments do we want to look at specifically, and who are we requesting feedback and context from at this time?

[Kit Collins]: But for further table setting, President Bears, do you have anything else you want to

[Kit Collins]: and as the paper sponsor at this time?

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate that.

[Kit Collins]: I think the timeline sounds right.

[Kit Collins]: You know, I imagine, you know, trying to put myself in the position of a

[Kit Collins]: Department head looking at this, I'm sure that there are some of those fees where what it is and what it should be will jump out as obvious, and others where it will take a little bit of calculation.

[Kit Collins]: What is the administrative cost incurred?

[Kit Collins]: What would a more appropriate number be to do that research into what neighboring communities are charging to make sure that it's consistent with our regional neighbors?

[Kit Collins]: I'm going to go to Councilor Callahan, and then I see Planner Evans' hand raised on Zoom.

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Callahan?

[Kit Collins]: I'll go now to Planner Evans on Zoom.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you very much, Daniel.

[Kit Collins]: I think that's really helpful for President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Planner Everins.

[Kit Collins]: President Bears, I appreciate this discussion.

[Kit Collins]: It seems like there's plenty of organization that would be helpful to both city staff and potentially developers and other people and entities that

[Kit Collins]: trying to do the functions that incur fees to make it more clear what we're working with, where it lives.

[Kit Collins]: And on the city side, part of the overall effort is not only to update some fees that are at least a decade, if not several decades out of date.

[Kit Collins]: But I think in all of this, we're always trying to look at, is the procedure by which we update this the one that makes sense?

[Kit Collins]: And so I'm glad that we're also thinking

[Kit Collins]: you know, getting straight on for the different fees, for the different functions.

[Kit Collins]: Is it by ordinance?

[Kit Collins]: Is it by rule of regulation?

[Kit Collins]: Set by a board that doesn't have to go through an ordinance?

[Kit Collins]: And I'd be interested, as we're doing this review, just to see what options we have.

[Kit Collins]: I think it's always, for myself as one Councilor, for something like fees where we're trying to make sure that it stays up to date, it is sometimes helpful to

[Kit Collins]: consider if we have other non-ordinance mechanisms for doing that, so there doesn't have to be a legislation every time to keep something, you know, proceeding with, you know, cost of inflation.

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Callahan.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Councilor Callahan.

[Kit Collins]: As we're, I think that we're going to be collecting input and feedback on ideas for a lot of departments and boards on this.

[Kit Collins]: And it's my hope that as we're going through and updating the fees themselves, we could also be

[Kit Collins]: you know, as it's been mentioned, working to get all of the fees in the same place right now, it's really, it's pretty disorganized with a lot of things existing in other appendices on different webpages.

[Kit Collins]: I think it'd be helpful to have all the fees in the same appendix.

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Kellihan.

[Kit Collins]: Any other questions or comments from councilors at this time?

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Councilor Leming.

[Kit Collins]: Second by Councilor Lemme.

[Kit Collins]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Kit Collins]: Yes.

[Kit Collins]: Yes.

[Kit Collins]: No.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Chair Sang.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate the, you know, I

[Kit Collins]: I'm glad that we have the opportunity to continue this conversation.

[Kit Collins]: I think for myself, my concerns also center around what this council has been talking about for

[Kit Collins]: months since before, you know, the March and the November 2023 election, which is the under-resourcing and under-capacity of our elections department.

[Kit Collins]: It's true of any department, and it's not specific or personal to anybody who's been involved in elections in Medford, that when there's not enough people on the case, things will fall through the cracks.

[Kit Collins]: I believe we did see that

[Kit Collins]: with November.

[Kit Collins]: We saw that less with March, and that's a positive thing.

[Kit Collins]: But I'm still really concerned.

[Kit Collins]: Of course, we have our chief of staff filling the role of the executive in that office right now, and we've seen transparency and communication increase from that department during that time.

[Kit Collins]: But obviously, everybody's extremely aware, I'm sure, most of all the chief of staff, that that's glaringly, obviously, not a permanent solution.

[Kit Collins]: I've made it really clear a lot of times, I think that that should be a director level position, especially this year, but every year we need the best possible candidate running elections in the city of Medford.

[Kit Collins]: I've said it many times before, I think that this is a department that needs to have more than two and a half full-time employees.

[Kit Collins]: When any department is stretched that thin and tasked with so much,

[Kit Collins]: things fall through the cracks.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think that it is a symptom of a properly resourced, you know, professional level, municipal level elections department to

[Kit Collins]: be it a state capacity wise where we're wrangling signage on an election day.

[Kit Collins]: And that's absolutely not a criticism of any person or involved or any system leading up to the March election, but rather this is, if this is the level of capacity that the elections department is at, to me, that is a resources and staffing issue.

[Kit Collins]: And I was happy to see that that was responded to very quickly.

[Kit Collins]: The issue was rectified, but our Medford deserves an elections department that has

[Kit Collins]: tackled the issue of keeping signage organized and is proceeding along to, you know, are we keeping our softwares modernized so that, you know, for example, files don't download as quickly as they need to.

[Kit Collins]: We should be at a level of resources and staffing where we can be a proactive elections department, as opposed to one that occasionally has to put out fires when there are really much more consequential things to be doing.

[Kit Collins]: So I absolutely would echo my fellow Councilors in saying whatever proposals the Elections Department and the Elections Commission has for identifying and prescribing and improving on current systems and identifying and improving on past problems, I'm eager to stand in support of those ideas.

[Kit Collins]: But my highest priority is getting to a place where we can elevate the

[Kit Collins]: to a director level position.

[Kit Collins]: I think that's really what's needed and taking a hard look at how many part time and full time employees does is really required for an elections department in a city of 60,000.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Chair Stang.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much for being here to

[Kit Collins]: speak to this and for, you know, all of the very obviously extra work you've been doing over the past several months to fill this gap in the elections department.

[Kit Collins]: I think the council really sees that, and speaking as one councillor, it's really appreciated, and I hope that this additional labor is over for you soon.

[Kit Collins]: No specific questions to the chief of staff at this point, but just, you know, to further echo my, I'm really happy to hear that.

[Kit Collins]: I think it's obviously totally sensible that, you know, priority number one is filling that role.

[Kit Collins]: Everything else flows from that, right?

[Kit Collins]: And it strikes me that, you know, I tend to look at most of the issues that we have to collaborate on in the city as, you know, a problem or perhaps a potential solution of,

[Kit Collins]: project management.

[Kit Collins]: This certainly seems like one you need to find that person through whom policy updates and further staffing evaluations and the work of the department will flow through.

[Kit Collins]: And so it's good to hear that that's being prioritized.

[Kit Collins]: I know that's a priority that this council shares.

[Kit Collins]: And then just to take it back to the big picture, I again want to

[Kit Collins]: sort of reaffirm, you know, in my perspective, what this conversation is and what it isn't.

[Kit Collins]: You know, I'll speak only for myself, but I know that every city councilor, you know, sees the hard work that's put in by the Elections Commission, and that has never been in doubt.

[Kit Collins]: And I think when we talk about having support and having resources and having bandwidth, it's about resiliency.

[Kit Collins]: And, you know, I think if, you know, if all the population of Medford

[Kit Collins]: stepped up in the way that our elections commissioners and that team does so reliably and so, you know, above and beyond, then, yeah, our staffing needs within the city would be a lot lower because that would be a city full of superheroes.

[Kit Collins]: But as a city council and as an administration, you know, it's our responsibility to make sure that these systems are resilient so that, you know, if another more enticing commission steals away, you know, the chair of the elections commission,

[Kit Collins]: that there's still ample people to do the work that absolutely needs to get done and can't not get done legally and for the health of the democracy of the city.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that's really the motivation behind these conversations is to say, how can we help to make sure that the elections department is as resilient as it needs to be?

[Kit Collins]: you know, so that the next election, another consequential one, you know, goes as well as March did or even better.

[Kit Collins]: And to make sure that city staff and commissioners and all residents and voters can feel that peace of mind throughout the year.

[Kit Collins]: So I really appreciate everybody's participation in this process.

[Kit Collins]: And I think it's really great to have these conversations out in the open.

[Kit Collins]: I was just gonna say kind of, you know, to wrap up, really appreciate your time tonight and all of the information, the context.

[Kit Collins]: I think that this has been a,

[Kit Collins]: a real exercise in transparency.

[Kit Collins]: And I hope that, you know, I think given the topic, I think that's a positive thing.

[Kit Collins]: And I would also say, you know, to echo your words, Chief Staff Sarian, and also what a mission, long day, Elections Commission Chairperson Lawrence said earlier, I don't think anybody on this council is saying, you know, we have to get to a point where we can

[Kit Collins]: you know, realistically assume that no problems will occur.

[Kit Collins]: We know that's not the case.

[Kit Collins]: We're doing this in the context and under the backdrop of reality after all.

[Kit Collins]: But, you know, I appreciate the ability, the opportunity to, you know, talk about what's being planned, what's being worked on so that things will, you know, be professionalized and modernized and be as we intend them to be.

[Kit Collins]: With that, I don't want to supersede any other councilors questions or motions, but after I think a long and productive discussion, I would motion to adjourn.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: I think it's helpful to get these drafts and recommendations after they've already been run by legal counsels.

[Kit Collins]: We know the committee is spending its time on something that

[Kit Collins]: we know could potentially go forward, and I think that's, you know, of course, it's a nice use of our time to know that this has been pre-vetted, to have legal opinion saying, yes, this is doable under the Special Act and under the ordinances.

[Kit Collins]: It makes sense to bring it into alignment with the Enabling Act from several decades ago.

[Kit Collins]: to know that the language adjustments proposed are ones that we legally can go forward with.

[Kit Collins]: And it's also great to begin this process knowing that we do have the ability legally to add that fifth bucket.

[Kit Collins]: Fifth, is that right?

[Kit Collins]: Right.

[Kit Collins]: For an affordable housing linkage fee.

[Kit Collins]: And I think it's worth underlining, especially since

[Kit Collins]: you know, for many residents who aren't deeply, you know, intimately embroiled in municipal finance, I think it's worth underlining what linkage fees are and why they're set up that way.

[Kit Collins]: You know, these are fees that are levied upon developments to kind of correlate with the municipal public sector infrastructural

[Kit Collins]: things, the public infrastructure that new developments will have an impact on.

[Kit Collins]: Developments have an impact on police, fire, roads, water and sewer, and developments also have an impact on housing affordability.

[Kit Collins]: This is another phenomenon that new developments brought into the city also have an impact on, as well as how many more cars will be driving on our roads and how many more potential units will public safety have to respond to.

[Kit Collins]: So I think it's really in keeping with the spirit of what linkage fees are a tool for to say, you know, new developments coming in impact the housing market and so there should be some sort of formula set up by the experts, you know.

[Kit Collins]: that correlate with that issue in City Hall to figure out what that formula should be so that we can make sure that housing affordability is compensated for when affecting developments come into the city.

[Kit Collins]: All that to say, I think this is a very worthy project.

[Kit Collins]: I'm very happy to support this.

[Kit Collins]: I don't have any, well, I guess my specific question at this point

[Kit Collins]: through the chair to Councilor Leming would be, what would the next step on this be?

[Kit Collins]: I know that some of this rests on, a lot of these specific decision points rest on the Office of Planning, Development, Sustainability, working in concert with the mayor to do those, to do those updates, you know, at least every three years to make that formula.

[Kit Collins]: What other details have to be worked out on the committee side other than setting up the enabling parts of the ordinance?

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I want to again thank Councilor Leming for

[Kit Collins]: his work on this.

[Kit Collins]: I'm really glad to be getting the ball rolling on really modernizing our linkage fees and appreciate the collaboration with the Office of Planning, Development and Sustainability.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much to our housing planner for weighing in on this tonight and for, you know, your office's review of the document.

[Kit Collins]: I would motion to keep the paper in committee.

[Kit Collins]: I look forward to hearing staff's comments on the proposed ordinance changes.

[Kit Collins]: I have a clarifying question then, which was, I thought that city staff was also going to provide further comment on the draft of the ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: If that's not the case, I would withdraw my motion in favor of reporting it out of committee, but I thought that we were going to further amend it before pushing it forward.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: So just to recap, the last time that we talked about this project was in November of last year in the previous term.

[Kit Collins]: And I don't remember the dates that we met on it previously in 2023, but I know that we've had numerous Committee of the Wholes on this topic before.

[Kit Collins]: Overall, I think that

[Kit Collins]: on the council, at least the last time this was discussed in the previous term.

[Kit Collins]: The consensus on the council was very clear.

[Kit Collins]: The intent here is to streamline the process by which one day food truck vendors may obtain that license so that they don't have to come before the city council.

[Kit Collins]: I think in the past, especially for city events, things of that type, it's just been a logistical scheduling problem for vendors to line up

[Kit Collins]: when to be the floor of the city council to get their permit in time before the event actually occurs.

[Kit Collins]: And I think unlike some other types of vendor licenses, it's, I think there's perhaps less of a clear need for a food vendor, a food truck vendor to stand and present and talk about their business and talk about the reason for wanting to have a food truck.

[Kit Collins]: at a one day event in the same way as it's important for people seeking, for example, first time common victualers license to come before the city council and present on the business that they're proposing to open up in the city.

[Kit Collins]: Given that, just to recap, kind of the goal of this ordinance is to take what is right now a fairly inconvenient and cumbersome process for a fairly limited scope, setting up shop as a food truck for one day, and make that simpler.

[Kit Collins]: So our goals coming out of the previous committee of the whole were to take the draft ordinance and really just simplify it to make sure that it aligned with newer existing Board of Health regulations in such a way that prospective food truck vendors could just go to the Board of Health, make sure that they met certain guidelines, obtain that license, and then go forth to be a food truck vendor for one day, perhaps at a pop-up,

[Kit Collins]: or for a one-day event, and have that be that, and not have to involve the city council.

[Kit Collins]: So we did request feedback from a number of department heads, some of which have followed up to give, I think, fairly limited comment.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think that Director O'Connor has given a lot of feedback at this point, though we've been in touch with her about this project.

[Kit Collins]: Our economic development department

[Kit Collins]: forwarded along comment to council leadership, kind of agreeing that streamlining and simplifying the process is good for businesses in general, and also kind of adding to the chorus that we've heard from the Chamber of Commerce and some other businesses in Medford saying, you know, the only real worry here is the potential for competition between mobile food truck vendors and existing brick and mortars.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that brings us back to the point that the intent of the council with this ordinance

[Kit Collins]: is to create a better process for those one-day food trucks.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think this is a project about getting more long-term food trucks into Medford.

[Kit Collins]: So I think what would be helpful for kicking us off would be, I know that Attorney Stein from KP Law is here.

[Kit Collins]: Attorney Stein, if you would be willing to walk us through the three documents that you've proposed here.

[Kit Collins]: I think that we have draft amendments to the City Council ordinances, we have draft Board of Health regulations,

[Kit Collins]: And then we also have one more, excuse me.

[Kit Collins]: City Council regulations of mobile food vendors.

[Kit Collins]: I think for myself, the City Council doesn't typically promulgate regulations, so I'm really interested in getting an overview of how these pertain to the goals coming out of our last meeting, and especially where the City Council regulations of mobile food vendors could potentially fit in, or if that's something that we should try to align inside of the Board of Health policies.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Pierce.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Attorney Stein, for that overview.

[Kit Collins]: That's very helpful.

[Kit Collins]: And I think if I'm hearing you correctly, just to reiterate, it seems like the main two points coming out of your analysis are satisfying the stipulations that are sort of within the Board of Health's purview to weigh in on, like adherence to the sanitary code, making sure that everything you want to be happening in terms of sanitation and food safety within any vendor providing food is happening.

[Kit Collins]: you know, things really on the board of health side.

[Kit Collins]: And then on the other side, this piece that more intersects with the city council authority is use of public ways by vendors, in this case, food truck vendors.

[Kit Collins]: And I think this is where, you know, I wanna give my fellow Councilors a chance to weigh in on this, but I think this is where I'm really curious if there's a way for us to designate this, this is a question of,

[Kit Collins]: you know, in one scenario, the city council exercises this authority to sign off on use of the public way by vendors by assessing every food truck vendor application that is submitted and saying, yes or no, this is an appropriate or safe use of the public way, or no, we don't think that in this case, the public way should be used by this particular food truck vendor.

[Kit Collins]: And I think for me, my priority for this meeting is talking about if there's more,

[Kit Collins]: that.

[Kit Collins]: I think the intent here is to get issuing one day permits, something that doesn't have to occur on our regular agendas anymore.

[Kit Collins]: And secondly, because I would hate for this to turn into an issue of the City Council is

[Kit Collins]: consistent rubric for why some and not others.

[Kit Collins]: I know for the outdoor dining ordinance, we put a lot of work in and we had many conversations with city staff to say, okay, so who needs to check what box when it comes to traffic safety and visibility and having the bollards this far away from the travel lane to make sure that these licenses can be issued in a way that we're sure

[Kit Collins]: you know, we're doing our due diligence to make sure that motorists and pedestrians are safe.

[Kit Collins]: And then we handed that over to, you know, the relevant city department to, like, sign that form on the application.

[Kit Collins]: So I'm wondering if there's something like that that we can do here.

[Kit Collins]: We're in our ordinances, you know, if need be, we're updating to say, yes, food trucks are allowed on the public way, but in order to do that, you have to fill out this license application.

[Kit Collins]: And on the use of the public way side that goes to

[Kit Collins]: the DPW commissioner or the chief of police to sign off on traffic safety metrics or something like that.

[Kit Collins]: The process is to obtain a license from the Health Division of the Inspectional Services Department.

[Kit Collins]: So that's administrative, Malden, similar, Board of Health, Cambridge, inspections by city staff, and then submission to Cambridge license.

[Kit Collins]: that we're going to be able to move forward with this.

[Kit Collins]: Um, commission, so it makes me optimistic that there's a path forward here where this can be administrative task, and we don't have to.

[Kit Collins]: I also think you know, as always, Councilors Scarpelli's point is well taken, and that's why I'm glad that we're targeting the intent of this ordinance at one day.

[Kit Collins]: Food truck vendors and hopefully We can find a simplified path towards that.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Give me a second.

[Kit Collins]: I'm organizing my thoughts.

[Kit Collins]: You go first, then I'll go.

[Kit Collins]: I have a comment I'd like to make, which could be an alternate.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Councilor Scarpelli.

[Kit Collins]: I agree.

[Kit Collins]: I think we've gotten out of scope here.

[Kit Collins]: Among other things, I'd like for us to be getting close to a point of resolution on this project, and I think that perhaps there is

[Kit Collins]: um, value in a conversation about this issue of does City Council adjudicate, um, licenses being issued over on school custodian property?

[Kit Collins]: Um, but we're getting out of our scope here and I and I think that there's

[Kit Collins]: to move forward on this ordinance without having to wade through all of the weeds on that.

[Kit Collins]: I do think that's a separate conversation, maybe one that informs this, but I think that the intent for the council here for many months has been to streamline the process for one day food truck vendors, and I don't want us to have to go through that process in order to finish up here.

[Kit Collins]: In my perspective, I think what we

[Kit Collins]: What I would like to see is an amendment to the city council ordinances that says, yes, we allow one day food truck vendors.

[Kit Collins]: There's some language in there that says, here's how we make sure it's a one day permit and not a one day that happens six days out of the week.

[Kit Collins]: Maybe it's the permitting authority, or sorry, the licensing authority may

[Kit Collins]: submit like one day licenses but only you know one per vendor for a three or six month period or something like that so we make sure that these are indeed one day licenses and not de facto you know all week round permits to Councilor Scarpelli's point.

[Kit Collins]: It seems to me that the overall formula here

[Kit Collins]: for conditions that must be satisfied to get a license is permission from the custodian or the private property owner plus adherence to Board of Health regulations and other public safety regulations equals the one day license.

[Kit Collins]: I

[Kit Collins]: Maybe I'm wrong about that.

[Kit Collins]: But I think that there's a path forward here where we could try to make some progress on the text of what's before us, perhaps modeling, simplifying what's before us along those lines, modeling some of the language around who creates the regulations for the licenses based off of our outdoor dining ordinance, which has already been passed.

[Kit Collins]: maybe that can be drafted perhaps by a member of this council, we could come back and then have legal review of that document as opposed to, I think we've gone through several rounds here and I think the context is very helpful and of course we appreciate Attorney Stein's time spent on this.

[Kit Collins]: But I think we're all very eager to get this to a simpler place and proceed from there.

[Kit Collins]: And I wonder if there's a way we can kind of scale this back to the basics and

[Kit Collins]: convene again as a council to make sure that we're locked in on the basics, and then have another meeting after legal review, where we finalize this.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate that.

[Kit Collins]: I would be happy to put that into a form of a motion unless we feel that the discussion has proceeded along enough that the suggestion is now irrelevant.

[Kit Collins]: But barring that, I would make the motion to

[Kit Collins]: authorize myself or President Bears to take a pass at a redrafting of this along the lines of this conversation.

[Kit Collins]: Aye.

[Kit Collins]: I thank my, especially newer Councilors for wading into this perhaps unexpectedly complicated topic.

[Kit Collins]: Appreciate Attorney Stein's time on this call and in preparing for this meeting.

[Kit Collins]: And I would motion to keep the paper in committee and adjourn.

[Kit Collins]: President.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you to my colleagues again for everyone's recommendations.

[Kit Collins]: It was great to kick off this discussion at our first committee of the whole on topic.

[Kit Collins]: Looking over the compiled recommendations from us all, I think that

[Kit Collins]: There are some, I think, clear avenues for consolidating this, even just looking at category one of preventing budget cuts.

[Kit Collins]: within the Schools Department, within the Board of Health, which Councilor Tseng just noted, within the Library Department.

[Kit Collins]: And then I think that this also characterizes kind of this shared priority of preventing the loss of positions that are currently grant funded within the Board of Health, within the Office of Outreach Prevention, and within the Planning, Development, and Sustainability Department.

[Kit Collins]: And I do believe that across all of our

[Kit Collins]: contributions, most of us in some way phrased that same recommendation around meet the school's budget request, meet the library budget request, don't cut any positions within Board of Health, Office of Prevention and Outreach, Planning Department, even if it means, and perhaps especially if it means finding a way to fit those positions into the operating budget or shift them over to other sources of grant funding.

[Kit Collins]: So I would put forward that I do believe there is consensus

[Kit Collins]: around all of the numbered points under category one, and I think that those can be consolidated into a maintaining level service for schools, libraries, Board of Health, and planning departments.

[Kit Collins]: Yes.

[Kit Collins]: Sure, I'll improv it.

[Kit Collins]: Libraries, Board of Health, Prevention and Outreach, PDS Department, including maintaining all currently grant-funded positions.

[Kit Collins]: And Mr. Clerk, I can email that to you.

[Kit Collins]: It's a new hand.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I just wanted to respond quickly to say I think Councilor Scarpelli's point is well taken and I think that it's, I think that we have

[Kit Collins]: you know, as usual, somewhat of a challenging needle to thread here where, of course, I think it's absolutely not the message to send to say, we care about these cuts and not those cuts.

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Scarpelli is absolutely right.

[Kit Collins]: That's, that's, you know, and I hope it would go without saying that's that's not the message that this council would want to be sending.

[Kit Collins]: But unfortunately, you know, we're placed in this difficult position of

[Kit Collins]: knowing that cuts are likely to be proposed somewhere.

[Kit Collins]: whatever this council decides that they will be, are highlighted.

[Kit Collins]: You know, in this case, I think many of us mentioned the schools department and the library department, because often that is where cuts are proposed, and that is where level service is not funded.

[Kit Collins]: I know, just speaking only for myself, that's why I prioritize those in my memo.

[Kit Collins]: So I think

[Kit Collins]: you know, a discussion point for this council is how to make sure that we target our recommendations towards those departments that we know are usually the most vulnerable, while saying, of course, we're gonna, at the same time, we're advocating for level service citywide.

[Kit Collins]: Neil Yu, I'll second the motion.

[Kit Collins]: very revealing conversations with the current finance director about the ways in which the software really is a problem right now.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Before you read them back, I just want to kind of note my support for keeping our list of recommendations short and sweet this year.

[Kit Collins]: And that's kind of going against my own instinct.

[Kit Collins]: I remember my first year on the council, the wish list that I submitted for our first committee of the whole on this topic was amounted to the hundreds of millions of dollars and ideas for how to make our

[Kit Collins]: city more functional and shore up all of our critical departments.

[Kit Collins]: So I'm extremely compelled by and sympathetic to all of the other recommendations that I also submitted two weeks ago and agree with everything that's been submitted by my fellow councillors.

[Kit Collins]: At the same time, I think that we're going into this knowing that this is going to be a difficult budget season after a couple of difficult budget seasons.

[Kit Collins]: I think that there is a power that comes from having a very succinct list and saying, you know, we've done the hard work and we've really considered

[Kit Collins]: what needs to be in that short list of things that we cannot go without in this budget cycle, even though we know it is going to be a hard one.

[Kit Collins]: And what I appreciate about this group of three that we've put together is that to me it's about level service,

[Kit Collins]: And I think over the past couple of years, we've had many important public discussions about the difference between level service and level funding.

[Kit Collins]: And what the residents and city staff deserve is level service, not level funding.

[Kit Collins]: So I think that this list prioritizes that.

[Kit Collins]: And I think it gets at the heart of the staffing and funding infusions that need to happen so that we can

[Kit Collins]: stop regressing in certain departments and start to move forward.

[Kit Collins]: You know, I think here on the city council we see that the most with the legal department, or lack thereof.

[Kit Collins]: So I think that these few recommendations that we put together so far kind of strike at

[Kit Collins]: what we really need to see in order to be functional as a body and functional as a city.

[Kit Collins]: Of course, if other councilors have recommendations of things that they need to be on the short list, I'm sure I'll find those ideas compelling, but I just wanted to note advocacy for a short, tight list this year.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much, Councilor Leming, and thank you again for facilitating this meeting in the chambers.

[Kit Collins]: I apologize that I can't be there in person today.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for taking up the mantle of calling on people in person.

[Kit Collins]: I truly appreciate it.

[Kit Collins]: So just to quickly introduce the topic before us.

[Kit Collins]: This is an exciting day.

[Kit Collins]: This is a red letter day, actually.

[Kit Collins]: This is our first committee meeting about the zoning paper, which I think as most folks here and probably watching are aware, this is something that the Council has advocated for and advocated for funding for over the course of several terms now.

[Kit Collins]: Late last term, we finalized the zoning consultants that we've been working with longitudinally for this zoning overhaul reconfiguration project, Emily Innis and associates.

[Kit Collins]: So just to quickly run through, you know, a draft agenda for this meeting.

[Kit Collins]: I'm hoping to give Emily and her team a chance to introduce themselves to the committee for the first time.

[Kit Collins]: I'm hoping that we can get into kind of an overview of the zoning overhaul that's before us, run over a kind of draft list of our top issues.

[Kit Collins]: And of course, we have a lot of fertile ground to pull from our comprehensive plan, our housing production plan, our climate action adaptation plan, all of these really thoroughly

[Kit Collins]: Thoroughly developed, you know, plans that have come out of years of community outreach across various departments of the city that will be really great fodder for the work that we're going to do in the council in terms of making those priorities those goals manifest in an updated zoning code and updated zoning map.

[Kit Collins]: But the work before us is to take those lofty goals and see how we can break them into themes, into coherent themes, into bite-sized chunks, and then to figure out a timeline so that we can get through as much of that work as possible in this term.

[Kit Collins]: So after we hear an introduction from Emily Innis and associates, I'm hoping that we can, as a council, start to have that conversation about taking those shared priorities, grouping them into categories,

[Kit Collins]: and beginning a conversation about what from our current governing agenda or other priorities fit into the scope of zoning and beginning to sketch out the timeline through which we might approach this work this term.

[Kit Collins]: But first, I'll pass it off to Emily and her team.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Councilor Leming.

[Kit Collins]: Really appreciate this beginning to the discussion from my fellow councilors and, you know, in the, you know, roughly 40-45 minutes that we have here today, I think that one great use of our time might be to start, of course, you know, we're not going to do anything

[Kit Collins]: final tonight, but I think it could be a good use of our time to make this concrete for ourselves and also for residents to, you know, we can take a look at our governing agenda, we can pull out specific policies that councillors feel are priorities from the Climate Action and Adaptation Plan, from the Comprehensive Plan, and looking at that slide from Emily, we can start to say, okay, green score, this looks like it would fit into the

[Kit Collins]: For example, climate resiliency, citywide policy, and here's when we're thinking of starting that.

[Kit Collins]: Does that make sense for that particular policy?

[Kit Collins]: Does that fit there?

[Kit Collins]: Would it have a better fit there?

[Kit Collins]: I think we have a lot that we are trying to do by the end of June 2025.

[Kit Collins]: I think that's going to be here before we know it for all of us.

[Kit Collins]: And I think the more quickly we can get concrete about what we all consent to work on together,

[Kit Collins]: at what point in the year the better position we'll be in to accomplish our goals.

[Kit Collins]: So just as kind of an invitation to my fellow councillors, you know, for the time that we have together this evening, if there are specific policies from our governing agenda or new proposals on the brain, I think that we should feel free to voice those and put them on the record.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Chairwoman, I appreciate that.

[Kit Collins]: And I appreciate Councilor Scarpelli's note just now.

[Kit Collins]: I know that that used to be something that before my time on the Council, the Council would occasionally hold committees of the whole out in the real world, outside of the chambers.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that might be an appropriate thing to consider when we're

[Kit Collins]: doing neighborhood-specific zoning changes later in the year.

[Kit Collins]: But I just wanted to underscore a point that's already been made, but that I think is really important, is that we have so many ideas and high-level policies to go on that are already, you know, the result of these months and months and years of community meetings about

[Kit Collins]: what we want to see in the community and what the zoning is that could bring those about.

[Kit Collins]: Those ideas from community members, those proposals from residents and from business owners, those were not, the point of those ideas is not to live in a plan.

[Kit Collins]: The point of those ideas is to be put into our zoning ordinances so that our city can evolve to be more what we envision.

[Kit Collins]: And so I just say, I think it's important for us to go into this process and also for residents who are perhaps

[Kit Collins]: you know, rejoining this effort, you know, for the first time in several months or years to know that, you know, this is the intent of this Council is to take the will of the community that has been expressed in part through these plans that have already been published, you know, and do the good work of making sure that those are actually going to become a reality in our community through the changes that we're going to make.

[Kit Collins]: especially support a motion to have Councilors submit their specific proposals, ideas from the governing agenda, from our various plans, new proposals to council leadership and the PBS team so that those can be compiled and we can review that as a team at our next committee meeting on this topic and move forward from there with the timeline.
