[Kit Collins]: I would motion to keep the paper in committee and adjourn.

[Kit Collins]: Yes.

[Kit Collins]: I'm happy to defer to a presentation by a member of the administration, President Bearsford.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you to my fellow Councilors for their comments on this.

[Kit Collins]: I just want to note that this is the second time that a Stabilization Fund paper has come before us.

[Kit Collins]: Last year, the administration submitted a similar but different paper.

[Kit Collins]: At that time, we decided that creating that structure and making a large appropriation all in one fell swoop was not the right timing for the city.

[Kit Collins]: This time, the paper comes to us

[Kit Collins]: After months of ongoing discussions about this city's financial future, those discussions must and will continue.

[Kit Collins]: I do believe that it is the best practice for cities like Medford to have a rainy day fund, in the same way that many households have a rainy day fund for unforeseen emergencies.

[Kit Collins]: I think that this is an appropriate time to create the structure and then subsequently have those conversations about how much is appropriate to put into the fund and when, because this paper does not call for an appropriation, simply the creation of the structure.

[Kit Collins]: I also want to note this, to just reemphasize, there's no money changing accounts in this paper.

[Kit Collins]: If there were to be, it would be a reappropriation of money already in the city's coffers and the community's coffers.

[Kit Collins]: I think that this is the right time to set up the structure and then again have those community conversations about how much it makes sense to put into that rainy day fund.

[Kit Collins]: And when the next time we have these community wide emergencies come up, we are better prepared to take care of Medford residents.

[Kit Collins]: I would motion for approval.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: I want to thank Councilor Leming for co-sponsoring this proposal with me.

[Kit Collins]: I'll try to be as brief as I can.

[Kit Collins]: Housing affordability, unaffordability continues to displace Medford residents from where we grew up, went to school, the communities that we worship in, study, have community ties where we go to work.

[Kit Collins]: It is becoming more and more out of the question for working class and middle class people to live here, and no one is going to swoop in and fix that for us.

[Kit Collins]: I know that Medford residents deeply value being a welcoming and diverse community.

[Kit Collins]: The question is, are we willing to have the conversations and utilize the tools that will help us keep it that way?

[Kit Collins]: If we want our Affordable Housing Trust Fund to be more than a talking point, we know that we need to create dedicated funding streams so that it can manifest in housing and programs that will make it possible for us to keep Medford residents in Medford and for us to welcome new neighbors.

[Kit Collins]: Real estate transfer fees are one tool that the Governor has indicated provisional support for.

[Kit Collins]: That's why we're proposing to consider it.

[Kit Collins]: Our methods for meaningfully funding affordable housing are too few and far between to dismiss this out of hand, and our existing funding streams, including CPA, are unfortunately insufficient on their own.

[Kit Collins]: The scale is too great.

[Kit Collins]: Displacement is already happening.

[Kit Collins]: As Councilwoman said, what's before us tonight is whether we want to have the conversation about how to tailor this tool to dedicate a small percentage of only the highest ticket real estate transactions towards the most underinvested in housing in our community, the housing we desperately need and have a very severe shortage of.

[Kit Collins]: I want to be clear, if we vote this into committee tonight, then we can and we will get into the weeds with the community.

[Kit Collins]: We can discuss how to tailor this to affect the appropriate type of highest value sales so as to capture a small percentage of the huge value increases that have come into this region as living in Medford and places like it has become more expensive and more desirable.

[Kit Collins]: We can consider exceptions, like for elders, for people making transfers to close family, or for people selling at a loss or at minimal profit.

[Kit Collins]: Essentially, we can go through what would need to happen in order for this to be a net positive for this community.

[Kit Collins]: And then I want to remind everybody, this would need approval from the mayor, our state delegation, as well as the governor for this to actually take effect.

[Kit Collins]: I want to be really clear, we are not implementing a tax tonight.

[Kit Collins]: We are proposing to send this idea to committee to start a conversation, and I believe it is a very necessary conversation.

[Kit Collins]: I thank my fellow councilors and the public for their time.

[Kit Collins]: I will motion for approval.

[Kit Collins]: You know what, I'll follow up with Mr. Castagnetti after the meeting to thank him for sending along that New York Times Post article.

[Kit Collins]: Appreciate it.

[Kit Collins]: And I just think it speaks to the point that we need to be pursuing every tool at our disposal when it comes to affordable housing that can work for everybody.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Um, this is an ordinance that I've worked on over my terms and city council I believe this is an exercise and compromise is the result of what we have put forward over a couple years of working on this hearing.

[Kit Collins]: strong opposition to the idea of regulating these devices and also very strong support for the idea of mitigating these devices that we know cause significant air pollution and also noise pollution.

[Kit Collins]: What we've arrived at is an ordinance that seeks to provide some reasonable constraints around which devices can be used,

[Kit Collins]: at what times of the day, where, and phases out the most polluting versions of these devices, gas-powered, for residential and commercial users over different timescales over the next several years.

[Kit Collins]: I do have one motion before we vote, which is Section 3858, subsection 2,

[Kit Collins]: think that the word continuous should be removed.

[Kit Collins]: A constituent got in touch and indicated that this created kind of a loophole that was counter to the goals of this section.

[Kit Collins]: So that would be to remove the word continuous from section 3858 subsection 2 before we vote.

[Kit Collins]: section 38, 58, and then numeral two in that section.

[Kit Collins]: Present.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Chair Lazzaro.

[Kit Collins]: I apologize for having to be virtual tonight.

[Kit Collins]: Can everybody hear me okay?

[Kit Collins]: Great.

[Kit Collins]: Let me know if the volume goes in and out at all.

[Kit Collins]: So thank you for...

[Kit Collins]: Having this be our main topic for tonight, I'm hoping that this will be a pretty straightforward discussion.

[Kit Collins]: First, I'll offer a brief introduction, and then I can run us through the draft ordinance before us that I'm hoping we can use as a jumping off point.

[Kit Collins]: Open it up to, you know, love to hear any comments from my fellow Councilors at this preliminary stage, comments from the community, and figure out some next steps that make sense for this community.

[Kit Collins]: So the idea for a wildlife feeding ordinance came up based on some outreach from constituents that I got over the course of the year last year, talking about

[Kit Collins]: some issues arising from overfeeding of wildlife in some of Medford's denser residential areas.

[Kit Collins]: Looking around a little bit more, given the characteristics of some of Medford's denser residential neighborhoods, this is an issue that can cause public health nuisances whenever we have these

[Kit Collins]: areas of the city with homes close together, if there's overfeeding of wildlife, we have permeable borders between our various homes and backyards and porches in the city.

[Kit Collins]: So the intent of this is to give the Board of Health and Code Enforcement the ordinance tools that they need in order to issue warnings, tickets, potentially fines, whenever there's an issue arising from overfeeding of wildlife that neighbors cannot resolve amongst themselves.

[Kit Collins]: I do want to emphasize that.

[Kit Collins]: The intent here is just to empower code enforcement to step in when it's necessary to reduce a nuisance that's in line with other goals of the Board of Health and Code Enforcement to make sure that residents' enjoyment of the outdoors is enhanced and not limited.

[Kit Collins]: So I want to be really clear from the beginning, this is not about saying you can't have a bird feeder.

[Kit Collins]: This is about saying if there's feeding going on that's causing too many seagulls or pigeons or raccoons or rats

[Kit Collins]: on somebody else's property.

[Kit Collins]: That's something that if neighbors can't sort that out amongst themselves, then co-enforcement needs to be able to.

[Kit Collins]: So this, I have a draft ordinance for us to look at as a jumping off point.

[Kit Collins]: This language is based on several other communities ordinances that have similar goals.

[Kit Collins]: The one that this is modeled most closely on is Westford, Mass.

[Kit Collins]: So, Chair Lazzaro, if it's okay with you, I can run through the draft ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: I'd be happy to share my screen, or if you'd like to, I can follow along.

[Kit Collins]: That'd be great.

[Kit Collins]: Great.

[Kit Collins]: Hang on one second, please.

[Kit Collins]: All right.

[Kit Collins]: Can everybody see where it says Wildlife Feeding Ordinance Draft 2.13?

[Kit Collins]: Great.

[Kit Collins]: So I'll just go through this pretty quickly.

[Kit Collins]: This was in councilor's packets for this week, so I'm sure this isn't the first time that my colleagues are seeing this.

[Kit Collins]: Standard ordinance format.

[Kit Collins]: Up top, we start with purpose and intent, stating that Medford is, of course, as we all know and as we all cherish, Medford is home to a large population of wild animals, including rats, pigeons, bulls, and raccoons.

[Kit Collins]: However, feeding such wildlife, whether on purpose or through neglect, can entice and attract wild animals onto private property.

[Kit Collins]: porches, backyards.

[Kit Collins]: And again, the emphasis here is on feeding occurring on one lot that is having adverse effects for either that lot or neighbors.

[Kit Collins]: But limiting the practice of feeding wildlife, whether intentionally or passively, and enforcing this prohibition, the city can help limit a major factor that entices wildlife into resident areas of the city.

[Kit Collins]: Again, not anti-wildlife.

[Kit Collins]: We just want to make sure that every organism stays where it's most healthy for it to be.

[Kit Collins]: We have a definition section just to make it clear what this is targeted towards and what it is not.

[Kit Collins]: I think that the more useful thing in this section is going into some detail about what constitutes feeding, and based on some of the issues that this ordinance project arose out of, I think it's important to know that feeding doesn't just mean intentionally distributing food for wildlife, but potentially leaving inappropriate

[Kit Collins]: wildlife food out in an area where realistically varmints are going to get to it.

[Kit Collins]: So section C, prohibited activity, no person shall feed any wildlife as defined above, nor distribute or scatter any foodstuffs in or on any private place or, sorry, any public place or private property.

[Kit Collins]: So this is a thing that we should not do because we know that it attracts wild animals into residential areas of the city.

[Kit Collins]: I want to highlight some of the exceptions that are going in in this early draft of the ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: Nothing in this section shall be interpreted so as to prohibit bird feeders.

[Kit Collins]: There is an exception to the exception.

[Kit Collins]: If it is appearing that a bird feeder is the cause of a public safety threat or nuisance, then perhaps the enforcing officer will step in and say, here's the cause of a nuisance.

[Kit Collins]: This must be resolved.

[Kit Collins]: I think that I personally have never heard of a case where a bird feeder is causing an issue.

[Kit Collins]: This also states, nothing in this section shall be interpreted so as to prohibit the feeding of pets, provided that if food for pets is determined to be the source of wildlife feeding, then in that case, if it's causing an issue, that person may be directed to make sure that that food is no longer accessible to wildlife.

[Kit Collins]: It also states, nothing in this section shall be interpreted to prohibit the storage of food products, pet food or any other material where it's not constituting an attraction to wildlife.

[Kit Collins]: And again,

[Kit Collins]: If a reasonable usage is resulting in an adverse effect, then in that case, if it's reported, if it's deemed to be an issue, the enforcing officer may say, this isn't necessarily an issue, but in this case, it's causing wildlife to come into your property or neighbor's property to an extent that is causing harm or might cause harm.

[Kit Collins]: And then they might order them to remove it and store it in a more secure way.

[Kit Collins]: Getting down to enforcement, I thought it'd be appropriate for the animal control officer, the health director, the code enforcement officers and their designees to share administration and enforcement of this ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: There are some other wildlife-related enforcement responsibilities that the health director already has.

[Kit Collins]: Obviously, this touches the purview of the animal control officer and code enforcement officers are often called upon to.

[Kit Collins]: administer some of these nuisance-related issues on public and private property.

[Kit Collins]: So I'd be curious to hear feedback from city staff on that, but I thought that was an appropriate place to start.

[Kit Collins]: And finally, in terms of penalties for non-compliance, it is my hope that

[Kit Collins]: But again, the goal of this, I think, is not to say, oh, you did something wrong.

[Kit Collins]: Well, gosh, we'll ticket you immediately.

[Kit Collins]: No.

[Kit Collins]: The point of this is to provide a recourse for when something is going wrong and neighbors aren't able to resolve it amongst themselves immediately.

[Kit Collins]: So I would hope that, as with our other ordinances at the discretion of the enforcing officers, sometimes this is a warning.

[Kit Collins]: Sometimes this is a written warning, an oral warning.

[Kit Collins]: Sometimes it escalates to a ticket if the issue is really not getting resolved.

[Kit Collins]: And in that case,

[Kit Collins]: You know, based on that, I have in this first draft, first offense is a written warning from an enforcing officer.

[Kit Collins]: Second offense, $50 ticket.

[Kit Collins]: Third and subsequent offenses, $100 ticket.

[Kit Collins]: And of course, per MGL, we are not able to charge more than a $300 ticket, I believe, for any civil code violation.

[Kit Collins]: And I think it makes sense.

[Kit Collins]: Again, this is supposed to be a deterrent, not something punitive.

[Kit Collins]: So I thought this could be good to hear my fellow Councilors' feedback.

[Kit Collins]: I'm not part of the audience and anything else.

[Kit Collins]: I also want to note before I stop talking and let my fellow Councilors respond to that, at our last meeting of the Public Health and Community Safety Committee, I did

[Kit Collins]: mentioned this ordinance, and as a follow-up, the clerk did circulate the ordinance to my fellow councilors and to relevant city staff requesting their feedback by March 15th.

[Kit Collins]: That was when I thought that the next meeting of this committee was going to be in April.

[Kit Collins]: The council meeting schedule changed since then, so the word has already been put out to relevant city staff to get their comment on that, and we'll be sure to have it by the next time that we meet on this ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I really appreciate my fellow Councilors initial reactions to this.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for taking this project so thoughtfully.

[Kit Collins]: initial reaction to the questions around, and I think it's a really good question, like how does this intersect with efforts to make sure that wildcats are attracted so that they can be spayed and neutered, which is important.

[Kit Collins]: There's a couple areas in the ordinance, and I appreciate Councilor Callaghan for speaking to this, where it might be covered, but I think that that would be a great thing to put to our animal control officer, as well as to have legal counsel take a look at when they do their review of this, just to make sure.

[Kit Collins]: that that should be would be interpreted the way that we intend.

[Kit Collins]: And again, the intent of this is to

[Kit Collins]: make sure that there's a recourse for when something is causing an issue, that there's a way for the code enforcement officer to step in.

[Kit Collins]: But I think that this is creating a good succinct list of questions to follow up with our staff and experts.

[Kit Collins]: And I would also be happy to, I'll probably make some motions at the end of our discussion, I'd also be happy to make sure that

[Kit Collins]: the Medford-based group, Kitty Connection, sees a copy of this just to make sure that it is on their radars as folks in the community who do work with wildlife.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Chair Lazzaro?

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I'll answer to either.

[Kit Collins]: I would make a motion to refer this version of the ordinance to KP Law for a legal review prior to our next meeting on the topic.

[Kit Collins]: That would be my first motion.

[Kit Collins]: Yes, thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I have two more.

[Kit Collins]: Second motion would be to have the city clerk recirculate this document to the relevant city staff, along with the questions that came out of this committee discussion, mainly around if this covers putting out food to trap feral cats for spaying and neutering.

[Kit Collins]: And then I would also motion to keep this paper in committee.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Essentially, what I put in my memo speaks to my recommendations.

[Kit Collins]: My priority is for this budget cycle.

[Kit Collins]: This is not going to be a budget year where I think that we are having the bandwidth to pilot a lot of new programs or start a lot of new positions.

[Kit Collins]: My focus is on maintaining level service for constituents and for students and workers in school systems.

[Kit Collins]: That's why my number one and number two priorities are meeting the school department budget request and meeting the library department budget request, making sure that we maintain level service and hours of operation at the library in particular, because that has been something that has been called into question in some past budget cycles.

[Kit Collins]: I wanted to call out specifically grant-funded personnel in the Health Department, Office of Outreach and Prevention, and the Planning Department because there are a lot of grant-funded positions in those departments specifically, but we know that all those positions are critical.

[Kit Collins]: In our community, they serve really important functions and the needs for those roles are not going away just because pandemic-era funding and grant funding is going away, so we need to make sure that we are maintaining level service by

[Kit Collins]: rolling those positions either onto other sources of grant funding or ideally making sure that those positions can be maintained within our operations, our operating budget this year and in future years.

[Kit Collins]: The next few key priorities for this year are ones that we've talked about around this time of year in the past.

[Kit Collins]: Trying to get a city solicitor and an assistant city solicitor online as quickly as we can.

[Kit Collins]: It's my belief that we need to raise the amount budgeted for salary for those positions so that we can be attracting competitive candidates.

[Kit Collins]: I do believe that this is a at this moment in time a tough position to hire for in this area in, in general, and I think that these positions are so important that we should prioritize escalating the amount of salary budgeted for these positions, so that

[Kit Collins]: we are competitive with some of our neighboring municipalities.

[Kit Collins]: I put some recommended dollar figures on here.

[Kit Collins]: Those are based off of my research into what our neighboring communities of Malden and Somerville primarily are paying for these positions.

[Kit Collins]: For example, in Malden, the budgeted salary for their city solicitor is around, it's a little over 117,000.

[Kit Collins]: In Somerville, it's 189.

[Kit Collins]: I believe that the figure I suggested to increase the city solicitor salary by less than $50,000 was based on the discrepancy with Malden.

[Kit Collins]: Is that true?

[Kit Collins]: Oh, sorry.

[Kit Collins]: That was based off the discrepancy with the city of Somerville.

[Kit Collins]: I know this is a big jump for one position, but I think we've all felt for the past few years how significant it is to not have a city solicitor in-house, and I think that that would be a

[Kit Collins]: I think that we can be pound wise by investing more money into these unfilled city positions.

[Kit Collins]: It's the same for the assistant city solicitor and in escalating the elections manager to a direct deliver position again I think that these are things that you know we see what happens when we don't invest in making sure that

[Kit Collins]: these positions are first and foremost filled.

[Kit Collins]: And second, you know, we really owe the people of Medford, the best possible person in all of these roles.

[Kit Collins]: And then I put the secondary priorities under areas of study slash secondary priorities.

[Kit Collins]: I know that these are things we're not going to be able to bring online early in fiscal 25.

[Kit Collins]: But I think that charting a course towards implementing a paid family and medical leave program for all city employees, apart from being the right thing to do and what all of our city employees deserve will help us

[Kit Collins]: fill key staffing roles.

[Kit Collins]: And I believe that a review of what needs to happen to bring our finance department software into the 2020s is something that we would see the benefit from.

[Kit Collins]: Once we achieve that, we need to figure out if that's something that can happen in three, five, or 10 years.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that every department would feel the positive effects of that.

[Kit Collins]: So I'm hoping that

[Kit Collins]: while not being things that I think are realistic to prioritize for fiscal 25, these are things that I hope that the administration is saving some capacity for studying this year.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears, and I thank all of my fellow councillors for coming into the meeting with their recommendations.

[Kit Collins]: I think it's really exciting that we're starting this conversation in March for the first time in

[Kit Collins]: the first time that I've been on the council, which is not that long, but I think that this conversation, this process is beginning earlier than it usually does.

[Kit Collins]: And I appreciate the administration's cooperation so far with trying to make the overall budgeting process more communicative and less rushed.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that this is a great start.

[Kit Collins]: I'm happy to hear that there's cohesion among a lot of us on a lot of the shared priorities, and I think that's not surprising because we hear all the same issues.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that when I think back over the past couple years of budget discussions and what the common threads that emerge are, you know, we're the funnel into which sort of the main problems and aspirations and grievances of the city

[Kit Collins]: comes into.

[Kit Collins]: And I think the conversation that we've been having about the law department for a couple of years is an example of this.

[Kit Collins]: We're seeing our capacity reduced within these chambers because we lack in-house legal support.

[Kit Collins]: We see it taking a lot of time on ordinances.

[Kit Collins]: We see legal issues coming up, like the BJ's lawsuit, as Councilor Scarpelli mentioned.

[Kit Collins]: And I think the work of this council, very productive in the past, has been to say, what's the common denominator here?

[Kit Collins]: What's the investment that we're not making that we need to make that could be the fulcrum for all this other change?

[Kit Collins]: If we had a staffed in-house legal department, I think we would be seeing the difference in our workflow, in the quality of our workflow, and how quickly we're able to get things done, and then there would be all the things that we are not seeing.

[Kit Collins]: All of the decisions that

[Kit Collins]: It's hard to make, or we have to put off, or we have to request from an outside legal perspective, and they're not super accountable to their timelines, to our timelines, because they don't work for us.

[Kit Collins]: It's all the negatives that we don't see because of a targeted investment, in addition to all the positives that we do start to see.

[Kit Collins]: I think that's still that common denominator that we're still looking for that targeted investment there.

[Kit Collins]: And I think the other one that this conversation, um, I would say over the past six months is also revealing is needed investments to the finance department.

[Kit Collins]: I think president bears put it very well.

[Kit Collins]: There's all these positives that we would start to see if we brought our financial software and staffing up to year 2024.

[Kit Collins]: And then there's all these negatives that once we stop having these problems and inefficiencies and, you know,

[Kit Collins]: deleted results that come from a severe shortage of staffing and outdated software.

[Kit Collins]: We won't know it when those problems start to go away, but we're certainly seeing them now.

[Kit Collins]: And it's exciting to me to see multiple voices in this room,

[Kit Collins]: noticing the same problems.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that we're identifying another area, like the legal department, that we really need the administration to target some investment into.

[Kit Collins]: I know that it's hard to contemplate in this financial environment, making a multi-million dollar investment.

[Kit Collins]: But as President Beer said,

[Kit Collins]: We're already spending a lot, not just in money, but in staff time on trying to use inefficient processes to do this work that we have to do anyway, and dealing with the problems that arise from doing it less efficiently than we have to.

[Kit Collins]: So I hope that that can be a topic that we really elevate this budget season.

[Kit Collins]: Again, this is a year when I think we have to be realistic, but I think that this is so foundational to so many departments that we can't afford to not

[Kit Collins]: prioritize the issue and at least try to get some, you know, in my recommendations, I put it forward as an area of study.

[Kit Collins]: Can we at least invest in a consultant to look at our software and say, here's a plan for how to get there?

[Kit Collins]: Can we at least start there?

[Kit Collins]: If not looking at what would it look to really divert some funding into an investment in this fiscal year and know that that's

[Kit Collins]: something that might feel short-term uncomfortable, but we have to think about the long-term downstream positive effects of that kind of investment.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: My preference in terms of where we go from here, I think that we built in a couple of weeks to move from individual council recommendations to full council recommendations.

[Kit Collins]: I think this meeting put us in a pretty good,

[Kit Collins]: I think that there's a very clear.

[Kit Collins]: Ben diagram.

[Kit Collins]: There's a lot of stuff in the middle.

[Kit Collins]: Top five, which as council leadership, you or I could assimilate into a document for us to vote on in a future committee of the whole, um, I think that it would be a pretty similar process if, um.

[Kit Collins]: you know, I think that we could, um.

[Kit Collins]: Yourself for myself.

[Kit Collins]: Um just took a stab at, you know, tallying up what was submitted the most times make a version of that document, and then we could similarly look at it as a group at a future committee of the whole and then make some final decisions.

[Kit Collins]: Um that evening and still have plenty of time to submit it before the 22nd.

[Kit Collins]: I just think that that will be, um, give Councilors time to digest, um,

[Kit Collins]: without some time to order our rankings.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I think that's an important question, especially for the folks for whom this is the first budget season.

[Kit Collins]: President Bears' overview of what I think is a reasonable way to approach this.

[Kit Collins]: what I would propose we, you know, what we literally send to the administration.

[Kit Collins]: We talk about our shared priorities.

[Kit Collins]: What are the things that we're going to say?

[Kit Collins]: There's 30 things we want.

[Kit Collins]: We're going to ask for five and hopefully get one or two.

[Kit Collins]: circulate this aggregated document among fellow Councilors.

[Kit Collins]: to circulate the document for council leadership to schedule a follow-up committee of the whole where we will prioritize those ideas, and then to submit that list of priorities to the administration by the 22nd after the meeting, along with councilors' individual memos and the records of our meetings on the topic.

[Kit Collins]: Yeah.

[Kit Collins]: Planning and Permanent Committee, February 28, 2024.

[Kit Collins]: This meeting will take place at 6 p.m.

[Kit Collins]: in the City Council Chamber, second floor, Medford City Hall and via Zoom.

[Kit Collins]: Mr. Clerk, would you please call the roll?

[Kit Collins]: Planning and Permitting Committee.

[Kit Collins]: The action and discussion item for this meeting is paper 24042, a resolution to discuss the implementation of the Housing Stability Notification Ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: And we've invited some members of the Planning, Development and Sustainability Office that are the staff that are tasked with implementing and enforcing

[Kit Collins]: this ordinance to be with us here tonight.

[Kit Collins]: I just want to make it clear, because this is a resolution to discuss the implementation of an ordinance that was passed around this time last year.

[Kit Collins]: The Housing Stability Notification Ordinance is an ordinance that was passed in February 2023 that created a new requirement for

[Kit Collins]: property owners of properties where there are tenants, that at the beginning and end of any lease, that they should send a document that is created by the City of Medford detailing tenants' resources and tenants' rights to those tenants at those given

[Kit Collins]: start and end times to any lease.

[Kit Collins]: That is the ordinance in a nutshell.

[Kit Collins]: It's fairly simple.

[Kit Collins]: We had a fairly lengthy process crafting the ordinance between 2022 and 2023.

[Kit Collins]: Now it's been about a year since we passed it, so the purpose of this meeting is to check in

[Kit Collins]: with the Planning, Development, and Sustainability Office that have been working hard, thinking about how it makes sense to roll out this ordinance, going through the necessary steps to put together that document, to draft it, to run it by legal counsel, and to be thoughtful about how to make sure that everybody in the community that ought to know about this new requirement does before we officially begin implementing and following up with people to ensure that it's being complied with.

[Kit Collins]: So with that, I'm going to open it up to preliminary comment from my fellow councillors that I'd love to hear just an overall update from our city staff.

[Kit Collins]: Any comments from my fellow councillors?

[Kit Collins]: Hearing none, I'd be happy to turn it over to Director of Planning, Development and Sustainability, Alicia Hunt, and our housing planner, Aditi, to give us an update on the

[Kit Collins]: You know, I know that there's been a lot of good work being done in the planning office to develop this document and to think through how we're gonna roll it out.

[Kit Collins]: So I'd love any sort of update that you can share on that process.

[Kit Collins]: I'll quickly chime in, and then I'll turn it back over to our subject matter experts.

[Kit Collins]: My understanding, and I appreciate that question, Councilor Scarpellirilli, because I think that's an important point to clarify.

[Kit Collins]: My understanding is this

[Kit Collins]: ordinance adds something to that process.

[Kit Collins]: So the state law creates a requirement for that document and that required notice and resources to be sent when there is a notice to quit.

[Kit Collins]: This ordinance says not necessarily just when there's an ordinance, sorry, when there's a notice to quit, but when a lease is beginning or when a lease is ending for other reasons.

[Kit Collins]: Let's make sure

[Kit Collins]: Right.

[Kit Collins]: If there's a foreclosure happening, let's make sure that the person occupying that home or about to occupy that home knows their rights and has these resources in those other scenarios as well, building on top of the state law that is specifically about notices to quit.

[Kit Collins]: Did I get that right, Director?

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Leming?

[Kit Collins]: Yeah.

[Kit Collins]: And if I, I appreciate, um, I,

[Kit Collins]: One of the goals of this meeting is just a general update of where we are at in rolling out the implementation.

[Kit Collins]: I think the other, especially now that it's been a year since we were talking about this in public meeting, is to have these clarifying conversations about what is the intent of this and what does it do and what are the consequences and what aren't the consequences.

[Kit Collins]: So, you know, as the sponsor of the original ordinance now passed,

[Kit Collins]: I think that there is nothing about the notification document that would affect eviction proceedings at all.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think that there's anything about the notification document that would... The intent of the document is to be something that can go to a tenant and say,

[Kit Collins]: Here's some info.

[Kit Collins]: If you have an issue, here's who you can call.

[Kit Collins]: You have a question, here's who you can call.

[Kit Collins]: If you have a question and this is the language you speak and it's not English, here's who you can call just to be informative.

[Kit Collins]: And the intent of that is to really make sure that people are empowered with information before they have any sort of issue or problem, which is intended to be.

[Kit Collins]: beneficial for a tenant or property owner, everybody in that relationship.

[Kit Collins]: So on the enforcement side, I don't think this would ever impact, you know, should a notice to quit be issued.

[Kit Collins]: If there's another condition that prompts an eviction, this would not affect that timeline.

[Kit Collins]: And I think we put it very clearly in the ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: You know, this is something that is intended to be an informative and educational ordinance, not something that we're going to be

[Kit Collins]: looking and looking for evidence of non-compliance to issue tickets, but rather to be something that we can follow up and saying, let's make sure that everybody gets the information before they need it, and that our city staff can be working proactively to make sure that this is getting out to the community in an accessible way.

[Kit Collins]: So I really appreciate the opportunity to clarify that.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Alicia.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate that approach.

[Kit Collins]: I think that, like we said, the goal of this is to be informative, if we all recognize that a healthy tenant-landlord relationship is one where everybody knows what their responsibilities are and their resources are, tenants included, and know what to expect and what to expect of themselves.

[Kit Collins]: And that's the best recipe for a healthy and unproblematic relationship.

[Kit Collins]: I saw President Bears, Councilor Leming, and then back to you, Councilor Scarpelli.

[Kit Collins]: Is that a cover your questions?

[Kit Collins]: That's great.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Director.

[Kit Collins]: And it's exciting to hear about different ways of collaborating with, you know, not just property owners, but also real estate agents in the city to make sure that all these initiatives and all the good work that I think everybody wants to be doing, that we can be staying on the same page and synthesizing about that.

[Kit Collins]: I'll go to the housing planner and then Councilor Bears.

[Kit Collins]: All right, thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bearsens, and I appreciate, you know, when we were developing this ordinance over the course of several months leading up to, I think we passed it in February 2023, most of our conversations were centered around how do we make this something that is accessible, that people can understand, that people who don't read English can language, can access in the language they understand.

[Kit Collins]: Essentially, how do we make this tool that is meant to be informational, how do we make it easy to access?

[Kit Collins]: And I really appreciate, you know, now that we're talking about

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate that City staff is taking the time to make sure that this is done right in that same spirit of we want to make sure that everybody who needs to know that this is a new requirement hears about it.

[Kit Collins]: And I appreciate that we're thinking through the communication channels that the city already uses, that the conversation is starting with.

[Kit Collins]: What can we use to physically get this into people's hands?

[Kit Collins]: Because we know it's probably a fraction of all Medford residents and property owners that are on the city's

[Kit Collins]: social media channels and accessing what local news we have left.

[Kit Collins]: And so I appreciate that those are, you know, perhaps going to be supplementary tools to getting this information out, but that primarily we're thinking through.

[Kit Collins]: you know, what's the best mailing to use so that this is cost-effective that we make sure that people hear about it.

[Kit Collins]: And I was especially happy to hear that staff is thinking in the direction of, you know, the mailing that will go out to property owners will include sort of a signal, like, there is a new requirement to send out a document.

[Kit Collins]: This is not that document.

[Kit Collins]: That document lives online.

[Kit Collins]: Like, here's how to access it.

[Kit Collins]: Here's how to print it out.

[Kit Collins]: Here's how to send it to the library and get it printed out, rather than sending a static document that then

[Kit Collins]: we'll get photocopied until it's illegible or we'll get updated and people won't benefit from that updated information and so on.

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Scarpelli.

[Kit Collins]: Do I have a second on the motion to keep the paper in committee and reconvene for another update, perhaps on timeline as we get later into the spring?

[Kit Collins]: Second from Councilor Leming.

[Kit Collins]: And just to reiterate, you know, the content of this meeting so far on the ongoing implementation rollout of the Housing Stability Notification Ordinance, we've had a, I think, a really helpful update from city staff where we're at with the timeline.

[Kit Collins]: What are the questions still on the table for finalizing the document and then alerting everybody who ought to be alerted about it?

[Kit Collins]: I know that there's some energy to try to get the document finalized and begin to roll that out, you know, this spring, by June, I think.

[Kit Collins]: This is a committee that meets often.

[Kit Collins]: It meets every two weeks.

[Kit Collins]: This is a fairly straightforward conversation because we've talked about this ordinance so many times before.

[Kit Collins]: I just say that to note that even though there's a lot of competition for meeting dates in this committee in particular, because we're doing zoning in this committee, I'm sure that this is something where we can have a quick update on an evening that's shared with other topics.

[Kit Collins]: So on the motion of Councilor Scarpelli, oh, peanut gallery over here.

[Kit Collins]: On the motion of Councilor Scarpelli to keep the paper in committee seconded by

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Leming, all in favor.

[Kit Collins]: Seconded by President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: And while the clerk is getting ready, I'd just like to say thank you again to Alicia and Aditi for working with us on developing this ordinance in the previous term and for doing such a thoughtful job of implementation in this one.

[Kit Collins]: We appreciate it.

[Kit Collins]: Yes.

[Kit Collins]: Matt, you got to stop doing that.

[Kit Collins]: Yes.

[Kit Collins]: Meeting is adjourned.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, everybody.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Thanks as always for being here and collaborating on this with us.

[Kit Collins]: Same to the Chief of Staff.

[Kit Collins]: Just to echo what my colleagues just shared, I think the

[Kit Collins]: You know, I certainly share the concern.

[Kit Collins]: It's very important to not be legislating something that we don't know is within our capacity or beyond our capacity.

[Kit Collins]: And I definitely appreciate the focus on that as we're still crafting this in draft form.

[Kit Collins]: And I completely agree to me the intent of the language that's currently in that section of the ordinance is just to create kind of some sort of timestamp for a check-in.

[Kit Collins]: I know the term report usually connotated as like a very structured, very detailed, like it must have X, Y, and Z type of document.

[Kit Collins]: To me, the intent is just to make sure that once a year we have some kind of record of here's where we were last year, here's where we are this year in terms of

[Kit Collins]: are we approaching it?

[Kit Collins]: What new tools have we developed?

[Kit Collins]: What is our sense right now of what we might need to get closer to that goal?

[Kit Collins]: And not some sort of mandate, not some sort of, you know, if it doesn't have this section, then it's invalid or something like that.

[Kit Collins]: A fairly, you know, the phrase I would use, I wouldn't put this in the ordinances, I would be pretty comfortable with this being as formal or as informal as possible.

[Kit Collins]: capacity allows it to be while we're trying to get this annual process off the ground.

[Kit Collins]: That's important to me is just knowing that we're going to have some kind of document and some kind of check-in in the fall every year that allows us to chart our progress towards the better information and the sophistication that I know the administration is already working towards and that we're eager to support.

[Kit Collins]: I was just collecting my thoughts.

[Kit Collins]: I certainly appreciate

[Kit Collins]: You know everything that the chief of staff has shared in this meeting and other and others.

[Kit Collins]: The, I think the point is really well taken and I definitely appreciate the spirit of, you know, just being transparent

[Kit Collins]: You know, I know that these are things that we all want to do, and I really appreciate the clarity around, you know, I know experientially what you want to do and commit to do and what you can do are not always a perfectly overlapping Venn diagram.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that, you know, as a city, we see how that plays out with our various challenges and episodes and things that we go through in trying to manage our capacity as a city overall.

[Kit Collins]: So I just want to note that that point is really well taken.

[Kit Collins]: You know, this ordinance has changed a lot.

[Kit Collins]: One thing that, again, and I respect the diversity of opinion about the exact language that this section is put into, one thing that makes me personally feel comfortable is just how flexible the language of this section is.

[Kit Collins]: And of course, I've made it clear before, you know, that in my mind, this says, you know, shall submit a report and doesn't really get prescriptive about what that has to look like beyond touching on certain topics.

[Kit Collins]: It does bring to mind to me because the Chief of Staff mentioned the Elections Department in terms of, you know, I think this conversation is a lot about thinking through contingencies.

[Kit Collins]: What about the years when this report isn't like all that we would dream it to be?

[Kit Collins]: Quite recently, the City Council asked for an elections after action report from the Elections Department and that report was not all that we dreamed it to be.

[Kit Collins]: So we talked about it and

[Kit Collins]: And that was how we took that document and got some meaning out of it by, you know, that spring conversation about, you know, this is what we would like to see in it.

[Kit Collins]: Next time, these are the questions that we still have.

[Kit Collins]: The conversation that we had about the report, I think, answered a little bit more some of those questions that weren't answered in the text of it.

[Kit Collins]: So I just bring that up as an example of

[Kit Collins]: um, why I feel comfortable with this language, knowing that, you know, I don't know, like, maybe we'll never have a season of going through this process laid out in the, uh, laid out in the ordinance where it will feel very challenging to do that.

[Kit Collins]: Maybe it'll feel, feel seamless, you know, starting this fall, maybe it won't.

[Kit Collins]: Um, but

[Kit Collins]: if it's not seamless, if there's friction there, if it's challenging to get a report together, if the report, like, has to be very concise, if the report has to be really bare bones the first year, if, you know, we read the report and we still have questions, well, I feel like we already have a model for how that can go.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that even just having a simple document to start out with, that's a jumping off point for a discussion in committee or written follow-up, to me, that's still productive to have, even if

[Kit Collins]: that conversation is about what's not included.

[Kit Collins]: So I just offer that.

[Kit Collins]: The version of the document that I'm looking at is the track changes one.

[Kit Collins]: appropriate to make a motion to accept the track changes along with those other technical amendments around the effective date and swapping the order of those sections?

[Kit Collins]: It was the one in the packet.

[Kit Collins]: Shall become effective upon passage.

[Kit Collins]: If this is just a simple finding the right

[Kit Collins]: term for the position and swapping it in.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate the overview since we looked at this last and since this is the first time that we're meeting about this in this current term.

[Kit Collins]: It's helpful to have the overview.

[Kit Collins]: I think that the comments that we've received from KP Law

[Kit Collins]: and some other partners have been helpful to get this closer to a finished product.

[Kit Collins]: In terms of starting at the beginning, you know, with the goals of this ordinance, I think it's clear throughout this process, you know, we've kind of tacked our way into a middle path between, you know, the goals of phasing out

[Kit Collins]: a very polluting technology while making sure that this is something that is manageable from an enforcement standpoint on the city side to make sure that it's a manageable time frame for large properties and commercial users to make sure that we're

[Kit Collins]: balancing the right regulations and restrictions for commercial users and for private users.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that our process has benefited a lot from hearing from constituents and commercial users in the past and hopefully tonight as well, as well as the Chamber of Commerce and making sure that we've been tailoring and tweaking this so that it's

[Kit Collins]: fair for different use cases.

[Kit Collins]: And over the past couple of versions, we've also kind of tweaked that in terms of what specific restrictions we're putting forward and also what metrics and measures we're using.

[Kit Collins]: whether it's the amount of months in the year that we allow use of the gas-powered leaf blowers versus electric, whether it's what we're using to measure if something is within allowable ranges or not.

[Kit Collins]: I'm glad to see kind of on that seam of fairness, making sure that this is fair for different types of users.

[Kit Collins]: I'm glad that we have removed some of the exemptions for municipal use of the leaf blowers.

[Kit Collins]: I think that anything that we're expecting of commercial users, we should expect of municipal contractors as well.

[Kit Collins]: So that's something that I'm happy to see.

[Kit Collins]: And I'm happy to see that this, I think, is the most readable version of the ordinance that we've had yet, which is, of course, super important because some of the people using this ordinance are just, a lot of them are just homeowners, residents who just want to know, is this okay?

[Kit Collins]: You know, is this what my community has in mind for, you know, reality testing?

[Kit Collins]: as well as possible every single day because of how the department is structured and any decisions that we have the jurisdiction to make around that.

[Kit Collins]: this administration or this person in the role right now or this person who's doing the job right now, it's about the department, it's about the community, it's about today, but it's also about five years from now, 10 years from now.

[Kit Collins]: It's always hard not to make these issues personal because we are a community made up of people who know each other and care for each other and sometimes have history with one another, but these decisions can't be made with anything other than that North Star of public safety in mind.

[Kit Collins]: Um.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: At the most recent planning and permitting committee meeting, which is the second meeting of that committee, in keeping with the theme of preliminary meetings, we picked up a two-year-old paper to explore a home rule petition around rent stabilization and just cause eviction protections.

[Kit Collins]: This will be the first of many conversations that we'll have on the paper with the end result being a home rule position, not an ordinance that the city council would or could pass outright.

[Kit Collins]: So more to come on that.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: She says yes in the chat.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: The idea for this ordinance came out of conversations that I had with several members of city staff and several residents over the course of last year.

[Kit Collins]: residents were complaining about specific sidewalks and residential neighborhoods that were rendered impassable by vegetation starting on private properties that have grown so long that folks couldn't walk on the sidewalk.

[Kit Collins]: I've talked about this with code enforcement, and it seems like there may be a gap in our municipal code that prevents them from having the statute that they need to do enforcement when

[Kit Collins]: the public way is impacted by plant growth, essentially, from private properties.

[Kit Collins]: So this would just be a really targeted project to make sure that there's enabling language in our code of ordinances so that code enforcement does have the ability to issue warnings and potentially tickets if need be when folks cannot travel on the public way because of stuff coming out of private property.

[Kit Collins]: So I would move the question to proceed this along to the Public Health and Community Safety Committee.

[Kit Collins]: So we're talking about the housing stability notification ordinance right now.

[Kit Collins]: This is an ordinance that we passed one year ago, actually just almost exactly a year ago, the Housing Stability Notification Ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: So it's been almost exactly a year since this council passed the housing stability notification ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: This is a pretty specific pretty limited ordinance that says when a property owner has a tenant in a building.

[Kit Collins]: The city shall develop a document that outlines just very, very basic tenants rights and resources, and the property owner renting to attendants to send that document to their tenant at the beginning or end of every lease.

[Kit Collins]: It's not a document that the landlord has to create it's something that they can download off of the city website and make sure that it's conveyed to their tenant this is opposed to.

[Kit Collins]: kind of empower people with information, and hopefully answer some questions before questions come up in the landlord tenant relationship.

[Kit Collins]: Like I said this was passed about a year ago there's been some turnover in the planning development sustainability office this is the first time we tried to do something like this in Medford so the point of this resolution is to hold a meeting.

[Kit Collins]: with Planning, Development and Sustainability staff and some others been working on this in the Office of Outreach and Prevention to check in on how gearing up for implementation and enforcement of this ordinance is going.

[Kit Collins]: There are several questions to discuss, including where are we at in terms of developing that document.

[Kit Collins]: I know that staff has been running it by legal and trying to get it to a place of completion.

[Kit Collins]: Then there's the matter of how to make sure that

[Kit Collins]: property owners are properly informed about this.

[Kit Collins]: Of course, we have to make sure that we're conveying this in the communication channels to make sure that people really going to hear about it.

[Kit Collins]: This is not intended to be punitive.

[Kit Collins]: This is intended to be informational.

[Kit Collins]: And I know that city staff was looking at very many communications, communication channels to make sure that the folks who need to know about this do know about this.

[Kit Collins]: So the point of this meeting is to meet with city staff and say, how's it going?

[Kit Collins]: Where are we at in the process?

[Kit Collins]: How can we help?

[Kit Collins]: So I would move to refer this conversation to the Committee on Planning and Permitting.

[Kit Collins]: City clerk.

[Kit Collins]: 24045 offered by as various council president resolution regarding scheduled annual budget process for FY 2025.

[Kit Collins]: Be it resolved by the Medford City Council that the council president request City

[Kit Collins]: for consideration in a Committee of the Whole meeting on Wednesday, March 6, 2024.

[Kit Collins]: Be it further resolved that, based on the schedule included in the soon-to-be finalized budget ordinance, the City Council and City Administration will follow the budget schedule for the FY 2025 City Budget.

[Kit Collins]: By March 1, 2024, City Councilors submit individual budget recommendations for consideration by Administration and Finance Committee,

[Kit Collins]: By Friday, March 22nd, 2024, City Council submits collective budget recommended to the mayor.

[Kit Collins]: From April 15th, 2024 to May 15th, 2024, City Council holds preliminary budget meetings with department heads.

[Kit Collins]: By Friday, May 31st, 2024, mayor submits comprehensive budget proposal to the City Council.

[Kit Collins]: As for the elections commission, I think that I would just really love for the conversation that we had the last time the election commission came before us in a regular meeting.

[Kit Collins]: a more explicit and a more specific response to the questions that we laid out in the original paper requesting the election after report.

[Kit Collins]: And so that's, as one Councilor, that's what I'll be looking for.

[Kit Collins]: That's what I'm hoping for.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that that was pretty well articulated by many Councilors who spoke in our last conversation about it with the Elections Commission.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Councilor Leming.

[Kit Collins]: And I thank the Councilor for chairing this meeting because I have to be remote tonight.

[Kit Collins]: Appreciate that.

[Kit Collins]: So this is the first time that we are talking about this paper in committee, even though it was introduced in 2022.

[Kit Collins]: So I wanted to begin

[Kit Collins]: with a brief overview of the paper, what it is, what it isn't, why it was brought up, when it was, and just to kind of place us at the beginning of a discussion about this topic.

[Kit Collins]: Like I mentioned, this was brought forward by myself and President Bears in 2022.

[Kit Collins]: At the time, this was a resolution that bundled together many ideas for housing stability-related home rule petitions.

[Kit Collins]: It included, these ideas included rent stabilization, tenant right to purchase, tenant right to counsel, just cause eviction protections, anti-price gouging protections, exemptions for small owner-occupant landlords.

[Kit Collins]: This was a resolution that bundled together kind of a roster of different ideas that have been used by various local municipalities all around the goal of

[Kit Collins]: trying to introduce some stability into a housing market that is governed by market forces.

[Kit Collins]: And I also want to speak a little bit to the particular moment during which this paper arose.

[Kit Collins]: This was, I believe, March of 2022.

[Kit Collins]: We had just had an issue right here in Medford Square, where a large apartment building on Bradley Road, all of the tenants had been served notices to quit.

[Kit Collins]: The story given was renovations to the apartments.

[Kit Collins]: But in effect, what we saw play out at the site was that a recent change of hands for the property and the property owners wanted to be able to rent those units at very much higher rates than they had been rented to for years.

[Kit Collins]: And we saw a lot of tenants leave the community.

[Kit Collins]: We saw a lot of tenants kind of have to react to this with not a lot of information, not a lot of options.

[Kit Collins]: and come to the City Council for help and say, what can we do?

[Kit Collins]: And unfortunately, we had to say, you know, there's not a lot that we can do.

[Kit Collins]: You know, we cannot intervene in this kind of situation.

[Kit Collins]: We can't get between, we can't get in the middle of this transaction.

[Kit Collins]: We can provide you with folks who are experts in this type of situation, but there's nothing that the City Council can do.

[Kit Collins]: to help you stay in your home, stay in your community, keep your commute the same, keep your kid in public schools.

[Kit Collins]: So these ideas came out of that conversation with those tenants, I believe almost all of whom eventually ended up getting displaced out of the community.

[Kit Collins]: And in that time, of course, we've seen other unfortunate examples of

[Kit Collins]: rent increases so exorbitant that they had the same effect of displacing tenants out of the community when they otherwise would have remained community members.

[Kit Collins]: So I just wanted to give that framing for why that came up when it did because it's been a little while.

[Kit Collins]: Chair Leming, if I may.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much.

[Kit Collins]: And thank you, Councilor Scarpelli, for raising that.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate that.

[Kit Collins]: I know that rent stabilization is absolutely an issue that gets people's hackles up, you know, wherever they feel about it.

[Kit Collins]: I completely appreciate that.

[Kit Collins]: I do want to, you know, and I think that Councilor Scarpelli, we're coming at this meeting actually in a similar frame of mind, you know, as you and I know through going through this process on various resolutions and ordinances.

[Kit Collins]: This is the beginning of a process.

[Kit Collins]: I think it's probably going to be a fairly lengthy and thorough process because this is such a delicate issue.

[Kit Collins]: Let me return to sort of the framing of the issue, because I hope that I can speak to some of the concerns that you brought up, and I think that they're important ones.

[Kit Collins]: For those folks who don't know, a home rule petition is when any city says to the state,

[Kit Collins]: All right, state, here's a thing that ordinarily cities can't do.

[Kit Collins]: We'd like for you to make an exception.

[Kit Collins]: So I think that one way we can think about this process is that we're beginning the process of collaboratively drafting a piece of legislation that we would like the permission to do.

[Kit Collins]: I know I heard from some folks this afternoon who said, please do not pass this bill.

[Kit Collins]: We're not passing a bill tonight.

[Kit Collins]: This is conversation number one of many about a topic that's going to take a lot of time to talk about.

[Kit Collins]: This is just the beginning.

[Kit Collins]: You know, there were meeting documents circulated before the meeting, which is common practice for us to circulate common drafts for Councilors to read before the meeting starts.

[Kit Collins]: My intent, and I'll make these motions later in the meeting, is for us to open up a conversation in this meeting.

[Kit Collins]: Afterwards, we'll circulate the documents to relevant city staff, stakeholders, and then we'll use them as a jumping off point for our next conversation on this.

[Kit Collins]: And just to follow up on the point I was making about the Home Rule petition,

[Kit Collins]: In the hypothetical scenario that we finish a home brawl petition about rent stabilization and just cause eviction, which is kind of the jumping off point that I created for a conversation tonight.

[Kit Collins]: If that were to go through, if this council were to approve it, then it would go to our state delegation and the jurisdiction would be with them to approve or not.

[Kit Collins]: And that is just the standard procedure for

[Kit Collins]: for any Home Rule petition.

[Kit Collins]: So I just wanted to make that clear, because I know these things are often opaque outside of City Hall in terms of the process that we're looking at here.

[Kit Collins]: Pause there in case there are any questions from fellow Councilors on the process, or if not, I can just quickly run through more of the table setting.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Chair Leming, and thank you, Councilor Sparkely.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate, and of course, I think it's obviously a goal that we share that everybody who'd like to weigh in has the opportunity to.

[Kit Collins]: It's not my, as one councilor, it's not my intent that we're going to take any substantive action or vote to take actions on this draft tonight, but rather that this can be a draft that

[Kit Collins]: constituents, councilors, stakeholders, and city staff can continue to review starting tonight and in the run-up to our next meeting on the topic, giving everybody ample time to review it, and then we'll revisit the same draft.

[Kit Collins]: So I hope that that'll provide a lot of opportunity for people to read it and digest it before we revisit it again.

[Kit Collins]: Having said that, and of course, happy to circle back to the process at any point.

[Kit Collins]: I just, I think that I'm sure that there are other people in the room and on the Zoom tonight who can speak to the potential uses of rent stabilization and how it's been used in Massachusetts before later in the meeting, but just to quickly kind of frame the conversation.

[Kit Collins]: Like I mentioned, rent stabilization, I think most people know what it is.

[Kit Collins]: It's a way for a government entity, usually a city, to set a cap by which rent costs may not increase above that amount in a given year.

[Kit Collins]: And then it sets forth the exceptions to that.

[Kit Collins]: Let me find the... Trying to find a handy quote that I found in my research about this.

[Kit Collins]: Okay, this is from, and pulling together some resources as I was preparing just myself for this meeting.

[Kit Collins]: This is one of the strategies that the Metropolitan Area Planning Commission touches on on its website.

[Kit Collins]: I think that they have a pretty handy encapsulation of what rent control does and doesn't do.

[Kit Collins]: They say rent control denies unlimited excessive rent increases, thus limiting profits.

[Kit Collins]: Rent control does, however, allow for annual increases that provide owners a fair return on investment with sufficient income to maintain property in a satisfactory manner.

[Kit Collins]: They go on to say rent control laws usually include provisions that protect a landlord's investment in these ways.

[Kit Collins]: For example, sometimes defining fair return, a hardship appeals process.

[Kit Collins]: So there are

[Kit Collins]: There are many levers and exemptions and ways to tailor these policies that I think we can look to other cities, including cities in Massachusetts, to guide our discussion as we start looking at drafts, as we get beyond the

[Kit Collins]: preliminary table setting stage and into crafting a home rule petition.

[Kit Collins]: I think that there's a lot of ways that cities have worked really hard to tailor this to their communities.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that that if this project goes forward, we'll be looking to do here in Medford is to say, what does this community need?

[Kit Collins]: And how can we tailor this to Medford?

[Kit Collins]: Like I said, the idea for this in Medford came out of a particularly visible displacement event.

[Kit Collins]: And that displacement in general in Medford continues to, we continue to see that happening in the community.

[Kit Collins]: I know for myself, I'm sure for some of my other Councilors, this is something that we hear about, unfortunately, from time to time, housing scarcity.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Councilor Callahan, for the question.

[Kit Collins]: I circulated around noon today through the city clerk some example language from the city of Somerville, a draft jumping off point document for our discussion for a potential home rule petition here in Medford, and a link to some background info from the MAPC.

[Kit Collins]: So you're correct, the original resolution included those ideas for seven home rule petitions.

[Kit Collins]: I thought that, you know, seven is a lot to do in one meeting.

[Kit Collins]: I'm not sure if it's the will of the council to advance with all of them.

[Kit Collins]: I thought that this meeting, we could begin a conversation about rent stabilization in other communities.

[Kit Collins]: They've bundled rent stabilization and just cause eviction together.

[Kit Collins]: So that's what the document circulated by the clerk does.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Chair Leming.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate that.

[Kit Collins]: And yes, I think it would be great to start hearing from some of the other city staff and advocates that I know are in the room.

[Kit Collins]: Just quickly, I want to say, you know, I think in my experience, it's, you know, I, sorry, two thoughts happening in my head at the same time.

[Kit Collins]: I just want to really emphasize that for the purposes of this conversation, we are beginning a discussion about something that has been brought up by the City Council two years ago.

[Kit Collins]: The intent to pursue this at some point has been public record for some time.

[Kit Collins]: The content of this resolution has been public record.

[Kit Collins]: I hear that people would like more time to look at the documents that have been circulated in support.

[Kit Collins]: It is true that we very often get supporting documents for meetings pretty close to the meeting time.

[Kit Collins]: At least that's been my experience for the past term.

[Kit Collins]: And I completely respect that people want more time to look through a draft.

[Kit Collins]: That's why I was hoping that the purpose of this meeting could be to begin the conversation and then give people the intervening two or four weeks to read it and develop feedback and bring that to our next committee meeting on this topic.

[Kit Collins]: So I think that we're all aligned on that.

[Kit Collins]: Before we turn it over to other speakers and people who have comments that they'd like to contribute to this discussion, I just want to again really emphasize that

[Kit Collins]: It's true that rent stabilization is talked about as if it's one thing, and it has one set of consequences, and those are always the same, and they're always bad.

[Kit Collins]: But that's really not true, and I think that we have the capacity and the creativity in this community to say, we have this issue.

[Kit Collins]: We know that there are people

[Kit Collins]: who want to move out of their parents' homes and get their own apartment in Medford.

[Kit Collins]: We know that there are people who want to have their own place.

[Kit Collins]: We know that there are couples that want to move in together.

[Kit Collins]: We know that there are people who can't afford to buy a home, but love it here and want to stay.

[Kit Collins]: And we know that rent costs are a huge problem.

[Kit Collins]: for all of those types of people.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that knowing this council, this is a proactive council, every member, I think that it is well worth our time to say, before we dismiss this, let's take a good long look at rent stabilization, something that other communities have looked at, and see if there's a way to tailor this to Medford so that we could keep more Medford residents in Medford.

[Kit Collins]: And I also want to note, again,

[Kit Collins]: And people will see this when they take more time with the examples from other communities and with the draft home repetition for Medford that are created as a jumping off point.

[Kit Collins]: But there are myriad exemptions that we can build in to make sure that this is not anything that is going to be dramatic or drastic for people who do own rental units in Medford, exemptions for smaller types of properties, exemptions for certain types of owners.

[Kit Collins]: That's all on the table.

[Kit Collins]: So I hope that we can proceed with cool heads because I think that everybody's going to have something productive to continue to contribute to this conversation.

[Kit Collins]: I'll leave it there.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Chair Levening, and thank you to all of the constituents, advocates, city staff that has spoken.

[Kit Collins]: Really appreciate getting some preliminary voices into the discussion.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that this is

[Kit Collins]: What our conversation just in the past 15 minutes has, I think, reinforced for me is that this is a topic and a term that is so heavily connotated that using these meetings to bring that nuance into the conversation and just to really recenter on what exactly is being proposed and how it differs from

[Kit Collins]: the idea that we have in our heads about what rent control is or must be, I think that that'll be where we get a lot of really productive work done.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate raising some of the details around what we mean when we say just cause eviction.

[Kit Collins]: And I hope that as we continue to enter into the details of this process, whether we're talking about just cause eviction or whether we're talking about really finessing the styles and levers around the specific numbers and exemptions and conditions around rent stabilization,

[Kit Collins]: I hope that we can, I think that we'll have a really quick conversation around the nuance and how to, again, make this something that is more helpful than not.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that grounding this in the overall context of how big of a problem displacement is in Medford and how increasing housing supply is deeply crucial and the council is very enmeshed in that work and it can never be fast enough to deal with the displacement that we have been seeing for years and continue to see.

[Kit Collins]: And I think we just have to challenge ourselves to do more than one thing at a time.

[Kit Collins]: So I really appreciate everybody being a part of this conversation from the outset and trying to help us do that as well as we can.

[Kit Collins]: I would like to make a motion to recirculate the background information.

[Kit Collins]: sample Home Rule Petition from Somerville and first draft of our Home Rule Petition from Medford that was circulated earlier today to all councillors, the Director of the Planning Development and Sustainability Office, to the Senior Planner, Housing Staff Planner,

[Kit Collins]: Of course, these will be available on the city website under the report for this committee meeting and to request feedback and comments by February 28th.

[Kit Collins]: And Mr. Clerk, I'd be happy to email that language over to you so you have it.

[Kit Collins]: That's just a motion to recirculate all of the meeting documents to Councilors and staff and request feedback by the 28th.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate that and I just wanted to jump in ahead of any other city staff who are going to speak and just say you know I really appreciate that overview and I think it's, it's certainly abundantly clear to me as one Councilor all the time and I feel pretty safe and speaking for my fellow Councilors that the health department, the Office of Prevention and Outreach, everybody involved in this type of preventative

[Kit Collins]: and supportive work in City Hall, just always doing such an incredible job with the resources that they have.

[Kit Collins]: You know the theme that's come up and kind of the testimony that we've heard so far that I suspect we'll hear over and over again for as long as we talk about this topic and future meetings is that, you know, just like we say that the housing crisis is a regional issue.

[Kit Collins]: So, so too is the homelessness issue.

[Kit Collins]: And so I think it's really
