[Kit Collins]: Yeah, I'd be happy to speak to as I've probably spent, second only to President Bears, I've probably spent the most time staring at this document of the Councilors assembled in assisting compiling ideas from

[Kit Collins]: from all of from all of the Councilors, you and I included.

[Kit Collins]: So I'm happy to speak to this is one that I submitted and just quickly run through some of the others.

[Kit Collins]: Eternity emergency response slash civilian oversight, being a topic that has been brought up to myself as one Councilor by constituents many times.

[Kit Collins]: Kind of I know that we're kind of broadly having a conversation about where these projects will occur.

[Kit Collins]: Over the course of the two years.

[Kit Collins]: So this one we have a goal date of starting not immediately perhaps beginning this conversation in July.

[Kit Collins]: perhaps with the conversation that we were just having, the hypothetical proposed warming center, ideally a regional collaboration, something that we're starting to do in Medford, and also I think dovetails with the resiliency hub work that several of our city staff were just talking about when we were talking about this need to kind of plug some of our social service needs here in Medford.

[Kit Collins]: So I'm interested to see how this

[Kit Collins]: this item on the governing agenda evolves as our conversation about the warming center evolves.

[Kit Collins]: I'm happy to speak to any of the ordinances briefly, if helpful.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Yeah, the overgrowth ordinance was born out of conversations I've had with constituents and staff about the need to empower city staff to do enforcement around essentially when vegetation on private property is grown so long that it is obstructing the public way.

[Kit Collins]: For example, a hedge or, you know,

[Kit Collins]: plants in somebody's yard that are so overgrown that they're spilling into the sidewalk and people can't walk in the sidewalk.

[Kit Collins]: They have to cross the street.

[Kit Collins]: They have to push their stroller in the street, et cetera, just to give city staff the ability to enforce around that because currently they don't.

[Kit Collins]: So that should be fairly straightforward.

[Kit Collins]: That's the idea there.

[Kit Collins]: Similarly, paper 23449 is, again, about giving city staff the authority to do enforcement around

[Kit Collins]: you know, not around activities when they become problematic.

[Kit Collins]: Similar to the overgrowth ordinance, it's not about policing everybody for your plants must be about a certain height.

[Kit Collins]: It's if something is happening to such an extent that it's becoming a problem, we should be able to do something about that.

[Kit Collins]: With the wildlife feeding ordinance, this is a measure that would empower city officials to

[Kit Collins]: issue warnings or tickets if persistent wildlife feeding is really creating nuisances or health hazards on private property.

[Kit Collins]: So after we run through the governing agenda I might put forward a motion to authorize myself as ordinance sponsor to circulate a draft ordinance to the members of this committee and city staff for comment ahead of this next committee meeting.

[Kit Collins]: After that regulating the retail

[Kit Collins]: reading facilities.

[Kit Collins]: There is no draft for this yet, this has come out of another, this has also come out of constituent request for this regulation.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: A ordinance that we passed in 2023, the community control over surveillance.

[Kit Collins]: over public surveillance ordinance requires the annual submission of reports from the city agencies that employ surveillance technology about those uses.

[Kit Collins]: So this is just an annual procedure of meeting with the agency that submit those reports and discussing them, fielding questions from Councilors in the public, is something that, per the language of the ordinance, belongs with this committee.

[Kit Collins]: So as the chair is aware, we have already scheduled the first meeting to go over an annual surveillance report for this committee's April meeting, which I am myself very much looking forward to, to go over Medford Police Department's annual surveillance report, which should only include the use of body-worn cameras for the part of the year leading up to March 2024.

[Kit Collins]: And that process will be ongoing on an annual basis.

[Kit Collins]: This is another sort of maintenance project that has to do with an ordinance passed in the previous term.

[Kit Collins]: As far as my understanding goes, the implementation process for the Housing Stability Notification Ordinance, which was also passed in 2023, I believe is still being worked on by partners in the Planning Department, the Board of Health, the Office of Outreach and Prevention.

[Kit Collins]: Getting the word out about this ordinance was, you know, no small feat to tenants and landlords alike.

[Kit Collins]: So this project would be to follow up with those partners in how broadcasting the news of this ordinance is going, how upkeep, how uptake is going, and how we can enforce that this ordinance is known about and being followed.

[Kit Collins]: And so this has a goal start date of April.

[Kit Collins]: I know our April meeting date, as we just said, is already pretty full.

[Kit Collins]: So maybe the chair and I can work on scheduling an appropriate date to schedule a meeting to begin to take up this project as well.

[Kit Collins]: Yes, it's my understanding and again, this, of course, the, uh, the parameters of this project would be.

[Kit Collins]: put forward by the Councilor that's leading on it, and it's currently listed as no Councilor owning this project.

[Kit Collins]: It's just put forward as a good idea.

[Kit Collins]: So I don't want to speak for whoever leads on this project and their priorities, but it's my understanding that rather than fitting, rather than creating a maintenance plan for emergency equipment based on a particular year's operating schedule, this is more about reconciling our emergency fleet

[Kit Collins]: with our capital spending plan, which is a multi-year document.

[Kit Collins]: So I think that this wouldn't need to wait for the submission of any annual operating budget, but rather be something that we do in parallel with our long-term budget planning collaboration with the administration.

[Kit Collins]: Just for clarity.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for the question.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for making space for that project.

[Kit Collins]: I think at this point, the clerk has helpfully reminded me that I don't need to officially motion to circulate a draft.

[Kit Collins]: So if it is all right with the chair, I would love for and I can communicate about this with you offline as well.

[Kit Collins]: I would love for that paper to be listed as an action item for our next meeting.

[Kit Collins]: And in the meantime, I will circulate a draft.

[Kit Collins]: Of the ordinance to the members of this committee and to city staff for their feedback so we can have a more substantive conversation next time.

[Kit Collins]: Yeah, exactly.

[Kit Collins]: A good question.

[Kit Collins]: That will be the first time that we review the draft in this committee.

[Kit Collins]: Any work and amendments and revisions that we make to the ordinance will be done in this committee.

[Kit Collins]: And then when this committee feels that it's ready to be put before the full council, we'll vote it out to a regular session for presumably a vote.

[Kit Collins]: I would motion to receive and place on file 24006, which is the paper to review the governing agenda.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: In February, we celebrate Black History Month.

[Kit Collins]: The story of Medford is a story of black achievement and black community, from abolitionist organizing, to local icons like Belinda Sutton, to the historic black community of West Medford.

[Kit Collins]: This Black History Month, we celebrate black history in Medford.

[Kit Collins]: We endeavor to hold black history and celebrate it every month of the year.

[Kit Collins]: And I hope that we can recommit ourselves to policies that will allow Medford to remain a diverse community for people of all backgrounds.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: The Planning and Permitting Committee had its first standing meeting to go over the projects that have so far been assigned to that committee over the coming term.

[Kit Collins]: and some papers in committee that have also been allocated to be worked on in that committee.

[Kit Collins]: And we'll continue to create a draft schedule for working through those ordinances oriented around the zoning project, which will organize much of our work for this term.

[Kit Collins]: I would motion to suspend the rolls and take out of order the scheduled public participation appearing at the end of the agenda.

[Kit Collins]: Then paper 24037, paper 24038, the elections papers, followed by 24021, and finally 24035.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate my fellow Councilors for bringing this forward.

[Kit Collins]: I certainly will be comfortable supporting the resolution tonight.

[Kit Collins]: I think it's also fine to discuss it more with relevant stakeholders and community members.

[Kit Collins]: For me, putting aside the medical and therapeutic uses associated with psychedelic plants, it's certainly not my belief that drug-related arrests and prosecutions should be a law enforcement priority, except when it comes to

[Kit Collins]: some of the things specifically exempted in the resolution, such as unauthorized commercial sale, distribution of minors, driving under the influence.

[Kit Collins]: Recent history, I mean, not so recent history has shown us that criminalization of substances does not meaningfully advance public health and public safety.

[Kit Collins]: At the same time, this is a holistic issue, so I look forward to future discussion about it.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: I've put forward an amended version of the resolution.

[Kit Collins]: I would motion to amend the resolution and adopt the revised language.

[Kit Collins]: A copy is in front of, sorry, a copy of the amended resolution is in front of all councilors and in the hands of the clerk.

[Kit Collins]: I would motion to amend the resolution and adopt the new language and have it read into the record.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for reading all of that into the record.

[Kit Collins]: I want to briefly speak to why I'm putting forth an amended resolution from what was submitted to be incorporated in the Council's formal agenda.

[Kit Collins]: After I put forward the resolution last week, I was contacted by many constituents who urged me to reconsider the language before us.

[Kit Collins]: With an issue such as this, it is critical to speak with as much clarity and precision as possible, even when and especially when it's uncomfortable.

[Kit Collins]: I was called upon to amend this resolution to more authentically and faithfully represent the harms endured on both sides of the Israel and Palestinian border.

[Kit Collins]: In addition, while the ultimate ask of this resolution is for an immediate and enduring bilateral ceasefire, I was also called upon to not let the historical context go unsaid and unacknowledged.

[Kit Collins]: I thank everybody who got in touch with me from the original request to put forward a ceasefire resolution to the many people who gave me feedback and worked with me to improve it.

[Kit Collins]: Despite my note about updating the language of this resolution, I also want to put forth a disclaimer that I don't believe I personally have the ability or maybe it's simply not possible to talk about this issue in a way that does not leave one group or another at risk of feeling diminished or blamed or impoverished.

[Kit Collins]: If you are feeling that way, please blame me or blame the insufficiency of language to talk about an issue that is breaking all of our hearts and has been breaking all of our hearts for decades, and most especially many people in this room.

[Kit Collins]: And thank you for being here.

[Kit Collins]: I want to speak briefly to why I elected to bring this resolution forward, apart from the fact that I was contacted by constituents to do so, that being the ultimate reason.

[Kit Collins]: I am Jewish.

[Kit Collins]: My ancestors on both sides came to America in the early 1900s because Eastern Europe wasn't safe for them.

[Kit Collins]: My last name is Collins because my great-grandfather couldn't get a job with a Jewish last name.

[Kit Collins]: My family knows that anti-Semitism is real and it is dangerous.

[Kit Collins]: I believe that past hardship and trauma and persecution are never valid nor meaningful, but we can seek to make past trauma and hardship, we can seek to get something out of that if we put that experience in service of other people and stand in solidarity with other people who are also facing oppression and persecution.

[Kit Collins]: Now we see a right-wing government using the grief of Jewish people, like me, and the name of Jewish people to justify the destruction of an entire civilian population in Gaza.

[Kit Collins]: There are no words that can adequately capture this horror, pain, and injustice.

[Kit Collins]: This resolution is long, but the ask is simple.

[Kit Collins]: Our US government is deeply entwined with and invested in the Israeli military.

[Kit Collins]: Our federal leaders have the influence, the power, and the purse strings to hasten an end to the killing.

[Kit Collins]: This issue is painful and divisive, more for some than for others.

[Kit Collins]: But ultimately, this resolution is about safety, and I believe that should unify us.

[Kit Collins]: Marginalizing Palestinians, whether legally, physically, or in the media, advances no one's safety.

[Kit Collins]: It's simply not right, and I would defy anyone to tell me that the mass murder, displacement, and destruction in Gaza will leave Israeli residents more safe from violent extremism.

[Kit Collins]: Some people would question the validity of city-level resolutions about this issue.

[Kit Collins]: To me, this is a Medford issue because Medford residents are invested in the issue.

[Kit Collins]: And while the U.S.

[Kit Collins]: government condones the killing and sends unrestricted military aid to Israel, communities right here in the U.S.

[Kit Collins]: are starved for funding.

[Kit Collins]: If you attend any average city council meeting, what you'll hear us talk about ultimately is how there aren't enough public dollars to pay for resident services, fully funded schools, affordable housing, road safety, and on and on.

[Kit Collins]: Meanwhile, our federal leaders authorized billions to help bomb kids in Gaza.

[Kit Collins]: I find that

[Kit Collins]: I find it unfathomable on a human level, and I find it infuriating as a Councilor.

[Kit Collins]: Those dollars should be promoting wellness at home, not destruction abroad.

[Kit Collins]: I hope that we can find unity in the unacceptability of this oppression and this loss of life, and in demanding an immediate and lasting de-escalation and ceasefire in Gaza.

[Kit Collins]: I hope that we as a council can join the groundswell of city councils, amplifying their residents' calls for ceasefire, and add Medford's voice to the chorus for peace.

[Kit Collins]: I hope we can find unity in diminishing no one's suffering and trauma, and in demanding safety and peace for all.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you to everybody who spoke.

[Kit Collins]: I already made the motion to adopt the new language and move forward with that new language.

[Kit Collins]: Motion to adopt, yeah, that's what I said.

[Kit Collins]: And I'll now motion to amend and adopt the new language.

[Kit Collins]: Got it.

[Kit Collins]: I hear everybody.

[Kit Collins]: I hear all of you.

[Kit Collins]: I don't know if it's possible for everybody to be heard equally, but I hear you.

[Kit Collins]: And I motion for approval of the resolution as amended.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate Councilor Lazzaro for bringing this forward.

[Kit Collins]: I'm really excited to start a discussion of what we can do to pilot a warming and cooling center of our own here in Medford.

[Kit Collins]: As Councilor Lazzaro stated, we've known for a long time now that it's not sustainable to keep directing our unhoused neighbors to the resources in other communities to stay safe and warm at night.

[Kit Collins]: communities and other resources are already overburdened.

[Kit Collins]: We need to start sometime at figuring out a path towards strengthening our own safety net and supportive services here in Medford.

[Kit Collins]: Obviously, this is really complicated and expensive, but it's important, and we all know that Medford has the creativity and the collaboration and the spirit of service to get it done.

[Kit Collins]: Motion to take paper 24028 out of order.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Councilor Callahan.

[Kit Collins]: Thanks.

[Kit Collins]: I got it.

[Kit Collins]: Um, can you hear me?

[Kit Collins]: 24028 offered by President Bayer's resolution calling on U.S.

[Kit Collins]: government to end blockade of Cuba.

[Kit Collins]: Whereas for 60 years, the United States has imposed an embargo on Cuba, having a devastating economic, social, and political impact on the people of Cuba.

[Kit Collins]: And whereas U.S.

[Kit Collins]: Senators Warren and Markey, U.S.

[Kit Collins]: Representatives McGovern, Presley, Lynch, Moulton, and Tran,

[Kit Collins]: city councils in neighborhood cities, and many state and local officials have called on the Biden administration to restore the policies of the Obama administration, reducing travel restrictions and removing Cuba from the state sponsors of terrorism list that were reversed under the Trump administration.

[Kit Collins]: And whereas the continuation of this policy has a detrimental impact on Medford residents and organizations who have family, business and research ties with people and organizations in Cuba.

[Kit Collins]: Now, therefore, be it resolved by the Medford city council that we urge the Biden administration

[Kit Collins]: and our congressional delegation to reverse the Trump decision to add Cuba to the state sponsors of terrorism list and restrict travel between the two countries and be it further resolved by the Medford City Council that we urge our congressional delegation to pass legislation to repeal any laws regarding the embargo on Cuba and be it further resolved that the city clerk please submit this resolution to the offices of Senator Warren, Senator Markey and Representative Clark.

[Kit Collins]: We started work on this last year.

[Kit Collins]: The goal of this is to create some conditions and permitting procedures around when rental units are taken off the market by for-profit developers and turned into condos to make sure that the community recaptures some of that value that is just being realized as real estate value.

[Kit Collins]: Present.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Yeah, I think that looking over the kind of the evolution of the draft ordinances will be most instructive for the newer councilors, but the original form of the ordinance spoke to both the annual budget process and also laid out a fairly prescribed structure for long-term budget planning, kind of revisiting

[Kit Collins]: five-year financial forecast regular intervals with the administration the same way as it creates a structure for looking at the annual operating budget with the administration every year.

[Kit Collins]: The administration has told us a lot about the various reasons why that is a difficult thing for them to operationalize at this point, but we still think that there's value in creating a kind of starter structure for how to begin to have those conversations in a

[Kit Collins]: regular way, even if we are not being as ambitious as the original form of the ordinance laid out.

[Kit Collins]: So to me, that is the most unfinished part of the ordinance, trying to figure out what can we start so that we are planting a seed for that kind of structure, while not legislating a process that the administration right now doesn't have the capacity to do every year.

[Kit Collins]: Well, I know that this is something I was actually going to ask about President Bears, which is why I grimaced after I touched my microphone.

[Kit Collins]: The classification and compensation study is a project that the administration initiated with the Collins Center, if I have that right to take a look at how we are compensating the various roles in City Hall to try to get context on if things are roughly right, you know, and this is

[Kit Collins]: would inform the types of salaries that we're putting out in our attempt to keep positions filled by competitive candidates.

[Kit Collins]: So a question that I have is the status on how complete that study is.

[Kit Collins]: And then I believe that the implementation for this council would be in, because pay rates to an extent live in our code of ordinances, personnel ordinances, that would be something for us to take out of the study and implement through our personnel ordinances.

[Kit Collins]: I was going to suggest perhaps to request the update come in a week before our next scheduled meeting of this committee.

[Kit Collins]: Okay.

[Kit Collins]: Which would be...

[Kit Collins]: by February 20th, if we go that route.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Yeah, I think it's an important point to make.

[Kit Collins]: I mean, in general, I think the point of these initial meetings and committees, the point of the governing agenda is to try to budget our work over this term to be manageable for Councilors and for projects to occur in the right order to be most effective.

[Kit Collins]: I think that the way that the various

[Kit Collins]: commercial vacancy tax, for example, these various exemptions that we've considered in the past, the new ones that we're considering, the way that those will intersect with a potential override or debt exclusion is kind of an interesting problem, kind of to the overall topic of like, then what order do we do things in, especially with the exemptions, which we know, the assessor's office requires like a fairly long runway.

[Kit Collins]: to be able to implement.

[Kit Collins]: I think that, I mean for myself, for the Good Lord and Lord Tax Credit, as that's a paper that I introduced, I think that the approach may be to study the issue, try to do the research, have the conversations, get our ducks in a row, perhaps like create some scenarios, and then as the conversations about

[Kit Collins]: revenue forecasting potential changes to property tax because of a debt exclusion or override, kind of have some scenarios ready to go.

[Kit Collins]: And of course, I think in some cases, we might want to deploy several strategies at the same time.

[Kit Collins]: If, for example, say we're doing a debt exclusion for a new high school, hypothetically, it occurs to me that that might be a thing that our finance department might say.

[Kit Collins]: let's sit down and consider these three to four financial mechanisms together instead of doing these very related things in separate channels.

[Kit Collins]: But I think that we can certainly pursue all of these projects in committee and really get our arms around the issue and study, could maybe create a set of if-then conditions for these various exemptions and new mechanisms.

[Kit Collins]: serving as liaison to bring together people who could work on implementing a program that's outside of our legal jurisdiction, but it's something that we have the platform to do.

[Kit Collins]: There are other cases where it is an ordinance that is something that we have the power to promulgate.

[Kit Collins]: If we're thinking about how to tailor this in a way that enforcement is going to go most successfully because we can do the legislation we don't do the enforcement.

[Kit Collins]: creating can be that balance between in line with our values and our aspiration, and achievable and actionable and doable.

[Kit Collins]: ideal renovations in many of those cases and it is also financially infeasible for the city at this point to just assume all of those private ways because they have to be brought to code first and that's millions and millions of dollars.

[Kit Collins]: So in my experience, when constituents come to this body and they say, hey, me and my neighbors have been having this problem, it's an opportunity to have a conversation.

[Kit Collins]: motion that will vote on from Councilor Callahan, the recommendation to study within the concept of our, sorry, within the review of our city charter, which we'll be doing later this year, a mechanism for triggering some sort of automatic or regular evaluation of all elected salaries.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that's important.

[Kit Collins]: not so that the salaries necessarily go up, but I think that part of the issue here has been, since there was not any sort of regular mechanism other than the city council deigning to consider an increase, we've gone 24 years without considering it.

[Kit Collins]: And that's why the initial proposal was for a triple-digit percentage increase, because we had so much time to make up for.

[Kit Collins]: So with all that being said, I'm glad that we're going to have that conversation later this year so that we can continue having this conversation about how to align compensation with our goals and our values and how to promote the elected bodies that our community deserves.

[Kit Collins]: And I'm looking forward to voting on compensation increase, one that I believe is fair and reasonable and very certainly the product of compromise tonight.

[Kit Collins]: So just to remind folks that

[Kit Collins]: I said this the first time that this issue came before us, but where I'm coming from on this is really that I just completely believe that we can do more than one right thing at a time.

[Kit Collins]: This proposal, the original proposal, which this is less than, was 0.05% of a $200 billion operating budget.

[Kit Collins]: I think that we need to challenge ourselves to do more than one right thing at a time.

[Kit Collins]: And I really appreciate the reminder that if we think that paying one city employee fairly is a grievance to another, then we are phrasing the question incorrectly.

[Kit Collins]: And this has always been a tough topic to talk about because

[Kit Collins]: We have so much work to do when it comes to paying all of our city employees fairly.

[Kit Collins]: And I think what's been painful about this process is the knowledge that so many of those issues are unresolved.

[Kit Collins]: And that's not okay, and it's not acceptable.

[Kit Collins]: This is the one opportunity that this council has legally to instigate a pay increase for any city employee.

[Kit Collins]: This is the one appropriation that we get, and it's kind of a weird quirk of our power.

[Kit Collins]: But as

[Kit Collins]: folks who are familiar with our work and the parameters of our jurisdiction know, when it comes to the budget and its appropriations, we get to vote yes or no, and that is it.

[Kit Collins]: We cannot appropriate.

[Kit Collins]: And so this does put us in this awkward position where we can instigate these compensation adjustments, and we can't do that directly for anybody else.

[Kit Collins]: And I think for that,

[Kit Collins]: that we do in these chambers the entire rest of the year.

[Kit Collins]: This is a really unusual topic for us to be talking about the entire rest of the year.

[Kit Collins]: I think we can be we can challenge ourselves to be the allies that the community deserves by supporting all other city employees and bargaining units by one vocally supporting them and standing with them and advocating for them and also by doing the bulk of the work of this council, which is doing the ordinances and the zoning and the business development work.

[Kit Collins]: in this chambers in collaboration with the administration, in collaboration with private partners that will bring up the city's bottom line and enable us to, as swiftly as we can, roll out improved living wages for all city employees, because that is all of our goals.

[Kit Collins]: I do not believe that this stands in the way of that goal, and that goal is not diminished by this change.

[Kit Collins]: And that's my opinion.

[Kit Collins]: Move the question.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much, everybody, for being here today.

[Kit Collins]: We really appreciate it.

[Kit Collins]: A lot to discuss here.

[Kit Collins]: I just want to start by saying I know that this discussion of this in the community has surfaced some painful and necessary truths about the underfunding of the schools and the need to provide every school worker with a living wage.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate that that's been one of the reminders that's come out of the discussion I just want to frame with that as a reassurance that as we talk about raising compensation for school committee for the first time in 23 years that that is close on my mind to speak only for myself.

[Kit Collins]: City Council is no legal authority to make allocations within the school's budget.

[Kit Collins]: I'm sure that there's been times when we all wish we had that authority.

[Kit Collins]: We don't have it.

[Kit Collins]: This is one thing that we do have authority over.

[Kit Collins]: The mindset that I'm coming to this discussion with is

[Kit Collins]: We know it's been 23 years since school committee had a cost of living adjustment or any sort of rationale for a compensation increase.

[Kit Collins]: As a Councilor with a vote to change that, I feel a responsibility to change that.

[Kit Collins]: It's something that I have the responsibility to change.

[Kit Collins]: We don't have any jurisdiction over any other salaries when it comes to the school's department.

[Kit Collins]: This is one thing that we do have authority over.

[Kit Collins]: And as a Councilor, knowing a bit about

[Kit Collins]: Our job, knowing a little bit about the school committee members job though of course, not with that level of granular detail, but knowing how hard our school committee members work as all public servants do in our various roles that are, you know, hard to compare but all contribute to.

[Kit Collins]: necessary work of the public sphere.

[Kit Collins]: Contemplating an increase for school committee members is something that, you know, I've gone on record and say I think that these jobs are equivalent.

[Kit Collins]: I'd like for us to consider, you know, leveling pay between these two legislative bodies.

[Kit Collins]: But I'm just, I'm excited to hear the perspectives of my fellow Councilors now that we've all had a few weeks to digest this and to think about the amendments that President Morell and former Councilor Knight made during our first meeting on the topic.

[Kit Collins]: So I do have some proposals to bring to our discussion tonight, but I'll hold those until we hear from, you know, some of my fellow Councilors and others in the space.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate hearing from my fellow councilors about this.

[Kit Collins]: A lot to respond to.

[Kit Collins]: I already started out my comments with where I'm coming from in my overall approach to this issue, so I'll do my best not to reiterate myself because I don't want to bore you all.

[Kit Collins]: I'm going to make a couple of proposals.

[Kit Collins]: First, I do just want to, I do feel like it's important to emphasize this isn't about

[Kit Collins]: feel like this shouldn't be a controversial statement.

[Kit Collins]: This isn't about this school committee.

[Kit Collins]: This is about the school committee.

[Kit Collins]: Whoever is on it, any changes that we pass will be in effect.

[Kit Collins]: into the future.

[Kit Collins]: What, speaking only for myself, what we'll be voting on, I would vote on regardless of who was in those chairs, because I think that, and it was mentioned also tonight, compensation, the need to, sometimes it comes up, we discuss how should volunteers be compensated?

[Kit Collins]: Should we compensate volunteers?

[Kit Collins]: How should boards and commissions be compensated?

[Kit Collins]: I have been a little bit obnoxious in saying whenever it comes up, I believe that we should compensate members of all boards and commissions.

[Kit Collins]: I just bring that up to say, I think it's,

[Kit Collins]: It's really understandable that these conversations get personal.

[Kit Collins]: For me, this is not personal.

[Kit Collins]: This is about how I think this body should be compensated.

[Kit Collins]: Moving on from that.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate Councilor Tseng's motion to raise.

[Kit Collins]: It wasn't a formal motion, a bit of a hint of motion, pre-motion perhaps.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate Councilor Tseng's idea around raising school committee compensation to follow the same year over year percentage increases that have occurred in the MTA contract from the numbers that we received, which would arrive at that

[Kit Collins]: $22,105.60 number in the year 2025.

[Kit Collins]: If you make that in the form of the motion, I am happy to support that.

[Kit Collins]: I like that for a couple of reasons.

[Kit Collins]: One, I've made it clear I'd like to support a proposal for a school committee compensation increase.

[Kit Collins]: I've been clear about that.

[Kit Collins]: I think anything that we do at this point, I think it makes a lot of sense for it to be not effective immediately, but go into effect at the start of the next fiscal year and be phased in in accordance with the start of future fiscal years.

[Kit Collins]: If you make that in the form of the motion, I will support that tonight.

[Kit Collins]: However, I have also been clear.

[Kit Collins]: We are a legislative body.

[Kit Collins]: We make policy.

[Kit Collins]: School committee is a legislative body.

[Kit Collins]: They make policy.

[Kit Collins]: I don't feel comfortable as one Councilor Tseng that I know our job to be more substantial or more work than theirs because I frankly haven't seen evidence of that.

[Kit Collins]: So I would also like to make the proposal in the form of a motion that school committee compensation be raised over the period of four years to be leveled to city council pay, July 1, 2024 through July 1, 2027, first two years meeting parity with that MTA contract line number, and then closing the gap in 2026 and 2027.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for your deference, Councilor Scarpelli.

[Kit Collins]: So we have two proposals before us.

[Kit Collins]: And again, I say this a lot, appreciate my fellow councilors comment.

[Kit Collins]: This is a sticky subject.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate the conversation that we're able to have about it.

[Kit Collins]: I know I've already put forth a proposal.

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Tseng has put forth another one that I also support.

[Kit Collins]: I don't know which of these will advance.

[Kit Collins]: Coming into this meeting, I know what I want to see is some increase for school committee members, and I would also like to see us create some sort of mechanism for regularly evaluating and updating and increasing

[Kit Collins]: school committee compensation and that of all elected officials in a regularized way.

[Kit Collins]: Maybe it's an automatic COLA increase, but I think one of the things that has made this conversation very difficult is that talking about school committee pay at all is an entirely discretionary conversation for the city council to bring up.

[Kit Collins]: And so it's been 23 years since we have, since I think it's been very murky, who controls that and why and how does it get brought up?

[Kit Collins]: And I think that that's just been a disservice to the conversation.

[Kit Collins]: All that to say, I don't know which of, if either of the two proposals that have currently been proposed will go forward.

[Kit Collins]: I'd like to propose a third towards that goal of setting some sort of creating some kind of mechanism for us to revisit this more than once every 23 years when everybody thinks of it.

[Kit Collins]: The motion would be for this council to refer this paper to the governance committee for consideration during charter review with the goal of creating a mechanism within the updated city charter to trigger automatic COLA increases and or compensation review for all elected positions at regular interviews.

[Kit Collins]: And I can forward that language to you, Mr. Clerk, if you like.

[Kit Collins]: And just to reiterate, the goal here is to come out of this with some sort of mechanism for looking at elected compensation so that it doesn't fall by the wayside for 23 years, because I think that that is one of the ingredients in this scenario when we haven't talked about it in a couple decades.

[Kit Collins]: And so when we do, one of the things we contemplate is a triple digit percentage increase because it's just been so long since we talked about it.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, that's my motion.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate you putting this into a visual format on the fly.

[Kit Collins]: I think at this point in the discussion, we've all spoken and heard and listened.

[Kit Collins]: There's a couple ideas out on the floor.

[Kit Collins]: personally, I think it's time to move the question.

[Kit Collins]: I think that in the intervening days between this goes on, the regular meeting agenda will pay time for us to reflect and absorb what we've discussed together, what we've heard from the public, and to think about path forward that makes sense now that we have some alternative proposals for us to vote on providing different ways forward.

[Kit Collins]: Sorry for my halting language, I'm like a nurse.

[Kit Collins]: I want to again reiterate, you know, I'll probably say this the next time this comes up as well.

[Kit Collins]: I do what I have the jurisdiction to do.

[Kit Collins]: You know, last year, a couple times, we were given the opportunity to vote on cost of living adjustment increases to non-union personnel while there were still unions being negotiated, while there were still union contracts being negotiated.

[Kit Collins]: And that was a discussion, which makes sense.

[Kit Collins]: I'm glad that it was, and it was brought up for an understandable reason.

[Kit Collins]: And I voted yes, because when I have the opportunity to vote yes on a raise, I'll vote yes on a raise.

[Kit Collins]: And I intend to do that here, depending on what my fellow Councilors support and what we decide that the best path forward is.

[Kit Collins]: If we had the jurisdiction to vote on raises for teachers and paras and custodians and other public servants, I would do that, but I don't.

[Kit Collins]: I'll vote for the raises that I have the opportunity to support.

[Kit Collins]: Um, and I just want to note also for folks here and folks watching, um, you know, if there are people here who don't usually attend our meetings, which, you know, I know sometimes people come to some meetings and others, it's super normal.

[Kit Collins]: Um, this is a really unusual topic for a city council meeting.

[Kit Collins]: We, a lot of issues were brought up that are more of what we talked about all the time.

[Kit Collins]: They can store fronts, the need for commercial development the need for business development, the need to reevaluate our zoning and our housing, and all the other things that are really what we interface with as residents on a day to day basis that is the bread and butter of the city council, and that all directly feeds into.

[Kit Collins]: the bottom line budget that affects how much we can appropriate to the schools for the schools to then appropriate.

[Kit Collins]: Once it enters the schools, we don't touch it, except for this.

[Kit Collins]: And I just also want to, while reemphasizing the validity of everything that's been said today, I believe that that work that takes up most of our time on this council exceeds by magnitudes in terms of what we can

[Kit Collins]: do in terms of revenue and support that feeds into necessary services in the schools and elsewhere throughout this community.

[Kit Collins]: it is more impactful than what will be at maximum, a 0.05% increase over as much as four years.

[Kit Collins]: And I don't say that to minimize the issue, the values behind the discussion are really important, but just to frame it in the larger discussion of what this council is trying to do all year long during budget season, creating more mechanisms and ordinances to bring more clarity and reality and long-term planning to our budget process, working on our commercial tax base through zoning and licensing and business development.

[Kit Collins]: That is all part and parcel of this work, and it is, in terms of dollars, more impactful.

[Kit Collins]: With that, I would move the question to vote on these proposals tonight.

[Kit Collins]: 24007, offered by President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Resolution to amend rule 33 of the rules of Medford City Council to establish standing committees.

[Kit Collins]: be it resolved by the Medford City Council that rule 33 committees of the rules of the Medford City Council be amended to the following.

[Kit Collins]: After the organization of the council, the president of the council shall form and set standing meeting times for the committee of the whole and the following standing committees.

[Kit Collins]: Administration and Finance Committee, Education and Culture Committee, Governance Committee, Planning and Permitting Committee, Public Health and Community Safety Committee,

[Kit Collins]: Public Works and Facilities Committee, Resident Services and Public Engagement Committee.

[Kit Collins]: All councilors shall be considered as members of each standing committee.

[Kit Collins]: The president shall name those members of each committee, including its chair and vice chair, who are authorized to vote on matters in the committee.

[Kit Collins]: All other members of each committee are not authorized to vote on such matters in the committee.

[Kit Collins]: A quorum of the committee shall be determined on the basis of voting members only.

[Kit Collins]: Each committee chairperson shall form subcommittees and appoint members of subcommittees as needed.

[Kit Collins]: The president or committee chairperson will give way to committee and subcommittee appointments via the longevity and interest of such appointees.

[Kit Collins]: Resolutions, ordinances and other papers are referred to committee by a majority vote of the members at a regular meeting of the City Council.

[Kit Collins]: If a councillor requests, the committee chair shall place any paper referred to the committee on the next scheduled committee meeting agenda or the agenda for another scheduled committee meeting.

[Kit Collins]: be it further resolved that papers and committee be referred from 2022 through 2023 subcommittees to 2024-2025 committees as described in the attached memorandum describing the proposed updated council committee structure.

[Kit Collins]: 24009 offered by President Bears's resolution to request Board of Health implement winter eviction moratorium.

[Kit Collins]: Whereas many cities and countries prohibited evictions between November 1 and March 31 due to winter cold that puts lives in danger and whereas Massachusetts has yet to implement a statewide policy to protect families from becoming unhoused

[Kit Collins]: and put out on the street in dangerously cold weather, and whereas over 1,200 households were evicted in Massachusetts in the winter of 2022 through 2023.

[Kit Collins]: Now, therefore, be it resolved by the Medford City Council that we request that the Board of Health declare an annual state of emergency and implement an eviction moratorium each winter to protect the health and safety of residents who face potentially fatal illness if evicted during the winter.

[Kit Collins]: President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Bears.

[Kit Collins]: the good landlord tax credit.

[Kit Collins]: This is kind of the colloquial phrase for a local option that was included very recently in the state tax relief package under Governor Healey.

[Kit Collins]: Essentially, this provides now a new way for cities to give a property tax break to landlords who choose to keep their rents below market rate.

[Kit Collins]: So it is a way to, in different framings, either incentivize or reward or

[Kit Collins]: thank, if you want to put it that way, small landlords who opt to offer more affordable rents to their tenants.

[Kit Collins]: It's not a one-size-fits-all mechanism.

[Kit Collins]: Cities can have several levers that they can pull on.

[Kit Collins]: They can choose

[Kit Collins]: up to what percentage of property tax to exempt landlords from.

[Kit Collins]: They can choose whether to enact this option for landlords who, oh, I always get this wording messed up.

[Kit Collins]: You can enact this if rents are affordable up to 200% AMI.

[Kit Collins]: We have the option to narrow it so that it's just for landlords who provide only much deeper affordability.

[Kit Collins]: That's like a whole spectrum that this council could investigate and decide what might be the best fit for this community, and all communities have that option.

[Kit Collins]: So there's a lot to deliberate on to explore this option further and decide what might be the best fit for Medford, for our landlords that are offering low market rate rents, all towards the goal of incentivizing small landlords to do this, because we have such an acute and ever-worsening affordable housing scarcity and crisis in Medford, as we do throughout the region, and as a way to make making that choice to offer affordability

[Kit Collins]: a little more doable for landlords and to further incentivize them to do so.

[Kit Collins]: And so my motion is to send this to the administration and finance committee where we can have a start discussion about it with our chief assessor and our finance director about implications for the city and get their insight on how to implement this.

[Kit Collins]: Sorry, now that we have approved the resolution to adopt committees with titles, I should just amend this to refer to the Administration and Finance Committee and not committee.

[Kit Collins]: Just by way of quick recap for the new Councilors in the room.

[Kit Collins]: Again, this is an update to the existing Chapter 70, which governs solid waste in Medford, how we deal with it.

[Kit Collins]: The updates align our current ordinance with best practices promulgated by MassDEP.

[Kit Collins]: We worked closely with the Planning Development Sustainability Office and the DPW Commissioner to make sure that this would align with what we are looking to do to hold the waste haulers in our community more accountable to our goals for having this be a smooth and efficient process for residents and businesses, as well as getting us closer to our waste reduction goals.

[Kit Collins]: Vice President Bears, we've spoken at length already in previous council meetings about the original reasons for bringing forward the request for an election postmortem and report, the errors and mishandlings that happened on election day, which again, were addressed, which should not have happened, and we need to know exactly how they won't happen again.

[Kit Collins]: And then the issues and mishandlings that happened leading up to the recount and needing a full accounting of why those happened and how exactly we'll know they won't happen again.

[Kit Collins]: To me, this is on the institutional scale, an example of people don't plan to fail, they fail to plan.

[Kit Collins]: We've discussed how going into this election,

[Kit Collins]: There were serious concerns about the capacity of the elections department because its staffing had dropped so low below its previous levels.

[Kit Collins]: And I think we really need to see, we need to see the diagnostic of what exactly happened and why.

[Kit Collins]: And we need to investigate.

[Kit Collins]: First, the Elections Commission, the Elections Department, and then as a community, as a council, we need to investigate what needs to happen so that we can go into our three very consequential elections in 2024 with the Elections Office and the Elections Commission feeling professional and organized and competent so that every voter and every resident in Medford can feel confident.

[Kit Collins]: about the three, again, very consequential elections that we will have in 2024.

[Kit Collins]: And I do think it bears emphasizing that by the time that we hear back from the Elections Commission at our January meeting, it will be less than two months until the first of those three elections.

[Kit Collins]: So I think everybody shares a sense of disappointment that it's necessary to have this conversation at all, that it's necessary to put a deadline on it because we haven't gotten a

[Kit Collins]: really any response so far.

[Kit Collins]: Maybe this will be one of the last very long list of unenviable tasks in your tenure as president of the City Council is calling on people to then speak about you.

[Kit Collins]: Well, Nicole, it's hard to know where to start in congratulating you on your two terms.

[Kit Collins]: Surely this must be one of the densest tenures of any Medford City Councilor to serve two years during a pandemic and then two as president.

[Kit Collins]: It's pretty remarkable what you've been able to accomplish in your two terms.

[Kit Collins]: And I think, you know, a phrase that I heard from you that I learned from you is occupying spaces that weren't designed for people like you.

[Kit Collins]: I think often about how you were running for city council two years before I did in completely certain terms.

[Kit Collins]: gave the way for myself and people like me to think about engaging in civic life in ways that are not traditional, that never felt possible or likely.

[Kit Collins]: And that's a gift that you gave to not just myself for this opportunity, but for the community of Medford for allowing, you know,

[Kit Collins]: representation to blossom and become better and become more representative.

[Kit Collins]: And as that continues to expand and to blossom over time, you will have been a crucial ingredient in that for future generations of Medford City Councils.

[Kit Collins]: I think it deserves repeating that you've presided over a really effective, a really civil,

[Kit Collins]: a friendlier Council than has always been true and I think that's a real benefit to the effectiveness of this Council I think that's a benefit to the community.

[Kit Collins]: I think that it makes City Hall more welcoming and inclusive space.

[Kit Collins]: And that's just so important and that will continue after you as well.

[Kit Collins]: so many projects that I hope that you can really feel the gravity of as you leave office.

[Kit Collins]: You were pushing for our zoning overhaul for two years before I was ever elected, and that's going to be a defining feature of the term ahead.

[Kit Collins]: In so many ways, you've teed us up for, you've teed up the future council, perhaps the council after that.

[Kit Collins]: for success with the projects that you've advocated for, that you've worked for, with the relationships that you've cultivated with members of, with City Hall staff, and with the new and better expectations that we have come to set for this City Council and that residents and staff have come to set for this City Council.

[Kit Collins]: So my hope for you is that you feel as positive and as proud about your tenure

[Kit Collins]: on city council as everybody else does, because it's a gift to leave us in such a position to be so much more effective and inclusive in our future work.

[Kit Collins]: So thank you for that.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for the sacrifices that you've made to be here.

[Kit Collins]: And I know that your life after city council will continue to be extremely full and busy doing incredible work on MIT campus, as well as taking care of the cutest two-year-old in Medford.

[Kit Collins]: But I, too, hope that we can lure you back in in the future.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you so much, Nicole.

[Kit Collins]: I would nominate Councilor Bears for President.

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Bears?

[Kit Collins]: He stays full name.

[Kit Collins]: Yes.

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Isaac B. Zach-Bears.

[Kit Collins]: I'm not going to.

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Stephanie.

[Kit Collins]: Even though this is the non-binding vote, we'll do this again in January.

[Kit Collins]: I want to thank my co-workers and future co-workers for their support and I look forward to supporting the work of the council over the coming year.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Councilor Bears.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Morell, sorry, to the chair you're sitting in, for introducing this paper.

[Kit Collins]: I thank you to everybody who's reached out over the past several days and took the time to be here tonight.

[Kit Collins]: I want to acknowledge, I know that there's a lot of engagement around this issue.

[Kit Collins]: I know there's a lot of strong feelings about this proposal.

[Kit Collins]: And I just, before I state my own thoughts, I just want to acknowledge that and thank you for being here.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for engaging in this process.

[Kit Collins]: As Councilor Bears said, this is a process.

[Kit Collins]: This is the initial introduction.

[Kit Collins]: This is what this process looks like coming up and sharing opinions and working through things together.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for being here.

[Kit Collins]: Want to use my time to explain my support for looking into this proposal, my support for achieving pay equity between the city council and school committee, my view on what this proposal is and what it isn't.

[Kit Collins]: I do not believe that this is in any way incompatible with what I think has been a core and shared goal of the City Council, at least in the one term that I've been a part of it, which is supporting all of our public school employees, supporting Medford Public Schools, and trying to ever improve the conditions of everybody that touches our public school systems.

[Kit Collins]: The students, their families, the teachers, the paras.

[Kit Collins]: all of the workers in our schools that help students and students' families thrive.

[Kit Collins]: I do not believe that this proposal is incompatible with that shared goal whatsoever.

[Kit Collins]: I think that this

[Kit Collins]: the equity between the school committee and the city council is something that I've wanted to, that I've hoped to have the opportunity to vote on ever since I first took office.

[Kit Collins]: These are two elected bodies.

[Kit Collins]: I know how hard we work.

[Kit Collins]: I have some glimmer of perspective of how hard the school committee works.

[Kit Collins]: They have responsibilities that we don't.

[Kit Collins]: I think it is outdated that our bodies are paid differently.

[Kit Collins]: That is the core reason for my support for this proposal.

[Kit Collins]: And even if it were to stop right there, that would be enough for me.

[Kit Collins]: But I see that this draws in a larger conversation about what we can and can't do in Medford, what we have and haven't done in Medford so far, especially every June during budget cycle and really all year round.

[Kit Collins]: If you watch the city council meetings, if you watch the school committee meetings, we are constantly talking about the resources that are afforded to Medford public schools, the people that work in them and everybody that experiences the work that is done in those buildings.

[Kit Collins]: And we are constantly in this conversation about why aren't we doing better and how can we continue to do better

[Kit Collins]: to better value and better resource what goes on in the schools, and better value and better resource the people that do the work of the schools.

[Kit Collins]: This proposal, I think, has brought up those values and those feelings and that imperative that we have to keep doing better.

[Kit Collins]: What I don't believe is that this is an either-or, and what I don't believe is that this is a zero-sum game.

[Kit Collins]: I know that if this proposal were to go forward even as written before amendments,

[Kit Collins]: This is not, this would not take from the same bucket of money that would otherwise go to the workers that contribute to MPS students experience.

[Kit Collins]: Hang on, please.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, thank you for letting me speak.

[Kit Collins]: This year, we found out that we had a 25 million sum of certified free cash, $25 million.

[Kit Collins]: When we talk about what we can and can't do in Medford and what we have and haven't done, I think that we need to stay, I try to stay, laser focused on what our real opponent is.

[Kit Collins]: Our real opponent is austerity budgeting.

[Kit Collins]: I believe that we have the money to value the people who choose to nominate themselves for school committee and go through the process of running and seek election and serve in that role.

[Kit Collins]: that we have the resources, that we can marshal the resources to do better by everybody who contributes to the Medford public school system.

[Kit Collins]: We talk about it all year long.

[Kit Collins]: We talk about how little authority the school committee, sorry, we talk about where the city council's authority lies and doesn't lie when it comes to making direct appropriations to our budgets, including the school budgets.

[Kit Collins]: We talk about this.

[Kit Collins]: all the time, often in great frustration.

[Kit Collins]: We don't have the power to influence bargaining units here in the city council.

[Kit Collins]: We don't have the authority to make appropriations whatsoever that is out of our purview.

[Kit Collins]: I know, speaking for myself, there's been countless times when I wished it was in our purview, because I'm so frustrated by what I see in the line items in the budgets that we have to vote yes or no on, because that's all that we can do on those budgets.

[Kit Collins]: So when it comes back to this proposal,

[Kit Collins]: Due to the constraints of our jurisdiction here, this is something that we are legally allowed to vote on.

[Kit Collins]: And there are many things that we will never have the opportunity to vote on, because that is not within our purview.

[Kit Collins]: When something comes in front of me that is an opportunity to discuss and interrogate, is this an opportunity to do a good thing?

[Kit Collins]: I want to take that opportunity.

[Kit Collins]: And I do not think it is in any way incompatible with continuing to do better.

[Kit Collins]: in the many areas, the many school-related areas where we need to keep doing better.

[Kit Collins]: It's not a zero-sum, and it's not an either-or.

[Kit Collins]: I look forward to hearing the discussion tonight, and I look forward to continuing to hold ourselves accountable to do this right, and to do right by all of our public employees, and to do as many things right as we can, all at the same time.

[Kit Collins]: And I don't think that we have to choose between one or the other.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: It's okay.

[Kit Collins]: There was a lot of, it feels cheap to say, there was a lot of really important perspectives shared tonight.

[Kit Collins]: I feel like even just saying that doesn't really do it justice, but I wanted to leave the last word to a lead sponsor of the paper.

[Kit Collins]: I did just wanted to quickly clarify one of my previous comments, because I think when I mentioned the free cash number, I was unclear, and I apologize for speaking unclearly.

[Kit Collins]: I was nervous.

[Kit Collins]: What I really meant to say was to try to recenter my comments on what I think is the most important part of most of the conversations that we have in the city council, which is that tight budgets are a choice.

[Kit Collins]: And they're not a choice that we make in this branch of government.

[Kit Collins]: I hope that a silver lining of this conversation can be elucidating for this body and for the school committee and for the residents, how our budgets get made.

[Kit Collins]: It's an ongoing process of making the budget every year.

[Kit Collins]: And for us, it just means approving it.

[Kit Collins]: We cannot appropriate, we cannot weigh in on collective bargaining.

[Kit Collins]: We cannot move money from one salary to another.

[Kit Collins]: We're sorely limited in what we can do.

[Kit Collins]: And I hope that this ongoing process allows us to have the conversation with the community

[Kit Collins]: how our budgets are shaped, and who shapes them, and what limited power lies where, because I think it's beneficial for the community to get a better sense of how that pie gets baked.

[Kit Collins]: But I think what makes me frustrated, what I hear in this room tonight, is that we, the administration, willfully keeps urgently needed funding away from the people and services that need it, year after year, on a scale that exceeds by magnitude the scale of these proposed COLA increases.

[Kit Collins]: And that is what I'll be focusing on as we continue to discuss this.

[Kit Collins]: And I hope that we can continue to center the conversation around this conversation and achieving equity and just what we need in our operating budget year after year.

[Kit Collins]: And I thank you to everybody who brought that to this conversation tonight and will in the future.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I just want to say, excuse me, thank you for bringing your concerns to us tonight.

[Kit Collins]: Glad to hear that we have some action steps we can quickly take on the construction infractions piece of things.

[Kit Collins]: really appreciate you speaking to, especially appreciate you actually reading the housing production plan.

[Kit Collins]: Well, I think that's probably the average way to read it.

[Kit Collins]: But I think that your comments resonate with a lot of the work that we've laid out for ourselves on the council.

[Kit Collins]: serving a wide range of users and households is deeply embedded in the work that we're trying to do through our zoning overhaul which we're very much gearing up for.

[Kit Collins]: We have a condo conversion ordinance that's still in progress so there are some, there's some ongoing council projects that touch on exactly what you're speaking so just encourage you to, you know, we'd love to, you know, have you be engaged in the public process and those as they unfold and

[Kit Collins]: These are projects that have come about because of what the community has said.

[Kit Collins]: We want housing to look like and not look like in Medford, so we welcome your continuing participation in the high-level policy that we try to implement to make sure that we don't just turn into a community of luxury condos where nobody can afford to live in.

[Kit Collins]: I'll echo that.

[Kit Collins]: I'm excited to vote on this tonight.

[Kit Collins]: I think that the recommendations that came out of the CD board, they affirm what's distinctive and significant about this district, its transit proximity.

[Kit Collins]: Had some really interesting conversations with your department about making sure that this is

[Kit Collins]: a couple weeks ago.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Roehl.

[Kit Collins]: So this is a project that we've been working on in subcommittee since March.

[Kit Collins]: The real seeds of this project were in the Solid Waste Task Force that met for a lot of 2022 under the direction of

[Kit Collins]: Director Hahn and consultants towards the goal of looking at tools available to us to start our next waste hauling contract with best possible deal for the city both in terms of cost effectiveness and in terms of progressing towards our zero waste goals which of course is integral to our overarching sustainability goals and one of the things that came out of that conversation not just recommendations for

[Kit Collins]: our next waste hauling contract was actually to tweak the existing Medford legislation around solid waste in Medford to make sure that we had the legislative foundation to make sure that we could hold our future waste hauler vendor to account in accordance with our sustainability goals.

[Kit Collins]: So in the Subcommittee on Ordinances and Rules, we worked closely with Director Hunt and her department.

[Kit Collins]: There are a couple

[Kit Collins]: main changes that we made, but overall we just took our existing waste hauling ordinance, which was pretty outdated in a lot of ways.

[Kit Collins]: So we made sure that it was updated to align with best practices coming out of the MAS DEP.

[Kit Collins]: And the origins of this document start with their template language.

[Kit Collins]: So it's been thoroughly vetted.

[Kit Collins]: This aligns with what other communities do in terms of waste hauling.

[Kit Collins]: One of the most consequential changes is that there's now a bundled service requirement, which essentially just says, if you offer trash pickup in Medford, you have to also offer recycling.

[Kit Collins]: And this is significant, because that way, vendors that only offer trash pickup cannot undercut vendors that offer both on price.

[Kit Collins]: And this will allow us to recycle the most in Medford in the most cost-effective way, which affects people on the city contract as well as everybody else.

[Kit Collins]: That's the main strokes.

[Kit Collins]: We did work with Director O'Connor from the Board of Health to make sure that this document aligns with current Board of Health regulations for waste haulers because they do, they operate the permitting side to make sure that everything is consistent to make this legible and understandable for generators as well as vendors.

[Kit Collins]: I do have a few last amendments that I'll make from the floor just on the definitions in article one after any further comment or questions from my fellow Councilors.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Amendments?

[Kit Collins]: Great.

[Kit Collins]: And thank you so much for your comments, and to everybody who worked on this with me.

[Kit Collins]: So just quickly, just some quick amendments for Article 1 in general.

[Kit Collins]: This was the last piece that we didn't amend in subcommittee, but I have some amendments that were run past a whole host of department heads, and I have a list if people are interested in seeing.

[Kit Collins]: We just wanted to take section 71, 72, sorry, 70-1, 70-2, and 70-3, put those into contemporary language and

[Kit Collins]: make sure that everybody who ought to be, every department that ought to be mentioned in those sections so that they could be tasked with enforcement would be.

[Kit Collins]: So I can read off those amendments.

[Kit Collins]: They're just a short paragraph each, and I'll also email that language to the city clerk.

[Kit Collins]: Yes, I'll email it to you.

[Kit Collins]: have the draft queued up but I didn't send it unless there was any controversy about this.

[Kit Collins]: Who will speak for the cinders?

[Kit Collins]: Well, I don't know who speaks for the cows.

[Kit Collins]: So for Section 70-1, the motion would be to strike the existing and replace with, you should have this in your email inbox,

[Kit Collins]: No private property may become a gathering place for debris, refuse, discarded, or abandoned items or other waste.

[Kit Collins]: Any property owner who has received written notice from the Department of Public Works, Medford Police Department, Code Enforcement Officer, or Medford Board of Health to remove any such material from their property must do so within the timeframe directed.

[Kit Collins]: Second is to take the existing section 70-2 and strike that and replace it with no debris, refuse, discarded items, or other waste, including yard waste and construction debris may be placed or dumped in any public place or public way in the city.

[Kit Collins]: All waste must be properly contained and properly placed for collection on scheduled collection days in accordance with the regulations, schedules, and policies promulgated by the Department of Public Works and Board of Health.

[Kit Collins]: Any person who has been ordered by the Department of Public Works, Medford Police Department, code enforcement officer, Medford Board of Health, or designee thereof

[Kit Collins]: to remove any improperly discarded material or waste from private or public property must do so within the time frame directed.

[Kit Collins]: And then finally, to just strike 70-3 because that information has been subsumed into the proposed 70-1 and 70-2.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Councilor Collins.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Morell, and I appreciate the councilors who brought this forward.

[Kit Collins]: I want to affirm what all of my colleagues have said so far.

[Kit Collins]: It shouldn't need to be restated that

[Kit Collins]: Our constituency deserves an elections office that is fully equipped at any time to defend full and fair access for every single voter.

[Kit Collins]: Individual staff members and volunteers and elected should not be having to fill the gaps or notice gaps or individually lobby or push staff members to do the right thing and correct issues at the 11th hour on election day.

[Kit Collins]: But this was the case last Tuesday.

[Kit Collins]: That was my experience.

[Kit Collins]: It's alarming.

[Kit Collins]: for anybody who works with City Hall in any capacity as an elected, as an appointed, or as a volunteer.

[Kit Collins]: That should never be an option, let alone be necessary.

[Kit Collins]: I think we all agree if even one voter is unable to cast their ballot because of incorrect mail ballot return information or unable to cast their ballot because they were

[Kit Collins]: you know, aspersions were cast about, can I bring my voter guide into the ballot?

[Kit Collins]: Or even if that concern is arisen, that concern isn't supposed to happen.

[Kit Collins]: That's why we have voter rights.

[Kit Collins]: That's why they're extremely important in this city, throughout the Commonwealth.

[Kit Collins]: If we are condoning those issues in our elections office, even for one voter, then we've failed.

[Kit Collins]: that's how high of a bar that we have to have for elections.

[Kit Collins]: As Councilor Scarpelli and others mentioned, we're in an age where, unfortunately, people are out looking for reasons to cast aspersions on the voting process.

[Kit Collins]: We cannot continue to open the city up to this kind of liability, and it's extremely frustrating because the City Council has brought up this issue before.

[Kit Collins]: We've tried to prevent this issue from happening before it happened for a second time, and it did.

[Kit Collins]: And we are saying now, as a council, we can't condone a disorganized and inconsistent voting experience, or even really a difficult voting experience for any voter.

[Kit Collins]: That's not how it's supposed to be.

[Kit Collins]: Voting isn't a privilege.

[Kit Collins]: It's a right, and it shouldn't be difficult.

[Kit Collins]: It should be easy.

[Kit Collins]: And it was difficult.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate the resolution to ask the administration for appropriation to fulfill full staffing in the elections office.

[Kit Collins]: I think that's necessary.

[Kit Collins]: I think we saw it was necessary before this election.

[Kit Collins]: And now I think that we're again seeing the symptoms of an underfunded essential municipal service.

[Kit Collins]: I think that we need to see this office restored to its full capacity because this is what a lack of capacity looks like.

[Kit Collins]: We need to see what accountability looks like, as Councilor Tseng said, and we need to know what went wrong specifically, and we need to know what will change specifically.

[Kit Collins]: tomorrow, next week, the week after that, so that our multiple elections next year will be airtight and that every resident that has felt a lack of confidence or disenfranchised by this process can know that our next elections are multiple, very consequential elections next year will be airtight.

[Kit Collins]: So I hope that the administration is listening and I hope that they will respond with the urgency that we feel.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Morell.

[Kit Collins]: Transgender Day of Remembrance is observed on November 20th.

[Kit Collins]: This is the day to think about and remember those who have tragically lost their lives due to hatred and bigotry and violence simply for being who they are.

[Kit Collins]: And it's a day to contemplate those who paved the way for others in the trans and greater LGBTQ plus community to be able to live their authentic lives and thrive in our community.

[Kit Collins]: against the history of hardship, enduring hardship.

[Kit Collins]: So I appreciate this opportunity to reaffirm our solidarity with the trans community and to have a moment to contemplate sacrifices and tragedies that have come before us and the work ahead to a fully equitable and safe society for all.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Morell.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Morell.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate, uh, Councilor bears for putting this forward.

[Kit Collins]: Um, I see this issue in action every time I try to drive to my house in South Medford from Wegmans.

[Kit Collins]: Um, and it's this is a citywide issue of, you know, every apartment that I've lived in in South Medford.

[Kit Collins]: There's

[Kit Collins]: one intersection that I look at 100 times a week where it seems to be a cut through street that inevitably has a daycare on that street.

[Kit Collins]: And you see the people get impatient with the main thoroughfare and they use the cut through, they speed down it.

[Kit Collins]: And it's, I agree it is a citywide issue and it's horrifying to see it every time because you're just waiting for something, you know, hair raising to happen and residents shouldn't have to live with that volume of high speed cut through traffic.

[Kit Collins]: And I completely agree that the

[Kit Collins]: widespread nature of this issue throughout the city.

[Kit Collins]: I think it shines a light on how what we really need is the resources to support citywide approach.

[Kit Collins]: I think a lot of the time with these issues, we can't control for every person who would speed if they got the opportunity.

[Kit Collins]: It's hard to devise a perfect

[Kit Collins]: quick fix.

[Kit Collins]: Often those aren't as those aren't the solves that we want them to be.

[Kit Collins]: So in the absence of resources, you know, tomorrow to type of street redesign work that would really result in safer, appropriately speeded streets, you know, I'm hoping that our traffic and

[Kit Collins]: transportation departments can look at Willis Avenue with haste because, you know, it's been getting, you know, this seems like it's an acute issue right now in neighborhoods.

[Kit Collins]: Neighbors have been speaking up about it, and it's my hope that absent, you know, the resources for a redesign, at least the solutions that seem to be working best on Willis Avenue, when we get the chance to roll those out, we can be taking the best practices and hopefully adopting those for the other many, many problem areas across the city.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Morell, and I appreciate you sharing that update.

[Kit Collins]: I also appreciate Councilor Scarpelli

[Kit Collins]: bringing this forward, and I appreciate your efforts to get out ahead of the issue.

[Kit Collins]: And I have a lot of concerns about this, and one of them is making sure that we're, since this issue is known, that we're being proactive with how we're communicating about it, and letting people know that this election is going to be, you know, has been above board, will be above board, and not sowing confusion.

[Kit Collins]: Because obviously,

[Kit Collins]: I think you said it very well, Councilor Scarpelli, that's the last thing that we need and it's unfortunate to have issues like this come up at this point in kind of the national mood around elections.

[Kit Collins]: And so, using this platform to reassure the voters, I think is very productive.

[Kit Collins]: I reached out to the Chief of Staff after seeing the update this afternoon with some questions, really glad to hear that.

[Kit Collins]: Manager Ripley already responded.

[Kit Collins]: to shed some light on the scale of the problem.

[Kit Collins]: That was one of the questions I had, as well as, you know, when we say checks and balances, I think it's important for us to know exactly what those are so that we can, you know, again, be reassuring residents about, you know, exactly the how and the why of this not being an issue for election integrity.

[Kit Collins]: So it's great to know, you know, the nuts and bolts for those who don't already know about how the

[Kit Collins]: state-assigned voter IDs.

[Kit Collins]: I didn't.

[Kit Collins]: It's great to know about that process so that we can all feel assured that, you know, extra ballots, if they're not disposed of before people get to City Hall, will not be counted.

[Kit Collins]: I think that's really important to emphasize.

[Kit Collins]: So it's unfortunate.

[Kit Collins]: I think it's important that we

[Kit Collins]: you know, be transparent about the mistakes that have been made and be transparent about how exactly they're getting fixed.

[Kit Collins]: And I'm glad that we are being properly hasty and responsible about fixing the issue.

[Kit Collins]: And clearly, you know, making sure that this type of snafu does not keep happening in this office is something that I'm sure we'll all be, you know, very keen on communicating with that office about in the future, because this isn't what Medford needs.

[Kit Collins]: Present.

[Kit Collins]: I'll be thinking of her and of the family in coming days.
