[Kit Collins]: Particular to the Tufts RAs fight, you know, I think that, you know, labor is labor and workers are workers and it's time to stop entertaining the narrative that seeking to collectively bargain is anything other than reasonable.

[Kit Collins]: I wish that Tufts would more enthusiastically respond with that attitude.

[Kit Collins]: All experts, I mean, all workers are the experts on their work and RAs are the experts on their role in the campus community, which of course affects the Medford community in myriad ways.

[Kit Collins]: They stabilize and counsel and provide logistical support for the dorms.

[Kit Collins]: Candidly, a truly bizarre waste of their administrative time and resources, of which we know they have many.

[Kit Collins]: And we know that there's so many more important needs that those could be put to, not just making the campus experience more livable for those living and working on campus, but for the community as well.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Morell.

[Kit Collins]: Very briefly, and I think that if I might speculate, I think that the point here is not that there's a strategy that should be taken, but just that clearly the process

[Kit Collins]: is broken and that's why we see these labor disputes, these labor struggles in our own community.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that we all want to see the overarching process change so that workers in our community, whether they're workers in our community that work for City Hall or workers in our community that happen to live on Tufts for now,

[Kit Collins]: that they can collectively bargain in a way that they can efficiently proceed to a just outcome.

[Kit Collins]: And I'm really heartened, and I think that this resolution and previous ones that the city council has worked on are evidence of this, that everybody behind this rail takes the opportunity.

[Kit Collins]: And everybody in this community, I think for the most part, takes the opportunity to stand with labor when they can on the actions that they feel that they can take.

[Kit Collins]: And behind this rail, I think it's our right to sometimes have different ideas of what is possible for us to do and what's strategic.

[Kit Collins]: That's our right.

[Kit Collins]: We have a diversity of opinions, but I think when push comes to shove, we are all doing our best to stand with the laborers and the workers in our community.

[Kit Collins]: With that, I would move for approval.

[Kit Collins]: Yes.

[Kit Collins]: Yes.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I think that Councilor Tseng covered most of what I was going to say relating to locking bins being actually shown to be a really secure way to rat proof containers, just you know, I think it's a common misconception that composting can increase

[Kit Collins]: rat problems, I think that's actually not necessarily the case, which is great for the city on a lot of fronts because of those locking containers can actually keep rats out better.

[Kit Collins]: I think that the bigger picture that we're all really concerned about, we all hear about all the time is that everybody's seeing rats everywhere all the time, and it's a problem.

[Kit Collins]: And this is something that we need to start being proactive about so that we don't have to resort to those rat extermination measures that I think nobody wants to use that are also a threat to other beloved parts of our ecosystem, like the bald eagles along the Mr. River watershed.

[Kit Collins]: You know, I think this is something that comes up a lot on the city council this is, you know, to really attack this in a proactive way takes money that we don't currently have in our operating budget.

[Kit Collins]: I think it would be great if we can align with our department heads and make sure that we're doing everything that we can be doing with our current resources.

[Kit Collins]: And we need to be pushing for that future operational budget so that we can have, you know, I think Councilor Scarpelli makes a great point.

[Kit Collins]: We need to have a standing working committee, working group, whatever that looks like, so that we're really addressing this problem and not letting it continue to boil over.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Morell.

[Kit Collins]: Appreciate Councilor Tseng for bringing this resolution forward with me.

[Kit Collins]: And I also want to acknowledge school committee member McLaughlin who helped us with the idea.

[Kit Collins]: And she actually liaised with Boston City Council member Mejia in Boston who worked on a similar resolution.

[Kit Collins]: I loved the idea of making an official proclamation to recognize Disability Pride Month in Medford.

[Kit Collins]: It's celebrated across the nation, across the world.

[Kit Collins]: disability has always existed, it will always exist, and like any other facet of diversity in our society, it should be acknowledged, it should be celebrated, and we should make sure that everybody across every spectrum of human being is adequately accommodated and embraced in our community.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Yes.

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Collins.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Morell.

[Kit Collins]: And thank you both, Director McKibbin and Director Hunt for being here.

[Kit Collins]: Again, I appreciate our longer discussion about this and our Committee of the Whole that we just wrapped up.

[Kit Collins]: Definitely, I agree with the comments that President Morell and Councilor Caraviello just made as this gets towards finalization.

[Kit Collins]: And just for the benefit of residents who weren't watching the conversation that we had at 6 p.m., you know, I think that this, authorizing this contract, which stands to encompass

[Kit Collins]: so many of our goals for getting towards zero waste, cost savings for the city, just a better experience for residents and businesses.

[Kit Collins]: I think that this positions us to be in a very exciting place as a city and for the city.

[Kit Collins]: You know, for me, I don't remember when recycling became the norm.

[Kit Collins]: I think that happened kind of before I was a fully lucid adult, but I think we're at the point in society now where if recycling isn't available, it feels weird and it feels wrong to most people to not have that option.

[Kit Collins]: And I think we're at a place

[Kit Collins]: societally, where hopefully, you know, within the next 10 or 20 years, we'll get to that place with composting.

[Kit Collins]: And that's so important for just the experience of being in our buildings and the overall waste stream, not to mention being a large emission source to not be composting these organics.

[Kit Collins]: So I think that this is really exciting for the city to be in the position to be a part of that pivot in Massachusetts of institutionalizing, just something that we should be doing.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Morell.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate Councilor Caraviello for bringing this forward.

[Kit Collins]: I took some time to read over the responses from Director Blake and Engineer Wartella that they sent over in lieu of their presence here tonight.

[Kit Collins]: One of the points that they mentioned is sort of in explaining

[Kit Collins]: how the current interventions at this intersection came to be.

[Kit Collins]: I thought it was very interesting.

[Kit Collins]: I think they use shorthand pilot to permanence for saying why we have these plastic barriers up now, which of course are not a permanent road intervention.

[Kit Collins]: And I think it illustrates to me, you know, why so many of our conversations about every operational and infrastructural issue in the city eventually comes back to money.

[Kit Collins]: I think that this is an issue that it is currently on the queue of

[Kit Collins]: projects where it sounds like the city would like to see a more permanent infrastructural solution, not classic barriers, not something movable, just something permanent.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: No, no problem.

[Kit Collins]: And you know no disagree with anything there I think that the point that, for me, the bottom line is, regardless of what we wish had been negotiated for at any point in the past.

[Kit Collins]: My bottom line is now we have to do what keeps that intersection, and that road as safe as possible.

[Kit Collins]: given the resources that we do have.

[Kit Collins]: And right now that means the plastic barriers I think engineer Wartella, I think I have the number right so that there's been 300 incidents near that intersection the past five years, unacceptable, anything that that can make that intersection safer is what we should do.

[Kit Collins]: I wish I mean this is why we talk about it all the time.

[Kit Collins]: that we can make every intersection and road and site of passage in the city of Medford as safe as possible to drastically reduce the incidence of any type of accident, because that's just the most basic service that the city should be providing the people who get around here.

[Kit Collins]: And we're not there yet.

[Kit Collins]: So I feel your frustration.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that this issue

[Kit Collins]: it does bring up a lot of issues that we're grappling with in the city and our lack of resources to do things that the way that we'd ideally like to see them done.

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Collins.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Director Hunt for presenting on this and giving us all the context around it.

[Kit Collins]: I certainly hear my fellow councilors observation about, you know, observations around doing things piece by piece.

[Kit Collins]: I completely empathize with that.

[Kit Collins]: I think that we're all, you know,

[Kit Collins]: think that this mechanism is kind of a bridge between what we have now and where we know we're going.

[Kit Collins]: We have the comprehensive plan.

[Kit Collins]: We have the existing character of the neighborhood.

[Kit Collins]: We know what there's demand for.

[Kit Collins]: We know what's currently there.

[Kit Collins]: And then we have plans to do a comprehensive rezoning and make sure that all of our neighborhoods are kind of brought into alignment with our comprehensive plan.

[Kit Collins]: So I think that this PDD mechanism is a way to make sure that we don't miss out on these opportunities while we're still ramping up for that comprehensive

[Kit Collins]: project.

[Kit Collins]: I'm really glad that we have it.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think any of us want to bypass these opportunities while they're on the table.

[Kit Collins]: And, you know, at the same time, very much looking forward to when we can do this within the structure of a comprehensive, you know, no or very few exceptions needed kind of zoning paradigm.

[Kit Collins]: So I would motion for approval after many of my fellow councillors additional comments.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Tseng.

[Kit Collins]: to mitigate a rate increase in the short term, a small amount, or trying to sock away a fairly significant amount of money to deal with the backlog that's going to keep increasing towards doing some truly necessary repairs.

[Kit Collins]: We have to put that, we have to put that to the voters.

[Kit Collins]: In this case, I think that this is,

[Kit Collins]: My vote is about trying to make the best of a situation that I can't celebrate, that I can't feel good about, but I'm trying to do the best that I can with what's in front of us.

[Kit Collins]: And in order to not be paralyzed by that and to make a decision,

[Kit Collins]: I have to think about what's within my jurisdiction, what can I make sure is in the budget, that we're better off having in the budget than wouldn't be, that isn't possibly on the table to be.

[Kit Collins]: But at the same time, you know, I want to reinforce for folks who are watching this meeting that this is the beginning of a process, not the end.

[Kit Collins]: votes on these individual amendments.

[Kit Collins]: I've said this before, but just to reiterate, you know, I think that these amendments would be additive for this whole community.

[Kit Collins]: Administrations change, but we always deserve a council that is truly empowered to represent our community members and act on their behalf, not just be a grandstanding body, not just be a rubber stamp.

[Kit Collins]: Right now, this council can't appropriate resources to ensure that the policies we do pass actually get enforced or if they are just left to gather dust.

[Kit Collins]: We can't hire staff to allow us to do our work confidently or effectively or with the resources that we need.

[Kit Collins]: We're not empowered to really collaborate with the administration to craft budgets that reflect what we hear from our constituents.

[Kit Collins]: So to me, these are important because these amendments would leave the community with seven more avenues.

[Kit Collins]: for meaningful representation in their city government, and that's really what it comes down to.

[Kit Collins]: The community's representatives should be able to actually materially represent them.

[Kit Collins]: So this is about

[Kit Collins]: you know, just making some important targeted tweaks to our 40-year-old charter so that we can start working for a better community now.

[Kit Collins]: Because I think that the work we have to do, the work that we've been trying to do, will be done better and faster with these amendments with a more balanced and collaborative government.

[Kit Collins]: And I don't think that that can wait, you know, half a decade or more to be able to work more effectively for the constituents.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: make do with pretty scarce resources.

[Kit Collins]: I remember one of the things that I've heard from members of our DPW staff and our engineer in the past is, you know,

[Kit Collins]: matters of public safety are always prioritized when possible.

[Kit Collins]: But our ceiling for what's possible is really low, and budgets are extremely tight when everybody's operating on skeleton resources.

[Kit Collins]: And I don't think that that is always the decision of individual staff people, but just operating in a very austere environment.

[Kit Collins]: So I think that's important to bring into conversation, because when we're talking about safety of our residents and safety of our residents in our private ways,

[Kit Collins]: The decisions that we make and the decisions that the administration makes about the resources that we have to deploy around our community in the interest of aesthetics and public safety, that trickles down to individual cases like this.

[Kit Collins]: And so I think it's fair to say we need insight from this position specifically and that role specifically, but also to say, if we don't have resources to go around where most of the people who come to us with an issue on a private way leave that conversation disappointed, we need to take a hard look at our books and see what would it take to be able to better serve those residents.

[Kit Collins]: Because as I know, we've talked as a council about how expensive it is to bring a private way back into the public fold.

[Kit Collins]: Um, you know, those are residents that were that we are sort of agreeing to leave in that situation when we don't build towards a plan where we can bring those back under public jurisdiction.

[Kit Collins]: Certainly we're aware of the same lack of capacity lack of effectiveness in our parking department as that, you know, takes its time to get up to speed, so to speak.

[Kit Collins]: And, you know, the large trucks issue made me prick up my ears because I know that's an issue that, you know, falls under state jurisdiction as well as city jurisdiction in terms of how do we regulate these huge commercial trucks on our residential streets and how do we make sure that's fair for both users, the commercial drivers that

[Kit Collins]: to get around businesses that depend on them, but the residents that are trying to have a human sized existence on their residential areas.

[Kit Collins]: All that being said, I think where we're at is how many of these systemic citywide and sometimes statewide issues are relaying at the feet of Oasis.

[Kit Collins]: that's where I'm coming down.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that we need to be fair here.

[Kit Collins]: We need to be fair to the business owner.

[Kit Collins]: We also need to work very, very hard to make sure that residents are protected, their quality of life is protected as much as possible.

[Kit Collins]: I know that Councilor Scarpelli made a motion.

[Kit Collins]: In the spirit of his motion, I'll make one that's slightly different, also for consideration for my fellow councilors.

[Kit Collins]: Certainly doesn't have just just to present a alternative proposal.

[Kit Collins]: And certainly Councilor Scarpelli, I appreciate what you put forward in the spirit of having a discussion where we can see where we convene residents and enforcement staff from the city as well as the business owners.

[Kit Collins]: An alternative proposal would be to just approve the license.

[Kit Collins]: with a date certain for a committee of the whole over the summer after a 90 day review period where we do discuss what's working, how are things going, we convene parking enforcement, we convene code enforcement, we have a better sense of where those pain points are.

[Kit Collins]: And again, this is potentially under a 90 day review process, we're able to go forward and issuing another extended license to another thriving business in the city.

[Kit Collins]: And we get the chance to say, let's hear from everybody about how it's going at a date certain.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President real.

[Kit Collins]: Well first I want to thank the moms demand action community group for your stewardship of this resolution not just with us on the council with the school committee with various players in the mayor's administration the mayor herself.

[Kit Collins]: really always wonderful to see a community group coalesce around a really important matter of community well being, especially with something an issue that the gravity of which really cannot be overstated.

[Kit Collins]: So thank you so much for your leadership on this resolution and bringing it forward to many officials and partners throughout the community.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you to my fellow Councilors for working with this on me to bring it forward to the council.

[Kit Collins]: Um, this is a I know President moral.

[Kit Collins]: We made her say a mouthful, but this is really a very simple resolution.

[Kit Collins]: Um, the safe storage program is something that many in the city have already committed to do something they're ready to do something that they're enthusiastic to do.

[Kit Collins]: It's just a matter of distributing information on how to keep guns that already exist in homes safer in those homes that they're away from kids.

[Kit Collins]: where they can do no harm.

[Kit Collins]: It's just about getting that information out to the community through communication channels that already exist.

[Kit Collins]: So it's low cost, it's really effective.

[Kit Collins]: I think when we read statistics like this about something so horrible, something that really defies words such as gun violence, unintentional gun violence, gun violence that occurs in the home, it can be sort of numbing to read those statistics.

[Kit Collins]: that I think something like this, the measures that the Moms Demand Action Chapter has been working on, the Be Smart Safety Program, it's such a simple and effective way to make sure that more violence is prevented in our communities.

[Kit Collins]: And so I'm really glad to be a part of this initiative and hope that we can continue to be a part of the implementation to make sure that the word gets out to as many Medford residents as possible.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Well, I just want to thank you for being here.

[Kit Collins]: I feel like there's not a lot that I could add that would be additive because you've said so much very clearly, briefly about what you've been going through for many, many years.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think there's anything that I could add to that.

[Kit Collins]: That wouldn't just be rhetorical that we've said already.

[Kit Collins]: And I know it's very clear, you know, it goes without saying, but you've said it, what you need is not more statements of support, but actual results.

[Kit Collins]: And it's obviously demonstrably true that times are getting harder.

[Kit Collins]: Cost of living is going up.

[Kit Collins]: It's not just inflation, it's cost of living, it's cost of everything.

[Kit Collins]: I think we probably all feel this in our personal budgets.

[Kit Collins]: And it's, we've been hearing about this for months, if not more, but it still is just completely, it's unfathomable to me how little you're being offered compared to

[Kit Collins]: the real value of that compensation compared to what it takes to live in this city.

[Kit Collins]: I don't get why we would make it so hard for people who want to serve their community to stay in this community.

[Kit Collins]: I don't get it.

[Kit Collins]: Like you said, nobody gets rich doing public service, they do it because of

[Kit Collins]: some kind of you know wanting to invest in the community.

[Kit Collins]: Why are we making it hard.

[Kit Collins]: I'm glad the Councilor Tseng brought up the, the $25 million in free cash that was certified last July that we heard about a couple months ago.

[Kit Collins]: And I said it then but when I heard about that.

[Kit Collins]: I wasn't happy, I was disgusted.

[Kit Collins]: It's like why are we sitting on this.

[Kit Collins]: As you said, you're the lowest paid workers in City Hall.

[Kit Collins]: So even if you were to get an 8% cost of living adjustment, I don't have the math brain that some other of my fellow Councilors do, but I don't think that would make a dent in $25 million.

[Kit Collins]: I want an explanation for why that isn't being allocated to bring up the baseline on the people who have needed it the most for the longest and haven't gotten anything.

[Kit Collins]: To make an offer to workers negotiating and then rescind that offer,

[Kit Collins]: That's a negotiating tactic that I've heard about in other contexts that I thought was, I'm not even sure what the word is, hostile, openly hostile.

[Kit Collins]: When I hear about that going on between other negotiating partners, it's meant to be intimidating.

[Kit Collins]: It's meant to be a show of force, show of power.

[Kit Collins]: Why would we do that to our clerks?

[Kit Collins]: I don't get it.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for being here.

[Kit Collins]: We appreciate you being transparent with us going through I think we obviously have plenty of options to think through in terms of how we can handle this especially as the opportunity of budget season comes before us.

[Kit Collins]: Yes.

[Kit Collins]: We're in the really early stages.

[Kit Collins]: You know, it's only fair the developers are making money off of the housing stock and the wonderful neighborhoods and the amenities that we have here in Medford the community needs to be benefiting to maybe that is measures to improve stability for the tenants the residents that are getting displaced because of those conversions in Medford

[Kit Collins]: Our jurisdiction here is limited.

[Kit Collins]: Our power here is limited.

[Kit Collins]: I too received a lot of messages from constituents after this very sad passing of a very beloved local bald eagle passed several weeks ago.

[Kit Collins]: And I think this is a problem that can really only be appropriately addressed regionally, not only because cities kind of can't

[Kit Collins]: address the issue of what rodenticides are being used on a piecemeal basis.

[Kit Collins]: We can't, you know, influence what private individuals are using.

[Kit Collins]: But also, you know, I think a statewide regional approach is what's going to make these less harmful approaches cost effective for places like municipalities and institutions to implement, so that we can make sure that what we're putting into the

[Kit Collins]: into our food chain, into our ecosystem is preserving the biodiversity such that we have along the mystic that I think we all really care so much about.

[Kit Collins]: So I'll be happy to support this this evening.

[Kit Collins]: And I really hope that this advances on the state level.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I appreciate the discussion on this issue so far for my fellow Councilors.

[Kit Collins]: And I just want to note I think that this dovetails with the conversation that we just had about the discussion of a capital improvement plan I think that this dovetails with the conversation that the rules and ordinances subcommittee was having immediately before this meeting about measures that we can take within our power of the city council so that we can be a better

[Kit Collins]: more meaningful, more actual source of representation, source of influence in the budget on behalf of this community.

[Kit Collins]: I think President Morell, you say it all the time, a budget is a statement of values.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that the measures proposed in this resolution kind of cut to the heart of some of my most frequent frustrations with what we hear from constituents.

[Kit Collins]: Why isn't this happening?

[Kit Collins]: Why isn't this, which essentially comes down to why isn't this budgeted for?

[Kit Collins]: Why is the supportive service not exist in our city?

[Kit Collins]: Why are things like this in this department?

[Kit Collins]: Why are things like this infrastructurally?

[Kit Collins]: And to have no real other recourse or explanation, but to say, I wish that we could at least have the discussion about what it would look like to appropriate funds so that this would change in the schools or this would change in the roads or the sidewalks or that we could entertain forming this new department to better support the segment of the constituency.

[Kit Collins]: We don't have that power.

[Kit Collins]: All that we have is the power to cut, to make line out of subtractions.

[Kit Collins]: And I think we're all very aware of what that kind of power results in, in a budget process.

[Kit Collins]: I think it's not democratic.

[Kit Collins]: There are a lot of elected officials in the city of Medford and there's only one that has a meaningful role.

[Kit Collins]: in the budget process.

[Kit Collins]: So I think that these measures could potentially get us to a new solution around that.

[Kit Collins]: Another one of our, I think our most common refrains in terms of deep, deep frustrations is not having the staff to carry out even the things that are within our jurisdiction to do.

[Kit Collins]: And that's, I don't really have words for how frustrating it is sometimes because I think it is a rarity for a council to be this unified on so many issues.

[Kit Collins]: That's a really big hurdle to overcome in any public body, I think.

[Kit Collins]: And yet we hit a stumbling block because we don't have the resources, we don't have the personnel to execute the work ethic that we do have on a disparate set of issues.

[Kit Collins]: So I think that whatever form this takes, if it's the form of a home rule petition, I think this is a discussion that needs to happen because I think these are roadblocks that could really be orders of magnitude in terms of

[Kit Collins]: increasing our influence to better represent the will of the community in these chambers.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Merlin.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Commissioner for being here again to speak on this again.

[Kit Collins]: I think this all sounds really reasonable.

[Kit Collins]: One of the things that I hear about from constituents most often is repairs needed on sidewalks.

[Kit Collins]: I think this is something that we all care about a lot because it's an accessibility issue and we need to make sure that, you know, all of our sidewalks in our city are traversable for all residents, no matter how they're getting around.

[Kit Collins]: So for a lot of intuitive reasons, I think this is something that it is important that the city is able to continue moving forward with because this backlog of repairs will only grow and get more expensive over time.

[Kit Collins]: So I'm happy to motion for approval for first reading.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Morell.

[Kit Collins]: urgent material needs for our community that we need right now when we need them.

[Kit Collins]: But I think this very vast overflow is evidence that we have not been good at that.

[Kit Collins]: And I think frankly, that's a source of shame.

[Kit Collins]: maybe that could be an appropriation for an affordable housing trust as soon as that comes online.

[Kit Collins]: There's already a discrepancy between the people who are eligible for affordable or subsidized housing and how much of that type of housing that we already have.

[Kit Collins]: So in a lot of ways, creating an affordable housing trust is really just a preliminary step, but it's one I'm glad we're finally taking.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Morell.

[Kit Collins]: So I wanted to use the council as a forum to make sure that as many Medford residents as possible heard about this upcoming change.

[Kit Collins]: Our nation's leaders have allowed for extra pandemic assistance to expire.

[Kit Collins]: So on March 3rd, every household that's currently using SNAP can expect to start receiving at least 95 fewer dollars a month.

[Kit Collins]: This is potentially very damaging to households, especially as cost of living and cost of food remains high.

[Kit Collins]: and local governments have been asked to help get the word out so people can prepare as best they can to fill the gap.

[Kit Collins]: Residents are encouraged to contact the Department of Transitional Assistance for more information about how they will specifically be affected to see if they can qualify for those new increases.

[Kit Collins]: And I did hear from the City's Director of Communications today that the City of Medford is planning to broadcast

[Kit Collins]: this information and those links to resources on the city website and social media channels.

[Kit Collins]: So to residents who are looking for those details about how to investigate this further and look into resources that they and their households can potentially use, I would counsel them to be on the lookout for that.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Love to see mutual aid infiltrate the council chambers.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Collins.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Morell.

[Kit Collins]: This council has talked about similar legislation in previous sessions.

[Kit Collins]: The current pilot program statewide still exempts wealthy nonprofits like universities from paying taxes, property taxes, and that short changes cities like ours from much needed, fairly deserved tax revenue.

[Kit Collins]: These are not the shoestring kind of nonprofits that probably the word comes to mind with these.

[Kit Collins]: high wealth nonprofits that are property tax exempt, their revenue is increasing, their endowments are often quite large, and it's not logical for them to be exempt from paying taxes to their host communities, something that every other resident and type of business is required to do.

[Kit Collins]: So this proposed legislation would be to change the existing law to make large nonprofits

[Kit Collins]: no longer able to pay taxes or compensation on a purely voluntary basis.

[Kit Collins]: And so I asked my colleagues for their support for this bill, which would make larger organizations, sorry, large organizations start paying their fair share.

[Kit Collins]: And I think we can all imagine the very material ways that recouping some of that lost revenue from large nonprofits like Tufts University and my Alma mater, how big of a difference that would make in our community.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Morell, and thank you for co-sponsoring this.

[Kit Collins]: This is pertaining to the National Opioid Settlements against the manufacturers and distributors of opioid painkillers.

[Kit Collins]: Late last year, it was announced that five additional settlements were reached with more opioid distributors, and states and cities are being allocated funds to go towards prevention and community-wide rehabilitation as resulting from the national opioid epidemic.

[Kit Collins]: The council did actually receive an update from Director of Communications earlier today with some good news.

[Kit Collins]: We are confirmed to receive a distribution as a result of this settlement and our Board of Health and Office of Prevention Department staff has already been anticipating the five additional settlements, which is to say the city is on top of it.

[Kit Collins]: which is great to hear.

[Kit Collins]: I'm grateful to hear that.

[Kit Collins]: And just to share with the community, the update that we received, which I think was also disseminated early December, these funds can be used for sort of pertinent uses such as opioid use disorder treatment, support for people in recovery, harm reduction, prevention of opioid misuse.

[Kit Collins]: And the city has a number of next steps that they'll be conducting community outreach about.

[Kit Collins]: including establishing a promote prevent support behavioral health commission, um, feedback and listening sessions with the community.

[Kit Collins]: And the city council will be hearing more about, um, the specific plan and role of that commission as it gets formed over the next year.

[Kit Collins]: Well, I thank Councilor Tseng for putting this forward.

[Kit Collins]: I think this is a clear example where, you know,

[Kit Collins]: words matter and formalizing the right policy matters.

[Kit Collins]: And I think it's, you know, a really, it puts our community in a very positive, strong light that this is a policy that our city staff are already carrying out and what we can do as a legislative body to make sure that we are using our power as a forum and a speaker box for the community to make sure that it's known to as many communities as possible, sorry, as many constituents as possible, that interfacing with any city department

[Kit Collins]: regardless of your immigration status, is a good thing to do, a safe thing to do, and that they can trust the outcomes of that interaction.

[Kit Collins]: I think that codifying this formally will help us just promulgate that to more of the community.

[Kit Collins]: And so I'm happy to support this tonight.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you President Earl I'd be happy to provide a summary of this ordinance and a summary of the process that has gotten us to where we are today.

[Kit Collins]: I'm very gratified to be able to put this ordinance forward for first reading the council has been discussing modifying and evolving this ordinance for almost a full year, almost a full year now in the public health and community safety subcommittee and committee of the whole.

[Kit Collins]: and in one-on-one conversations with city administration, our chief of police, and other department heads, legal experts, and with community advocates.

[Kit Collins]: This ordinance is about being proactive to safeguard our community against nascent, privately developed surveillance technologies, which are both rapidly evolving and severely underregulated at the state and federal levels.

[Kit Collins]: I think this is a very exciting moment for this council and for the city.

[Kit Collins]: While we would be far from the first city to have a CCOPS ordinance, Medford has the chance to be a real leader here and a model for other communities.

[Kit Collins]: This ordinance, with the inclusion of some floor amendments that I'm going to propose in a minute, presents a clear and a structured way for the community, the City Council, and the administration to communicate and to collaborate.

[Kit Collins]: The outcome of that communication and collaboration

[Kit Collins]: will be the development of use policies and parameters for surveillance technologies now and in the future that are properly weighed benefits and the risks of these technologies.

[Kit Collins]: When we do choose to put surveillance technology to use in our city, we will know that we have had the intentional conversations about costs and benefits.

[Kit Collins]: We will have discussed the potential risks and the helpful benefits and how to balance both so as to safeguard community members against threats to personal privacy, civil liberty, and over-surveillance.

[Kit Collins]: As a city council, we will know that we have a guaranteed seat at the table when potentially large impacts to our constituents' lives and potentially huge purchases are decided.

[Kit Collins]: We will have a clear and a structured way to let this people's forum be a people's forum on these very real 21st century issues.

[Kit Collins]: And we will be able to guarantee that our constituents have a chance to ask questions and to be heard.

[Kit Collins]: Surveillance technology is already in use in communities around America.

[Kit Collins]: There's no turning back the clock on this new class of corporate technology.

[Kit Collins]: However,

[Kit Collins]: We can do what we can under our local purview to take this as an opportunity to involve the public to hear from experts and to build trust between our government and our community.

[Kit Collins]: So the version of the ordinance that we'll be voting on tonight is the product of four years of advocacy by the community coalition behind it, and months of discussion among city council and the administration.

[Kit Collins]: Since March of last year we have substantially modified added to and subtracted from the original draft.

[Kit Collins]: These changes centered around paring down the reporting requirements to make this ordinance more manageable, making it more clear that routine office tools are not considered surveillance technology, and also clarifying the reporting requirements are to be high level and general rather than onerous and granular.

[Kit Collins]: Throughout this process we have had productive good faith conversations with this administration, especially this chief of police in those conversations we've been able to address a number of outstanding concerns that were raised even after this ordinance was reported at committee, and I know that no document is perfect.

[Kit Collins]: And there are partners within and without of this administration, who have, who would have preferred different approaches to certain aspects of this ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: Still I'm grateful that we seem to have reached an agreement across a broad range of stakeholders on a set of amendments that we believe would make this ordinance doable workable for this community.

[Kit Collins]: And there is a document before Councilors, along with the clean and also redlined versions of the

[Kit Collins]: ordinance tonight, outlining the floor amendments that we intend to propose, and I will move that they be adopted prior to us taking a vote tonight.

[Kit Collins]: So, to sum up, I believe this has been a collaborative process helping us craft what I think is the most Medford tailored version of this ordinance that we could have arrived at.

[Kit Collins]: In short, this ordinance would advance the goals of transparency, accountability, community participation, and trust building, goals that we all share, within a scope that our department heads can accomplish within their existing duties.

[Kit Collins]: I thank my fellow Councilors for their deference with my preamble.

[Kit Collins]: and I ask for your support tonight.

[Kit Collins]: And President Morell, I know that there are audience members here to speak on the ordinance, and I would ask if you'd be willing to invite them up to speak after my co-sponsor.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Councilor Scarpelli.

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Collins.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Morell, and I appreciate my colleagues thoughtful consideration of what's before us this evening, not just a 12 page ordinance, but also 12 floor amendments to go with it.

[Kit Collins]: And Councilor Scarpelli, to your point, I honestly, I do hear you on the legal council piece.

[Kit Collins]: I think that that is a concern that this entire body shares, and I'm sympathetic to your view that, you know, at some point we have to draw the line when it comes to demanding appropriate legal representation for this council.

[Kit Collins]: At the same time, I've made this clear many times

[Kit Collins]: to me, serving in public office is a privilege.

[Kit Collins]: None of us know how long we're going to get to sit in this chair and I'm committed to doing what I can while I can for a lot for as long as I sit in this chair.

[Kit Collins]: So when I hear about an ordinance that a community group has been pushing for for four years, if I have the opportunity to work on it, I'm going to work on it.

[Kit Collins]: That's my personal opinion and I respect yours.

[Kit Collins]: On the issue of the 12-4 amendments,

[Kit Collins]: You know, I think this is something that is procedurally well within bounds so there are other comments that I've heard that I don't quite know how to countenance but if any of my fellow Councilors would like us to go more in depth on what's before us.

[Kit Collins]: I know we did kind of a speed read round I'd also be very happy to walk anybody through it.

[Kit Collins]: I touched on this in my opening remarks but all of these floor amendments have come from.

[Kit Collins]: conversations that we have had with the city administration over the past months, in the past two weeks, as recently as today, all in service of trying to pass an ordinance that is manageable and doable for this administration.

[Kit Collins]: I'm sorry if that process didn't feel transparent at first blush, but there's, you know, all of this in spirit of this ordinance can be talked through.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Scarpelli.

[Kit Collins]: No, these are, these are, sorry, Councilor Caraviello, these are new amendments that we're proposing after it was reported out of committee of the whole.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Morell.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you chief appreciate you being up here.

[Kit Collins]: You know, like I said earlier today, I really appreciate your candor, I know that this is a difficult conversation I really appreciate that you've been willing to have it with us with me for a year with others for four years.

[Kit Collins]: You know, I respect where you're coming from and I just want to reiterate that I don't want to repeat our conversation from earlier from two weeks ago, etc.

[Kit Collins]: you know, to the extent that we're having this conversation in the public forum, just for the sake of responding to you and putting it on the record.

[Kit Collins]: You know, I do want to emphasize that, you know, again, our intent here is not to be anti-surveillance technology.

[Kit Collins]: You know, that there is a reason that the ordinance is called Community Control over Public Surveillance.

[Kit Collins]: I think it's evidenced by our December Committee of the Whole when we had a whole range of city departments petitioning for exemptions or asking questions.

[Kit Collins]: How will this affect me?

[Kit Collins]: How will this affect me?

[Kit Collins]: It's really not our intent to

[Kit Collins]: target your very reliable department specifically, and I hope that you know that that intent is sincere.

[Kit Collins]: We've done our best to enshrine that in the language of the ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: This is intended to be proactive, not reactive to anything that your department or any other has done or done wrong.

[Kit Collins]: You know, I think I try to say often

[Kit Collins]: you know, policy and ordinances.

[Kit Collins]: They're not about just today and they're not about tomorrow and not about next week.

[Kit Collins]: They're about decades and even generations.

[Kit Collins]: You know, they're about putting something in place that will benefit the community when nobody who's currently in this room is still in this room.

[Kit Collins]: And I think we've tried our best to create a policy that will be right for the community, even when, you know, there's the next Jack Buckley leading the police department.

[Kit Collins]: And even when the city council looks entirely different so that we still have those structures for community input

[Kit Collins]: for transparency, regardless of who is at the helm.

[Kit Collins]: You know, over the past year, we've heard your very reasonable concerns about making sure that this is something that you can actually do, because we all know you have so much on your plate, and we've tried to only pare down this ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: I just want to say all that for context, for folks watching at home, for others who are participants in this process, and to say, you know, I really do appreciate your good faith discussions with us throughout this entire process.

[Kit Collins]: It's really appreciated, and I hope that you do feel

[Kit Collins]: heard.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Brown.

[Kit Collins]: What a treat to have two of my ordinance projects come before the council on the very same night.

[Kit Collins]: Good thing it's a holiday.

[Kit Collins]: I'm very glad to be bringing this forward tonight.

[Kit Collins]: This paper was first proposed by Councilor John Falco in 2021.

[Kit Collins]: Very grateful to him for proposing this paper and for the opportunity to carry the project forward as Housing Subcommittee Chair.

[Kit Collins]: In contrast to the ordinance that we just discussed, this ordinance is extremely simple.

[Kit Collins]: It creates a new requirement that all property owners in Medford distribute a simple, perhaps one or two page document prepared for them by the city to their tenants at the beginning and termination of any lease or upon eviction.

[Kit Collins]: This document would also be provided to homeowners that are being foreclosed upon.

[Kit Collins]: The goal of this policy is to make sure that all residents in Medford are aware of the housing rights to which they are already entitled, and the resources that are already available to them.

[Kit Collins]: People should know what their rights are, what to expect, and where to turn for help before some kind of stressful or emergency situation occurs.

[Kit Collins]: This information is often hard to find.

[Kit Collins]: Whether you're a tenant, an owner, or an owner being foreclosed upon, having to scramble for information, or not know where to turn for help benefits nobody.

[Kit Collins]: This ordinance ensures that relevant information is distributed through the community in a streamlined way proactively.

[Kit Collins]: I want to just briefly outline the process of this project.

[Kit Collins]: The council has been meeting on this paper since the fall first in the housing subcommittee, and then in a recent committee of the whole.

[Kit Collins]: We began by discussing the examples of three of our neighboring communities, Cambridge Boston and Somerville, who also have housing stability notification ordinances.

[Kit Collins]: We compared and contrasted these ordinances and selected the best parts of each example.

[Kit Collins]: We also reviewed the actual notification document that's currently used in each of these cities to inform our discussion.

[Kit Collins]: At every step we discussed the ordinance with the city departments that would be implicated by this ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: These partners included the Board of Health, which stepped up to do enforcement.

[Kit Collins]: The Office of Planning, Development and Sustainability volunteered to create the housing notification document.

[Kit Collins]: based on resource documents that their office already has available, and they also consulted on how to best begin the rollout of this ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: The Office of Prevention and Outreach, whose work in our community is closely aligned with the goals of this ordinance, offered their insight on equity and implementation strategies.

[Kit Collins]: I'm very heartened that this ordinance has the approval and even the enthusiasm of our city departments that are already responsible for housing stability and community outreach projects in our community.

[Kit Collins]: Finally, I just want to say this is an ordinance that is primarily intended as an educational tool.

[Kit Collins]: Thanks to the collaboration and the input of our city partners, I believe that this ordinance will be simple to implement and serve as another tool toolbox for promoting stable housing in Medford, through expanding awareness of existing housing rights and resources in our community.

[Kit Collins]: Sorry?

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Collins.

[Kit Collins]: Yeah, thank you for that question, Councilor Knight.

[Kit Collins]: This doesn't currently exempt any housing situations other than short or long-term like hospital care facilities in the city of Medford.

[Kit Collins]: So I believe it would implicate student housing situations, whether that's private property owners or the dormitories themselves.

[Kit Collins]: I wanna be clear, this doesn't create any new housing rights or responsibilities.

[Kit Collins]: It doesn't create the right to remain

[Kit Collins]: in a housing situation for longer than a person would already be able to do that.

[Kit Collins]: It's just a simple document that's delivered upon move in and move out.

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Collins, Advices and Affairs.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Morell.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Councilor Knight, for entertaining this line of questions.

[Kit Collins]: I think that we discussed similar issues with the Director of the Board of Health at our recent

[Kit Collins]: committee of the whole around enforcement, the fee structure, fine structure.

[Kit Collins]: The $300 was booked because it's statutorily defined and also because it's commensurate with other fines for ordinances that we already have in the books in the city of Medford.

[Kit Collins]: More importantly, when we discussed, when we were kind of first hashing out who would enforce the ordinance earlier in the subcommittee process after it was determined that it'd be more appropriate for it to be the Board of Health rather than code enforcement.

[Kit Collins]: You know, like I said,

[Kit Collins]: I think this is a phrase that I probably borrowed directly from Director O'Connor.

[Kit Collins]: This is primarily intended to be an educational tool.

[Kit Collins]: This ordinance isn't on the books that we can go around issuing $300 fines to landlords that don't know that this is something they're supposed to be doing.

[Kit Collins]: After all, the penalty for the first warning is a written fine, and this is to be endorsed, sorry, enforced at the discretion of, in this case, the Board of Health Director or their designee.

[Kit Collins]: So I say that to say, I don't think that this is the kind of thing where

[Kit Collins]: You know, if a landlord is delinked and accidentally, or we have some kind of extenuating circumstance, overall, it's at the discretion of the director of the Board of Health to enforce this towards the goal of actually promoting housing stability, not towards it generating revenue.

[Kit Collins]: And that was a discussion that we had pretty explicitly with the Board of Health director earlier in this ordinance process.

[Kit Collins]: Can we take those separately?

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Collins.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I just wanted to note before we take the vote on this Council and I appreciate your amendment and thinking through this on the floor.

[Kit Collins]: Having not considered such an amendment before, I think it's worth putting on the record that as a Tufts alumnus myself, I've seen firsthand, I don't think that this is an ordinance that would be in any way difficult for them to implement.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that there is some value for an institution that professes to be a community partner to participate in such an ordinance so that should students move off campus after graduating from Tufts University, like myself, that they are given a headstart in, you know,

[Kit Collins]: like we're talking about being aware of the housing rights and responsibilities and resources that they can expect from their community.

[Kit Collins]: So I don't know that this is a major point, but I just felt it's worth expressing that I don't think it's going too far to ask a major and wealthy community partner to participate in a good faith ordinance.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Collins.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Morell.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, Mr. South, for being here for tonight and for always keeping us updated.

[Kit Collins]: You know, there's a lot that's astonishing in what you shared with us tonight and what you've shared with us over email in recent days.

[Kit Collins]: It's hard to even remark on it, but I wanted to just thank the rank and file that you represent for being here.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for your organizing.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for your efforts.

[Kit Collins]: There's so much to really be astonished by, even though we've heard, I don't even, I'm running out of adjectives to use, you know, the scope of what's being offered to your bargaining units compared to what could be expected to be reasonable or fair.

[Kit Collins]: Just one thing that's ringing in my head

[Kit Collins]: 2% with concessions in a climate of six plus percent inflation, it puts me at a loss.

[Kit Collins]: And I'm glad to see that the rank and file is not willing to accept such an offer.

[Kit Collins]: I think that one of the exemplars of this, we're actually outsourcing or privatizing the folks who are negotiating with our collective bargaining units.

[Kit Collins]: And if there's not a crystallizing example of this problem, if that's not it, I don't know what it is.

[Kit Collins]: It's a really frustrating time, I think, to be on the city council and have what rounds down to no power over the root causes of this, which is our inability to invest in our city employees the way that they deserve and the way that our city deserves, the way that our residents deserve.

[Kit Collins]: I think,

[Kit Collins]: Obviously, this all comes down to will, comes down to the will to invest in our city the way that it serves, and that it comes down to the ability to do that.

[Kit Collins]: We're talking about the budget, but all of our realm of possibility here flows from that.

[Kit Collins]: I think we passed this year's budget on June 28th.

[Kit Collins]: I think this probably goes for all my fellow councilors.

[Kit Collins]: What date did we start worry about our next budget?

[Kit Collins]: June 29th.

[Kit Collins]: It's a discouraging time to be in,

[Kit Collins]: to be looking at what's going on right now and staring down the barrel of what we're ever going to be able to offer to the folks who make the city work and make the city run next year and the year after that.

[Kit Collins]: When it comes down to what we're able to offer the city employees, it's not just the work that they do, it's investing in the people themselves.

[Kit Collins]: And I don't know how we're going to expect to maintain, let alone improve our city and the experience of our city if we're not

[Kit Collins]: figuring out how to invest in the people that make that happen.

[Kit Collins]: So I just wanted to share some of my disbelief over what we are hearing tonight, what we've been hearing, and thank you to all the city employees that are standing up for what you deserve.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Morell.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you to all BJA's representatives for joining us again in the chambers.

[Kit Collins]: Just to pick up on the thread that Councilor Knight was speaking to, for the benefit of residents that are observing this process, ultimately this is a permit that is allowed by right.

[Kit Collins]: I wasn't on the council when this process began.

[Kit Collins]: I think it's, as it's been stated, it's no secret that this was a project that not everybody on this council was convinced was needed.

[Kit Collins]: here in Medford but it's a by right project.

[Kit Collins]: I'm really grateful for this process that's allowed us to get clarity on hearing from residents, knowing exactly what neighbors want to see from this space in order to, you know, see that reciprocal relationship more fully.

[Kit Collins]: You know, through this process, I think we've been able to arrive at a package of conditions that can address specific things that the abutting neighbors need to see to get to specific outcomes that will help us be as as neighborly as possible as possible when this gas station goes into operation.

[Kit Collins]: You know, and really attach that as a condition to the permit, not a handshake deal something that we can continue, make sure is followed up on and make sure that this relationship is as good as possible for the people that will affect most directly, the butters.

[Kit Collins]: your willingness to engage in this process and really deeply appreciate all of the constituents that reached out to us during this process on both sides of the issue.

[Kit Collins]: And I think what's before us is kind of a best case scenario for this going forward.

[Kit Collins]: So I'll be supporting this this evening.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: I found them in order and I move for approval.

[Kit Collins]: Myself and others in the Medford Arts community received word just a week or two ago that there is a planned opening for Arts Collaborative Medford's very long-planned, long-anticipated community arts center sometime later this year.

[Kit Collins]: At this point, it's looking like it's going to be in the spring.

[Kit Collins]: This has been the product of years and years and years of work and effort on the part of many in Medford's arts community.

[Kit Collins]: As a working artist myself, you know it's hard to overstate how important it is to have a community art center actually within our city limits, it's, it's very hard to find.

[Kit Collins]: space for arts, for community arts within our communities.

[Kit Collins]: These spaces are really scarce, they're really precious, they really mean a lot to artists working in all types of media.

[Kit Collins]: So I'm really excited to see what this can do to leverage a very rich existing arts community in Medford and I just want to wish a very hearty congratulations to everybody who's worked on this project so far.

[Kit Collins]: you know, we all get the emails and the calls when we, you know, usually it's around the big sweep.

[Kit Collins]: Because I think we see the patterns where there are residents, as Councilor Bears says, there are residents who have been on the email list all along, they get the phone calls, and then there are folks who just, they don't know what they don't know.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that ideally would be part of a revamped communication strategy, but I'd love it if we could do as much as we could.

[Kit Collins]: Thanks.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Morell.

[Kit Collins]: So this is bringing up a topic that has been brought up innumerable times by, I don't know how many Councilors in the past, probably all of them.

[Kit Collins]: It seems like over and over again, we hit against the fact that even our provider network are very close to hitting their bandwidth.

[Kit Collins]: And I know that it's in my mind so strongly all the time that our regional network of providers is inundated.

[Kit Collins]: There's so much need, you said for housing, food insecurity, there's so much need.

[Kit Collins]: And I know that that's one of the many things that we need a regional approach for, we need more state assistance for.

[Kit Collins]: Where this comes in as I think,

[Kit Collins]: Given that it's so important for us to streamline on the local level as much as possible to make sure that everybody in our community who needs those resources can access them in an easy way.

[Kit Collins]: I think this program is doing that and that everybody in the community can have equitable access to the resources that are available.

[Kit Collins]: And I really hope that that work can continue in parallel with, you know, regionally and with our other providers working to make sure that we have more places to direct people to, you know, I'm sure it's heartbreaking for your staff every time you have to say,

[Kit Collins]: I can get you on that wait list.

[Kit Collins]: I can get you on that list.

[Kit Collins]: I can't wait.

[Kit Collins]: I can't get you on that wait list.

[Kit Collins]: And I'm sure that's, I'm sure that's really hard.

[Kit Collins]: So I just thank you for, thank you for this work.

[Kit Collins]: I'm really excited to see how it continues.

[Kit Collins]: you know, your, your role in, in, in getting us up to speed to be any more, you know, painful than it has to be.

[Kit Collins]: just to make sure that that's as streamlined as possible.

[Kit Collins]: We do really appreciate your hard work.

[Kit Collins]: Yes.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Morell.

[Kit Collins]: You know, mostly right now, I want to, I know there are community members in the room, I want to hear

[Kit Collins]: from community members.

[Kit Collins]: But I just wanted to say at the outset, you know, yesterday's incident was heartbreaking.

[Kit Collins]: It's traumatizing during an already extremely raw and difficult time.

[Kit Collins]: These events affect the whole community.

[Kit Collins]: As leaders, I think it's our responsibility to hear from people who are the most affected, the students, the families, teachers, and staff.

[Kit Collins]: I think we can all agree, nothing is more important than our public schools being safe and stable and supportive

[Kit Collins]: everybody who has to be inside of them.

[Kit Collins]: I think that's a really shared goal.

[Kit Collins]: And I think this heartbreak is shared that our schools are not safe.

[Kit Collins]: They're not secure.

[Kit Collins]: They don't feel supportive.

[Kit Collins]: And, you know, in this conversation, you know, I want to hear from the people most affected.

[Kit Collins]: That's the folks who go to the schools every day and the people who love them.

[Kit Collins]: As we mentioned, you know, many Councilors, myself included, have papers later on the agenda for ways that this council can act within its power to try and be part of the solution.

[Kit Collins]: We'll get into more of that later.

[Kit Collins]: It's deeply troubling that we have to be having this conversation.

[Kit Collins]: It's hard to put into words how to express sympathy for something so painful that's happened to kids just going to school and their families.

[Kit Collins]: It's a sorry thing, the events that precipitated this discussion, but we have to have it and we're gonna have it.

[Kit Collins]: Councilor Scarpelli and others were calling for urgent action.

[Kit Collins]: We're calling for the council to act within its purview to try and be part of the solution.

[Kit Collins]: And I completely agree, completely agree.

[Kit Collins]: You know, we have to use our powers as city councilors to try and be part of the solution.

[Kit Collins]: We aren't the school committee.

[Kit Collins]: We can't be the school committee.

[Kit Collins]: We can't make the type of the decisions that the school community is empowered to make.

[Kit Collins]: We can use the powers that we have as the city council to try to direct resources where they need to go to try to be a part of the community-wide conversation.

[Kit Collins]: to emphasize the voices of the folks that are most affected by this, to listen to the people who know best where those resources need to go.

[Kit Collins]: And I'm glad that we get to be a part of that conversation.

[Kit Collins]: I hope that going forward, this can be more collaborative, that we can all do our specific roles, but in concert with each other.

[Kit Collins]: And lastly, since Councilor Scarpelli's resolution calls for public input, if anybody's here to give input, I just want to acknowledge that not everybody does feel comfortable speaking in public, especially on live TV.

[Kit Collins]: It's not for the faint of heart.

[Kit Collins]: And also not every comment, especially when kids and school security is involved, is best said in a public setting.

[Kit Collins]: I just wanna restate for the record, whether we're in session or not, I'm available to any resident, to any constituent to field ideas, to hear your questions.

[Kit Collins]: If you just need a listening ear, if you don't feel comfortable speaking tonight, you can always reach out to me, we're available.

[Kit Collins]: So I just wanted to say that at the outset of any community input.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Morell.

[Kit Collins]: And I'm speaking off the cuff here.

[Kit Collins]: So I just want to say, you know, I think that what the community deserves today in the aftermath of yesterday's events, in the aftermath of other traumatic, tragic events, what the community deserves is

[Kit Collins]: a communicative, collaborative city council.

[Kit Collins]: They deserve clear communication, resolve to work together productively from all their elected leaders.

[Kit Collins]: We owe our community better than infighting.

[Kit Collins]: You know, we've disagreed on many things many times before.

[Kit Collins]: Behind this rail, it'll happen again.

[Kit Collins]: That's what we're here to do.

[Kit Collins]: We're here to represent different viewpoints for perspective on issues.

[Kit Collins]: We're here to represent different viewpoints for how to, how to craft strategy and how to respond to problems in our community and how to plan for the future.

[Kit Collins]: But I think that we owe today, especially today and all days, we owe the community a productive use of our time, discussing available strategies for what we can do within our powers to try to deal with the problems before us.

[Kit Collins]: I, you know,

[Kit Collins]: What, what looks like a buzzword to one Councilor might be somebody else's best good faith, earnest approach at doing something that is within our power, within our purview to try to address specifically a problem that exists.

[Kit Collins]: It's put forth in good faith.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that tracks both ways.

[Kit Collins]: I don't think it's productive for us to launch into

[Kit Collins]: veiled personal attacks.

[Kit Collins]: You know, I don't want, I don't want that to be what tonight is.

[Kit Collins]: I think that we have to come together.

[Kit Collins]: We have to discuss the strategies that we've put forth.

[Kit Collins]: We might not agree on all of them, but what our community is calling out for is a good faith, earnest discussion of strategies.

[Kit Collins]: It does our community no good to spill a lot of ink and spill a lot of airtime, fighting about things that we cannot control.

[Kit Collins]: The community deserves better than a performance.

[Kit Collins]: we need to discuss strategies that we have the capacity to enforce.

[Kit Collins]: And sometimes we will disagree about what those best strategies are, but that's what our time should be for.

[Kit Collins]: So I have a rationale for why I brought the strategies that I think are most important to talk about here.

[Kit Collins]: I know those feelings aren't universally shared.

[Kit Collins]: I'll save that for when those papers are brought up, but I really hope that we can maintain

[Kit Collins]: clear communication and sticking to the issues at hand and striving for concrete strategies for as much of this evening as possible, because that's what the community needs from us.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you.

[Kit Collins]: Um, I it's, it's hard to add anything after a story like that.

[Kit Collins]: I don't have anything to add.

[Kit Collins]: I just wanted to thank you for, for being here.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you for sharing your story.

[Kit Collins]: I'm not a parent.

[Kit Collins]: I can't fathom what it's like to be a parent and go through something like that.

[Kit Collins]: Something that unfortunately a lot of families in our public school systems have to go through.

[Kit Collins]: It's heartbreaking.

[Kit Collins]: I think, you know, over the past year, this grant, I mean, I know it's gone on for more than the past year, but you know, what's come out of this has been one of the things that I, you know, feel most proud of in the city.

[Kit Collins]: great to be able to see some first steps towards language equity, doing a better job of reaching out to the people who, you know, historically do not show up to city hall or not reached out to don't speak the language, you know, in whatever way, I think this is really important work.

[Kit Collins]: Um, I think that it's important for us to get a picture of what, um, doing that, doing that work of bringing

[Kit Collins]: more of the community into community spaces, how that breaks down into roles and positions and programs, kind of gives those numbers some context.

[Kit Collins]: As a Councilor, and I know that you in your office, you get this 10 times more than we do, but we hear from people looking for housing, we hear from people who are looking for pro bono legal representation, the eviction crisis in Medford Square several months ago, eviction help, tenant organizing,

[Kit Collins]: I've been very involved with the mutual aid network for several years.

[Kit Collins]: What strikes me every time these conversations come up is it seems like over and over again, we hit against the fact that even our provider network are very close to hitting their bandwidth.

[Kit Collins]: And I know that.

[Kit Collins]: It's in my mind so strongly all the time that our regional network of providers is inundated.

[Kit Collins]: There's so much need, you said for housing, food insecurity, there's so much need.

[Kit Collins]: And I know that that's one of the many things that we need a regional approach for, we need more state assistance for.

[Kit Collins]: Where this comes in as I think, given that it's so important for us to streamline on the local level as much as possible to make sure that everybody in our community who needs those resources can access them in an easy way.

[Kit Collins]: I think this program is doing that and that everybody in the community can have equitable access to the resources that are available.

[Kit Collins]: And I really hope that that work can continue in parallel with regionally and with our other providers working to make sure that we have more places to direct people to.

[Kit Collins]: I'm sure it's heartbreaking for your staff every time you have to say, I can get you on that wait list.

[Kit Collins]: I can get you on that list.

[Kit Collins]: I can't get you on that wait list.

[Kit Collins]: And I'm sure that's really hard.

[Kit Collins]: I just thank you for this work.

[Kit Collins]: I'm really excited to see how it continues.

[Kit Collins]: And like vice president Baird said, so anyway, this council can support you and continue that work.

[Kit Collins]: We're partners with you.

[Kit Collins]: I just wanted to thank you for coming for us, for having these numbers prepared and for your candor.

[Kit Collins]: I think we all know that when you took the job here, you didn't sign up for a cakewalk, but we all know how much is on your plates with catching up from our financial backlog, reconciling everything, and we don't want

[Kit Collins]: you know, your role in getting us up to speed to be any more, you know, painful than it has to be.

[Kit Collins]: So I'm hoping that, you know, I'm looking forward to the presentation in January.

[Kit Collins]: I really appreciate, you know, your help in dialing down how to get us what we need.

[Kit Collins]: just to make sure that that's as streamlined as possible.

[Kit Collins]: So again, thank you for being here.

[Kit Collins]: We do really appreciate your hard work.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you, President Morell.

[Kit Collins]: Um, you know, mostly right now, I, I want to, I know there are community members in the room.

[Kit Collins]: It's traumatizing during an already extremely raw and difficult time.

[Kit Collins]: Um, these events affect the whole community as leaders.

[Kit Collins]: the most affected, the students, the families, teachers and staff.

[Kit Collins]: I think that's a really shared goal.

[Kit Collins]: And I think this heartbreak is shared that our schools are not safe.

[Kit Collins]: They're not secure.

[Kit Collins]: They don't feel supportive.

[Kit Collins]: And, you know, in this conversation,

[Kit Collins]: You know, I want to hear from the people most affected.

[Kit Collins]: That's the folks who go to the schools every day and the people who love them.

[Kit Collins]: It's, it's deeply troubling that we have to be having this conversation.

[Kit Collins]: I'm just, it's, it's hard to put into words, you know, how to express sympathy for

[Kit Collins]: something so painful that's happened to kids just going to school and their families.

[Kit Collins]: It's, you know, it's a sorry thing, the events that precipitated this discussion, but we have to have it and we're gonna have it.

[Kit Collins]: You know, Councilor Scarpelli and others were calling for urgent action.

[Kit Collins]: We're calling for the council to act within its purview to try and be part of the solution.

[Kit Collins]: And I completely agree, completely agree.

[Kit Collins]: You know, we have to use our powers as city councilors to try and be part of the solution.

[Kit Collins]: We aren't the school committee.

[Kit Collins]: We can't be the school committee.

[Kit Collins]: We can't make the type of the decisions that the school committee is empowered to make.

[Kit Collins]: We can use the powers that we have as the city council to try to direct resources where they need to go, to try to be a part of the community-wide conversation, to emphasize the voices of the folks that are most affected by this, to listen to the people who know best where those resources need to go.

[Kit Collins]: And I'm glad that we get to be a part of that conversation.

[Kit Collins]: I hope that going forward, this can be more collaborative

[Kit Collins]: that we can all do our specific roles, but in concert with each other.

[Kit Collins]: It's not for the faint of heart.

[Kit Collins]: And also not every comment, especially when kids and school security is involved, is best said in a public setting.

[Kit Collins]: What's the plan for the survey?

[Kit Collins]: What is the goal for how many people to be surveyed?

[Kit Collins]: What is the process for making sure that we get a representative cross section of the community actually weighing in?

[Kit Collins]: Will that be reported?

[Kit Collins]: How will that feedback be translated into policy with this issue in particular because it involves an ordinance?

[Kit Collins]: And I think that when we do put out a survey, especially knowing that it's an issue that constituents are looking to hear about, I think that we need to be proactive about managing expectations, both for

[Kit Collins]: the timetable on which things are proposed to maybe change and also the scope that it's possible to change things within.

[Kit Collins]: And again, especially that's relevant here because it would involve city council action as well as administrative action.

[Kit Collins]: But I think that in many cases, that's really lacking when this sort of, we're just putting feelers out there type of action gets done.

[Kit Collins]: I think it's really, we owe it to the community to let them know, we wanna hear your feedback and also this is the universe of possibility.

[Kit Collins]: I've had the opportunity to speak with you privately and thank you for giving me your time and your perspective.

[Kit Collins]: We owe that to our public school students and their families.

[Kit Collins]: Talk is cheap, we all know this.

[Kit Collins]: Roles change hands, policy is an expression of values.

[Kit Collins]: That being said,

[Kit Collins]: I want to support policies that will help to effectuate direct impact that this body can enforce.

[Kit Collins]: I don't love to share this, but I'm not comfortable supporting the main papers tonight as written.

[Kit Collins]: I do want to share why.

[Kit Collins]: I believe this proposed ordinance, I share similar concerns.

[Kit Collins]: I believe it would conflict with national law.

[Kit Collins]: I believe it would be unenforceable.

[Kit Collins]: I believe that we need to pay

[Kit Collins]: Deep attention to resources.

[Kit Collins]: Hold our administration accountable to following through on resources.

[Kit Collins]: A public forum is deeply important.

[Kit Collins]: I don't know that we can enforce that.

[Kit Collins]: I know that we owe our students and our teachers and our school staff more resources to create the environment that our students deserve.

[Kit Collins]: In the interest of avoiding a conflict with mass general law, I feel unable to support this paper as written.

[Kit Collins]: I believe that we can hold school leadership accountable to our shared goals while also maintaining checks and balances in our city government.

[Kit Collins]: That's not to say that I don't support changes to school policy that would arm our school administration and school staff with better systems and tools to prevent school violence and create the best possible experience for our students and our public schools families.

[Kit Collins]: I just don't believe that this is something that we can do.

[Kit Collins]: I know that our teachers, our school staff, our school committee want what is best for our students.

[Kit Collins]: I know that we need, and I think that most of them would agree, that policy changes and resource changes to improve the condition and the environment of our schools, ensuring the best possible environment for kids to learn and thrive in safely.

[Kit Collins]: We have to effectuate that.

[Kit Collins]: I think that the B paper offered by Councilor, Vice President Bears is one piece of an overall puzzle of aligning resources with our values.

[Kit Collins]: I'd be happy to support that tonight and continue the discussion about the main paper.
