[Kit Collins]: I think that we have to do the work of looking inward and saying, if there does seem to be a communication breakdown, if we feel like we're not hearing these stories, let's first look at the environment that we're perpetuating and creating.

[Kit Collins]: What can we be doing?

[Kit Collins]: so that we can be receiving this communication?

[Kit Collins]: Is there things that we could do to make these spaces ones in which everybody can feel comfortable talking about these uncomfortable and sometimes outright dangerous topics?

[Kit Collins]: I think that there's a role for the city council to have in being a really full-throated proponent of anti-racism measures.

[Kit Collins]: And I think lots of constituents would be really eager to see the city council take on

[Kit Collins]: a more bullish approach to advocating for anti-racist dialogue, as well as, you know, as Councilors have said, policies that address structural inequities.

[Kit Collins]: So just to sum up, you know, I agree, we all have the responsibility to start these conversations.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that, you know, we need to be creating spaces where people feel, everybody can feel comfortable

[Kit Collins]: talking about these issues.

[Kit Collins]: And if we're observing the fact that we don't yet have perfect communication about these issues, I think that we also have to consider that the fact of white supremacy and racial divide is a reason for that.

[Kit Collins]: So thank you for the opportunity.

[Kit Collins]: Hi there.

[Kit Collins]: Yeah, my name is Kit Collins.

[Kit Collins]: I live at 42 William Street in South Medford.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you to everybody who's spoken so far.

[Kit Collins]: Thank you to Councilor Bears for bringing this resolution.

[Kit Collins]: I too support the motion to hang a banner reading Black Lives Matter on City Hall.

[Kit Collins]: And just to echo some of the sentiments that have already been stated, but just to reinforce them with my voice, I believe that this is not a political statement.

[Kit Collins]: It is a statement in support of

[Kit Collins]: basic civil rights and the right of every person to enjoy freedom and safety in their community.

[Kit Collins]: I think that when we say Black Lives Matter, we're affirming in some way, you know, the same values that we affirm when we lobby the city council for safer streets.

[Kit Collins]: It's an affirmation that we're not okay with the fact that for some people, because of the color of their skin, their life is more difficult, it's more precarious, more dangerous for them.

[Kit Collins]: It's an affirmation that we are not okay with that being the case for anybody in the country or any of our neighbors here in Medford.

[Kit Collins]: It's an affirmation that we are a city where we want everybody to enjoy freedom, joy, safety, security.

[Kit Collins]: And to the point that, you know, I think that there are concerns about this message being controversial, it being provocative, it making certain residents feel uncomfortable.

[Kit Collins]: You know, I would say to those people and to anybody who's hearing from their constituents those concerns, if you think that Black Lives Matter means that white lives don't matter or that they matter less,

[Kit Collins]: Then you can just read up on it.

[Kit Collins]: Just Google the movement for black lives and like read over the website because that's really not what it means.

[Kit Collins]: And anybody who takes that kind of issue from this language is simply misinformed.

[Kit Collins]: It's really simple.

[Kit Collins]: It's about civil rights.

[Kit Collins]: And this is the language of a movement for civil rights.

[Kit Collins]: I want to live in a city where we're not afraid to voice our support for that.

[Kit Collins]: And then I want us to back it up with real substantive action.

[Kit Collins]: But like Nicole said, and a lot of people after her,

[Kit Collins]: We got to do the simple language thing first.

[Kit Collins]: You know, we got to prove that we can do that.

[Kit Collins]: It's simple to do that.

[Kit Collins]: We should do it.

[Kit Collins]: Let's do it.

[Kit Collins]: And then let's get on to the harder, more important stuff.

[Kit Collins]: Thanks.

[Kit Collins]: Thanks, Kit.

[Kit Collins]: I'm, just holding my mic kind of close because it's kind of bad um, I would just like to make a comment that I think that In this moment as the pandemic as much as we might hate to admit it is still very much ongoing It's going to be going on for a very long time, even though that's a reality that nobody is happy about I think that

[Kit Collins]: a really important part of the city council's leadership is to be a leader in how we are modeling behavior for how to act during a pandemic.

[Kit Collins]: I think it is, we're not even getting close to the time where we can begin going back to normal safely.

[Kit Collins]: And I think that the actions of the city council, not just in how

[Kit Collins]: the budget meetings turn out, but in general the tone of what is acceptable, what is enthusiastically participated in, should be considered modeling for the whole Medford community as how we should be conducting ourselves safely during a pandemic.

[Kit Collins]: And I bring this up, I think it's most important because it's not just for

[Kit Collins]: The health of the people who will literally be in that room and their families I really think that it's important for us all to remember that this pandemic And infectious disease and health health in general is a racial justice issue.

[Kit Collins]: It is an economic justice issue We cannot forget just because the pandemic is wearing on It's becoming increasingly inconvenient.

[Kit Collins]: It's becoming increasingly tedious That um, you know, they're the most vulnerable members of our community are still being put at the most risk when more people go out

[Kit Collins]: Become carriers without knowing it continue to spread this disease We are very far away along from having a vaccine and I think that even though it really stinks.

[Kit Collins]: We all need to dial down Remain in the mindset of protecting our communities and I would really love to see the medford city council embody that spirit of protecting the most vulnerable as well through what they are willing to enthusiastically do

[Kit Collins]: to support one another and protect each other from this disease.

[Kit Collins]: Thanks.
